('51', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 1
('51', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('51', 0, 2, 3, 72) 8 p.m., January 1/6, 1931
('51', 0, 3, 4, 98) NARANDAS, This week, too, I have not received your packet so far.
('51', 0, 3, 5, 164) It must have been posted as unregistered parcel and, if so, I shall probably get it tomorrow.
('51', 0, 3, 6, 258) But I started writing the Ashram letters today, or rather yes terday.
('51', 0, 3, 7, 328) I had a letter last time from Danibehn from Bombay.
('51', 0, 3, 8, 380) My reply to her is enclosed.
('51', 0, 3, 9, 409) She is from Marwar, it seems.
('51', 0, 3, 10, 439) If you know, inform me whether that is so.
('51', 0, 3, 11, 482) I have given her address in the letter itself, thinking that you may not have it with you.
('51', 0, 3, 12, 573) Last week there were a few remarks in pencil by way of criticism of Anasakatiyoga by a Maratha friend; the remarks were unsigned.
('51', 0, 3, 13, 703) If you remember the name, let me know it.
('51', 0, 3, 14, 745) We were both weighed today.
('51', 0, 3, 15, 773) My weight came to 100 and Pyare lal’s to 122. I have lost a pound; it is not worth taking note of.
('51', 0, 3, 16, 872) The wei ght may increase or decrease by a pound or two even if the time of weigh ing changes or according as one is weighed before or after passing stool.
('51', 0, 3, 17, 1027) If a person gets himself weighed immediately after drinking water, his weight will be found to have increased.
('51', 0, 3, 18, 1138) If he gets himself weighed after passing urine, there will be corresponding decrease in his weight.
('51', 0, 3, 19, 1238) So long as I myself feel quite fit, pass stool without difficulty, have an appetite and eat well, there is no reason at all for concern.
('51', 0, 3, 20, 1375) If I can carry on like this for six months, the experiment will have succeeded.
('51', 0, 3, 21, 1455) I have made an inportant change, which I describe here for those of you who may be interested to know about it.
('51', 0, 3, 22, 1567) Almonds are soaked in hot water and the peel is removed.
('51', 0, 3, 23, 1624) They are then crushed into a paste.
('51', 0, 3, 24, 1660) This is mixed with four ounces of water and the mixture is boiled till the water evaporates and a butter like jelly is left behind.
('51', 0, 3, 25, 1792) I eat it with vegetables.
('51', 0, 3, 26, 1818) It not only tastes good but seems to be more easily digested than almond paste not boiled in water.
('51', 0, 3, 27, 1918) It is possible that, even if the almonds are crushed into very fine paste but the latter is not boiled in water, the stuff remains undigested and passes out with stool.
('51', 0, 3, 28, 2087) But I have no doubt that the jelly which I eat is digested.
('51', 0, 3, 29, 2147) Even a person with very delicate stomach may be able to digest almonds cooked in this manner.
('51', 0, 3, 30, 2241) The jelly may again be mixed with water and turned into milk.
('51', 0, 3, 31, 2303) It will, of course, have no
('51', 1, 0, 1, 2331) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 1, 1, 2, 2371) One can add a little jaggery or sugar, or even lime juice and salt, to the liquid.
('51', 1, 1, 3, 2454) I don’t advise anyone just now to make this experiment.
('51', 1, 1, 4, 2510) But the information which I have given may perhaps be useful to anyone who is interested in making such experiments or cannot digest milk.
('51', 1, 1, 5, 2649) Apart from this change, my diet remains what it was.
('51', 1, 1, 6, 2702) The quantity, too, remains unchanged.
('51', 1, 1, 7, 2740) I hope to reach very high speed on the Gandiv spinning wheel.
('51', 1, 1, 8, 2802) I had never been able to reach 200, let alone 255, per hour before now.
('51', 1, 1, 9, 2874) On the takli I have not been able to go beyond 75 80 rounds.
('51', 1, 1, 10, 2935) I cannot spin even 75 comfortable.
('51', 1, 1, 11, 2970) I spin about 60 comfortably.
('51', 1, 1, 12, 2999) But I can say that my hand has now set well on a bamboo takli.
('51', 1, 1, 13, 3062) It still seems a hard task for me to spin 100 rounds.
('51', 1, 1, 14, 3116) 2 o’clock, Saturday I got your packet yesterday.
('51', 1, 1, 15, 3165) Since it was a parcel and they do not carry packets during holidays, two days were wasted.
('51', 1, 1, 16, 3256) But I see that it cost you only three annas to send the packet as a parcel, whereas, if it had been sent as a letter, the postage would possibly come to as much as a rupee.
('51', 1, 1, 17, 3429) You may, therefore, follow whichever method you think right.
('51', 1, 1, 18, 3490) I have mentally reconciled myself to getting the packet on Fridays and adjusted my programme accordingly.
('51', 1, 1, 19, 3596) Here they are very careful in handing over the packet immediately to me after examining its contents.
('51', 1, 1, 20, 3698) They are equally careful in dispatching the packets from here.
('51', 1, 1, 21, 3761) Who is Palibehn?
('51', 1, 1, 22, 3778) Her question is the same as Premabehn’s.
('51', 1, 1, 23, 3819) I need not, therefore, write separately to her.
('51', 1, 1, 24, 3867) Send her a copy of my letter to Premabehn, or show it to her if she is in the Ashram.
('51', 1, 1, 25, 3953) As regards printing extracts from my letter, what I have written about yajna can certainly be given below Chapter II.
('51', 1, 1, 26, 4071) Any other portions which seem useful can also be printed.
('51', 1, 1, 27, 4129) But where and in what manner is for you to decide.
('51', 1, 1, 28, 4180) You can include such material in the Gitabodh in footnotes at relevant places or as independent extracts.
('51', 1, 1, 29, 4286) Keep the Doctor informed about Ratilal and deal with the latter tactfully so that he may keep to the right path.
('51', 1, 1, 30, 4399) Look upon him as an animal, uncultured and enslaved by passion.
('51', 1, 1, 31, 4463) When he is overcome by passion, he goes mad.
('51', 1, 1, 32, 4508) There are many kinds of passion; Ratilal is enslaved by three: for sex, for eating and for spending money extra vagantly.
('51', 1, 1, 33, 4630) He becomes when these passions are not satisfied.
('51', 1, 1, 34, 4680) Running away from the Ashram has a beneficial effect on him in some measure.
('51', 1, 1, 35, 4757) He calms down after a few days.
('51', 1, 1, 36, 4789) God alone knows how he will end up.
('51', 1, 1, 37, 4825) Sometimes such persons even attain jnana.
('51', 1, 1, 38, 4867) He is certainly not wholly wicked.
('51', 2, 0, 1, 4902) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 3
('51', 2, 1, 2, 4945) The quantity of spinning which you are able to do seems much indeed to me.
('51', 2, 1, 3, 5020) One can do with the left hand any work which the right hand does.
('51', 2, 1, 4, 5086) Bhau can spin on the takli equally well with either hand.
('51', 2, 1, 5, 5144) It will not be bad if Kanu goes to Wardha and learns Bhau’s skill, and also gets some experience of the place.
('51', 2, 1, 6, 5255) If there is any other boy, besides Kanu, who can and wishes to go, I see no harm in sending him.
('51', 2, 1, 7, 5352) Your body seems to have changed altogether.
('51', 2, 1, 8, 5396) Personally, I am confident that ultimately it will become purer in its functioning.
('51', 2, 1, 9, 5480) Will not Parnekar leave the Ashram for a while and go somewhere else to improve his health?
('51', 2, 1, 10, 5572) The fact that the bull was brought back and the manner of its being found were a miracle indeed.
('51', 2, 1, 11, 5669) Do you follow our method or some other method in preparing mava from milk?
('51', 2, 1, 12, 5744) Do you experience any difficulty in selling it?
('51', 2, 1, 13, 5792) If that is so, you may write to Ghanshyamdas, Mahavirprasad, Jivanlal and others and they will probably buy it up.
('51', 2, 1, 14, 5907) If you can supply it regularly, even an advertisement in a newspaper will help.
('51', 2, 1, 15, 5987) Do not give up walking.
('51', 2, 1, 16, 6011) It is a practice worth clinging to at any cost.
('51', 2, 1, 17, 6059) If you follow fixed rules in your work, you can include many things in the day’s programme.
('51', 2, 1, 18, 6151) Devdas had written a letter to me; what has been done in regard to it?
('51', 2, 1, 19, 6222) I have requested that he should recall the contents of the letter and write again to me.
('51', 2, 1, 20, 6311) I have received no reply to this.
('51', 2, 1, 21, 6345) 6.45 p.m., Monday, January 5, 1931 I have acknowledged having received the leather for sandals.
('51', 2, 1, 22, 6441) The address of the lady to whom letter No.
('51', 2, 1, 23, 6484) 82 is addressed is known to Ramnarayan 1 (of Ajmer).
('51', 2, 1, 24, 6537) If you send the letter to Martand of somebody else, he will post it.
('51', 2, 1, 25, 6606) Read my letter to Kashinath.
('51', 2, 1, 26, 6635) I need not add to what I have written in it.
('51', 2, 1, 27, 6680) Jivandas is in Sabarmati Jail.
('51', 2, 1, 28, 6711) Does anyone visit him?
('51', 2, 1, 29, 6734) If not, some body should go and visit him.
('51', 2, 1, 30, 6777) Tell him that I often remember him.
('51', 2, 2, 31, 6813) Blessings from
('51', 2, 3, 32, 6828) BAPU January 6, 1931
('51', 2, 4, 33, 6849) 1 Ramnarayan Chaudhary
('51', 3, 0, 1, 6872) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 3, 1, 2, 6912) [PS.] I started this letter on the first and I described the position with regard to my experiment in diet as it was on that day.
('51', 3, 1, 3, 7042) I had a feeling of indigestion on Saturday night and on Sunday diarrhoea started.
('51', 3, 1, 4, 7124) But this time I suffered no pain at all.
('51', 3, 1, 5, 7165) There was no griping even.
('51', 3, 1, 6, 7192) There were frequent motions.
('51', 3, 1, 7, 7221) They continued even yesterday, but the number was less.
('51', 3, 1, 8, 7277) I am writing this at 5 a.m., after prayer.
('51', 3, 1, 9, 7320) I think the motions will be much fewer today.
('51', 3, 1, 10, 7366) My work was not interrupted in any way.
('51', 3, 1, 11, 7406) Yesterday I sat up for exactly ten and a half hours and finished all the work.
('51', 3, 1, 12, 7485) This time there were a good number of other letters too.
('51', 3, 1, 13, 7542) Of course eating has been stopped.
('51', 3, 1, 14, 7577) The cause of diarrhoea seems to be jowar and bajra.
('51', 3, 1, 15, 7629) I shall know it by and by.
('51', 3, 1, 16, 7656) I have not decided how to resume eating.
('51', 3, 1, 17, 7697) There is no cause at all for worry.
('51', 3, 1, 18, 7733) I have informed you because I thought I must.
('51', 3, 1, 19, 7779) At present I take lime juice with jaggery and soda bicarb.
('51', 3, 1, 20, 7838) I will write again tomorrow.
('51', 3, 2, 21, 7867) BAPU [PPS.] There are 83 letters.
('51', 3, 3, 22, 7901) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I
('51', 3, 4, 23, 7944) 2. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('51', 3, 5, 24, 7973) 12 Noon, Wednesday, January [7] 1 1931
('51', 3, 6, 25, 8012) NARANDAS, You must have received the packet dispatched yesterday.
('51', 3, 6, 26, 8078) Today I feel better.
('51', 3, 6, 27, 8099) I started with diluted curds yesterday.
('51', 3, 6, 28, 8139) Today I ate raisins and a little quantity, twice, of crushed, cooked almonds.
('51', 3, 6, 29, 8217) These is no complaint about stools.
('51', 3, 6, 30, 8253) That is, after 4 in the morning, I have felt no call.
('51', 3, 6, 31, 8307) Don’t worry at all.
('51', 3, 6, 32, 8327) Ba and Mirabehn must not worry.
('51', 3, 6, 33, 8359) I will drop a postcard again tomorrow.
('51', 3, 6, 34, 8398) I am able to do all my work.

('51', 4, 1, 2, 8573) 3. LETTER TO KASHINATH TRIVEDI
('51', 4, 2, 3, 8604) YERAVDA MANDIR, January 7, 1931
('51', 4, 3, 4, 8636) KASHINATH,
('51', 4, 4, 5, 8647) I have your letter.
('51', 4, 4, 6, 8667) What you say about Shanta is correct.
('51', 4, 4, 7, 8705) Kuhne baths cannot but benefit her.
('51', 4, 4, 8, 8741) I have written about Mother in my previous letters.
('51', 4, 4, 9, 8793) Has she really given up the traditional notions of pollution?
('51', 4, 4, 10, 8855) I have had no letter from Mama.
('51', 4, 4, 11, 8887) I have read Babu Bhagwandas’s article.
('51', 4, 4, 12, 8926) He has suggested the first two remedies ironically to show their impossibility.
('51', 4, 4, 13, 9006) He believes in the third one.
('51', 4, 4, 14, 9036) I have thought much about the problem and written about it and suggested every remedy I could.
('51', 4, 4, 15, 9131) I don’t think unity will be brought about through artificial means.
('51', 4, 4, 16, 9199) If either we or they display pure love, the problem would be solved immediately.
('51', 4, 4, 17, 9280) It is difficult to say definitely in what form such love will express itself.
('51', 4, 4, 18, 9358) What you say about the Maulana Saheb is correct.
('51', 4, 4, 19, 9407) There is no doubt about his patriotism.
('51', 4, 4, 20, 9447) He said what he believed.
('51', 4, 4, 21, 9473) Even if we think someone’s views to be erroneous, how can we blame him for holding those views?
('51', 4, 4, 22, 9569) It is on such occasions that tolerance is required.
('51', 4, 4, 23, 9621) Leva Patidars in Gujarat do observe the purdah.
('51', 4, 4, 24, 9669) It is observed among other communities, too, in Kathiawar.
('51', 4, 5, 25, 9728) Blessings from
('51', 4, 7, 26, 9743) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5271
('51', 5, 0, 1, 9787) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 5, 1, 2, 9827) 4. LETTER TO KALAVATI TRIVEDI
('51', 5, 2, 3, 9857) January 7, 1931
('51', 5, 3, 4, 9873) KALAVATI, Yes, purdah is observed here and there in Gu[jarat] too.
('51', 5, 3, 5, 9940) After all Gu[jarat] is a part of India!
('51', 5, 3, 6, 9980) Hirabehn is in a pitiable plight.
('51', 5, 3, 7, 10014) Teach the people of Ras to spin on the takli and make bamboo takli locally.
('51', 5, 3, 8, 10090) I don’t understand about Samalbhai.
('51', 5, 3, 9, 10126) Do write again.
('51', 5, 3, 10, 10142) I shall enquire into the dispute.
('51', 5, 3, 11, 10176) Keep yourself fit.
('51', 5, 3, 12, 10195) Learn shirshasana or sarvangasana for your feet.
('51', 5, 3, 13, 10244) Learn the method.
('51', 5, 3, 14, 10262) Kashinath can read from the book available at the Ashram and write to you.

('51', 5, 13, 25, 10598) 6. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('51', 5, 14, 26, 10627) Thursday, January 8, 1931
('51', 5, 15, 27, 10653) NARANDAS, The news about my having had diarrhoea must not be published.
('51', 5, 15, 28, 10725) I passed a little stool yesterday at four in the morning.
('51', 5, 15, 29, 10783) After that, I passed stool again today at 10 o’clock.
('51', 5, 15, 30, 10837) I have therefore, taken half a spoon of castor oil, and, after I have had a motion, I will take milk or curds, whichever I think will suit me.
('51', 5, 15, 31, 10980) Or I may take something else which may be equally harmless.
('51', 5, 15, 32, 11040) The body is quite fit.
('51', 5, 16, 33, 11063) 1 Vide “Letter to Shanta”, 1 1 1931.
('51', 6, 0, 1, 11100) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 7
('51', 6, 1, 2, 11143) The tongue is perfectly clean.
('51', 6, 1, 3, 11174) There is no cause at all for anyone to worry.
('51', 6, 1, 4, 11220) As I thought I ought to inform you about the attack, I wrote about it on Monday and will continue to write every day till I am completely all right so that you may all feel relieved.
('51', 6, 2, 5, 11403) Blessings from
('51', 6, 4, 6, 11418) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I

('51', 6, 6, 8, 11485) YERAVDA MANDIR, January 8, 1931
('51', 6, 7, 9, 11517) PRABHAVATI,
('51', 6, 8, 10, 11529) I have your letter.
('51', 6, 8, 11, 11549) It is a good sign that there are some days in between when you don’t suffer from your usual complaint.
('51', 6, 8, 12, 11652) You must have received my previous letter.
('51', 6, 8, 13, 11695) I am very eager indeed that you should go over to the Ashram without delay.
('51', 6, 8, 14, 11771) Why doesn’t Jayaprakash write to me?
('51', 6, 8, 15, 11808) And what is the position about him now?
('51', 6, 8, 16, 11848) Is it now fixed that he is joining that college?

('51', 7, 0, 1, 12006) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 7, 1, 2, 12046) 8. LETTER TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('51', 7, 2, 3, 12078) Y. M., January 9, 1931
('51', 7, 3, 4, 12101) MY DEAR ANAND, Your letter.
('51', 7, 3, 5, 12129) Your reply to Jairamdas is correct.
('51', 7, 3, 6, 12165) But now that Vidya’s people will not take back the money, the immediate problem is solved.
('51', 7, 3, 7, 12256) Your idea to treat it as a gift to the nation is quite good.
('51', 7, 3, 8, 12317) The right course now is so to shape and simplify your life that you will not henceforth have to fall back upon either father for pecuniary help.
('51', 7, 3, 9, 12462) For the past you need not think of returning debt to the nation in coin but return it in kind, i.
('51', 7, 3, 10, 12560) e., through your joint labour.
('51', 7, 3, 11, 12591) And when you dedicate yourselves wholly to the nation you have repaid the debt.
('51', 7, 3, 12, 12671) Is this clear?
('51', 7, 3, 13, 12686) There is no question of being physically near me whilst you are out.
('51', 7, 3, 14, 12755) If you become a prisoner again, even then there is only a remote possibility.
('51', 7, 3, 15, 12833) Your satisfaction must be derived from serving not me personally but what I stand for.
('51', 7, 3, 16, 12920) Love to both of you.
('51', 7, 5, 17, 12941) From a microfilm.
('51', 7, 5, 18, 12959) Courtesy: National Archives of India and Anand T. Hingorani
('51', 7, 6, 19, 13019) 9. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI January 9, 1931
('51', 7, 7, 20, 13064) NARANDAS, I think I am very well today.
('51', 7, 7, 21, 13104) I am writing this after the midday meal.
('51', 7, 7, 22, 13145) I had a normal motion.
('51', 7, 7, 23, 13168) In the morning I took almond paste mixed with water and dates.
('51', 7, 7, 24, 13231) Just now, I had fenugreek leaves, liquid curds and dates.
('51', 7, 7, 25, 13289) The diet tomorrow, God will decide.
('51', 7, 7, 26, 13325) There is no cause for worry.
('51', 7, 7, 27, 13354) The weight is bound to go down after four days of fasting.
('51', 7, 7, 28, 13413) It came to 96. If things go well tomorrow, I shall recover some of the lost weight during the next week.
('51', 7, 7, 29, 13518) Tell Mirabehn that I got yesterday the card she posted on Tuesday.
('51', 7, 7, 30, 13585) I got your packet only today.

('51', 9, 2, 3, 15030) January 10, 1931
('51', 9, 3, 4, 15047) KUSUM (SENIOR), It pains me every time you fail to keep your resolution.
('51', 9, 3, 5, 15120) The books you have sent are not the ones which I meant.

('51', 9, 3, 8, 15289) The grammar which you have sent will be useful to him.

('51', 9, 3, 12, 15460) Pyarelal’s is good.
('51', 9, 3, 13, 15480) You must have noted that I have had to give up eating jowar and bajra for the present.

('51', 9, 7, 16, 15626) 14. LETTER TO GOVIND PATEL January 10, 1931
('51', 9, 8, 17, 15670) GOVIND, I got your beautiful letter.
('51', 9, 8, 18, 15707) The word is not dandvrat but dandavat and the phrase means respectful greetings offered by prostrating oneself straight like a stick on the ground.
('51', 9, 8, 19, 15855) In the original phrase, dandavat is an adjective and the noun, pranam 1, is understood.
('51', 9, 8, 20, 15943) But we have been using the word dandavat as a noun too.
('51', 9, 9, 21, 15999) Blessing from
('51', 9, 11, 22, 16013) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3496

('51', 10, 9, 13, 16583) Today I feel very good.
('51', 10, 9, 14, 16607) I am writing this after the midday meal.
('51', 10, 9, 15, 16648) The diet today has been the same as it was yesterday.
('51', 10, 9, 16, 16702) For the evening meal yesterday I had almonds and dates, stirred in water.
('51', 10, 9, 17, 16776) Today, too, I had curds for mid day meal.
('51', 10, 9, 18, 16818) I had a normal motion.
('51', 10, 9, 19, 16841) Durga should add potassium permanganate to enema water, enough to turn it into pink.

('51', 10, 9, 21, 16969) She should also swallow every day 30 grains of soda bicarb with water.
('51', 10, 9, 22, 17040) If gas continues even after this, she should give up oranges for a day or two.
('51', 10, 9, 23, 17119) If it becomes necessary to write to me about her health, you may write whenever you wish to.

('51', 15, 10, 16, 23334) I could once say which verse in the Gita I liked most.
('51', 15, 10, 17, 23389) It was the one beginning, “The impressions of senses, O son of Kunti.” Today I cannot be positive about it.
('51', 15, 10, 18, 23497) Different verses appeal at different times according to the state of mind at the moment.
('51', 15, 10, 19, 23586) I feel no interest now in deciding which I like most.
('51', 15, 10, 20, 23640) The entire Gita is dear to me.
('51', 15, 10, 21, 23671) She is the mother.
('51', 15, 10, 22, 23690) If anyone asks a child which limb of its mother is dear to it, the question would be meaningless.
('51', 15, 10, 23, 23788) That is how I feel in regard to the Gita.
('51', 15, 10, 24, 23830) It was quite cold here for two or three days.

('51', 17, 7, 9, 26049) 29. LETTER TO TEHMINA P. JOSHI January 11, 1931
('51', 17, 8, 10, 26097) DEAR SISTER, You seem to be very greedy.
('51', 17, 8, 11, 26138) Where is the need to write long letters from here?
('51', 17, 8, 12, 26189) You can write long ones.
('51', 17, 8, 13, 26214) I can write long ones if I write about my speeches to the birds and the talks in silence with the stars.
('51', 17, 8, 14, 26319) But how can I expose to the human race my lectures delivered to the birds?
('51', 17, 8, 15, 26394) And my talks with the stars are after all secret.
('51', 17, 8, 16, 26444) Hence I can write only short letters but must receive long ones from you.
('51', 17, 8, 17, 26518) Perhaps they may not pass on to me the cutting carrying your speech.
('51', 17, 8, 18, 26587) But don’t I know what you would say?
('51', 17, 8, 19, 26624) I am glad you went to see the Ashram.

('51', 18, 8, 14, 27229) 31. LETTER TO CHANDRAKANTA
('51', 18, 9, 15, 27256) January 11, 1931
('51', 18, 10, 16, 27273) CHANDRAKANTA, It is now 5 o’clock in the morning.
('51', 18, 10, 17, 27323) It is all right that you wrote a long letter.
('51', 18, 10, 18, 27369) I think it is your duty to go to your parents once for a fixed period.
('51', 18, 10, 19, 27440) It will be better if you go there to improve your health or after you have recovered.
('51', 18, 10, 20, 27526) It is necessary to take Ganga behn’s permission.
('51', 18, 10, 21, 27575) If there is much pending work there, it would be better to go after finishing it.
('51', 18, 10, 22, 27657) That will also be the way to save Brother from further reproaches.
('51', 18, 10, 23, 27724) Your going will appease your parents’ anger.
('51', 18, 10, 24, 27769) After all, are they not Sumangal’s elders too?
('51', 18, 10, 25, 27816) We should put up with our elders’ anger and even their hostility.
('51', 18, 10, 26, 27882) As your manner and behaviour towards them increase in humility, they will gradually calm down.
('51', 18, 10, 27, 27977) As for your expenses, you should accept the money from them as long as they are willing and in a position to send it.
('51', 18, 10, 28, 28095) But you should assure them and yourself that you can earn your expenses.
('51', 18, 10, 29, 28168) You should now consider yourself a daughter of the Ashram.
('51', 18, 10, 30, 28227) You may rest assured that you will be able to earn your livelihood even outside should such a necessity arise.
('51', 18, 10, 31, 28338) I know that you still have a craving for literary knowledge.
('51', 18, 10, 32, 28399) You may increase it as and when you get opportunities for it.
('51', 18, 10, 33, 28461) But do not think that those who have more of literary knowledge serve better.
('51', 19, 0, 1, 28539) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 19, 1, 2, 28580) capacity for service depends solely on selflessness and character.
('51', 19, 1, 3, 28647) How much service Gangabehn renders!
('51', 19, 1, 4, 28683) And what is her store of literary knowledge—or Mithubehn’s, or Laxmidas’s, or Imam Saheb’s?
('51', 19, 1, 5, 28775) If you go over such examples from present and ancient times, you will at once see the truth of what I am saying.
('51', 19, 1, 6, 28888) On the other hand, there are hundreds of highly educated persons in the country.
('51', 19, 1, 7, 28969) They lack either the ability or the will to make sacrifices, and therefore they live useless lives, if they are not actually a burden on others.
('51', 19, 1, 8, 29114) All this argument certainly does not mean that I am against that type of knowledge, or that there is nothing more for you to acquire.
('51', 19, 1, 9, 29248) Do increase your fund of knowledge when you get an oppor tunity.
('51', 19, 1, 10, 29313) But consider the present as a time to gain experience, to serve, and therefore, while cherishing the desire to increase your knowledge, restrain it just now and cheerfully devote yourself to service.
('51', 19, 1, 11, 29513) It was natural that Mother’s grief made you feel unhappy and you cried.
('51', 19, 1, 12, 29585) But we do wish to train ourselves to control such crying too.
('51', 19, 1, 13, 29647) Mother’s grief sprang from ignorant attachment.
('51', 19, 1, 14, 29695) About your having been tempted to eat chillies it is not so much that you did something wrong, but that you weakened in your resolve and were therefore guilty of a lapse.
('51', 19, 1, 15, 29866) We should never depart from our resolutions in matters big or small.
('51', 19, 1, 16, 29935) But don’t worry.
('51', 19, 1, 17, 29952) Forget the lapse and start again.
('51', 19, 1, 18, 29986) No point now remains unanswered.
('51', 19, 2, 19, 30019) Blessings from

('51', 20, 8, 13, 30856) 33. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('51', 20, 9, 14, 30879) January 7/12, 1931
('51', 20, 10, 15, 30898) MIRA, Though the Ashram post has not yet been received as it gene rally is, in order to avoid pressure on my time I commence the letters now.
('51', 20, 10, 16, 31040) Here is the fourth verse 1 : “O Goddess Earth, with the ocean for thy garment, mountains for thy breasts, thou consort of Vishnu (Preserver), I bow to thee; for give the touch of my feet.” Bowing to the earth we learn or ought to learn t o be humble even as the earth is humble.
('51', 20, 10, 17, 31319) She supports the beings that tread upon her.
('51', 20, 10, 18, 31364) She is therefore rightly the consort of Vishnu.
('51', 20, 10, 19, 31412) This conception in my opinion does no violence to truth.
('51', 20, 10, 20, 31469) On the contrary it is beauti ful and is wholly consistent with the idea that God is everywhere.
('51', 20, 10, 21, 31565) There is nothing inanimate for Him.
('51', 20, 10, 22, 31601) We are of the earth earthy.
('51', 20, 10, 23, 31629) If earth is not, we are not.
('51', 20, 10, 24, 31658) I feel nearer God by feeling Him through the earth.
('51', 20, 10, 25, 31710) In bowing to the earth, I at once realize my indebtedness to Him and if I am a worthy child of that Mother, I shall at once reduce myself to dust and rejoice in establishing kinship with not only the lowliest of human beings, but also with lowest forms of creation whose
('51', 20, 11, 26, 31981) 1 Of Ashram Bhajanavali; vide Vol. “Let us repent”, 2 4 1931.

('51', 37, 6, 19, 61823) KASHINATH, I think the more important reasons for your decision to live outside the Ashram were your own wish to do so and the facilities which you would enjoy thereby.
('51', 37, 6, 20, 61992) I too do not believe Narandas to be a perfect man.
('51', 37, 6, 21, 62043) But I believe that his mistakes are unintentional, and that he makes fewer mistakes than others would.

('51', 38, 1, 10, 63272) I have carefully gone through the extract quo ted by you.
('51', 38, 1, 11, 63330) I felt that it showed more emotion than calm reflection.
('51', 38, 1, 12, 63387) It attributes to me something that I have never held or said.
('51', 38, 1, 13, 63449) I have never asserted that the Pandavas, Krishna and other characters are not historical persons.
('51', 38, 1, 14, 63547) My view is that, though all of them might be historical persons, the Mahabharata is not a work of history in the modern sense of the term.
('51', 38, 1, 15, 63686) Caesar, John, Henry, etc., were historical kings, but we know that Shakespeare’s plays named after them are not works of history.
('51', 38, 1, 16, 63816) He used historical events and characters for his dramatic purpose in the plays.
('51', 38, 1, 17, 63896) Further, I never thought or said that the Gita was composed for expound ing non violence.
('51', 38, 1, 18, 63986) On the contrary, I have believed and have said, that at the time of the Gita, war was accepted as normal, though they believed in the dharma of non violence.
('51', 38, 1, 19, 64144) Nevertheless, I believe that the teaching of the Gita does not justify war, even if the author of the Gita had intended otherwise.
('51', 38, 1, 20, 64275) I hold that physical warfare, armed warfare can never be non violent.
('51', 38, 1, 21, 64345) Those who perform animal sacrifice may, and do, say that belief in non violence does not forbid such sacrifice.
('51', 38, 1, 22, 64457) But whatever they say, animal sacrifice is a violence.
('51', 38, 1, 23, 64512) And this also is true about armed warfare.
('51', 38, 1, 24, 64555) To regard it as a necessity and not subject to the general rule, and then to regard it as sanctioned by religion is one thing, but it is quite another to say that it is non violent.
('51', 38, 1, 25, 64737) I feel that Gadreji’s article suffers from looseness and confusion of thought.
('51', 38, 1, 26, 64816) Being a prisoner, I cannot make a public reply, but it is open to you to send my reply to Gadreji for his information.

('51', 39, 7, 10, 65420) 59. LETTER TO MIRABEHN January 14/18, 1931
('51', 39, 8, 11, 65463) MIRA, Again I commence the Ashram letters with yours and that just after the morning prayer.
('51', 39, 8, 12, 65556) The 5th verse 2 is : “May the Goddess Saraswati (of learning) the Destroyer completely of black ignorance, protect me, she who is white as the mogra flower, the moon and a garland of snow, who has worn white robes, whose hands are adorned with the beautiful bamboo of her veena (a kind of violin), who is seated on a white lotus and who is always adored by Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva and the other gods.” January 18, 1931 To me the thought here is very beautiful.
('51', 39, 8, 13, 66015) Learning of course means wisdom.
('51', 39, 8, 14, 66048) The emphasis on threefold whiteness that of snow, moon, f lower and the white dress and white seat is intended to show that uttermost purity is an indispensable part of wisdom or learning.
('51', 39, 8, 15, 66237) As you explore the deeper meaning of these and kindred verses, you will find every virtue personified and made a living reality instead of a dead diction ary word.
('51', 39, 8, 16, 66401) These imaginary gods are more real than the socalled real things we perceive with our five senses.
('51', 39, 8, 17, 66500) When I recite this verse, for instance, I never think that I am addressing an imaginary
('51', 39, 9, 18, 66588) 1 Vide letter to the addressee, “Letter to Vanamala Parikh”, 10 1 1931. This letter was presumably written on Saturday week.
('51', 39, 9, 19, 66713) 2 Of Ashram Bhajanavali; vide “Ashram Bhajanavali”.
('51', 40, 0, 1, 66765) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 41
('51', 40, 1, 2, 66809) picture.
('51', 40, 1, 3, 66818) The recitation is a mystical act.
('51', 40, 1, 4, 66852) That when I analyse the act intellectually, I know that the goddess is an imaginary being, does not in any way affect the value of the recitation at prayer time.
('51', 40, 1, 5, 67014) If all this is not clear to you, you must unhesitatingly tax me.
('51', 40, 1, 6, 67079) So you are to be travelling again.
('51', 40, 1, 7, 67114) I can only say ‘do not over do it, do not strain yourself endurance.’ I telegraphed about Surendra 1. He must have given up his fast.
('51', 40, 1, 8, 67248) For me, I am quite right.
('51', 40, 1, 9, 67274) I have not yet gone back to vegetables or bread.
('51', 40, 1, 10, 67323) Almonds, dates and a little milk or curds and lemons seem to keep me perfectly fit.
('51', 40, 1, 11, 67407) To be able to keep standing at the takli for nearly two hours is not a bad feat for me and I sit at the wheel for nearly two hours without any support to the back.
('51', 40, 1, 12, 67571) Add to that nearly 45 minutes for carding and sliver making.

('51', 40, 4, 16, 67755) DURGA, I hope that your experiment of eating oranges is going on.

('51', 41, 1, 2, 68925) spinning wheel means all the processes through which cotton passes.
('51', 41, 1, 3, 68993) God is no doubt the sole help of the poor, but the spinning wheel is His hands and feet, and, the poor man or woman who holds it holds God.
('51', 41, 1, 4, 69133) We may not be able to live on simple fare as the poor do, but we ought to ply the spinning wheel for their sake.
('51', 41, 1, 5, 69246) And to ply the spinning wheel means to examine its infinite capacity and reveal it to the world.
('51', 41, 1, 6, 69343) This is a study of no ordinary value.
('51', 41, 1, 7, 69381) And to pursue it means to live the teaching of the Gita.
('51', 41, 1, 8, 69438) I need not say all this to Mahadev, but, at this hour of prayer, these deeper sentiments of my heart come out spontaneously as I think of him.
('51', 41, 1, 9, 69581) Perhaps I would not be able to express them before others in the same manner.

('51', 44, 1, 2, 72894) 68. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('51', 44, 2, 3, 72924) 8 p.m., January 14/19, 1931
('51', 44, 3, 4, 72952) NARANDAS, I got the post today at 8 in the morning.
('51', 44, 3, 5, 73004) I found on the cover stamps worth eleven annas.
('51', 44, 3, 6, 73052) On the packet, the stamps used to be three annas worth.
('51', 44, 3, 7, 73108) I don’t feel, however, that paying the extra eight annas every time will be an extravagance.
('51', 44, 3, 8, 73201) This time at any rate I didn’t feel that it was so, for your letter contained news of Surendra’s fast and I could send a wire to you to persuade him to give it up.
('51', 44, 3, 9, 73365) These days the officials here are careful about the post received from and addressed to the Ashram.
('51', 44, 3, 10, 73465) At both ends, therefore, we are likely to receive it regularly.
('51', 44, 3, 11, 73529) Inform Surendra.
('51', 44, 3, 12, 73546) Show this to Nathji or write to him.
('51', 44, 3, 13, 73583) I see igno rance and impatience in Surendra’s step.
('51', 44, 3, 14, 73635) The ignorance is on two counts.
('51', 44, 3, 15, 73667) There is ignorance in the belief that, when imprisoned, one is prevented from doing work of service and, secondly, in the belief that one does service by giving up one’s life in this manner.
('51', 44, 3, 16, 73858) The duty of everyone in Surendra’s circumstances is to preserve his body carefully and use it for service.
('51', 44, 3, 17, 73965) In jail one can spin and weave and do many other kinds of productive work.
('51', 44, 3, 18, 74040) Upright conduct will have its effect on the masses.
('51', 44, 3, 19, 74092) That is also part of service.
('51', 44, 3, 20, 74122) I see cowardice and lack of understanding in ending one’s life by fasting.
('51', 44, 3, 21, 74197) Surendra’s motive is noble, but the good ness of the motive does not by itself condone the intrinsic badness of an action.
('51', 44, 3, 22, 74320) Considered from every point of view, therefore, Surendra’s action 102 in embarking on a fast was blameworthy.
('51', 44, 3, 23, 74430) Obtain Nathji’s opinion and let me know what he thinks.
('51', 44, 3, 24, 74486) If Surendra has anything to say in defence of his action, let him.
('51', 44, 3, 25, 74553) I don’t wish to suggest that one may not give up one’s life in any circumstances.
('51', 44, 3, 26, 74635) All that I mean is that Surendra’s circumstances are not such as will justify his doing so.
('51', 44, 3, 27, 74727) Madhavji has decided to follow my example in experimenting with jowar and bajra.
('51', 44, 3, 28, 74808) Dissuade him from doing so.
('51', 44, 3, 29, 74836) For one thing, my experiment, cannot be considered to have succeeded.
('51', 44, 3, 30, 74906) Even if it is so considered, an experiment of this kind should not be imitated too hastily.
('51', 44, 3, 31, 74998) Milk and dates have agreed with him, and let him cling to them.
('51', 44, 3, 32, 75062) I may say that I have earned the right to make experiments and play with my body after many years’ practice till it has become
('51', 45, 0, 1, 75189) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 45, 1, 2, 75230) accustomed to such experiments.
('51', 45, 1, 3, 75262) This can be said about few others.
('51', 45, 1, 4, 75297) Moreover, this is not the time for such experiments.
('51', 45, 1, 5, 75350) Let us not shed tears over your not having received my postcards regularly.
('51', 45, 1, 6, 75426) After all, am I not a prisoner?
('51', 45, 1, 7, 75458) What facilities are given should be accepted as a kindness.
('51', 45, 1, 8, 75518) I have no complaint to make about my health now.
('51', 45, 1, 9, 75567) At present my diet consists of dates, almonds, curds and lime juice.
('51', 45, 1, 10, 75636) I am watching the effects of these.
('51', 45, 1, 11, 75672) I do not take more than ten tolas of curds, whether in liquid or semi liquid form.
('51', 45, 1, 12, 75755) I take them only once.
('51', 45, 1, 13, 75778) I don’t think I can digest more just now.
('51', 45, 1, 14, 75820) The total number of almonds at two meals comes to forty, and that of dates, at three meals, to seventy.
('51', 45, 1, 15, 75924) I will not increase the number for some time.
('51', 45, 1, 16, 75970) Perhaps I may reduce it.
('51', 45, 1, 17, 75995) I am proceeding cautiously.
('51', 45, 1, 18, 76023) This quantity of food contains plenty of ener gy.
('51', 45, 1, 19, 76073) It is yet six days before this letter will be posted.
('51', 45, 1, 20, 76127) If I make any changes during this period, I will write about them.
('51', 45, 1, 21, 76194) There is not the slightest cause for worry.
('51', 45, 1, 22, 76238) The almonds are first soaked in water and peeled, they are then roasted and crushed into a jelly.
('51', 45, 1, 23, 76336) I follow this method in order to save time.
('51', 45, 1, 24, 76380) The other method of crushing the almonds without roasting them and then boiling the paste in water is of course an excellent one.
('51', 45, 1, 25, 76510) We should realize that we can never do our yajna work too methodically.
('51', 45, 1, 26, 76582) The vigilance which we exercise in such work will keep us vigilant in all other matters, provided of course we are sincere at heart.
('51', 45, 1, 27, 76715) If even now Keshu calms down and devotes himself to work, I will not believe that he has wasted his time so far.
('51', 45, 1, 28, 76828) You took a very good step indeed.
('51', 45, 1, 29, 76862) Tell Devdas that I agree with what he says.
('51', 45, 1, 30, 76906) I would be ashamed to be released on the ground of illness.
('51', 45, 1, 31, 76966) I would rather prefer to take milk and curds and preserve my health.That is actually what I am doing.
('51', 45, 1, 32, 77068) The primary aim of my experiment is to keep up my health here by exercising self restraint.
('51', 45, 1, 33, 77160) The experiment was started entirely for the sake of health, but, since it also satisfied my cons cience, a spiritual motive has entered it.
('51', 45, 1, 34, 77300) Do what is necessary to settle the affair of Nanibehn and Budha bhai.

('51', 45, 1, 36, 77456) Tell Sarja that I regard her as very fortunate.

('51', 48, 8, 10, 81951) I do not know where you are.
('51', 48, 8, 11, 81980) I am sure your agitation must have subsided now.

('51', 48, 8, 13, 82143) The first verse of the morning prayer, too, speaks of sat chit sukh.
('51', 48, 8, 14, 82212) 2 Till we have attained that state, all else in us is imperfect.
('51', 48, 8, 15, 82277) We should be indifferent to honour and insult.
('51', 48, 8, 16, 82324) We should, therefore, do, to the best of our ability, the task that has fallen to our lot.

('51', 49, 1, 2, 82646) 72. COMMENTS ON GALLEY PROOFS OF “HOW TO COMPETE WITH FOREIGN CLOTH” 1
('51', 49, 2, 3, 82717) YERAVDA MANDIR, POONA, January 20, 1931 I have gone through the pages of your book in the form of proofs.
('51', 49, 2, 4, 82823) You have presented some good statistics in the book.
('51', 49, 2, 5, 82876) The information given about mills is more than that of handlooms.
('51', 49, 2, 6, 82942) After reading it, I feel that “How to compete with Foreign Cloth” will be more appropriate as its name.
('51', 49, 2, 7, 83046) You have not referred very minutely to the importance of hand spinning in the achievement of boycott of foreign cloth.
('51', 49, 2, 8, 83165) If you are convinced that hand spinning is the master key, you ought to present that fact clearly.
('51', 49, 2, 9, 83264) It is my growing conviction that a permanent boycott of foreign cloth is impossible without hand spinning, and without hand spinning, it is difficult for hand weaving to exist.
('51', 49, 2, 10, 83441) If you agree with this opinion, you must make this very clear.
('51', 49, 2, 11, 83504) In spite of my partiality for hand spinning I do not agree with the contention of Mr. Talcherkar that machine spun yarn is weaker than hand spun yarn.
('51', 49, 2, 12, 83655) I consider this claim of superiority of hand spun yarn unfounded and it is unproved by experience.
('51', 49, 2, 13, 83754) But what does it matter?
('51', 49, 2, 14, 83779) The machine made bread, in spite of its being more round, smooth and attractive than hand made bread, will always be considered unacceptable when compared to the hand made bread.
('51', 49, 2, 15, 83958) I visualise some difficulty in sending back your letter.
('51', 49, 2, 16, 84015) You are at one with me in regard to hand spinning.
('51', 49, 2, 17, 84066) Therefore, what more can I wish?
('51', 49, 2, 18, 84099) Make this point as clear as you can.
('51', 49, 2, 19, 84136) Mills and handlooms are mutually antagonistic.
('51', 49, 2, 20, 84183) Mills do have a place the national economy of India will surely continue for many

('51', 50, 4, 13, 85743) 73. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('51', 50, 5, 14, 85769) January 20, 1931
('51', 50, 6, 15, 85786) DEAR MAJOR DOYLE, I thank you for your prompt reply.
('51', 50, 6, 16, 85839) The Times of India’s latest report says that Sjt.
('51', 50, 6, 17, 85889) Appasaheb Patwardhan commenced his fast on 10th instant.
('51', 50, 6, 18, 85946) I know that he has not superfluous flesh on him and it is a matter of great anxiety to me to feel that he may be still fasting.
('51', 50, 6, 19, 86074) Could you please ascertain how he is doing and let me know also whether permission has been granted him to spin.
('51', 50, 6, 20, 86187) Your reply raises what is to me a very big question.
('51', 50, 6, 21, 86240) You call the labour of spinning a privilege.
('51', 50, 6, 22, 86285) But to all who spin for sacrifice it is a sacred And why is it impossible for administrative reasons to have instruments of this labour all over the prison if it is not impossible to have instruments of labour?
('51', 50, 6, 23, 86496) In 1922 all the prisoners who wished were allowed to spin in this prison and their work was used for the prison as may be done again.
('51', 50, 6, 24, 86630) The wheels too were made in the prison.
('51', 50, 6, 25, 86670) I am not idly raising this question of spinning.
('51', 50, 6, 26, 86719) It is, as you as well as the Government are aware, a matter of vital importance for me and some of my associates.
('51', 50, 6, 27, 86833) It goes politics and economics.
('51', 50, 6, 28, 86865) With some of
('51', 50, 7, 29, 86878) 1 A note by M.P. Gandhi, the writer, reads: “The necessary alterations were made in the book in the light of Bapu’s comments and certain paragraphs were elaborated as suggested by Bapu.”

('51', 51, 1, 2, 87106) us life would not worth living if we could not serve God through this little labour.
('51', 51, 1, 3, 87191) Evidently C class prisoners who have been spinning in Sabarmati, Nasik and perhaps other prisons have been doing so without authority and with the unwarranted connivance of the local officials.
('51', 51, 1, 4, 87385) But such a sacred duty cannot be performed in a precarious manner under connivance.Either the Government should recognize the right of prisoners to spin even as they recognize their right to pray and eat and perform the other necessary functions although their performance may, as it does, cause inconvenience or they should say they are not prepared to recognize this right in which case in justice it should be withdrawn from all classes of prisoners.
('51', 51, 1, 5, 87839) In reality the discrimination in such a matter between A class and B class prisoners on the one hand and C class on the other shows clearly the absurdity and the injustice of the classification of prisoners.
('51', 51, 1, 6, 88047) And I feel myself with all the conveniences given to me regarding spinning to be a much pampered and privileged prisoner.
('51', 51, 1, 7, 88169) I have no desire to enjoy a single privilege that any other prisoner may not for similar reasons enjoy.
('51', 51, 1, 8, 88273) I would ask youplease therefore to treat this matter of sacrificial spinning as one of urgency.
('51', 51, 1, 9, 88369) I am sorry again to put you and the Government to trouble but you and they will appreciate my position.

('51', 57, 6, 16, 96365) 5 a.m., January 24, 1931
('51', 57, 7, 17, 96390) MATHURADAS, I heard about your request for permission to leave the Ashram.
('51', 57, 7, 18, 96465) If you have made the request so that you may cultivate greater purity outside, what you have done is all right.
('51', 57, 7, 19, 96577) But if you have asked for permission to leave the Ashram in despair, thinking that, since you have committed an error once, you are certain to commit more errors in future, then your action is wrong.
('51', 57, 7, 20, 96777) No one in the world is totally free from shortcomings.
('51', 57, 7, 21, 96832) We have come together in the Ashram not because we are perfect, but in order that we may know our shortcomings and overcome them.
('51', 57, 7, 22, 96962) We should not feel unhappy if on some occasion we commit an error.
('51', 57, 7, 23, 97029) We should feel unhappy only if in committing it we had willingly yielded to a weakness in us or had not been vigilant enough, if we had not struggled, or not sincerely enough, to overcome it.
('51', 57, 7, 24, 97221) You should never lose heart.
('51', 57, 7, 25, 97250) Think over this letter and do what you think proper.

('51', 59, 6, 14, 99396) 89. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('51', 59, 7, 15, 99419) January 21/25, 1931
('51', 59, 8, 16, 99439) MIRA, It is again Wednesday morning after prayer.
('51', 59, 8, 17, 99489) If I am fortunate like last week, I may get the post about 8 a.m.
('51', 59, 8, 18, 99555) But it gives me pleasure to copy out the verses (this time they will be two) for you before I commence the weekly batch of letters.
('51', 59, 8, 19, 99687) Here then are 6th and 7th verses 1 with the notes made at the time: 6. “O God with a curved mouth and big body, refulgent like ten million suns, keep me ever free from harm whilst doing beneficent acts.” NOTE.
('51', 59, 8, 20, 99897) This is addressed to God represented by the mystic letter pronounced ‘Om’; mark its curved mouth and big body.
('51', 59, 8, 21, 100008) Its mystic splendour has been sung by the Upanishads.
('51', 59, 8, 22, 100062) 7. “Guru (teacher) is Brahma, he is Vishnu, he is Mahadev, he is the great Brahman itself.
('51', 59, 8, 23, 100153) I bow to that guru.”
('51', 59, 9, 24, 100174) 1 Of Ashram Bhajanavali,
('51', 60, 0, 1, 100199) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 61
('51', 60, 1, 2, 100243) This refers of course to the spiritual teacher.
('51', 60, 1, 3, 100291) This is not a mechanical or artificial relationship.
('51', 60, 1, 4, 100344) The teacher is not all this in reality, but he is all that to the disciple who finds his full satisfaction in him and imputes perfection to him who gave him a living faith in a living God.
('51', 60, 1, 5, 100533) Such a guru is a rarity at least nowadays.
('51', 60, 1, 6, 100576) The best thing therefore is to think of God Himself as one’s Guru or await the Light in faith.
('51', 60, 1, 7, 100671) No further comment beyond the notes seems necessary.
('51', 60, 1, 8, 100724) The decision as to further translation is made.
('51', 60, 1, 9, 100772) For my own satis faction, must embark upon the translation.
('51', 60, 1, 10, 100832) Any short cut will be longer in the end.
('51', 60, 1, 11, 100873) There will be no stopping after making the commencement.
('51', 60, 1, 12, 100930) I seem, therefore, to be dreading the commencement whilst the present pressure continues.
('51', 60, 1, 13, 101020) The dread is more mental than real.
('51', 60, 1, 14, 101056) But mind supersedes reality.
('51', 60, 1, 15, 101085) I see you are already in Sind.
('51', 60, 1, 16, 101116) I hope the Sind cold has not worried you.
('51', 60, 1, 17, 101158) It can be as cold as the Punjab in Sind.
('51', 60, 1, 18, 101199) You must have met Jamshed Mehta—a noble type of man.
('51', 60, 1, 19, 101252) He is by himself an institution.
('51', 60, 1, 20, 101285) And Iexpect to hear from you about Kikibehn, Gangabehn and Mrs. Malkani and Mrs. Jeramdas, and of course Anand and Vidya.
('51', 60, 1, 21, 101407) January 25, 1931 I have your letter from Sind.
('51', 60, 1, 22, 101454) The rendering of the 2nd chapter is excellent.
('51', 60, 1, 23, 101501) There are two correction I would suggest.
('51', 60, 1, 24, 101543) Instead of ‘notion’, I should have ‘weakness’ at page 1 and at page 7 instead of ‘followers of Vedas’ I should have ‘the Vedic literalists’.
('51', 60, 1, 25, 101684) The second correction is vital, not so the first.
('51', 60, 1, 26, 101734) The followers of the Gita are also followers of the Vedas.
('51', 60, 1, 27, 101793) But these follow the spirit.
('51', 60, 1, 28, 101822) The literalists, as the very name implies, follow the letter.
('51', 60, 1, 29, 101884) I do not know whether I was to return the notes you have sent.
('51', 60, 1, 30, 101947) I shall not re read your letter, but am preserving the notes till I hear further from you.
('51', 60, 1, 31, 102038) They are no longer required for immediate publication, though this one is good enough any day for publication subject to the vital correction.
('51', 60, 1, 32, 102181) What you say about rebirth is sound.
('51', 60, 1, 33, 102218) It is nature’s kindness that we do not remember past births.
('51', 60, 1, 34, 102279) Where is the good, either, of knowing in detail the numberless births we have gone through?
('51', 60, 1, 35, 102371) Life would be a burden if we carried such a tremendous load of memories.
('51', 60, 1, 36, 102444) A wise man deliberately forgets many things even as a lawyer forgets the cases and their details as soon as they are disposed of.
('51', 60, 1, 37, 102574) Yes, ‘Death is but a sleep and a forgetting.’ My health is quite good.
('51', 60, 1, 38, 102645) Energy sometimes astonishes me.
('51', 60, 1, 39, 102677) I fancy that could not negotiate two hours’ continuous standing at the
('51', 61, 0, 1, 102748) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 61, 1, 2, 102789) takli whilst I was at the Ashram.
('51', 61, 1, 3, 102823) I was weighed on Thursday and I was 98 lb., a gain of 2 1 2 lb.
('51', 61, 1, 4, 102887) in one week.
('51', 61, 1, 5, 102900) It is an achievement.
('51', 61, 1, 6, 102922) I am, have been for the past five days on vegetables, brown bread, almonds (paste), dates and sour limes.

('51', 64, 5, 5, 107445) 97. LETTER TO MAHALAKSHMI M. THAKKAR
('51', 64, 6, 6, 107482) January 25, 1931
('51', 64, 7, 7, 107499) MAHALAKSHMI,
('51', 64, 8, 8, 107512) Conditions are the same in every home.
('51', 64, 8, 9, 107551) Since all of us try, consciously or unconsciously, to seem better than others, it is necessary for us to be vigilant.
('51', 64, 8, 10, 107669) You of course are.
('51', 64, 8, 11, 107688) I have started eating cereals because I had always wanted to give up milk.
('51', 64, 8, 12, 107763) If I could have lived, like the other prisoners here, on jowar and bajra, that would have made me happy, and served other purposes too.
('51', 64, 8, 13, 107899) But jowar bajra did not agree with me.
('51', 64, 8, 14, 107938) Now I eat only wheat.
('51', 64, 8, 15, 107960) Nobody else should copy me.
('51', 64, 8, 16, 107988) As for you, the diet which you have adopted is the right one.
('51', 64, 8, 17, 108050) If I succeed in my experiment, I shall advise others.
('51', 64, 8, 18, 108104) Till then, milk and fruits remain the best diet.
('51', 64, 8, 19, 108153) I keep well.
('51', 64, 8, 20, 108166) At present, I eat dates once, bread and boiled vegetable twice, and twice or thrice almonds crushed into paste.

('51', 70, 8, 23, 118945) 106. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('51', 70, 9, 24, 118989) January 26, 1931
('51', 70, 10, 25, 119006) While waiting on the platform of the Chinchwad station to board the train for Bombay, Mr. Gandhi gave the following message to the Indian people: I have come out of jail 2 with an absolutely open mind,
('51', 70, 11, 26, 119208) 1 Vide, “Letter to R. V. Martin”, 16 1 1931.
('51', 71, 0, 1, 119253) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 71, 1, 2, 119294) unfettered by enmity, unbiased in argument and prepared to study the whole situation from every point of view and discuss the Premier’s statement 1 with Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and other delegates on their return.
('51', 71, 1, 3, 119506) I make this statement in deference to the urgent wish expressed in a cable sent to me from London by some of the delegates.
('51', 71, 2, 4, 119630) When asked whether he had any statement to make regarding Mr. Ramsay Mac Donald’s speech, he said he had studied it carefully, but was not yet prepared at that stage to make any comment whatsoever especially owing to the appeal of Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru.
('51', 71, 3, 5, 119884) Questioned as regards his movements in the near future, he said: I have no plan and no policy mapped out.
('51', 71, 3, 6, 119990) I am proceeding to Bombay to talk over things wigh some friends but I do not know just where I shall go from there or how long I shall stay in Bombay.
('51', 71, 4, 7, 120141) Q. What is your opinion regarding the immediate release of all political prisoners?
('51', 71, 5, 8, 120225) A. I most sincerely believe that every political prisoner now in jail for being connected with my civil disobedience movement should be liberated immediately, and none of us as leaders should be happy as long as any of our brethren or sisters are in jail.
('51', 71, 6, 9, 120481) Q. What will you do if the Government do not see eye to eye with you in this matter?
('51', 71, 7, 10, 120566) A. I cannot say at this juncture as I have made no plans.
('51', 71, 8, 11, 120624) Asked if he was happy at being free once again, he replied: I really do not know.
('51', 71, 9, 12, 120706) Mr. Gandhi expressed great appreciation of the treatment he received in jail, and when .
('51', 71, 9, 13, 120795) asked .
('51', 71, 9, 14, 120803) if he expected to go back again in the near future, Mr. Gandhi .
('51', 71, 9, 15, 120868) replied: Possibly, you never know.

('51', 72, 6, 25, 122266) 108. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS BOMBAY, January 27, 1931 I personally feel that the mere release of the Working Committee members makes a difficult situation infinitely more difficult and makes any action on the part of the members, if not altogether impossible, almost impossible.
('51', 72, 6, 26, 122544) The authorities evidently have not yet perceived that the movement has so much affected the mass mind that the leaders, however eminent they may be, will be utterly unable to dictate to the masses a particular course of action.
('51', 72, 6, 27, 122772) This, in my opinion, is a very healthy condition, because independent thinking is the very essence of the spirit of democracy.
('51', 72, 6, 28, 122899) The thousands therefore who are in different prisons of India are
('51', 73, 0, 1, 122965) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 73, 1, 2, 123006) better able to deliver the goods than all the released leaders combined.
('51', 73, 1, 3, 123079) In my opinion, therefore, if the release of leaders is to be effective, the release of all the satyagrahi prisoners is a necessary condition and this release will, in its turn, be ineffective if repression is not stopped altogether.
('51', 73, 1, 4, 123312) I would like to draw the distinction which is very vital between civil disobedience and the action of those thousands who are now in prison.
('51', 73, 1, 5, 123453) Civil disobedience is deliberate disobedience of non moral laws by way of protest not necessarily against the laws covered by disobedience but any general grievance.
('51', 73, 1, 6, 123619) In the present case, however, the men and women have not in the vast majority of case resorted to civil disobedience, but a wholly artificial condition has been produced by the Viceregal ordinances.
('51', 73, 1, 7, 123818) The satyagrahis have not resisted any natural or moral laws, nor have they resisted the common law of the country, nor yet the statute law of the country; but they have been forced to resist autocratic ordinances which were designed to interfere with common law rights such as the right of persuading addicts to the drink or drug habit to give it up, of persuanding the drink and drug dealers to give up that calling or the dealers in, or purchasers of, foreign cloth to give up the sale and purchase of such cloth.
('51', 73, 1, 8, 124334) It may be said that a breach of the salt law is undoubtedly civil disobedience.
('51', 73, 1, 9, 124414) I hold, however, that even in connection with the salt law the people have merely exercised a natural right that millions posses of manufacturing salt out of the waters in their neigh bourhood.
('51', 73, 1, 10, 124608) The only instance, therefore, of civil resistance that I can just now recall is in connection with the salt raids and possibly the forest laws.
('51', 73, 1, 11, 124752) The raids have a history into which I do not wish to go at the present moment.
('51', 73, 1, 12, 124831) What I am anxious to clear is that, even if, after conference with the friends who are coming from the Round Table Conference, it is found that the Premier’s statement affords sufficient ground for the Congress to tender co operation, the right of picketing cannot be given up, nor the right of the starving millions to manufacture salt; and, if these elementary rights are recognized, most of the ordinances will naturally have to be withdrawn.
('51', 73, 1, 13, 125277) It is, therefore, highly necessary for the public, as also the Govern ment, to understand the fundamental Congress position.
('51', 73, 1, 14, 125402) Manufacture of salt and boycott of foreign cloth and of liquor are not intended to register the resistance of the nation to the existing
('51', 74, 0, 1, 125539) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 75
('51', 74, 1, 2, 125583) misrule, but they are intended to achieve these three things for all time.
('51', 74, 1, 3, 125658) No amount of goodwill established between Great Britain and India, so far as I can see, will reconcile the public to the drink evil, the foreign cloth evil or the prohibition to manufacture salt.
('51', 74, 1, 4, 125854) Speaking for myself, I am hankering for peace, if it can be had with honour; but, even if I stood alone, I could be no party to any peace which does not satisfactorily solve the three questions that I have mentioned.
('51', 74, 1, 5, 126071) I should, therefore, judge the Round Table Conference tree by its fruit.
('51', 74, 1, 6, 126144) I have given the three tests that are in operation, but, as the public knows, there are eight more.
('51', 74, 1, 7, 126244) 1 I want the substance of independence—no shadow—and, even as a doctor names the disease of his patient after a proper diagnosis so will I name the tree of the Round Table Conference after I have examined the fruit in the light of the eleven points which are conceived in terms of the man in the street.
('51', 74, 2, 8, 126548) Replying to a further question as regards his treatment in the Yeravda Jail, Mr. Gandhi said : I was a pampered prisoner, in one sense.
('51', 74, 2, 9, 126684) So far as physical comforts were concerned, the prison authorities left no stone unturned to supply them.
('51', 74, 2, 10, 126790) I have, therefore, so far as I am concerned, nothing but good to say of the authorities regarding my food.
('51', 74, 2, 11, 126897) Of course, I was strictly isolated from the fellow satyagrahis and conditions were imposed which made it impossible for me to see those who were near and dear to me.
('51', 74, 2, 12, 127063) But the general treatment of the C class prisoners leaves much to be desired.
('51', 74, 2, 13, 127141) The Superintendent of the Yeravda Prison, Major Martin, I think, is a good man.
('51', 74, 2, 14, 127221) He is anxious to make the prisoners in his charge happy; but he is hidebound by rules and regulations which make it impossible for him to make the prisoners comfortable even so far as their daily meals are concerned.
('51', 74, 2, 15, 127438) To give one instance, there is a rigid rule to the effect that the ordinary prisoner can have only jowar or bajra roti, and of these he must have that grain which is the cheapest at the time.
('51', 74, 2, 16, 127630) Here there is no consideration whatsoever of the bodily wants of the prisoner.
('51', 74, 2, 17, 127709) To quote another instance, these prisoners cannot have even a grain of salt extra.
('51', 74, 2, 18, 127792) They must be content with what is put in their dal or vegetable.
('51', 74, 2, 19, 127857) I can multiply such instances.
('51', 74, 2, 20, 127888) In a sentence, I can sum
('51', 74, 3, 21, 127913) 1 For the eleven points, vide “Clearing the issue”, 30 1 1930.
('51', 75, 0, 1, 127976) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 75, 1, 2, 128017) up my impression by saying that there is no human touch generally between the officials and the prisoners.
('51', 75, 1, 3, 128124) I have appreciated The Times of India’s efforts to better the lot of the numberous C class prisoners.
('51', 75, 1, 4, 128226) If there was any human touch, the very simple suggestion made by Mr. David would have been acted upon long ago.
('51', 75, 1, 5, 128338) Up to the time of leaving the jail, I saw no such sign.
('51', 75, 1, 6, 128394) I am convin ced that C class prisoners have to undergo much avoidable suffering.
('51', 75, 1, 7, 128475) The classification into A, B and C, I regard to be highly irritating and wholly unjustified.
('51', 75, 1, 8, 128568) What is wanted is real relief for the vast majority of prisoners and that cannot come through classification but through humane considerations.
('51', 75, 2, 9, 128712) Answering a question as to what he meant by the statement that he was a “pampered prisoner”, Mr. Gandhi explained that, while all his physical wants, by way of food, etc., were provided, he was mentally and spiritually tortured by being kept in splendid isolation and by way of compensating him for such isolation he was provided with all the food that he wanted.
('51', 75, 3, 10, 129076) Mr. Gandhi was reminded of the passage in the Viceroy’s recent statement that there was little difference between the goal which the Government had before them and that of the Congress and that the difference was only with reference to the method of reaching that goal.
('51', 75, 3, 11, 129346) Speaking on this point Mr. Gandhi said: In the first instance, I am not at all satisfied that a common term has been used to mean the same thing.
('51', 75, 3, 12, 129492) Secondly, the Congress has pursued nothing that the situation did not render absolutely necessary.
('51', 75, 3, 13, 129591) In my opinion when the history of the last decade comes to be written the palm will be given to the women of India.
('51', 75, 3, 14, 129707) They have brought swaraj nearer.
('51', 75, 3, 15, 129740) They have added several inches to their own height and that of the nation.
('51', 75, 4, 16, 129815) Mr. Gandhi was next referred to the report from Yeravda to the effect that he had handed some mysterious document in sealed envelope to the Superintendent of the jail before his departure.
('51', 75, 4, 17, 130004) He denied having given any such document to the Superintendent.

('51', 79, 1, 2, 134429) explained on what terms we might consider the statement of enter into negotiations on the basis of it.
('51', 79, 1, 3, 134532) They are truce terms.
('51', 79, 1, 4, 134554) For myself I am bound by my declaration in Bombay that I continued to adhere to the condition which I had laid down in Yeravda.
('51', 79, 1, 5, 134682) I have now added one more condition.
('51', 79, 1, 6, 134719) Why should we not demand an inquiry into the incident the memory of which brought tears to the eyes of a person like Sardar Sardul Singh?
('51', 79, 1, 7, 134857) What we have suffered so far is nothing in comparison with what we shall be made to suffer in future.
('51', 79, 1, 8, 134959) We are, therefore, justified in demanding that a tribunal should be set up for an independent inquiry into such incidents, that a report of the inquiry be published and the officers found guilty be removed.
('51', 79, 1, 9, 135166) Though we do speak of forgetting and forgiving the misdeeds of others, it would be a sin to forget certain things.
('51', 79, 1, 10, 135281) We may forgive Dyer and O’Dwyer for the Jallianwala massacre, but we cannot afford to forget it.
('51', 79, 1, 11, 135378) We may also forgive the authors of the atrocities here, though some of the incidents here have been more cruel than the massacre at Jallianwala Bagh.
('51', 79, 1, 12, 135528) History offers no parallel to the atrocities committed on women in the Kaira District.
('51', 79, 1, 13, 135615) The papers could not even report what cruelty was inflicted on women—mere women—who were never guilty and could never be guilty of any violence.
('51', 79, 1, 14, 135760) Under the present conditions, how could any such reports appear in the papers?
('51', 79, 1, 15, 135839) An independent court should go into all these incidents, and in future also there should always be an inquiry into incidents such as the arrest and beating up of advocates, of a person like Sunnab.
('51', 79, 1, 16, 136037) Mention was made of the prisoners.
('51', 79, 1, 17, 136072) Those under a death sentence should not be hanged.
('51', 79, 1, 18, 136123) My personal religion tells me not only that they should not be hanged but also that they should not even be kept in prison.
('51', 79, 1, 19, 136247) However, that is my personal opinion, and we cannot make their release a condition.
('51', 79, 1, 20, 136331) The death sentence on the Sholapur men was executed in spite of the doubt expressed by the judge and in spite of so many earnest appeals from the public.
('51', 79, 1, 21, 136485) Shall we say that, if such death sentences continue to be executed, we shall not enter into negotiations with t he Government?
('51', 79, 1, 22, 136612) There is a risk in making any such condition.
('51', 79, 1, 23, 136658) We can with justice demand only the release of those who had joined the present struggle.
('51', 79, 1, 24, 136748) We should not, therefore, include in the truce terms the release of others.
('51', 79, 1, 25, 136824) Hence I adhere to my statement.
('51', 79, 1, 26, 136856) Yes, those who have not been regularly tried in a court should of course be released.
('51', 79, 1, 27, 136942) We can decide even today to enter into talks with the British Government, but only on the condition that I have laid down.
('51', 79, 1, 28, 137065) That condition holds good also for a truce.

('51', 80, 1, 2, 137153) Who would describe the breaking of the salt law as civil disobedience?
('51', 80, 1, 3, 137224) Breaking of a law would be civil disobedience only if we intended to obey it after peace was concluded.
('51', 80, 1, 4, 137328) We cannot give up even one of the demands put forward in the negotiations carried on from Yeravda.
('51', 80, 1, 5, 137427) Ido not believe that Mac Donald’sstatement grants us anything.However, even a consideration of it can be undertaken only if the Government concedes our demands.
('51', 80, 1, 6, 137588) As for myself, I felt even when I started on the Dandi march that I had done my part, and I left it to the Congress to act as it wished or to stop the movement.
('51', 80, 1, 7, 137749) If you tell me that my work is over and that I should return to the Ashram, I would immediately do so.

('51', 80, 1, 10, 138030) I have no shadow of doubt in my mind that I could lead the people better.

('51', 80, 1, 17, 138464) But there can be no question of the people yielding.

('51', 80, 1, 19, 138571) I have no doubt that we can carry on this fight for any length of time.
('51', 80, 1, 20, 138643) But the Government’s capacity for brutality is so great that we must gird up our loins to face more of it.
('51', 80, 1, 21, 138750) We have still to free the oppressed millions in the world, to free the entire world.
('51', 80, 1, 22, 138835) It waits for a miracle from India.
('51', 80, 1, 23, 138870) For my part, I should like you to go from here with the firm determination that you will give up your life, to do whatever is yet necessary for winning swaraj.
('51', 80, 1, 24, 139030) I fear that yet more beastliness will be let loose on us—I say “fear” because we can never wish that man may become still more beastly; but if he does, how can we help it?

('51', 81, 1, 2, 139330) 115. TO THE READER
('51', 81, 2, 3, 139349) ALLAHABAD, February 1, 1931 In renewing your acquaintance after so many months, I feel within me a glow of pleasure that under the greatest difficulty the paper has con tinued publication.
('51', 81, 2, 4, 139538) 1 I had told my co workers that, in the event of suppre ssion by the authorities, the paper were to continue publication even though it was a hand written sheet multiplied to the extent of volunteers coming up to make copies.
('51', 81, 2, 5, 139764) Where there is perfect coordina tion and will ingness, copies can be thus multiplied without end and no printing press in the world an compete with such an effort.
('51', 81, 2, 6, 139928) But I know that this is true in theory.
('51', 81, 2, 7, 139968) In practice, one does not find that willing ness.But nothing is impossible for ahimsa or active, unadulterated love.
('51', 81, 2, 8, 140085) It surmounts all diffi culties.
('51', 81, 2, 9, 140117) My companions have chosen an effective though in my opinion a method less in keeping with the spirit of ahimsa and truth which know no secrecy.
('51', 81, 2, 10, 140261) But I do not judge them.
('51', 81, 2, 11, 140286) On the contrary, their organizing ability has commanded my admiration and respect.
('51', 81, 2, 12, 140369) I do not yet know how over seven thousand copies are being issued with such regularity.
('51', 81, 2, 13, 140457) I must content myself with thanking the invisible helpers and the numerous readers who have continued their association with Young India.
('51', 81, 2, 14, 140595) In renewing contact with the readers through these sheets, let me redeclare my faith.
('51', 81, 2, 15, 140681) Over eight months’ contemplation in solitude has, if possible, increased my faith in truth and ahimsa.
('51', 81, 2, 16, 140784) At the risk of incurring ridicule, I repeat what I have said so often that voluntary universal adoption of khaddar with all its vast implications means purna swaraj and that civil disobedience becomes a necessary duty only because khaddar has not yet obtained the hold it should.
('51', 81, 2, 17, 141064) But of all this hereafter.
('51', 81, 2, 18, 141091) Young India (Supplement), 5 2 1931
('51', 81, 3, 19, 141126) 1 The reference is to its cyclostyled publication during Gandhiji’s incarceration.

('51', 82, 1, 2, 141253) 116. WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION 1
('51', 82, 2, 3, 141289) ALLAHABAD, February 1, 1931 The Working Committee having, out of regard for the wishes of Srijuts Sastri Sapru and Jayakar, suspended the publication of its reso lution passed on January 21, 1931, an impression got abroad that the movement of civil disobedience has been suspended.
('51', 82, 2, 4, 141571) It is, therefore, necessary to reiterate the decision of the Committee that the movement is to continue unabated until explicit instructions are issued to the contrary.
('51', 82, 2, 5, 141740) This meeting reminds the public that picketing of foreign cloth and drink and drug shops, in itself is no part of the civil disobedience campaign, but that it is the exercise of ordinary right of a citizen, so long as it remains strictly peaceful and causes no obstruction to the public.
('51', 82, 2, 6, 142028) This meeting further reminds the sellers of foreign cloth, including foreign yarn, and Congress workers that the boycott of foreign cloth, being a vital necessity in the interest of the masses, is a permanent feature of national activity and will remain so till the nation has acquired the power to exclude foreign cloth and foreign yarn from India, whether by total prohibition or prohibitive tariff.
('51', 82, 2, 7, 142430) Whilst appreciating the response made by dealers in foreign cloth and foreign yarn to the appeal of the Congress to bring about a boycott of foreign cloth, this meeting reminds them that it is not open to any Congress organization to hold out hopes of their being able to dispose of their existing stock in India.
('51', 82, 3, 8, 142744) The History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I, p.
('51', 82, 4, 9, 142800) 1 Presumably drafted by Gandhiji

('51', 83, 3, 4, 142939) H.E. THE VICEROY, DELHI
('51', 83, 4, 5, 142963) DEAR FRIEND, You have made a public appeal 1 to me for co operation in connec tion with the further work of the recently held Conference in London and ascribed to me a belief in the sincerity of British promises and declara tions.
('51', 83, 4, 6, 143194) I wish that I could endorse your ascription.
('51', 83, 4, 7, 143239) I told you on the 23rd December 1929, that subject to honourable exceptions I had found to my great sorrow that British declarations and promises were insincere.
('51', 83, 4, 8, 143401) Had I not found them so, the active voluntary co operation that I had tendered to British officials in India and outside would never have been with drawn.
('51', 83, 4, 9, 143556) But I assure you that I am simply waiting for a sign in order to enable me to respond to your appeal.
('51', 83, 4, 10, 143658) I confess, however, that some of the signs are highly ominous.
('51', 83, 4, 11, 143721) In Borsad, in the district of Kaira, on the 21st January, a cruel, uncalled for and unchivalrous lathi charge was made upon wholly innocent women and girls who were forming a procession which was marching to a women’s meeting that was to be held in order to protest against the brutal treatment a of girl 2 17 years old by a police official.
('51', 83, 4, 12, 144063) Neither the procession nor the meeting was prohibited.
('51', 83, 4, 13, 144118) The injuries were severe in several cases.
('51', 83, 4, 14, 144161) Some of those who were assaulted belong to the Satyagraha Ashram at Sabarmati.
('51', 83, 4, 15, 144240) One of them, an old widow 3, a member of the Managing Board of the Ashram, was drenched in blood.
('51', 83, 4, 16, 144338) To give you some idea of the nature of the police barbarity, I give you a free translation of her letter 4 to me.
('51', 83, 4, 17, 144452) The facts stated in that letter are capable of easy proof.
('51', 83, 4, 18, 144511) The Collector himself was in Borsad on this date.
('51', 83, 4, 19, 144561) At the time of writing this, I cannot recall anything in modern history to parallel this official inhumanity against wholly defenceless and innocent women.
('51', 83, 4, 20, 144717) I may complete the outline of this picture by stating that there were no men

('51', 84, 1, 16, 146729) Such an enquiry is necessary because I assume that the Government of India do not want to countenance methods such as I have described.
('51', 84, 1, 17, 146865) The four cases I have cited are but recent examples.
('51', 84, 1, 18, 146918) I invite you, therefore, to appoint an impartial and representative committee of enquiry acceptable to the Congress to investigate the allegations of excesses against officials in different parts of India since the inauguration of the civil disobedience campaign.
('51', 84, 1, 19, 147182) If such a committee is appointed I am sure that the Congress will lead evidence before it to show that in very many cases the conduct of officials has been contrary to the expectations raised in the preambles to your ordinances and in your repeated declarations.

('51', 85, 5, 8, 147829) 118. INTERVIEW TO REUTER
('51', 85, 6, 9, 147854) ALLAHABAD, February 1, 1931
('51', 85, 7, 10, 147882) Interviewed by Reuter’s special correspondent, Gandhiji said : All speculation regarding split among the members of the Working Committee is pure myth.
('51', 85, 7, 11, 148034) On the contrary the proceedings yesterday and today were perfectly unanimous, and the behaviour of the members cordial.
('51', 85, 7, 12, 148154) All were of one mind that the movement cannot be withdrawn or suspended unless truce is declared.
('51', 85, 7, 13, 148252) It should be obvious to everybody that a mass movement like the one now going on cannot be suddenly and without a reasonable hope of a final settlement stopped, nor can it be called off unless the hope of a settlement is shared by the vast mass of the people; and this can never happen so long as repression in its virulent form continues, as witness, the latest example in the shape of wanton assaults upon Srijuts Bhashyam and Sundaram.
('51', 85, 7, 14, 148691) I have been daily receiving reports from men and women of unimpeachable character giving me details of repression not confined to any particular part of India.
('51', 85, 7, 15, 148851) A friend has handed me a letter containing harrowing details of atrocities said to have been committed by the police in the district of Midnapore (Bengal).
('51', 85, 8, 16, 149007) 1 In his letter dated February 4, addressed to Gandhiji, G. Cunningham wrote : “His Excellency regrets that he is unable to accept the suggestion.
('51', 85, 8, 17, 149154) He would equally decline to entertain any similar proposal to initiate any general enquiry into the responsibility for excesses committed by adherents to the civil disobedience movement .
('51', 85, 8, 18, 149342) His Excellency therefore sees no profit in the general exploration of charges and counter charges that would be made.
('51', 85, 8, 19, 149460) Nor can he feel that it would assist the discharge of what he considers at the present time the most important task of affording opportunity to all, who are willing to do so, to join in the constructive work of bringing to fulfilment the purpose clearly stated by the Prime Minister.”
('51', 86, 0, 1, 149745) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 87
('51', 86, 1, 2, 149789) In my opinion nothing short of an absolutely impartial and thorough going enquiry into these charges can satisfy either the public mind or the requirements of justice.
('51', 86, 1, 3, 149957) I do not see how it is possible to conduct negotiations for peace with repression fouling the atmosphere hour after hour.
('51', 86, 1, 4, 150079) The Hindu, 2 2 1931

('51', 86, 4, 7, 150157) Speaking in Hindi while seated on the dais, Mahatma Gandhi said that it
('51', 86, 5, 8, 150229) afforded him great pleasure in seeing an assembly of such a large crowd as
