('51', 86, 7, 10, 150385) to the people for the great deeds of bravery and sacrifices done by the people during
('51', 86, 8, 11, 150471) the period of eight months.
('51', 86, 8, 12, 150499) He said that whenever he thought of those brave deeds
('51', 86, 9, 13, 150553) and sacrifices he was at once reminded of his sisters.
('51', 86, 9, 14, 150608) The whole world was surprised,
('51', 86, 10, 15, 150639) said Mahatma Gandhi, at the considerable sacrifices made by people in the national
('51', 86, 11, 16, 150722) struggle, especially at the share taken by the women of India.
('51', 86, 12, 17, 150785) The women who were considered absolutely ignorant and always lived in purdah gave up their purdah forthwith at the nation’s call, they sacrificed their
('51', 86, 13, 18, 150937) children, offered for the struggle even their little girls and did not put any obstacles in the way of their husbands participating in the fight.
('51', 86, 13, 19, 151083) And, he said, the women’s sacrifices were not confined to that alone but they themselves discarded the purdah
('51', 86, 14, 20, 151193) and went out to participate in the fight.
('51', 86, 15, 21, 151235) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi said that any number of families would be found in the country, which would have given every one of its members for the national struggle.
('51', 86, 15, 22, 151401) In a fight with guns, old men, women, boys and girls were exempted, but India’s fight for freedom was such that everybody could participate in it.
('51', 86, 16, 23, 151548) Resuming the speech, which Mr. Shiva Prasad Gupta repeated 1, Mahatma Gandhi, while busy at his takli, said that the women of the country had been lifted
('51', 86, 17, 24, 151702) high on account of their sacrifices, by three or four inches and consequently the height of the whole country was also raised by three or four inches which naturally provided an occasion for the Indians to feel proud.
('51', 86, 18, 25, 151920) Young children had also given proofs of their bravery, said Mahatma Gandhi.

('51', 86, 19, 27, 152079) would include children aged six and eight also.

('51', 87, 1, 2, 152322) national struggle God was also with them.
('51', 87, 1, 3, 152364) It was a heavenly precept that victory was bound to come if they remained on the path of truth and non violence, and in such a victory there would be the share of not one individual but of all people and all the communities.
('51', 87, 1, 4, 152589) There could be no considerations of superiority and inferiority in the case of people participating in such a struggle and it was Mahatma Gandhi’s conviction that if they really remained on the path of righteousness and peace the danger of communal quarrels with which they were faced frequently, would altogether disappear.
('51', 87, 2, 5, 152914) Mahatma Gandhi, therefore, appealed to the people that whether there be war
('51', 87, 3, 6, 152990) against the Government or disputes among themselves, they should never leave the
('51', 87, 4, 7, 153071) path of peace and righteousness, the result of which would be that they would never
('51', 87, 5, 8, 153155) suffer defeat.
('51', 87, 6, 9, 153170) He realized that sufficient observance of the principle of non violence had
('51', 87, 7, 10, 153246) been made but at the same time he wished to warn the public that the least mistake on

('51', 87, 9, 12, 153420) whole world that they would carry on the fight peacefully and with firm devotion to
('51', 87, 10, 13, 153504) the motherland.

('51', 87, 11, 15, 153588) from it they would be regarded, said Mahatma Gandhi, as cheats before God and the
('51', 87, 13, 16, 153670) Resuming, Mahatma Gandhi said that he would reiterate what he had been
('51', 87, 14, 17, 153741) saying all along, namely, that every man, woman, boy, and girl should start
('51', 87, 15, 18, 153817) spinning at the charkha and use khaddar made of the yarn spun by him or her and

('51', 87, 17, 21, 153976) everything that was bad, for Indians wanted to govern the country themselves and if
('51', 87, 18, 22, 154060) the government went into hands polluted with misdeeds, the country would be ruined.
('51', 87, 19, 23, 154144) As the noise continued on account of the inability of the audience to hear, in spite of Mr. Gupta’s repeating the speech at the top of his voice, Mahatma Gandhi said that he did not want to take much of the time of the people on account of the noise, and with blessing to the people he concluded his speech abruptly to the utter disappointment of those who expected some pronouncement from Mahatma Gandhi with regard to the situation arising out of the declaration of the British policy, it being the first public speech delivered by him after his release from the Yeravda Jail.

('51', 88, 1, 2, 154957) 120. MESSAGE TO PEOPLE OF MIDNAPORE
('51', 88, 2, 3, 154993) ALLAHABAD, February 2, 1931 I have made myself acquainted with your condition to the extent it was possible without a local visit.
('51', 88, 2, 4, 155124) I tender my congratulations for your courage and patience with which you have borne your suffer ings.
('51', 88, 2, 5, 155226) Out of such sufferings will be born a new nation pulsating with life.
('51', 88, 2, 6, 155296) Earthly possessions are no compensation for loss of liberty.
('51', 88, 2, 7, 155357) It is a matter of joy that you have preferred deprivations of these to that of your liberty.
('51', 88, 2, 8, 155450) I hope you will not neglect the duty of manufac turing free salt.
('51', 88, 3, 9, 155516) M. K. G.
('51', 88, 4, 10, 155525) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('51', 88, 4, 11, 155571) Courtesy : Narayan Desai
('51', 88, 5, 12, 155596) 121. NOTE TO URMILA DEVI
('51', 88, 6, 13, 155621) ALLAHABAD, Silence Day, February 2, 1931 Hunger strike can be resorted to in matters of self respect.
('51', 88, 6, 14, 155723) It is a weapon to be most sparingly used.
('51', 88, 7, 15, 155765) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('51', 89, 1, 2, 155877) 122. LETTER TO K. SANTANAM
('51', 89, 2, 3, 155904) February 2, 1931
('51', 89, 3, 4, 155921) MY DEAR SANTANAM,
('51', 89, 4, 5, 155939) I have just heard from Rajaji the awful news of your wife’s death.
('51', 89, 4, 6, 156006) But I know that you are god fearing and brave—for those who believe in Him nothing is awful.
('51', 89, 4, 7, 156099) He gives and has the right to take away.
('51', 89, 4, 8, 156140) If you are permitted let me have a line that you are at peace with yourself.
('51', 89, 6, 9, 156217) BAPU SJT.
('51', 89, 6, 10, 156227) K. SANTANAM B. BLOCK
('51', 89, 7, 11, 156248) CENTRAL PRISON VELLORE S. INDIA

('51', 90, 2, 3, 156694) February 2, 1931

('51', 90, 7, 22, 157326) 125. LETTER TO VASUMATI PANDIT February 2, 1931
('51', 90, 8, 23, 157374) VASUMATI, How fortunate you are.
('51', 90, 8, 24, 157407) You got beaten and were also awarded a jail sentence.
('51', 90, 8, 25, 157461) All of you have upheld the honour of the Ashram and brought glory to your sex.
('51', 90, 8, 26, 157540) All people do not yet see the full significance of this incident 1. Its real value will be appreciated after some time.
('51', 90, 8, 27, 157660) I hope you did not even feel angry with the person who beat you.
('51', 90, 8, 28, 157725) All of them are like our brothers.
('51', 90, 8, 29, 157760) If we do not feel angry, they are bound to change some day.

('51', 91, 1, 2, 157970) 126. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('51', 91, 2, 3, 158002) February 2, 1931
('51', 91, 3, 4, 158019) CHHAGANLAL, I got all your letters.
('51', 91, 3, 5, 158055) But I have had no rest after leaving the rest house.
('51', 91, 3, 6, 158108) Today is my silence day and so I have got some time, though the stream of visitors continues.
('51', 91, 3, 7, 158202) I simply cannot forget the Borsad incident.
('51', 91, 3, 8, 158246) The people have not yet realized its significance.
('51', 91, 3, 9, 158297) I am taking up the matter.
('51', 91, 3, 10, 158324) The Ashram women have immortalized themselves and the Ash ram.
('51', 91, 3, 11, 158387) Our prayers and the vows of self discipline have borne fruit.
('51', 91, 3, 12, 158449) Other women also have shown such courage.
('51', 91, 3, 13, 158491) There were some in this procession too.
('51', 91, 3, 14, 158531) But I have formed the impression that the special merit of the sacrifice made by the Ashram women lies in the religious spirit which inspired it.
('51', 91, 3, 15, 158677) My future movements are uncertain.
('51', 91, 3, 16, 158712) Probably I shall reach Bombay on the 4th.
('51', 91, 3, 17, 158754) Panditji’s ship is in mid ocean, so that even for his sake I may have to stay on here.
('51', 91, 3, 18, 158841) I keep good health.
('51', 91, 3, 19, 158861) About other developments, you will read in the papers.
('51', 91, 3, 20, 158916) I am trying for the release of the other prisoners, but only within limits proper for us.
('51', 91, 3, 21, 159006) Those who are released by the Government on the expiry of their sentences try to return to the jails immediately.
('51', 91, 3, 22, 159120) Write to me wherever I am.
('51', 91, 3, 23, 159147) For the ensuing official year of the Congress, Sardar has been elected Presi dent.
('51', 91, 3, 24, 159230) This increases the responsibility of Gujarat.
('51', 91, 3, 25, 159276) It may have been necessary for women from outside Kaira District to go there.
('51', 91, 3, 26, 159354) Who took the lead in showing this discourtesy?
('51', 91, 4, 27, 159401) Blessings from
('51', 91, 6, 28, 159416) From a photostat of the Gujarati : G.N. 5500

('51', 93, 12, 18, 161106) 132. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('51', 93, 13, 19, 161138) February 2, 1931
('51', 93, 14, 20, 161155) GANGABEHN, How shall I compliment you?
('51', 93, 14, 21, 161194) You have shown that you are what I had always thought you were.
('51', 93, 14, 22, 161258) How I would have smiled with pleasure to see your sari made beautiful with stains of blood.
('51', 93, 14, 23, 161350) I got excited when I knew about this atrocity, but was not pained in the least.
('51', 93, 14, 24, 161430) On the contrary, I felt happy.
('51', 93, 14, 25, 161461) I would have certainly felt unhappy if none of you were among the victims of that assault.
('51', 93, 14, 26, 161552) I know that there is ignorant attachment even in feeling thus, but I cannot conceal my attachment to the Ash ram even if I tried to do so.
('51', 93, 14, 27, 161691) The shortcomings of the inmates of the Ashram are intolerable to me.
('51', 93, 14, 28, 161760) Likewise, I feel happier when I see their
('51', 94, 0, 1, 161802) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 95
('51', 94, 1, 2, 161846) virtues than when I see the virtues of others.
('51', 94, 1, 3, 161893) Is it a great thing that you did not feel angry with those who hurt you?
('51', 94, 1, 4, 161966) Would you be angry with Kaku if he beat you?
('51', 94, 1, 5, 162011) These others who beat you were also your sons, who had become blind through ignorance.
('51', 94, 2, 6, 162098) Blessings from
('51', 94, 4, 7, 162113) From a copy of the Gujarati : C.W. 8771. Courtesy : Gangabehn Vaidya

('51', 96, 1, 2, 164039) 138. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('51', 96, 2, 3, 164070) February 2, 1931
('51', 96, 3, 4, 164087) NARANDAS, I am writing this at about 10 p.m.
('51', 96, 3, 5, 164132) on silence day.
('51', 96, 3, 6, 164148) I started observing silence at 11.30 p.m.
('51', 96, 3, 7, 164190) yesterday and so a little more time must pass before I can give it up.
('51', 96, 3, 8, 164261) After my release it is only today that I may say I had some time for rest, though of course even today I had to listen to many people and hear their stories.
('51', 96, 3, 9, 164419) All the same, I have certainly been able to write, for the first time after my release, the letters enclosed with this and some others.
('51', 96, 3, 10, 164555) See if you can pass on their letters to Surendra 1, Gangabehn 2 and Vasumati 3, or inform them of their substance.
('51', 96, 3, 11, 164670) How is Durgabehn’s health?
('51', 96, 3, 12, 164697) I have not asked Mahadev about it.
('51', 96, 3, 13, 164732) I don’t know where he is at present.
('51', 96, 3, 14, 164769) What is the position about Madhavji’s diet?
('51', 96, 3, 15, 164813) Tell him that he cannot insist on being supplied milk and dates and that he should be satisfied if they agree to provide them at his own cost.
('51', 96, 3, 16, 164956) Though I have been released, I feel as if I had not been released.
('51', 96, 3, 17, 165023) If others are not released and if the situation does not improve, I shall have no choice but to court imprisonment.
('51', 96, 3, 18, 165139) My programme in general is as follows : I intend to start from here tomorrow evening so as to reach Bombay on Wednesday evening.
('51', 96, 3, 19, 165268) I shall be there up to Friday at any rate.
('51', 96, 3, 20, 165311) If, however, Panditji’s health deteriorates, I may not be able to leave even tomorrow.
('51', 96, 3, 21, 165398) Or it may also happen that, after meeting Sastriji and others, I may have to leave on Friday to return here.
('51', 96, 3, 22, 165507) Address the post accordingly.
('51', 96, 3, 23, 165537) That is, address it to me at Bombay till I inform you otherwise.
('51', 96, 3, 24, 165602) I am yearning to visit Kaira district.
('51', 96, 3, 25, 165641) I intend to go there if I am free on Friday.
('51', 96, 3, 26, 165686) God alone knows when and where we shall meet.
('51', 96, 3, 27, 165732) Unless some reason connected with the struggle brings me to the Ashram.
('51', 96, 3, 28, 165804) I wish to visit neither the Ashram nor Ahmedabad.For permanent headquarters, I should naturally choose Karadi, but I see no possibility at present of my wish being fulfilled.
('51', 96, 3, 29, 165979) I feel unhappy at the thought that I shall no
('51', 96, 4, 30, 166025) 1 They were in jail.
('51', 96, 4, 31, 166046) 2 ibid.
('51', 96, 4, 32, 166054) 3 ibid.

('51', 97, 1, 2, 166103) longer be able to send discourses for Gitabodh.
('51', 97, 1, 3, 166151) If you come to know more about Kaira, let me know.

('51', 97, 5, 6, 166261) 139. LETTER TO CHANDRAKANTA
('51', 97, 6, 7, 166289) February 2, 1931
('51', 97, 7, 8, 166306) KANTA, Your question is all right You can find the answer only in my letters.
('51', 97, 7, 9, 166384) Happiness and unhappiness are states of mind.
('51', 97, 7, 10, 166430) But how can we perceive that they are so?
('51', 97, 7, 11, 166472) Certainly not by reading.
('51', 97, 7, 12, 166498) We can do so only by experience.
('51', 97, 7, 13, 166531) That is why suffering is necessary.
('51', 97, 7, 14, 166567) Here by suffering I mean what is regarded as such by the world.
('51', 97, 7, 15, 166631) Illness of the body, phy sical assault, hunger, getting robbed, being insulted, etc.,—it is the mind which experiences all these forms of suffering.
('51', 97, 7, 16, 166780) A devotee of God, a yogi, one who has merged in the Brahman, has become a sthitaprajna, —these are not affected by such sufferings but remain content even in their presence as they do in so called happiness.
('51', 97, 7, 17, 166988) When one becomes equi minded in this way one will attain self knowledge.
('51', 97, 7, 18, 167061) Is this clear?
('51', 97, 8, 19, 167076) Blessings from
('51', 97, 9, 20, 167091) BAPU [PS.] You too may have occasion to be assaulted 1. Remain unconcerned whether such occasion arises or not.
('51', 97, 11, 21, 167203) From a photostat of the Gujarati: Chandrakanta Papers.
('51', 97, 11, 22, 167258) Courtesy: Gandhi National Museum and Library

('51', 100, 4, 5, 169683) Boatmen’s Association in the “Swaraj Bhawan”.

('51', 100, 7, 8, 169883) cultivators who were not disposed to stop payment of their rents.

('51', 100, 8, 10, 169969) Sunday’s incident of the villagers travelling without tickets, 1 and deprecated their
('51', 100, 9, 11, 170055) action as the Congress had not launched a campaign of travelling without tickets.

('51', 100, 11, 13, 170219) railway service.

('51', 102, 4, 9, 172322) 147. LETTER TO D. B. KALELKAR
('51', 102, 5, 10, 172352) February 5, 1931 For anything to be achieved five factors have to co operate.
('51', 102, 5, 11, 172430) Among them, fate has been placed the last, but it is in effect the first.
('51', 102, 5, 12, 172504) What can we do when fate itself is against us?
('51', 102, 5, 13, 172551) Panditji suffered no inconvenience during the journey.

('51', 102, 9, 22, 172966) ALLAHABAD, February 5, 1931
('51', 102, 10, 23, 172994) DEAR SISTER, I have your letter.
('51', 102, 10, 24, 173027) I thank you for it.
('51', 102, 10, 25, 173047) I am sorry that you were harassed.
('51', 102, 10, 26, 173082) You suggest my fasting in expiation.
('51', 102, 10, 27, 173119) It certainly calls for a fast.
('51', 102, 10, 28, 173150) However, I feel that I should not resort to such a strong measure so soon after being released from prison.
('51', 102, 10, 29, 173258) For the present, therefore, I am making enquiries with regard to this sad affair.
('51', 102, 10, 30, 173340) After the enquiries are over, I will do what is necessary.
('51', 102, 10, 31, 173399) I would request you to regard those who harassed you as your brothers and harbour no grudge against them.
('51', 102, 10, 32, 173505) Their exercising coercion is bad, but considering that boycott of foreign cloth is a worthy cause I expect help from women like you.

('51', 103, 7, 14, 174507) 150. INTERVIEW TO “THE PIONEER”
('51', 103, 8, 15, 174539) ALLAHABAD, February 5, 1931 I am a man of peace, but circumstances have made my life one of struggle.
('51', 103, 8, 16, 174641) I shall, however, leave no stone unturned to attain peace.
('51', 103, 8, 17, 174700) It is no joy to me to submit thousands who have a childlike faith in me to suffering.
('51', 103, 9, 18, 174786) In answer to a question whether he found the Prime Minister’s declaration 1
('51', 103, 10, 19, 174862) satisfactory, he said that he had resolutely refrained from coming to definite conclu sions on the subject.
('51', 103, 10, 20, 174970) Mr. Sastri, Mr. Jayakar, and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru have cabled to me to suspend judgment and I have the highest esteem for these patriots who love their country as intensely as I claim to do.They may be able to explain to me satisfactorily that Mr. Ramsay MacDonald’s declaration conveys something beyond what I have been able to make out on a cursory reading, and, if in the light of my eleven points, I see that a settlement is possible, I shall readily advise
('51', 103, 11, 21, 175433) 1 Vide “Prime minister’s declaration at R.T.C”, 19 1 1931.
('51', 104, 0, 1, 175492) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 105
('51', 104, 1, 2, 175537) the calling off of the civil disobedience movement.
('51', 104, 2, 3, 175589) Mr. Gandhi proceeded to discuss the allegations made against the police and
('51', 104, 3, 4, 175665) said he had a large file on the subject containing evidence from men upon whose word
('51', 104, 4, 5, 175750) he relied.
('51', 104, 4, 6, 175761) When reminded that his version was one sided, he added : I do not ask you to accept my allegations against the police.
('51', 104, 4, 7, 175880) Let us have an impartial investigation and I am quite prepared to lead evidence and abide by the verdict of the tribunal.
('51', 104, 5, 8, 176002) On its being pointed out that the police had generally conducted themselves
('51', 104, 6, 9, 176078) with the utmost forbearance under the most difficult conditions, he replied : I do not complain about ordinary repression.
('51', 104, 6, 10, 176201) If I violate the law, I expect to be arrested.
('51', 104, 6, 11, 176248) The Government may want to maintain order but there must be some relation between offence and punish ment.
('51', 104, 6, 12, 176355) Departure from this rule has been much more general than you suppose.
('51', 104, 7, 13, 176425) Responding to a question whether it was not inevitable that there should, in extraordinary times, be a certain amount of severity as it must be impossible exactly to measure action, Mr. Gandhi interjected : Why should it be inevitable?
('51', 104, 7, 14, 176661) It was not so in South Africa and the reason for that was that they had a national Government there.
('51', 104, 8, 15, 176762) Explaining himself further, Mr. Gandhi made a specific grievance of confis cations said to have taken place in Gujarat and Bengal.
('51', 104, 8, 16, 176893) Many have lost their homes.
('51', 104, 8, 17, 176921) The sufferers may have been guilty of non payment of taxes or not, but if property worth, say, Rs. 50 lakhs has been appropriated for dues, say, of about a lakh, it must be restored.
('51', 104, 8, 18, 177104) The Government have nothing to gain by refusing to restore the property and my suggestion is not without precedent.
('51', 104, 9, 19, 177220) He insisted that the matter should not be left to Local Governments, but should go before an entirely impartial tribunal.
('51', 104, 9, 20, 177342) The presentation of an inventory does not, however, establish a claim, and I quite see that confiscations must be satisfactorily proved by the complainants.
('51', 104, 10, 21, 177499) Mr. Gandhi referred also to the release of political prisoners.
('51', 104, 10, 22, 177563) On attention being drawn to the promise of the Government to release prisoners on the termi nation of the civil disobedience movement, he remarked : I know that they will be released.
('51', 104, 10, 23, 177747) But I have difficulties, though not insuperable, facing me.
('51', 104, 10, 24, 177807) Some of our people are already perturbed
('51', 105, 0, 1, 177848) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 105, 1, 2, 177890) at my conciliatory statements.
('51', 105, 1, 3, 177921) But when I am convinced that I should call off the movement, I hope also to convince them.
('51', 105, 1, 4, 178012) When I called off the last non co operation movement at Bardoli, I had only to act on my own and not wait for any indication from the Government.
('51', 105, 1, 5, 178158) The circumstances today are different.
('51', 105, 2, 6, 178197) Dealing with the proposed Constitution, Mr. Gandhi said that with 80 per cent of the budget placed beyond the purview of the legislature and only 20 per cent left which would be inadequate for “nation building” purposes, there was not much satisfaction to be gained.
('51', 105, 2, 7, 178464) If our co operation is wanted, it will not do to tell us simply to adhere to a consideration of the unsettled questions.
('51', 105, 2, 8, 178585) We must have the freedom to reopen the discussions on the so called safeguards.
('51', 105, 3, 9, 178665) Mr. Gandhi also said that, in regard to the Indian States, there seemed to be no protection for the people of the States.
('51', 105, 3, 10, 178787) The Congress would be untrue to itself if it did not seek it, and I cannot bring myself to believe that Mr. Ramsay Mac Donald would deny in his dealings in the matter all the teachings of a lifetime.
('51', 105, 4, 11, 178987) Mr. Gandhi, however, felt hopeful that the States and communal questions could be adjusted.
('51', 105, 4, 12, 179079) But he was clearly of opinion that the Congress participation depended on two things: first, satisfactory adjustment of the preliminaries of suspension of the civil disobedience movement; and secondly, satisfaction regarding the Conference.
('51', 105, 4, 13, 179320) He concluded : I am doing everything to terminate civil disobedience which will be done if I am sure that full restoration will be made, prisoners are released, an impartial inquiry is held into the alleged police excesses led to, in many cases, by action taken for offences created by the pro clamation of new regulations, and generally certain other necessary adjustments are made.
('51', 105, 4, 14, 179704) The Pioneer, 6 2 1931
('51', 105, 5, 15, 179726) 151. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('51', 105, 6, 16, 179754) LUCKNOW, February 5, 1931
('51', 105, 7, 17, 179780) Asked by the Free Press representative at Lucknow about some message for the country, Mahatma Gandhi said : I have no message to give.
('51', 105, 7, 18, 179915) I can only emphasize what I have been saying, that continuous repression about which evidences are daily accumulating makes it well nigh impossible to contemplate
('51', 106, 0, 1, 180078) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 107
('51', 106, 1, 2, 180123) From all over the country I am getting reports that the autho rities are ruthless and sometimes even devoid of all decency.
('51', 106, 1, 3, 180247) And that, on the top of this, they do not hesitate to deny the truth of the allegations made on behalf of the suffering public.
('51', 106, 1, 4, 180375) The most painful part of the whole affair is that the Political Departments at the top defend the conduct of the police and wilfully—that is the only expression I can use—shut their eyes to everything said on behalf of the public, no matter how well supported the allegations might be.
('51', 106, 1, 5, 180661) I have not a shadow of doubt in my mind that the allegations about the unchivalrous and cruel conduct of the police in respect of women’s processions in Borsad are true, and yet the Director of Public Information has made what reads like an oracular statement incapable of being contradicted.
('51', 106, 1, 6, 180954) I am sure that if a really impartial enquiry is made, it would be found that the Director of Public Information had become a tool in the hands of unscrupu lous officials who have not hesitated to add falsehood to their barbarity.
('51', 106, 1, 7, 181184) I know that I am using strong language, but anything less strong will be untruthful on my part.
('51', 106, 1, 8, 181280) I would like to be proved wrong in having believed the reports I have received, in which case I should tender my apology to the officials concerned.
('51', 106, 2, 9, 181429) When asked by another Press representative about his future programme, he said that it depended upon the health of Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('51', 106, 2, 10, 181566) The Hindustan Times, 7 2 1931
('51', 106, 3, 11, 181596) 152. MESSAGE TO “DARIDRANARAYANA”
('51', 106, 4, 12, 181630) LUCKNOW, February 6, 1931 As Daridranarayana is the name given, I trust the performance too will match the name.
('51', 106, 4, 13, 181743) In the present times if a raja brings out a paper for his subjects he has to be doubly careful.
('51', 106, 4, 14, 181839) If he considers himself the master, the subjects are brought to ruin, but by regarding himself as their servant he uplifts both himself and the subjects.
('51', 106, 5, 15, 181993) MOHANDAS GANDHI From a photostat of the Hindi : G.N. 8695; also C.W. 2891. Courtesy : Kumar Suresh Singh

('51', 110, 1, 2, 186539) 158. SPEECH AT MOTILAL NEHRU’S FUNERAL, ALLAHABAD
('51', 110, 2, 3, 186589) February 6, 1931 Though a great leader of India has passed away today, I see on your faces not grief but elation.
('51', 110, 2, 4, 186703) That should be so.
('51', 110, 2, 5, 186722) When leaders leave us, it does not behove us to shed tears.
('51', 110, 2, 6, 186782) For, what is happening here is not consigning to the flames the lifeless flesh of a devotee, but our witnessing great sacrifice that the nation has made.
('51', 110, 2, 7, 186936) This is not the first such occasion in my life.
('51', 110, 2, 8, 186984) At the time of the Lokamanya’s death also we had such a vast crowd.
('51', 110, 2, 9, 187052) I see before me a scene similar to the one I had seen then.
('51', 110, 2, 10, 187112) The people had been praying and singing songs.
('51', 110, 2, 11, 187159) They were filled with a certain kind of exaltation.
('51', 110, 2, 12, 187211) At first I could not realize that, but as soon as I recovered from the grief which had momentarily clouded my reason, I understood how the people had felt that the Lokamanya’s death was the crowning glory of his life long sacrifices.
('51', 110, 2, 13, 187445) I witnessed similar scenes at the time of Deshbandhu’s death and of Lalaji’s, Hakimji’s, Mahomed Ali’s.
('51', 110, 2, 14, 187549) What a great effect on the world and on Londoners had Mahomed Ali’s death made!
('51', 110, 2, 15, 187629) The reason was that he had gone to England to serve the country’s cause and that he sacrificed his life in it.
('51', 110, 2, 16, 187740) I am happy that today also the people have displayed the same feeling.
('51', 110, 2, 17, 187811) If you have fully understood the significance of this, it is well that you have thus observed the occasion.
('51', 110, 2, 18, 187919) Otherwise, the world would call us fools and say that a crowd of unfeeling people had collected at a fair.
('51', 110, 2, 19, 188026) What we see before us is a national sacrifice.
('51', 110, 2, 20, 188073) On this occasion, I ask of you that you disperse only after taking some definite vow to do whatever little you can for the country.
('51', 110, 2, 21, 188205) You will indeed deserve praise if you do this.
('51', 110, 2, 22, 188252) Now, on this occasion, I will narrate to you an interesting story.
('51', 110, 2, 23, 188319) Panditji was a huge lion and he had fought big battles in his life.
('51', 110, 2, 24, 188387) And similarly he fought the god of death.
('51', 110, 2, 25, 188429) You may say that he was defeated, but I do not believe that it is true.
('51', 110, 2, 26, 188501) During this last illness of his, I visited him daily and occasionally he sent for me too.
('51', 110, 2, 27, 188591) He did that yesterday.
('51', 110, 2, 28, 188614) I joked with him.
('51', 110, 2, 29, 188632) I have no words to praise the doctors.
('51', 110, 2, 30, 188671) They had done their very best, and would have given their lives if that would have saved his life.
('51', 110, 2, 31, 188770) It is because they had such faith that they had taken him to Lucknow for treatment.
('51', 110, 2, 32, 188854) Their faith was the result not of Panditji’s physical condition, but of his courage.
('51', 110, 2, 33, 188939) I told Panditji
('51', 111, 0, 1, 188955) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 111, 1, 2, 188997) that, if he recovered, I would believe that swaraj was won.
('51', 111, 1, 3, 189057) He smiled and said that it had been won already.
('51', 111, 1, 4, 189106) Though he could not speak distinctly, he had enough peace of mind to be able to say this.
('51', 111, 1, 5, 189196) Why did he believe that swaraj had already been won?
('51', 111, 1, 6, 189249) Could anyone say that swaraj was not won when sixty thousand people had gone to jail, when people had faced numerous lathi charges and made so many sacrifices?
('51', 111, 1, 7, 189409) I did not visit him last night, but I tell you what Panditji’s wife told me.
('51', 111, 1, 8, 189486) During his life he had not followed the practice of praying with Ramanama, and used to make fun of religion, because he abhorred hypocrisy and false show and was angered by men practising irreligion in the name of religion.
('51', 111, 1, 9, 189710) But I know his heart and knew that he believed in God.
('51', 111, 1, 10, 189765) Last night he had been uttering Rama’s name aloud.
('51', 111, 1, 11, 189816) Panditji’s tongue had never uttered a word of grief or despair—only a weak man like me would do that.
('51', 111, 1, 12, 189918) But he never uttered Rama’s name either.
('51', 111, 1, 13, 189959) However, yesterday he remembered that name.
('51', 111, 1, 14, 190003) He also used to say that he had forgotten gayatri—he had given up the practice of reciting it because of the irreligion he saw around him.
('51', 111, 1, 15, 190142) But, as he told his wife, he had recollected the gayatri verse that day.
('51', 111, 1, 16, 190215) This means that Panditji departed a pure man.
('51', 111, 1, 17, 190261) May his pure self sacrifice result in making us purer too.
('51', 111, 1, 18, 190320) Before leaving here, resolve what you will do for the cause for which this great man sacrificed his son, daughter and son in law.
('51', 111, 1, 19, 190450) The pledge which has stirred you is to win swaraj with the twin means of non violence and truth.
('51', 111, 1, 20, 190547) Keeping these two means in your mind, take whatever vow you wish to before you leave.
('51', 111, 1, 21, 190633) In your enthusiasm today, you forgot yourselves and used thoughtless words.
('51', 111, 1, 22, 190709) We are here today to serve the cause of peace, and it behoves us to be peaceful.
('51', 111, 1, 23, 190790) Even soldiers, the men who work with weapons of steel, remain disciplined and peaceful, though of course outwardly.
('51', 111, 1, 24, 190906) Leave this place with that peace in your mind and that discipline in your outward behaviour.
('51', 111, 1, 25, 190999) Take, with this fire as witness, whatever sincere pledge you can fulfil.
('51', 111, 1, 26, 191072) May God inspire you to take that pledge.
('51', 111, 1, 27, 191113) [From Gujarati]
('51', 111, 2, 28, 191129) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('51', 117, 1, 2, 198206) 172. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('51', 117, 2, 3, 198234) ALLAHABAD, February 9, 1931
('51', 117, 3, 4, 198262) Mahatma Gandhi has issued a statement to the Press today at 11 a.m., asking that the fifteenth of February, the Shraddha Day, should be observed all over India as
('51', 117, 4, 5, 198425) “Motilal Day”.
('51', 117, 4, 6, 198440) The following is the full text of the statement : Next Sunday (15th instant) is the first day of the shraddha ceremony for the soul of the late Panditji Motilal Nehru.
('51', 117, 4, 7, 198608) I suggest that as a mark of respect for his memory and to commemorate his unexampled sacrifice for the country, all work should be suspended and the day observed by the nation as one of greater dedication to the cause he loved and for which he lived.
('51', 117, 4, 8, 198859) Those who believe in puri ficatory fast will fast for the day breaking it in the evening.
('51', 117, 4, 9, 198949) I suggest the following programme : 1. Meetings all over the country at 3 p.m.
('51', 117, 4, 10, 199028) so far as possible and so as to enable the peasantry to return to their homes in due time.
('51', 117, 4, 11, 199119) 2. People should march in silent procession to the meetings with national flags.
('51', 117, 4, 12, 199200) 3. Perfect silence should be observed at the meetings.
('51', 117, 4, 13, 199255) 4. The following declaration may be made by the assembly speaking word for word after the chairman: “We assembled in this meeting for commemorating the great and noble sacrifice of the late revered Pandit Motilal Nehru hereby solemnly resolve to dedicate ourselves more fully than hitherto to the cause of the country so as to hasten the advent of purna swaraj.” Dedication may be in any of the following ways, for instance : (a) giving up intoxicating drink or drugs and persuading others to do so, (b) undertaking to picket peacefully and without obstruction such drink and drug shops till such time as total prohibition becomes the law of the land or for a period, (c) treatment similar to (a) and (b) regarding foreign cloth, (d) resolution to spin a minimum quantity of yarn per day, N.B. Spinning includes a knowledge of carding and so far as possible preparing one’s own slivers.
('51', 117, 4, 14, 200142) (e) resolution to wear nothing but hand spun and hand woven khadi,
('51', 118, 0, 1, 200209) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 119
('51', 118, 1, 2, 200254) (f) buying or selling such khadi on the memorial day, (g) giving to the national cause whatever is within one’s capacity or at least the day’s earnings, (h) doing any service or any act of self denial not covered by the preceding clauses.
('51', 118, 2, 3, 200493) He further says : 1. It is of the utmost importance that all suspension of work and every other act should be absolutely voluntary.
('51', 118, 2, 4, 200625) There should be no compulsion of any kind whatsoever.
('51', 118, 2, 5, 200679) 2. To make the demonstration impressive perfect discipline is essential.
('51', 118, 2, 6, 200752) 3. Men, women and children belonging to all classes and communities are expected, in their tens of thousands, to take part in the demonstration.
('51', 118, 2, 7, 200897) 4. If the people at large will it, complete boycott of foreign cloth can be accomplished on the memorial day.
('51', 118, 2, 8, 201007) It would be the noblest monument that is within the power of the nation to raise in one day to a patriot who himself at one time was given to all sorts of foreign luxuries and who when he realized his duty discarded and burnt his costliest clothes as we generally discard worn out clothings.
('51', 118, 2, 9, 201299) 5. So far as possible people should declare their individual act of self denial or resolution at the meeting and in every case to the Congress sub committee of his or her taluk or firka.
('51', 118, 2, 10, 201486) An abstract of results should be sent to headquarters.
('51', 118, 2, 11, 201541) The Hindustan Times, 9 2 1931

('51', 120, 11, 17, 204443) 177. LETTER TO MANAGER, “YOUNG INDIA” February 9, 1931
('51', 120, 12, 18, 204498) BHAISHRI, After reading in the papers about the attack on you, I stopped sending articles to you for the journal.
('51', 120, 12, 19, 204612) The loss of the cyclo styling equipment is, from our point of view, certainly a sort of defeat for us.
('51', 120, 12, 20, 204715) It has had no effect on me.
('51', 120, 12, 21, 204743) For we have no right at all to own property.
('51', 120, 12, 22, 204788) In a tyrannous state, the tyrant claims every pie as his property and, through that claim, he is able to oppress the sub jects.
('51', 120, 12, 23, 204916) If, in such a state, an individual or group of individuals becomes indifferent to property, the tyrant’s power of oppression ends.
('51', 120, 12, 24, 205047) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 22 2 1931

('51', 121, 7, 26, 206315) 179. STATEMENT ON INDIA’S PUBLIC DEBTS
('51', 121, 8, 27, 206354) [February 10, 1931] 2
('51', 121, 9, 28, 206376) Mr. Gandhi was shown Reuter’s telegram about the Daily Mail’s comments on the demand for the repudiation of public debts.
('51', 121, 9, 29, 206498) Mr. Gandhi made it quite clear that it was no question of repudiation, but what he wanted was the matter should be placed before an impartial tribunal, who would judge whether the loan was raised in the interests of India or not; and if not, the loan should be charged to the British revenues.

('51', 122, 3, 11, 207490) Under organized despotism luckless ness is luck, poverty a blessing, riches a curse, evil is enthroned, good ness nowhere, in one clause all values are transposed.
('51', 122, 3, 12, 207654) We have only felt from afar the heat of the fire we must pass through.
('51', 122, 3, 13, 207725) Let us be ready for the plunge.
('51', 122, 3, 14, 207757) That is my reading just now.
('51', 122, 3, 15, 207786) And it fills me with joy.
('51', 122, 3, 16, 207812) A halting peace will be dangerous and I can see no sign of real peace coming.

('51', 129, 1, 2, 217915) 191. LETTER TO VICEROY
('51', 129, 2, 3, 217938) ANAND BHAWAN, ALLAHABAD, February 14, 1931
('51', 129, 3, 4, 217981) DEAR FRIEND, As a rule I neither wait for outward prompting nor stand on ceremony, but straightway seek personal contact with officials whenever I feel such contact is needed in the interest of a cause.
('51', 129, 3, 5, 218184) But somehow or other, in the present case, I have missed the guidance of the inner voice.
('51', 129, 3, 6, 218274) But I have received suggestions from friends whose advice I value that I should seek an interview with you before coming to any decision.
('51', 129, 3, 7, 218412) I can no longer resist this advice.
('51', 129, 3, 8, 218448) I am aware of the responsibility resting on my shoulders.
('51', 129, 3, 9, 218506) It is heightened by the death of Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('51', 129, 3, 10, 218561) I feel that without personal contact and heart to heart talk with you, the advice I may give my co workers may not be right.
('51', 129, 3, 11, 218686) The friends I have referred to read into the proceedings of the London Conference a meaning and a hope I would like to share.
('51', 129, 3, 12, 218812) There are other difficulties to be overcome before I can advise sus pension of civil disobedience and co operation in the remaining work of the Conference.
('51', 129, 3, 13, 218968) It was felt that, before the Working Com mittee took any final decision, it might be better for me to meet you and discuss our difficulties with you.
('51', 129, 3, 14, 219118) I therefore ask you, if you are willing, to send me an appointment as early as may be possible.
('51', 129, 3, 15, 219214) 1 I would like to meet not so much the Viceroy of India as the man in you.
('51', 129, 3, 16, 219289) Could I expect a reply by Monday next ?
('51', 129, 3, 17, 219329) In the absence of a reply I propose to leave Allahabad on Tuesday for Bombay, where I am expected to pass four days.
('51', 129, 3, 18, 219446) My address in Bombay is Laburnum Road.
('51', 129, 5, 19, 219485) Your faithful friend,
('51', 129, 6, 20, 219507) From a photostat : C.W. 9332. Courtesy : India Office Library

('51', 130, 1, 2, 219655) 192. LETTER TO PRABHAVATI
('51', 130, 2, 3, 219681) February 15, 1931
('51', 130, 3, 4, 219699) PRABHAVATI, I got your letter.
('51', 130, 3, 5, 219730) I don’t require any more details about your health now.
('51', 130, 3, 6, 219786) If you give up all worries, your health will improve very rapidly.
('51', 130, 3, 7, 219853) Let there be no weight on your mind.
('51', 130, 3, 8, 219890) It is I who have to worry for you; why, then, do you worry?
('51', 130, 3, 9, 219950) As you give up worrying, the body will become free from tensions and the fainting fits will gradually disappear.
('51', 130, 3, 10, 220063) For your headaches, you should bandage your head with a mud pack be fore going to bed, as I used to do.
('51', 130, 3, 11, 220167) Twice or thrice every day, you should lie down flat on a bed, and rest.
('51', 130, 3, 12, 220239) Even if you don’t get sleep, you should lie down.
('51', 130, 3, 13, 220289) And see that you don’t suffer from constipation.
('51', 130, 3, 14, 220338) Your diet is all right.
('51', 130, 3, 15, 220362) I certainly cannot wish that you should eat beyond your appetite.
('51', 130, 3, 16, 220428) Father came and stayed here for four days.
('51', 130, 3, 17, 220471) On the whole, I found his health good just now.
('51', 130, 3, 18, 220519) Rajendrababu was of course there, and with them was Anugrahababu.
('51', 130, 3, 19, 220585) I cannot say when I shall be able to go to Bombay.
('51', 130, 3, 20, 220636) Come and see me wherever I settle down for a few days.

('51', 131, 0, 1, 221510) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 131, 1, 2, 221552) 194. SPEECH ON MOTILAL DAY 1, ALLAHABAD February 15, 1931
('51', 131, 2, 3, 221610) At 3 p.m.
('51', 131, 2, 4, 221620) Mr. Gandhi arrived at the meeting with, among others, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and took his seat on the rostrum .
('51', 131, 3, 5, 221733) After the .
('51', 131, 3, 6, 221745) flag song by a few ladies, Mr. Purushottam Das Tandon requested, at the suggestion of Mahatma Gandhi, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad to preside at the meeting.
('51', 131, 4, 7, 221898) Mr. Gandhi, who sat on the rostrum spinning on the takli, then addressed the audience.
('51', 131, 4, 8, 221985) It was a belief, he said, entertained in all religions that a person’s soul never dies and the shraddha ceremony was performed with a view to giving peace to the deceased soul.
('51', 131, 4, 9, 222162) A person generally does not leave his body without a single desire.
('51', 131, 4, 10, 222230) Some desire is always left in him unfulfilled.
('51', 131, 4, 11, 222277) Pandit Motilal Nehru, said Mr. Gandhi, died with a longing for swaraj.
('51', 131, 4, 12, 222348) It was his constant wish that the entire country should be free and the reins of her government should be in the hands of her own representatives, and that justice should be done to the poorest in this land, be they Hindus, Moslems, Christians, Parsis, or Sikhs.
('51', 131, 4, 13, 222611) It, therefore, struck him, said Mr.Gandhi, that some such things should be done that day as would real shraddha for giving peace to the soul of Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('51', 131, 4, 14, 222777) He, therefore, issued an appeal for the celebration of the memorial day.
('51', 131, 5, 15, 222850) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said that a bath in the Ganges was no shraddha.
('51', 131, 6, 16, 222921) certainly cleansed the body but purification of the inner selves could only be done by inward act.
('51', 131, 6, 17, 223020) Such act was the pledge which they had just then taken.
('51', 131, 6, 18, 223076) But it was useless if they did not act up to it.
('51', 131, 6, 19, 223125) They had to do something that would hasten the advent of swaraj and that they knew would give peace to the soul of Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('51', 131, 6, 20, 223262) He knew of thousands of people giving their lives simply because of their anxiety not to break their pledges.
('51', 131, 6, 21, 223372) Mr. Gandhi hoped that the people who had taken the vow to work for the attainment of complete swaraj would abide by their pledges.
('51', 131, 7, 22, 223503) In the course of his observations Mr. Gandhi also appealed to the people to continue their efforts for bringing about Hindu Muslim unity of which he was reminded by the recent disturbances in sacred Kashi.
('51', 131, 7, 23, 223709) He added that the attainment of Hindu Muslim unity was also the mission of Pandit Motilal Nehru’s life and it was Mr. Gandhi’s conviction that if the people combined to bring about that unity and attained it, other work for the attainment of swaraj would become very easy.
('51', 131, 7, 24, 223982) He had learned, said Mr. Gandhi, that Hindus and Muslims in Kashi were cutting each other’s
('51', 131, 8, 25, 224074) 1 The tenth day shraddha ceremony of Motilal Nehru; vide also “Statement to the press”, 9 2 1931. 2 Then Purushottam Das Tandon, President of the provincial Congress Committee, moved the resolution embodying the vow prescribed by Gandhiji.
('51', 131, 8, 26, 224314) The pledge was repeated word for word by the audience.
('51', 132, 0, 1, 224369) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 133
('51', 132, 1, 2, 224414) throats.
('51', 132, 1, 3, 224423) He did not want swaraj at the expense of a single party.
('51', 132, 1, 4, 224480) Neither he nor Pandit Motilal Nehru cared for swaraj exclusively for Hindus or Muslims.
('51', 132, 1, 5, 224568) Swaraj under which Hindus and Muslims and others could live together was the aim of his life.
('51', 132, 1, 6, 224662) It was, therefore, a matter for great shame if either community committed ex cesses against the other.
('51', 132, 1, 7, 224765) It would be appropriate if everyone in the audience took the pledge to promote communal unity.
('51', 132, 2, 8, 224860) He added that in the course of the struggle they had lost Lokamanya Tilak, Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan, Lala Lajpat Rai and Deshbandhu Das; and now Pandit Motilal Nehru was gone.
('51', 132, 2, 9, 225034) It was time, therefore, that they did their duty and attained the good for which their leaders had died.
('51', 132, 2, 10, 225139) The Pioneer, 18 2 1931

('51', 133, 5, 6, 226419) 198. LETTER TO GUNAVATI KUNWAR MAHARAJ SINGH
('51', 133, 6, 7, 226464) ALLAHABAD, February 16, 1931
('51', 133, 7, 8, 226493) DEAR SISTER, Under the impulse of pure affection and contrary to my wont, I ate your bread without inquiring how it was prepared.
('51', 133, 7, 9, 226623) In order to be able to copy it, I asked for the recipe.
('51', 133, 7, 10, 226679) Now that I know it I must tell you that it is forbidden food for me.
('51', 133, 7, 11, 226748) I do not eat eggs nor cow’s or buffalo’s milk and at present no milk at all.
('51', 133, 7, 12, 226825) Nor do I take sugar as a rule.
('51', 133, 7, 13, 226856) I may not therefore take the loaf you have so kindly sent again.
('51', 133, 7, 14, 226921) Let this discovery cause you no distress.
('51', 133, 7, 15, 226963) That the loaf was forbidden food for me causes me none.
('51', 133, 7, 16, 227019) The remembrance I have of your affection for me, I shall treasure.
('51', 133, 7, 17, 227086) If I have given you the information, I have done so to tell you why I may not eat the second loaf and also to appear before you as I am with my limitations.
('51', 133, 8, 18, 227243) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('51', 138, 5, 6, 234828) 206. SPEECH AT DELHI February 17, 1931
('51', 138, 6, 7, 234867) At about 9 a.m., as Mahatmaji came out into the park, he was received with vociferous cheers by the crowd.
('51', 138, 7, 8, 234974) Addressing the people gathered there, Mahatma Gandhi said he was sorry that he saw no takli in Delhi, everywhere else he had seen taklis being plied by men and
('51', 138, 9, 9, 235134) Continuing, he said, because he was going to see the Viceroy today, it did not mean that they should go to sleep.

('51', 138, 10, 12, 235365) The Hindustan Times, 19 2 1931
('51', 138, 11, 13, 235396) 207. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY (VICEROY’S VERSION) February 17, 1931
('51', 138, 12, 14, 235462) There was no one present except Gandhi and myself.
('51', 138, 12, 15, 235513) We began with general talk, in the course of which I dwelt upon the change in British opinion, which I hoped India would not make of no avail.
('51', 138, 13, 16, 235656) 1.Future procedure.
('51', 138, 13, 17, 235676) I sketched the ideas as they at present stand.
('51', 138, 14, 18, 235723) 2.Scope of further discussions.
('51', 138, 14, 19, 235755) I said there were three main principles in the Conference structure : Federation; Indian responsibility; reservations and safeguards.
('51', 138, 14, 20, 235889) These were fundamental, but the detailed application of these principles was open to further examination and discussion.
('51', 138, 14, 21, 236010) It would be as unprofitable for his friends to try to pull out the linchpins of federation and safeguards as it would be, say, for my Conservative friends to go back on the principle of responsibility.
('51', 138, 15, 22, 236212) 3.He said that Congress could not give an undertaking in no circumstances to resume civil disobedience.
('51', 138, 15, 23, 236316) I said that I could not bind them to any such pledge; but that the whole point was whether he and his friends had in mind a temporary and grudging truce or a genuine attempt to make a permanent peace.
('51', 138, 15, 24, 236517) He said : “Certainly the latter”, but that he only wished to guard himself against imputations of bad faith if, as he trusted would not be, they found themselves wholly mistaken in the spirit of
('51', 139, 0, 1, 236712) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 139, 1, 2, 236754) the later discussions.
('51', 139, 2, 3, 236777) 4.He asked about the right of raising “dissolution of partnership”.
('51', 139, 2, 4, 236845) I said that I regarded the question as academic, but presumed he could discuss it if he so desired.
('51', 139, 2, 5, 236945) But I added that it would have a very damaging effect on British opinion if he made any public statement to this effect.
('51', 139, 2, 6, 237066) He agreed, and said that he desired to be able to say that he was not precluded, if he should so desire, from raising the question, and to protect himself from the charge that he had taken His Majesty’s Government unawares if he did.
('51', 139, 3, 7, 237300) 5.He then referred to the question of debts.
('51', 139, 3, 8, 237345) I said there could be no discussion on repudiation (which he said was not intended), but that if it was a question of the examination of particular apportionment of liability between Great Britain and India, or India and Burma (in the event of separation), I did not suppose that objection would be taken on principle, however unprofitable such discussions might seem to me likely to be.
('51', 139, 4, 9, 237733) 6.He raised the question of the States’ subject.
('51', 139, 4, 10, 237782) I said that I presumed he could raise the matter in discussion, but he would be up against the Princes.
('51', 139, 4, 11, 237886) He acknowledged this and left me with the impression that Congress felt they had to raise the question, but did not attach undue importance to it.
('51', 139, 5, 12, 238033) 7.Proportion of representation in the later Conference discussions.
('51', 139, 5, 13, 238101) He did not anticipate much difficulty.
('51', 139, 5, 14, 238140) He attached no importance to proportions, provided they could get enough to have their various elements represented and to enable them to pull their due weight on Committees, etc.
('51', 139, 5, 15, 238320) If necessary, other sections of opinion could be increased too.
('51', 139, 5, 16, 238384) He said he thought it might be necessary to ask the Working Committee for a few more key men.
('51', 139, 5, 17, 238478) I told him that I had contemplated a Congress representation of about 12, and 15 or 20 were larger figures than I could think necessary.
('51', 139, 5, 18, 238615) He agreed to keep the numbers as low as he could; and said he would consider a suggestion I made about working on the plan of “substitute” delegates, to bring others in without swelling the official numbers.
('51', 139, 6, 19, 238823) 8.We then got on the practical points, if, as he said civil disobedience was suspended.
('51', 139, 6, 20, 238911) I at once took him upon the word ‘suspended’ and said that what I had in mind was effective abandonment.
('51', 139, 6, 21, 239016) He said he did not attach importance to the word, but wished to protect the position defined in paragraph 3 above.
('51', 139, 7, 22, 239131) Practical points were :
('51', 139, 8, 23, 239155) (1) Release of satyagrahis, including some sentenced under martial law in Sholapur.
('51', 139, 8, 24, 239239) I said that my distinction of principle was violence and inciters to violence on the one side, about whom I could do nothing, and non violent satyagrahis on the other.
('51', 139, 9, 25, 239407) (2) Meerut prisoners.
('51', 139, 9, 26, 239429) He argued for their discharge, but not, as I under stood, as a condition.
('51', 139, 9, 27, 239503) I said that they had nothing to do with civil disobedience, but I was as much disturbed as he was at the protracted proceedings, and would examine the case with a view to seeing whether
('51', 140, 0, 1, 239689) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 141
('51', 140, 1, 2, 239734) anything could be done to accelerate the conclusion of the trial.
('51', 140, 1, 3, 239800) More than that I could not say, as I could recognize no association between Communists and non violent satyagrahis.
('51', 140, 2, 4, 239916) (3) He raised the question of the Bengal detenus, not, as I understood, as a condition, but in order to inform me that a great many people had been locked up who in no way deserved it.
('51', 140, 2, 5, 240101) I omitted to make the obvious point that each case was submitted to two Judges, but told him that, if he wished to submit any evidence of a case in which the police had dropped on the wrong man, I would pass it on to the Governor of Bengal who would look into it personally.
('51', 140, 2, 6, 240376) He did not seem to attach great importance to the question.
('51', 140, 3, 7, 240436) (4) Land and property.
('51', 140, 3, 8, 240459) I said that third parties who had bought could not be disturbed.
('51', 140, 3, 9, 240524) Any adjustment that was requisite for settlement would have to be through unofficial agency.
('51', 140, 3, 10, 240617) He brought forward a good many technical points, on which I said little beyond adher ing to the main principle that Government could be generous with what was still in its own possession, but not with what third parties had acquired.
('51', 140, 3, 11, 240851) He promised to submit a note.
('51', 140, 4, 12, 240881) (5) Remission of fines.
('51', 140, 4, 13, 240905) Those that were uncollected I said could probably be remitted.
('51', 140, 4, 14, 240968) But I could not press local Governments to entertain the suggestion of restoring fines already collected.
('51', 140, 4, 15, 241074) This was a matter on which local Governments would exercise their own discretion.
('51', 140, 4, 16, 241156) He did not press this very hard.
('51', 140, 5, 17, 241189) (6) Restoration of presses and securities.
('51', 140, 5, 18, 241232) I said the same principle must apply, i.e., what was in Government’s possession could be restored, but securities that had been forefeited fell into same category as fines paid.
('51', 140, 6, 19, 241410) (7) Reinstatement of officials resigned or dismissed.
('51', 140, 6, 20, 241464) I said that I could not press any local Government to reinstate any officials whose places had been filled; and that the utmost I could do would be to invite local Governments to examine all cases on their merits with the object of acting as generously as circumstances permitted towards those who had resigned, whether out of pressure or because they had been swept off their feet by the civil disobedience movement.
('51', 140, 6, 21, 241882) Dismissals stood in a somewhat different category, and I anticipated Governments would feel greater difficulty about this class of case inasmuch as officials had presumably not been dismissed without cause; but I was ready to invite local Governments to examine these cases also on their merits.
('51', 140, 7, 22, 242178) (8) Repressive ordinances.
('51', 140, 7, 23, 242205) I said these could go, except the Burma Terro 
('51', 141, 0, 1, 242252) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 141, 1, 2, 242294) rist Ordinance, adding that, if the Press reverted to encouragement of violence, it would be necessary for Government to take action against it.
('51', 141, 2, 3, 242439) (9) Punitive Police, he asked, should be withdrawn.
('51', 141, 2, 4, 242491) I said it was a new point to me, but would if necessary invite local Governments to consider it.
('51', 141, 3, 5, 242588) 9.Enquiries into police excesses.
('51', 141, 3, 6, 242622) He dropped the idea of a general enquiry, but pressed very hard for special enquiries, if necessary in camera.
('51', 141, 3, 7, 242733) I put the counter 
('51', 141, 4, 8, 242752) arguments, and said that I could not go further than promise investigation by local Governments and if desired by myself of specific complaints.
('51', 141, 4, 9, 242897) This he said was not much, as the truth could only be ascertained by cross examination of evidence on both sides.
('51', 141, 4, 10, 243011) I told him that there was so much on the other side that I did not think he was entitled to press for enquiries that could only have the purpose of placing the police in a position of defendants, and to this I was not able to agree.
('51', 141, 4, 11, 243244) I would see any matter he chose to submit and he must trust to my assurance that local Governments would examine it fairly.
('51', 141, 4, 12, 243368) I had also no objection to publicly exonerating those who had brought charges from any imputation of bad faith.
('51', 141, 4, 13, 243480) He was not satisfied with this.
('51', 141, 5, 14, 243512) 10. He read over to me other points on which he proposes to speak tomorrow.
('51', 141, 5, 15, 243588) Salt; Peaceful picketing and there may have been something else.
('51', 141, 6, 16, 243653) 11. I told him that I thought it was of great importance, if we were to succeed in our peace efforts, that the temperature should be lowered, and asked him to get Bombay to go slow in picketing, etc.
('51', 141, 6, 17, 243853) He promised to do so.
('51', 141, 7, 18, 243875) 12. We agreed to meet again alone tomorrow with possibly a larger meeting with others in to follow.
('51', 141, 8, 19, 243975) 13. Although I made the point in Paragraphs 3 and 8 that I drew a clear distinction between action by Congress on the basis of a temporary truce with the intention of resuming the campaign, and a genuine desire to co operate in constructive work, it is important to leave him in no doubt when we meet again (though I don’t think there is any) that the various items of action by Government are dependent on effective abandonment of the movement.

('51', 142, 1, 2, 244570) 208. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY (GANDHIJI’S REPORT)
('51', 142, 2, 3, 244618) [February 17, 1931] 1
('51', 142, 3, 4, 244640) The Viceroy had impressed me very well.
('51', 142, 3, 5, 244680) He had impressed me as much as Lord Reading had done, except that Lord Reading was clever and he took undue advantage of my discussions with him.
('51', 142, 3, 6, 244826) Lord Irwin talked to me in a friendly way and frankly admitted that it was his mistake that we had not met so far.
('51', 142, 3, 7, 244941) The second thing he admitted was that the British public had been aroused the most by my move ment.
('51', 142, 3, 8, 245041) This attitude of his shows that he wants to make peace.
('51', 142, 3, 9, 245097) He desires peace because he has been touched by the struggle.
('51', 142, 3, 10, 245159) He is wondering how long he can allow the struggle to continue and feels that now he would be obliged to rely on the gun alone.
('51', 142, 3, 11, 245287) I took out the resolution at the very outset.
('51', 142, 4, 12, 245333) MAHADEV DESAI.
('51', 142, 4, 13, 245348) Was there no talk about your letter ?
('51', 142, 5, 14, 245386) GANDHIJI.
('51', 142, 5, 15, 245396) No, there was no specific mention of that but I felt that he liked the letter.
('51', 142, 5, 16, 245475) I certainly told him that I was ready for a settlement and in the mean time Shuaib had come and asked me whether I would not write a letter in this manner, that I had placed that matter before the Working Committee and they approved of it, and so I had written.
('51', 142, 5, 17, 245737) I went on reading the resolution.
('51', 142, 5, 18, 245771) About the initial portion regarding the constitution, he said: “There is no diffi culty about discussing anything, but I can’t say how much you will gain out of it.
('51', 142, 5, 19, 245936) But you can certainly open the discussion.” I did not make any attempt to know what his views were.
('51', 142, 5, 20, 246036) But he said if we wanted to discuss the clause regarding secession we should do that only in the Conference.
('51', 142, 5, 21, 246145) But no one was going to listen to it and if I pressed the point too much, persons like him who wanted to help me would be put in an awkward position.
('51', 142, 5, 22, 246295) Then immediately he came to the truce terms.
('51', 142, 5, 23, 246340) We discussed which of the conditions could be dropped.
('51', 142, 5, 24, 246395) And the discussion on the inquiry itself took up half the time.
('51', 142, 5, 25, 246459) The greatest difficulty is about the issue of the inquiry.
('51', 142, 5, 26, 246518) He is not against it but he said that it made his position very delicate.“Will you be satisfied if I conduct the inquiry?” Thus by asking this question he had given up his case.
('51', 142, 6, 27, 246696) 1 In the source the report by Gandhiji of the interview is given under February 18, 1931.
('51', 143, 0, 1, 246786) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 143, 1, 2, 246828) asked him: “How will you conduct the inquiry?
('51', 143, 1, 3, 246874) Have you ever heard of a person having dis pensed justice without hearing both the sides?
('51', 143, 1, 4, 246964) You have our unsifted account and a similar account given by the police.
('51', 143, 1, 5, 247037) What will you make out of it?” He agreed that nothing could be achieved.
('51', 143, 1, 6, 247110) “The position today is that you have declared us liars before the whole world.
('51', 143, 1, 7, 247189) How will it behove you to negotiate with liars like us?
('51', 143, 1, 8, 247245) Have a look at the whole communique.
('51', 143, 1, 9, 247282) Should we swallow the allegations that everything we said was fabricated?” He had no reply to give to all this (At this point Ansari came, so some things had to be repeated.) One thing was clear from his talk that those people are also tired just as some of us are.
('51', 143, 1, 10, 247548) “I shall certa inly send a cable that you want the clause regarding secession to be inclu ded but the position of people like me who want to help you will become very awkward.” I can understand that.
('51', 143, 1, 11, 247748) He apologized about the matter of the public debt.
('51', 143, 1, 12, 247799) He said, “So far I thought you wanted repudiation of the debts, but you have certainly every right to demand distribution of the war expenses.
('51', 143, 1, 13, 247942) We shall see how we can examine the question of fair distribution.
('51', 143, 1, 14, 248009) I also desire the same thing as you do regarding the Native States, but you have to persuade the States themselves.
('51', 143, 1, 15, 248125) We shall not prevent you from doing so.
('51', 143, 1, 16, 248165) I wish to give you as much help as I can.” He admits that all our demands are just.
('51', 143, 1, 17, 248249) He did not say that even one of them was unjust but only put forward his diffi culties.
('51', 143, 1, 18, 248337) At the very beginning I explained to him whatever I had to say about our conditions.
('51', 143, 1, 19, 248422) He said it would be difficult to release the Meerut prisoners and he wondered how much pressure he could bring to bear upon the Governor of Bengal regarding the release of detenus there.
('51', 143, 1, 20, 248609) Moreover, all these things might be done but he asked, “How can we do them if you want to make that a condition prece dent?
('51', 143, 1, 21, 248733) We have collected fines from many; how can we refund them all?
('51', 143, 1, 22, 248796) How can we pay compensation for property burnt down or destroyed?
('51', 143, 1, 23, 248862) The proceeds of property sold, however, can be refunded.” I said : “Can you say this even in those cases where the market value has not been taken into acount and you have got rupees ten for a property worth rupees one thousand?
('51', 143, 1, 24, 249091) Is there equity in this?” He saw the point and asked us to give him a list of the losses incurred.
('51', 143, 1, 25, 249190) He saw the point regarding taxes also.
('51', 143, 1, 26, 249229) “How can you exact taxes from people who have been ruined?” About the fairness of taxation, I told him the story of Mah mood.
('51', 143, 1, 27, 249355) Once a woman went to him to seek justice.
('51', 143, 1, 28, 249397) Mahmood told her
('51', 144, 0, 1, 249414) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 145
('51', 144, 1, 2, 249459) : “You live so far away that I cannot carry justice there.” She said : “Stop ruling over us.” Mahmood said, “Yes, that region should be excluded from the empire.” Irwin laughed and said that justice should be done.
('51', 144, 1, 3, 249674) (While speaking of my keenness for peace, I casually told him : “I wrote to you a letter even from Yeravda but you did not reply to it.
('51', 144, 1, 4, 249810) I do not complain but I want to show you how keen I am on a settlement.”) He asked me, “How can we throw the police to the wolves?” I said, “We do not want that.
('51', 144, 1, 5, 249972) We want the enquiry only to establish whether the police have committed any atrocities.” The discussion about the inquiry alone took half the time.
('51', 144, 1, 6, 250120) That means they consider the condition to be very difficult.
('51', 144, 1, 7, 250181) Only for that reason will it be an acid test for us.
('51', 144, 1, 8, 250234) The Governor of Bombay was sitting outside.
('51', 144, 1, 9, 250278) I was introduced to him.
('51', 144, 1, 10, 250303) I could not talk to him because I was in a hurry for my meal and the A.D.C. came and told me that my car had arrived.
('51', 144, 1, 11, 250421) The Viceroy had also asked me whether it would do if the Governor conducted an independent enquiry.
('51', 144, 1, 12, 250521) I asked him “In what way is the Governor in a better position than you to do so?
('51', 144, 1, 13, 250602) Why should we submit to the excesses of the police?
('51', 144, 1, 14, 250654) Why shouldn’t they, over whom we are going to rule one day, consider themselves our servants right from today itself ?” The gist of the whole talk is that he very much wants a settle ment and the other thing is that if we give up a single point of ours, our whole case will be ruined.
('51', 144, 1, 15, 250939) I on my part told the Viceroy that if he granted that the Congress was something to reckon with, he must accede to our reasonable demands.
('51', 144, 1, 16, 251078) The reference to Mirabehn came up in the beginning and in the end.
('51', 144, 1, 17, 251145) At the end, I said, “She must have cooked my meal and must be waiting for me.” In the beginning I had said, “How can I sever my connection with you?
('51', 144, 1, 18, 251294) I have so many English friends.
('51', 144, 1, 19, 251326) Take for ins tance Mirabehn.
('51', 144, 1, 20, 251355) I don’t know her family and her father and yet she has completely lost herself in me.
('51', 144, 1, 21, 251441) Andrews keeps sending me cables from Cape Town asking me to arrive at a settlement.
('51', 144, 1, 22, 251525) How can I give up this Andrews?
('51', 144, 1, 23, 251557) Horace Alexander also writes to me and he advises me not to arrive at a settlement.
('51', 144, 1, 24, 251641) Having written that he apologizes!
('51', 144, 1, 25, 251676) Is it possible for me to sever all these relations?
('51', 144, 1, 26, 251728) And yet if co operation is not possible, I shall have to do so.
('51', 145, 0, 1, 251792) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 145, 1, 2, 251834) “If both of us desire not to quarrel, we shall not quarrel.
('51', 145, 1, 3, 251894) I have come with a determination not to fight as far as possible.” I had assured him that “I do not want to tell you anything except the truth.
('51', 145, 1, 4, 252038) I do not want to conceal anything from you, I do not want to have a single mental reservation.
('51', 145, 1, 5, 252133) Hence you can tell me whatever you wish to.
('51', 145, 1, 6, 252177) You can say whatver you have heard about my associates and tell me whatever you want, can question me about them.” Talking about the release of the Meerut prisoners, he expressed his difficulty but he described the sentence passed on the Sholapur Martial Law prisoners as preposterous.
