('51', 146, 1, 2, 253143) 210. MESSAGE TO VISITORS
('51', 146, 2, 3, 253168) DELHI, February 18, 1931
('51', 146, 3, 4, 253193) Mahatmaji came out 1 at 1.40 p.m.
('51', 146, 3, 5, 253227) and was cheered by hundreds of visitors, including a large number of ladies, who were anxious to have his darshan.
('51', 146, 4, 6, 253342) Mahatmaji put two questions to the crowd assembled.
('51', 146, 4, 7, 253394) He first asked : How many of you are dressed in khaddar?
('51', 146, 5, 8, 253451) Everybody raised his hand.
('51', 146, 5, 9, 253478) Then Mahatmaji asked : I want only those to raise hands who are dressed in hand spun and hand made khaddar.
('51', 146, 6, 10, 253586) Nearly thirty per cent of the assembled raised their hands.
('51', 146, 6, 11, 253646) Then he asked them
('51', 146, 7, 12, 253665) how many were dressed in foreign clothes.
('51', 146, 7, 13, 253707) Only three hands were raised.
('51', 146, 7, 14, 253737) He told
('51', 146, 8, 15, 253745) them : Use khaddar.
('51', 146, 8, 16, 253765) This is my message.
('51', 146, 8, 17, 253785) Now go home, all of you.
('51', 146, 9, 18, 253810) Then with a smile he hurried to his car which drove him to the Viceregal Lodge.
('51', 146, 9, 19, 253890) The crowd raised shouts of “Mahatma Gandhi ki Jai” and melted away.
('51', 146, 9, 20, 253958) The Hindustan Times, 20 2 1931
('51', 146, 10, 21, 253989) 211. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY (VICEROY’S VERSION) February 18, 1931
('51', 146, 11, 22, 254055) I had a further talk with Mr. Gandhi this afternoon.
('51', 146, 11, 23, 254108) He began by telling me that he had, as requested by me yesterday, sent a telegram 2 to Bombay saying that he had been informed that picketing was taking a serious form and was in danger of leading to violence, and that that kind of thing must be stopped.
('51', 146, 11, 24, 254363) He promised to let me know the result.
('51', 146, 12, 25, 254402) He then proceeded to develop the points left over from yesterday beginning with :
('51', 146, 13, 26, 254484) (1) Punitive Police.
('51', 146, 13, 27, 254505) I told him that, as I had said yesterday, it was a new point to me and that I imagined the action of local Governments would be dictated by the circumstances of each case.
('51', 146, 13, 28, 254677) I could imagine cases in which local Governments might be willing to withdraw them as also others in which such withdrawal would have to be postponed.
('51', 146, 13, 29, 254828) We left it at the point that I said in the event of a settlement being
('51', 146, 14, 30, 254899) 1 Of Dr. Ansari’s house 2 Vide “Telegram to Perin Captain”, 17 2 1931.
('51', 147, 0, 1, 254970) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 147, 1, 2, 255012) reached I would draw local Governments’ attention to the matter.
('51', 147, 2, 3, 255077) (2) He developed an argument of which this was the gist.
('51', 147, 2, 4, 255134) In districts where
('51', 147, 3, 5, 255153) resort has been had to coercive processes for collection of taxes due, such further
('51', 147, 4, 6, 255237) collection shall be suspended pending examination of cases by an officer through an
('51', 147, 5, 7, 255321) enquiry, in which the people will be afforded an opportunity of stating their case.
('51', 147, 6, 8, 255405) point was that many of the coercive processes have been extra legal, and have
('51', 147, 7, 9, 255483) imposed far greater material damage on the people than the value of the tax due to be
('51', 147, 8, 10, 255569) collected.
('51', 147, 8, 11, 255580) He was only asking for the right of proving such a case as would lead
('51', 147, 9, 12, 255650) Government to redress real injustice.
('51', 147, 10, 13, 255688) I said that without fuller knowledge of the facts and the issues involved I could express no opinion beyond telling him that it seemed the kind of thing in which serious difficulty would be likely to arise.
('51', 147, 10, 14, 255895) I told him that in my view, as in the case we were discussing yesterday of enquiries into police excesses, I regarded the whole state in which we now found ourselves as that of something very like a state of war.
('51', 147, 10, 15, 256108) Under such conditions no doubt great hardship was unavoidable, but it had by no means been confined to one side.
('51', 147, 10, 16, 256221) His presentment of the case seemed to me to suggest that we were dealing with unjustifiable departures from a state of affairs which had in other respects been normal, and appeared to rest on the assumption that Government was in the dock and under the necessity of justifying its action to people who had themselves been wholly free from blame.
('51', 147, 10, 17, 256567) He would not expect me to accept that kind of interpretation of the present position.
('51', 147, 11, 18, 256653) He answered this by reverting to his original arugment that he was pleading for no more than redress of what he believed he could show to be a manifest excess of administrative action leading to real injustice.
('51', 147, 12, 19, 256864) (3) Salt.
('51', 147, 12, 20, 256874) Here he developed the romantic side of the salt campaign, dwelling much on the inhumanity of depriving families who had natural opportunities of doing so, of taking advantage of them to manufacture salt.
('51', 147, 12, 21, 257078) (I am not sure whether it confined to salt for their own use or not.) What he desired was that Government should either alter the law or acquiesce in its breach, by way of not prohibiting such private action.
('51', 147, 12, 22, 257287) He instanced the Sarda Act and the Age of Consent Act as examples of Government looking the other way in matters of administration.
('51', 147, 13, 23, 257419) I told him that there was a wide distinction in my view between Government administering a particular law with discretion, through instructions communicated to its own officers, and Government advertising to the world that it was prepared to condone such breaches.
('51', 147, 13, 24, 257684) The latter really amounted to an invitation to all and sundry to commit them.
('51', 147, 13, 25, 257762) If, as he said, such informal breaches of the Salt Law had been in the habit of taking place before, I had no reason to suppose that Government would wish to administer the Salt Law any more or any less strictly than had been the case hitherto.
('51', 148, 0, 1, 258007) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 149
('51', 148, 1, 2, 258052) He said that he was not asking for any public declaration, but for a private assurance that Government would not interfere with private breaches of the law; he had not in mind raids on salt depots or anything on that scale.
('51', 148, 2, 3, 258276) I told him that I felt considerable difficulty about his propositon having regard to the fact that the circumstances surrounding private breaches of the law had greatly altered since his salt campaign.
('51', 148, 3, 4, 258478) (4) Peaceful picketing.
('51', 148, 3, 5, 258502) He asked me whether I took any objection to its continuance.
('51', 148, 3, 6, 258563) I told him that peaceful picketing appeared to me a misnomer.
('51', 148, 3, 7, 258625) I had a long list of cases on my table showing the violent results that had flowed from so called peaceful picketing, and I found it impossible to believe that peaceful picketing could fail to produce similar results in future.
('51', 148, 3, 8, 258853) I quoted Benares, Amritsar, etc.
('51', 148, 3, 9, 258886) I further said that I could not tolerate interference with legitimate trade, as evinced by Congress intimidation in the matter by way of sealing foreign cloth, mock funerals and all the rest.
('51', 148, 3, 10, 259078) Lastly, I said that picketing as a political weapon was objectionable and its continuance was quite incompatible with Congress coming into Conference discussions.
('51', 148, 3, 11, 259241) He was really setting about his principal purposes of swadeshi and temperance in the wrong way by pursuing a policy at once negative and belligerent; why could he not apply himself to the positive and pacific programme of preaching swadeshi and temperance without interference with personal liberty?
('51', 148, 4, 12, 259541) To all this he said he had no wish to do more than peacefully persuade; he only attached importance to it as a social and economic business, not pri marily political.
('51', 148, 4, 13, 259708) He and the Congress would prohibit violence, mock funerals
('51', 148, 5, 14, 259767) and all such forms of pressure; but he could not see why people might not stand near a grog shop in the endeavour to reform the drunkard; if violence or molestation occurred, it could be dealt with under the ordinary law I told him that experience was against him in this matter, and that I feared it would not be easily possible for him to get the subtle distinction present to his own mind observed in practical action by many different people in different parts of the country.
('51', 148, 6, 15, 260248) 2.I then took up a few general matters.
('51', 148, 6, 16, 260288) First of all I explained to him that in everything I had said I was only speaking personally for myself, and that on many matters it would be necessary to consult local Governments or the Secretary of State, and on all matters it would be necessary for me to consult my own council.
('51', 148, 6, 17, 260571) This he recognized.
('51', 148, 6, 18, 260591) I then told him that I had heard of the probability of himself and Vallabhbhai Patel visiting Gujarat.
('51', 148, 6, 19, 260694) I could have little doubt that, if they went there, they would stimulate the civil disobedience movement, in which the Government of Bombay could evidently not acquiesce.
('51', 148, 6, 20, 260865) I asked him therefore to keep himself and Vallabhbhai away for the present at all events.
('51', 148, 6, 21, 260955) He told me that he had just summoned Vallabhbhai to come here and went on to say that, if our negotiations succeeded, no difficulty would arise; if they failed, I understood him to say that he and his friends
('51', 149, 0, 1, 261164) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 149, 1, 2, 261206) had decided, or might decide, to offer themselves for re arrest.
('51', 149, 1, 3, 261271) It would then be for Government to do what they wished, but he would certainly when his work was finished here wish to go to Gujarat and could not do otherwise.
('51', 149, 2, 4, 261432) 3.I finally told him that everything I had said about possibilities of reciprocal
('51', 149, 3, 5, 261514) action by Government was dependent upon the effective abandonment of the civil
('51', 149, 4, 6, 261593) disobedience campaign.
('51', 149, 4, 7, 261616) He asked me what this meant; it would be impossible for him
('51', 149, 5, 8, 261676) to agree to a period of ten days or fifteen days before reciprocal action was taken by
('51', 149, 6, 9, 261763) Government.
('51', 149, 6, 10, 261775) I said I had not that in mind; what I was rather concerned with was that
('51', 149, 7, 11, 261848) before Government [took] reciprocal action they should be satisfied that the Working
('51', 149, 8, 12, 261933) Committee’s instructions had in fact reached local organizations and that they were
('51', 149, 9, 13, 262017) being loyally carried out.
('51', 149, 9, 14, 262044) There was no question of impugning the trustworthiness of
('51', 149, 10, 15, 262102) the Working Committee, who might reach an agreement with Government here; on
('51', 149, 11, 16, 262179) the other hand, it was not unreasonable that Government should be satisfied that the
('51', 149, 12, 17, 262264) agreement honourably reached by the Working Committee was in fact being
('51', 149, 13, 18, 262336) honourably given effect to by the local organizations.
('51', 149, 14, 19, 262391) He appeared to accept this.
('51', 149, 15, 20, 262419) 4.I then recurred to the question we had discussed yesterday as to the contingent resumption by Congress of civil disobedience.
('51', 149, 15, 21, 262547) I said that it would be an impossible position for me to recommend to His Majesty’s Government to take all the steps we had been discussing if they were at any moment in the course of subsequent discussions liable to be told by Congress that the provisional conclu sions arrived at, at any stage, were unpalatable and they therefore broke up and went back to their campaign.
('51', 149, 15, 22, 262922) Could he give me any assurance on the point?
('51', 149, 16, 23, 262967) He said that, as he had explained yesterday and as I had accepted, Congress could not pledge themselves, either for all time or in this particular matter, not again to have resort to civil disobedience; but if they went into the Conference he would be prepared to say that they went in meaning to strain every nerve to make it a success.
('51', 149, 16, 24, 263305) He did not however wish to conceal from me that, if, when the discussions had concluded, the scheme was still unsatisfactory to them, they must reserve their liberty to return to civil disobedience.
('51', 149, 16, 25, 263504) He could not anticipate what their decision might be; circumstances might alter, they might desire to wait and see what happened in Parliament; but in no case would he anticipate recurrence to civil disobedience while the discussions were proceeding; and he hoped that it would never be necessary at all.
('51', 149, 17, 26, 263809) 5.I asked him whether he thought, in spite of the attitude I had felt necessary to adopt as regards salt, peaceful picketing, enquiries into excesses and other matters on which I had been unable to meet him, it would be desirable to have a somewhat more formal discussion?
('51', 149, 17, 27, 264082) In such event I should contemplate that we might have invited Sastri, Sapru, Jayakar, Shafi, Chhatari, possibly a non official European from the Assembly, another non official Moslem, Malaviya, Ansari, Bikaner and Bhopal.
('51', 149, 17, 28, 264304) He appeared to welcome the idea rather warmly, saying that he thought Malaviya was
('51', 150, 0, 1, 264387) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 151
('51', 150, 1, 2, 264432) indispensable, but added that he might like to bring one or two of his own and instanced Jawaharlal, Vallabhbhai and Sen Gupta.
('51', 150, 1, 3, 264560) He might have liked, he added, to have had Subhas Bose, but he was at present in prison.
('51', 150, 1, 4, 264649) I said that in such case I should propose to reinforce myself by representatives of my Government.
('51', 150, 2, 5, 264748) I told him that I would consider this and let him know, if I could, tomorrow,
('51', 150, 3, 6, 264826) adding that I thought, if such further talks were held, a formal communique should be
('51', 150, 4, 7, 264912) issued after each meeting to avoid public misunderstanding.
('51', 150, 4, 8, 264972) He agreed and said that
('51', 150, 5, 9, 264996) he would hold himself at my disposal.
('51', 150, 6, 10, 265034) 6.The general impression I gathered was that, though there are a good many
('51', 150, 7, 11, 265109) snags still in the road, he is disposed to co operate.
('51', 150, 7, 12, 265164) The principal snags evidently
('51', 150, 8, 13, 265194) are the question of the scope of further discussions and of contingent resumption of
('51', 150, 9, 14, 265279) the campaign.
('51', 150, 9, 15, 265293) On the latter however I believed it to be impracticable to get any
('51', 150, 10, 16, 265360) greater measure of assurance than he was willing to give me in our final interview this
('51', 150, 11, 17, 265448) evening.
('51', 150, 12, 18, 265457) In conclusion and not connected with the above, he mentioned the case of
('51', 150, 13, 19, 265530) Bhagat Singh.
('51', 150, 13, 20, 265544) He did not plead for commutation, although he would, being
('51', 150, 14, 21, 265603) opposed to all taking of life, take that course himself.
('51', 150, 14, 22, 265660) He also thought it would
('51', 150, 15, 23, 265685) have an influence for peace.
('51', 150, 15, 24, 265714) But he did ask for postponement in present circums 
('51', 150, 16, 25, 265766) tances.
('51', 150, 16, 26, 265774) I contented myself with saying that, whatever might be the decision as to
('51', 150, 17, 27, 265848) exact dates, I could not think there was any case for commutation which might not be
('51', 150, 18, 28, 265933) made with equal force in the case of any other violent crime.
('51', 150, 18, 29, 265995) The Viceroy’s powers
('51', 150, 19, 30, 266016) of commutation were designed for use on well known grounds of clemency,
('51', 150, 20, 31, 266088) and I could not feel that they ought to be invoked on grounds that were admittedly
('51', 150, 21, 32, 266171) political.

('51', 151, 2, 3, 266392) DELHI, February 18, 1931
('51', 151, 3, 4, 266417) Mahatma Gandhi unlike yesterday had taken leave of the Viceroy inside the
('51', 151, 4, 5, 266491) room and went straight to his car.
('51', 151, 4, 6, 266526) He was met by the Associated Press correspondent

('51', 151, 7, 10, 266714) Will you consult the Working Committee before coming back ?

('51', 151, 8, 12, 266819) Replying to another question, he said humorously : You can say, it is all hanging up in the clouds.

('51', 151, 10, 15, 266989) 213. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY (GANDHIJI’S REPORT) February 18, 1931
('51', 151, 11, 16, 267055) Today we were with the Viceroy for slightly less time than yesterday, and so reached home at 5.30 p.m.
('51', 151, 11, 17, 267158) Today’s talk was more concentrated and the man was more cautious than yesterday.
('51', 151, 11, 18, 267239) It was a most strenuous fight today, but it left no unplea santness in the mouth at the end.
('51', 151, 11, 19, 267332) Once or twice we felt that the hope of a settlement was dwindling but thereafter did not feel like that.
('51', 151, 11, 20, 267437) Today the salt tax, suspension of collection of land revenue and picketing alone were discussed.
('51', 151, 11, 21, 267534) When I explained to him the whole position about salt, the Viceroy said : “You think any Government in the world can tolerate disobedience of its laws?”
('51', 151, 12, 22, 267687) GANDHIJI.
('51', 151, 12, 23, 267697) I may enunciate a counter proposition to it: No Government in the world can enforce all its laws.
('51', 151, 13, 24, 267795) I then cited the example of the Sarda Act and mentioned Act III of 1885 of South Africa and the Gold Law, and told him that the Government was supporting the demand for the protection of those who were guilty of their breach.
('51', 151, 13, 25, 268021) I talked about the Age of Consent Act and asked him why the Government tolerated the breach of all those laws.
('51', 151, 13, 26, 268132) “I know that you have issued a circular that no action should he taken under the Sarda Act.”
('51', 151, 14, 27, 268225) VICEROY.
('51', 151, 14, 28, 268234) That is a confidential circular.
('51', 152, 0, 1, 268267) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 153
('51', 152, 1, 2, 268312) G.I do not want you to issue a public circular.
('51', 152, 1, 3, 268360) We shall tell our people quietly that they can make and collect salt without any fear.
('51', 152, 2, 4, 268447) V.I am seized of your position.
('51', 152, 3, 5, 268479) He used these words repeatedly.
('51', 152, 3, 6, 268511) About the Salt Act, he even said that when we would have our own Government, we could repeal it.
('51', 152, 4, 7, 268608) G.How can I betray the thousands of people whom I advised to break this law?
('51', 152, 5, 8, 268685) About the land tax also, the Viceroy had administrative difficulties.
('51', 152, 6, 9, 268755) G.Our case is that the Government has taken more coercive steps than were necessary and the officers have exceeded the instructions given to them.
('51', 152, 6, 10, 268902) In such cases the tax ought not to be collected.
('51', 152, 7, 11, 268951) V.Who is to decide that?
('51', 152, 8, 12, 268976) G.You may appoint an officer for the purpose, but he should have our approval.
('51', 152, 8, 13, 269055) He should only inquire whether there have or have not been excesses as alleged by us.
('51', 152, 9, 14, 269141) The Viceroy opposed picketing strongly.
('51', 152, 9, 15, 269181) I explained to him that it had been going on all the time.
('51', 152, 9, 16, 269240) “It is being done for many years now and there is nothing against it in the Common Law.
('51', 152, 9, 17, 269328) You can take action under the Common Law if there is breach of peace or violence.”
('51', 152, 10, 18, 269411) V.But you have made picketing a political weapon.
('51', 152, 11, 19, 269461) G.It may have a political result, but essentially, it is an economic, social and moral weapon.
('51', 152, 11, 20, 269556) Even if Lancashire stops itstextile business, we would still have to declare boycott of foreign cloth and also continue picketing.
('51', 152, 11, 21, 269687) Even if you forgo the revenue from the sale of liquor, we would still have to take steps against those who drink.
('51', 152, 12, 22, 269801) In short, the Viceroy was convinced of the justice of all our demands, but he talked of administrative difficulties.
('51', 152, 12, 23, 269918) I reminded him : “There is no just grievance in law without a remedy.” After this he asked me many questions.
('51', 152, 13, 24, 270028) V.If you attend the Round Table Conference and the results are not to your satisfaction, must you resume civil disobedience?
('51', 152, 14, 25, 270153) G.I will have to unless we feel that we shall get something from the changes proposed.
('51', 152, 14, 26, 270240) Otherwise I shall have no choice but to resume the movement.
('51', 152, 15, 27, 270301) V.On further thought, I find this position dangerous for the Government.
('51', 152, 15, 28, 270374) How can we stultify ourselves like that?
('51', 152, 15, 29, 270415) In that case, would it not be better that you do not attend the Round Table Conference?
('51', 152, 16, 30, 270503) Then there was again some discussion about safeguards.
('51', 152, 16, 31, 270558) Regarding defence,
('51', 153, 0, 1, 270577) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 153, 1, 2, 270619) the Viceroy said : Suppose a committee of military experts proves to your satisfaction that India cannot defend herself without British troops, even then would you wish that that safegurd should be removed?
('51', 153, 2, 3, 270826) G.What do you mean by “proving to my satisfaction”?
('51', 153, 2, 4, 270878) I would invite German, American and other experts and confront your mili tary experts with them.
('51', 153, 2, 5, 270975) If, after their discussions, I feel that we must retain the British army for some time, I would definitely agree to do so.
('51', 153, 3, 6, 271098) The Viceroy found this whole discussion embarrassing.
('51', 153, 4, 7, 271152) V.Now I am fully seized of your position.

('51', 153, 9, 26, 272558) Then as I was going to his bathroom, he accompanied me and said : “Now tell me whether I did not do well in not arresting you in your Ashram?” I said : “How do we know it?
('51', 153, 9, 27, 272730) A crowd of thousands had assembled in the Ashram, and I heard that a special was waiting for me and that I would be arrested at 12 o’clock.
('51', 153, 9, 28, 272870) So I peacefully went to sleep.” At this, the Viceroy had a hearty laugh.
('51', 153, 9, 29, 272943) I continued: “Many friends had
('51', 153, 10, 30, 272974) 1 Sapru, Jayakar and Srinivasa Sastri
('51', 154, 0, 1, 273012) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 155
('51', 154, 1, 2, 273057) thought that this salt movement would fizzle out, and said that Mahatma Gandhi would get tired in 20 days or so and that the Government would not take any notice of the movement.
('51', 154, 1, 3, 273236) But who knew what was going to happen?” The Viceroy said : “You planned a fine strategy round the issue of salt.”
('51', 154, 2, 4, 273350) These two titbits are not worth narrating anywhere.
('51', 154, 2, 5, 273402) Now the third one.
('51', 154, 2, 6, 273421) I talked about Bhagat Singh.

('51', 154, 2, 8, 273567) But if you want to make the present atmosphere more favourable, you should suspend Bhagat Singh’s execution.” The Viceroy liked this very much.

('51', 154, 2, 11, 274015) However, this is the evil of capital punishment, that it gives no opportunity to such a man to reform himself.

('51', 154, 2, 13, 274287) I myself would release him, but I cannot expect any Government to do so.

('51', 156, 1, 2, 277868) 215. MY NOTEBOOK
('51', 156, 2, 3, 277885) MOTILALJI’S DEATH Pandit Motilalji’s death means to me more even than to the brave widow whose sorrow it is my privilege during these days to share.
('51', 156, 2, 4, 278034) I take the blow as an additional test of my faith in God’s greatness and goodness.
('51', 156, 2, 5, 278117) Panditji has died a true warrior’s death.
('51', 156, 2, 6, 278159) It is therefore well with him.
('51', 156, 2, 7, 278190) He lives more amply and more truly by dying.
('51', 156, 2, 8, 278235) I pray to God that he may endow me with greater consecration to the service of the cause for which alone life is worth living in these days of purification through sacrifice and suffering.
('51', 156, 3, 9, 278424) MEMORIAL Friends have asked me to advise a memorial subscription such as was raised to the memory of the late Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan, Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das and Lala Lajpat Rai.
('51', 156, 3, 10, 278607) I have resisted the temptation because (1) I personally cannot shoulder the burden; (2) I may any day be summoned to Yeravda or some such place of recreation; and (3) the only true memorial that can just now be raised to the memory of the deceased patriot is by intenser dedication to hasten the advent of swaraj.
('51', 156, 4, 11, 278921) MAULANA MAHOMED ALI I was privileged to offer my tribute to the memory of Maulana Mahomed Ali by sending from Yeravda a cable message to Maulana Shaukat Ali.
('51', 156, 4, 12, 279079) But I cannot resume the Editorship of Young India without publicly declaring that in him I have lost one whom I rejoiced to call brother and friend and the nation has lost a fearless patriot.
('51', 156, 4, 13, 279271) We had differences of opinion between us, but love that cannot stand the strain of differences is like “a sounding brass and tinkling cymbal”.
('51', 156, 5, 14, 279414) PEACE NEGOTIATIONS It is not for the soldier to worry about peace.
('51', 156, 5, 15, 279481) For him both struggle and peace are alike.
('51', 156, 5, 16, 279524) He has to do with the utmost joy the task that comes to him without counting the costs or the consequence.
('51', 156, 5, 17, 279631) The consequence he knows.
('51', 156, 5, 18, 279657) The cost is never too high for him.
('51', 156, 6, 19, 279693) PICKETING Picketing is a dharma only when it is absolutely non violent.
('51', 156, 6, 20, 279765) Those who have no faith in non violence had better give it up altogether.
('51', 156, 6, 21, 279839) I can find out ways and means of combating the inroads
('51', 157, 0, 1, 279894) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 157, 1, 2, 279936) of foreign cloth even though there be no picketing, but I know for certain that boycott brought about by violent picketing is bound to fail in the end.
('51', 157, 1, 3, 280088) It was this knowledge that induced me last March to entrust picketing of foreign cloth shops and drink and drug shops to women who are instinctively non violent.
('51', 157, 1, 4, 280250) Violence in picketing can be both active and passive.
('51', 157, 1, 5, 280304) The passive type can be more dangerous than the active.
('51', 157, 1, 6, 280360) Both must be shunned.
('51', 157, 2, 7, 280382) KHADI Without khadi there is no boycott.
('51', 157, 2, 8, 280423) Therefore we must concentrate on khadi.

('51', 162, 1, 2, 288168) 226. SPEECH AT DELHI
('51', 162, 2, 3, 288189) February 20, 1931
('51', 162, 3, 4, 288207) Mahatma Gandhi began by offering Id felicitation to his Muslim brothers and sisters.
('51', 162, 3, 5, 288292) He said on such an occasion and in the presence of such an un precedented gathering, his thoughts went to Maulana Mahomed Ali whose death had pained him a great deal.
('51', 162, 3, 6, 288459) Ever since he had returned to India from South Africa he had thought of Delhi as the Delhi of Maulana Mahomed Ali, Swami Shraddhanand and Hakim Ajmal Khan so much so that even now, though their physical presence was to be missed their unseen presence could still be felt.
('51', 162, 3, 7, 288731) He was equally pained to miss at such a critical juncture as the present Pandit Motilal Nehru whose death was so recent that their eyes were yet wet with tears.
('51', 162, 3, 8, 288892) Mahatmaji, continuing, said : I know you are all anxious to hear something from me of the talks I am having with His Excellency the Viceroy.
('51', 162, 3, 9, 289033) I am afraid I may not take the public into confidence about what happened between His Excellency and me.
('51', 162, 3, 10, 289138) For one thing I am pledged not to do so and secondly it is not going to help us.
('51', 162, 3, 11, 289219) But I may say this much, that these talks have been conducted in a most friendly manner and with much sweetness.
('51', 162, 3, 12, 289332) What will be the result I cannot say.
('51', 162, 3, 13, 289370) The result is in the hands of God.
('51', 162, 3, 14, 289405) It is His will that will prevail.
('51', 162, 3, 15, 289439) Your duty is that you must continue to do what India expects of you.
('51', 162, 3, 16, 289508) Dr. Ansari belonging as he does to Delhi has naturally spoken highly of the part played by Delhi; but I am a witness to the great sacrifices that have been made throughout India and I can say how Delhi stands in comparison with any other province.
('51', 162, 3, 17, 289756) For that you deserve my congratulation.
('51', 162, 4, 18, 289796) Resuming his speech, Mahatmaji said : Here as elsewhere the part played by women is indescribable.
('51', 162, 4, 19, 289895) When the history of this movement comes to be written, the sacrifices made by the women of India will occupy the foremost place and just as with women so also with children.
('51', 162, 4, 20, 290069) Their wonderful awakening has fortified me in my faith that God is with us in this struggle.
('51', 162, 4, 21, 290162) These young folk had never been organized for such work, never been trained for it.
('51', 162, 4, 22, 290246) How they came to achieve all this I have not been able
('51', 162, 5, 23, 290301) 1 At this stage the speech was interrupted on account of disorder among a section of the people who could not hear Gandhiji.
('51', 163, 0, 1, 290426) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 163, 1, 2, 290468) to divine nor has anyone else whom I have consulted been able to enlighten [me] as to who guided them; only God could have done so.
('51', 163, 1, 3, 290600) But remember that, in the sacred battle, whatever sacrifices you have made are trifling.
('51', 163, 1, 4, 290689) Let them not puff you up with pride, what we want for India is purna swaraj.
('51', 163, 1, 5, 290766) And who can calculate what further sacrifices India will have to make to achieve that goal?
('51', 163, 1, 6, 290858) I assure you that I am doing as much as is humanly possible to bring about peace so that the people may not have to go through further suffering and sacrifices but everything is in God’s hands and if it be not His will that any understanding be arrived at, then I will have to tell the people that they must be ready for much further suffering.
('51', 163, 1, 7, 291203) The sacrifices that we have made are as nothing before the sacrifices other nations have made for the sake of freedom.
('51', 163, 1, 8, 291322) But there is a reason why we have not had to suffer as much as other nations.
('51', 163, 1, 9, 291400) It is as clear to me as daylight.
('51', 163, 1, 10, 291434) The reason is that when we pledged ourselves to achieve purna swaraj we also took the vow that whatever we do in furtherance of the goal would be in consonance with truth and non violence.
('51', 163, 1, 11, 291623) And when I think of the part played by the whole of India, especially by the rural population, I think we have substantially fulfilled the pledge of truth and non violence.
('51', 163, 1, 12, 291796) But I cannot deceive myself nor will I permit you to deceive yourselves.
('51', 163, 1, 13, 291869) We have followed truth and non violence, but we have not made them an article of faith.
('51', 163, 1, 14, 291957) They have been to some a matter of policy, but even if you have accepted it as a policy, you may not act or think in terms of violence so long as you adhere to the policy.
('51', 163, 1, 15, 292129) The very thought of untruth or violence is a breach of the pledge.
('51', 163, 1, 16, 292196) You will remember that at the Ahmedabad Congress 1 this matter was thoroughly thrashed out in the presence of leaders like Hakim Ajmal Khan and Dr. Ansari and, after full deliberation, it was decided that so long as we bound ourselves to adhere to our policy of truth and non violence in thought, word and deed, the slightest breach of that pledge meant a breach of faith.
('51', 163, 1, 17, 292569) I may tolerate the allegation that Indians are not fit for swaraj, but I cannot for a moment tolerate the allegation, if it were true, that my countrymen were untrue or dishonest.
('51', 163, 1, 18, 292749) There can be no greater tragedy than this, that Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs and Christians who believe in God were ungodly and guilty of a breach of faith.
('51', 163, 1, 19, 292900) Such people are not fit for freedom.
('51', 163, 1, 20, 292937) They are fit for slavery and worse.
('51', 163, 2, 21, 292973) 1 In December 1921.
('51', 164, 0, 1, 292993) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 165
('51', 164, 1, 2, 293038) For this reason, I have always laid the greatest stress on the point that it was open to you to abandon the policy and adopt a different one but so long as you pin your faith to truth and non violence, do not deceive yourself or the world.
('51', 164, 1, 3, 293278) Therefore when I heard that there has been some excesses on the part of our people in the picketing of foreign cloth, I was deeply pained.
('51', 164, 1, 4, 293417) I have not been able to investigate into the allegations but you know that in 1921 22 I expiated for the excesses by suspending the movement.
('51', 164, 1, 5, 293559) That sort of expiation is today out of the question but I must say that wherever these excesses are going on, they must stop.
('51', 164, 1, 6, 293685) It is better that dealers in foreign cloth continue to sell it and those addicted to drink continue to do so, than that we resort to excesses in picketing.
('51', 164, 1, 7, 293841) But there is another danger I wish to warn you against.
('51', 164, 1, 8, 293897) If we take to these excesses, we shall be opening the door for self destruction, when we have swaraj, for there will then be no third power with machine guns to intervene and restore peace.
('51', 164, 1, 9, 294087) We shall be fighting one another and fratricidal war will spell destruction.
('51', 164, 1, 10, 294164) If, there fore, you have the slightest apprehension in your mind that picketing cannot be done without resorting to excesses, you had better give it up.
('51', 164, 1, 11, 294317) I want you to remember that I am an expert in these matters.
('51', 164, 1, 12, 294378) I am sure we have in the past done considerable picketing without the slightest resort to violence.
('51', 164, 1, 13, 294478) Do not be afraid that the moment we eschew the excesses our work will fall through.
('51', 164, 1, 14, 294562) I would ask you not to worry.
('51', 164, 1, 15, 294592) Rest assured that the man who is asking you today to keep to your moorings must have some alternatives to suggest but I shall not dwell on it today.
('51', 164, 1, 16, 294741) I have received letters of complaint and I am making enquiries.
('51', 164, 1, 17, 294805) It is possible that we have committed mistakes.
('51', 164, 1, 18, 294853) I will ask all Congress workers to consider these carefully and correct whatever mistakes we may have been guilty of.
('51', 164, 1, 19, 294971) I appeal to you to eschew all excesses.
('51', 164, 1, 20, 295011) You may like to know what I mean by ‘excesses’.
('51', 164, 1, 21, 295059) I invite the curious to come to me for the explanation.
('51', 164, 1, 22, 295115) And now a word to the foreign cloth dealers.
('51', 164, 1, 23, 295160) Do not deceive your selves or the country by thinking that you have done your duty by refra ining from selling foreign cloth for a few months.
('51', 164, 1, 24, 295303) This foreign cloth trade must stop for ever, because it is only by this means that we can promote the well being of millions of our countrymen.
('51', 164, 1, 25, 295447) I will respectfully submit to the foreign cloth dealers that a complete boycott of foreign clo th is their dharma.
('51', 164, 1, 26, 295562) Sacrifices they will have to
('51', 165, 0, 1, 295591) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 165, 1, 2, 295633) make but what are those sacrifices compared to the greater sacrifices that are being made by other sections of the public?
('51', 165, 1, 3, 295756) I believe that through the charkha and khaddar, the boycott can be made a success and I am working according to my belief.
('51', 165, 1, 4, 295879) Cloth merchants are arriving here the day after tomorrow.
('51', 165, 1, 5, 295937) I want the pressmen to convey my message to them.
('51', 165, 1, 6, 295987) Thus they will be able to realize their duty.
('51', 165, 1, 7, 296033) Citizens of Delhi, I do not flatter myself that you have gathered here in your thousands to do honour to me; you have come to proclaim to the world that you are all determined to achieve purna swaraj.
('51', 165, 1, 8, 296234) Let not my talks with the Viceroy worry you for a moment.
('51', 165, 1, 9, 296292) Do not think of them.
('51', 165, 1, 10, 296314) But go on with your work.
('51', 165, 1, 11, 296340) Only remember that the result is not in my hands, not in the hands of Dr. Ansari of Pandit Malaviya, but in your hands.
('51', 165, 1, 12, 296460) I am but an instrument, and I am acting only as your humble ambassador.
('51', 165, 1, 13, 296532) Everything will depend upon what you do and what you will fail to do.
('51', 165, 1, 14, 296602) May God give you strength to keep the pledge of truth and non violence.
('51', 165, 2, 15, 296674) Gandhiji delivered his speech in Hindi and it was not wholly audible to large
('51', 165, 3, 16, 296752) sections of the vast throng and Gandhiji made a special request to newspaper
('51', 165, 4, 17, 296829) correspondents to publish only authorized text or summary of the speech and
('51', 165, 5, 18, 296905) announced that the Press report of the speech would be looked through by him.

('51', 166, 1, 2, 297592) before but declined to make any statement at the present stage.
('51', 166, 2, 3, 297656) Questioned as to whether he would still retain his first impression created by the Viceroy which Gandhiji had described in his previous interview, he replied that he must revise that opinion now.
('51', 166, 2, 4, 297852) Personally, in the course of the conversations he had found Lord Irwin to be frank, cordial and friendly.
('51', 166, 3, 5, 297958) Replying to the last question as to whether he would expiate by calling off the movement if there was a recrudescence of violence by Congressmen, as in 1922, Gandhiji said : Last time when I did expiate, the method of non violence in politics was a new one and people were unused to what I call absolute, downright plain speaking on the part of leaders.
('51', 166, 3, 6, 298312) There fore I said with regard to myself that people very often thought as if I spoke with mental reservations and even said what I did not mean.
('51', 166, 3, 7, 298457) And that only hurt me but I at once realized that it would injure the cause itself and so I felt it necessary, in order to drive home the truth to the masses, that they must take me literally in all I spoke and that there was no conscious mental reservation.
('51', 166, 3, 8, 298716) This I could only do by some definite drastic action which even millions could understand in a moment and hence I deliberately adopted the method of public expiation by open fasting and I saw that the very first experiment along this line had produced effective and startling results and I continued that till the Chauri Chaura culmination in 1922. That having been brought home and I having declared myself only responsible for the initiative of the campaign and not for the further conduct of it or its stoppage, it would be improper on my part now to interfere through the method of fasting.
('51', 166, 3, 9, 299311) It is the Working Committee which is responsible for the campaign now and it alone can interfere with or shape is conduct.
('51', 166, 3, 10, 299434) This, however, should not be taken to mean that I disown my moral responsibility for the violence done by a single Congressman, and if some violence is done by Congressmen it produces such a sore on my system that I cannot bear it.
('51', 166, 3, 11, 299666) I cannot say what I shall then do, for in all such things I am not guided by reason, but by instinct or in other words by the inner voice and one never knows where that voice would lead you to.

('51', 166, 4, 13, 299891) 229. TO READERS You should not be misled or confused if I approach the Viceroy or if the Congress Working Committee holds talks regarding a
('51', 167, 0, 1, 300031) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 167, 1, 2, 300073) settlement.
('51', 167, 1, 3, 300085) Your dharma is to carry on the task which lies before you, viz., that of serving the nation.
('51', 167, 1, 4, 300178) If you do so, there will be an honourable settlement, if one is at all possible.
('51', 167, 1, 5, 300259) But if as soon as you hear of negotiations for a settlement, you either fall asleep or start enjoying yourselves or become even slightly slack, the settlement will fall through.
('51', 167, 1, 6, 300437) You should know that the Con gress would never accept a dishonourable settlement.
('51', 167, 1, 7, 300519) A satyagrahi can neither add to nor subtract from [his demands].
('51', 167, 1, 8, 300584) Just as an honest business man maintains fixed prices, similar is the case with the satyagrahi.
('51', 167, 1, 9, 300680) A soldier’s demands are not reduced just because he becomes slack; similarly, soldiers cannot add to their demands when they deep advancing and getting more daring.
('51', 167, 1, 10, 300845) Hence, neither I nor any other Congressman can accept anything which is even slightly less than our demand.
('51', 167, 1, 11, 300953) Therefore if the nation becomes lax, there will be no settlement and the struggle will drag on.
('51', 167, 1, 12, 301049) The settlement will be reached early if the people keep up their fervour.
('51', 167, 1, 13, 301123) You should realize that at present the most important task is the boycott of foreign cloth.
('51', 167, 1, 14, 301215) This boycott can be made to succeed only by convincing the people through reason and not through force.
('51', 167, 1, 15, 301319) This requires intelligence and organization and constitutes the test of our sacrifice.
('51', 167, 2, 16, 301406) MILL OWNERS If these mill owners so desire, they can make a success of the boycott.
('51', 167, 2, 17, 301490) The following is the plan of action : 1. They should prepare a list of those who trade in foreign goods.
('51', 167, 2, 18, 301595) 2. They should give their own goods in exchange for foreign cloth with traders who are prepared for this exchange.
('51', 167, 2, 19, 301710) Dealers in foreign cloth should let go a certain percentage in valuing their stocks of foreign cloth.
('51', 167, 2, 20, 301812) Mills should put the minimum prices of their goods.
('51', 167, 2, 21, 301864) 3. The mill owners can sell the above mentioned foreign cloth outside the country or they may set fire to it, or they may seal it up and set it aside for being dealt with after swaraj has been won or, in other words, they can ask for some compensation from the new Government in case they have to suffer a heavy loss.
('51', 167, 2, 22, 302182) This requires the following—some intelligence, some sacrifice, some order, some self confidence, some foresight, some faith in the people and whole hearted determination to boycott foreign cloth.
('51', 168, 0, 1, 302378) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 169
('51', 168, 1, 2, 302423) as this is something that can be readily suggested, it can also be readily put into practice.
('51', 168, 1, 3, 302517) No one should look for guidance to anyone else; instead, those who are convinced should begin to act and plead with other mill owners to follow suit.
('51', 168, 1, 4, 302667) A good beginning can be made even if a few mill owners get together and act jointly.
('51', 168, 2, 5, 302752) CONGRESS The contribution which the Congress can make in this regard depends upon the beginning which the mill owners make.
('51', 168, 2, 6, 302876) The contribution of the former can be secured through picketing.
('51', 168, 3, 7, 302941) DEALERS IN FOREIGN CLOTH 1. You must give up the temptation of trading in foreign cloth; it is poison.
('51', 168, 3, 8, 303044) 2. Do not entertain the false notion that this trade can be resumed under swaraj or within a short time.
('51', 168, 3, 9, 303149) There is no swaraj for the poor, at any rate, if this trade is not stopped in India.
('51', 168, 3, 10, 303234) 3. No one asks you to lay down your lives, no one asks you even to sacrifice all you have.
('51', 168, 3, 11, 303325) However, everyone asks you to rid yourselves of the filth which you have gathered.
('51', 168, 3, 12, 303408) You must realize that it is not as if you cannot trade in anything except foreign cloth.
('51', 168, 3, 13, 303497) People cannot do without cloth; hence there is no alternative for them but to buy cloth which is made in India.
('51', 168, 3, 14, 303609) 4. If only you can see it, your true interest lies in this boycott.

('51', 169, 6, 14, 305092) 232. SPEECH AT COUNCIL OF ALL INDIA MUSLIM LEAGUE, DELHI February 22, 1931
('51', 169, 7, 15, 305167) MR. PRESIDENT AND BROTHERS OF MY COUNTRY, You all know, I am physically so weak that I am unable to make a speech while standing; when I try to do so, every part of my body trembles.
('51', 169, 7, 16, 305350) Maulvi Mohammad Yaqub has said that my coming here meant the coming of 21 crores of Indian brethren.
('51', 169, 7, 17, 305451) I am a Bania, and there is no limit to my greed.
('51', 169, 7, 18, 305500) It has always been my heart’s desire to speak, not only for 21 crores but for 30 crores of Indians.
('51', 169, 7, 19, 305600) Today you may not accept that position of mine but my early upbringing, my childhood and youth, has been to strive for Hindu Muslim unity.
('51', 169, 7, 20, 305739) No one may dismiss it today as merely a craze of my old age.
('51', 169, 7, 21, 305800) My heart is confident that God will grant me that position to speak for the whole of India one day, and even if I die striving for it, I
('51', 170, 0, 1, 305937) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 171
('51', 170, 1, 2, 305982) shall achieve peace of mind.
('51', 170, 1, 3, 306011) I do not know what the result of my talks with the Viceroy would be, nor can I say when the talks will result in something, but if God wishes that Congress should participate in the Conference and if there is a settlement between the Government and the Congress, the question of Hindu Muslim unity will be one which will engage our first attention.
('51', 170, 1, 4, 306360) And I give you all the assurance at my command that what I can do to achieve that end we will be always willing to do.
('51', 170, 1, 5, 306479) Hindu Muslim unity is not a question of bargain—that we should continue fighting for one, two or five seats.
('51', 170, 1, 6, 306588) Unity can be achieved by giving up mutual fears and mistrust.
('51', 170, 1, 7, 306650) Unless our hearts are purified and we regard Hindus and Muslims as one, unity cannot be established.
('51', 170, 1, 8, 306751) Rest assured that it is not a matter of loaves and fishes, but of trust and love.
('51', 170, 1, 9, 306833) If Hindus and Muslims are two eyes of the country, as Sir Syed Ahmed said, there should be no occasion for quarrel or distrust—no one can say that one eye is better than the other.
('51', 170, 1, 10, 307014) It is quite conceivable that two brothers may have different faith and yet both may live in harmony and peace.
('51', 170, 1, 11, 307125) I wonder why the people fight in the name of religion and for the sake of religion.
('51', 170, 1, 12, 307209) I am ready to serve you in the matter of establishing Hindu Muslim unity and now since you have made a way for me into your heart, I shall try to enter it.
('51', 170, 1, 13, 307365) It is a question of lover and beloved.
('51', 170, 1, 14, 307404) I am in search of it; I was anxiously waiting for it.
('51', 170, 1, 15, 307458) If Hindu Muslim unity is achieved, the mission of my life would be fulfilled.
('51', 170, 2, 16, 307536) Thanking the League for the invitation, Mahatmaji said : I wish you may continue to invite me as you have invited me today and you shall have no occasion to repent.
('51', 170, 2, 17, 307701) (Laughter and cheers) The Hindustan Times, 25 2 1931

('51', 175, 1, 2, 313148) 241. LETTER TO REGINALD REYNOLDS 1
('51', 175, 2, 3, 313183) CAMP DELHI, February 23, 1931
('51', 175, 3, 4, 313213) MY DEAR REGINALD,
('51', 175, 4, 5, 313231) I honour you for your long, frank and emphatic letter.
('51', 175, 4, 6, 313286) It will help me to remain firm where firmness is required.
('51', 175, 4, 7, 313345) Having said this, let me tell you that I do not at all agree with you that I was wrong in suspending judgment or action pending the arrival of the three friends.
('51', 175, 4, 8, 313507) Satyagraha can afford to wait.
('51', 175, 4, 9, 313538) It can be gentle, and should be gentle, where gentleness is a duty.
('51', 175, 4, 10, 313606) However mistaken their judgment may be found to be, I regard these friends as equal lovers of their country with me.
('51', 175, 4, 11, 313723) I have no business to judge them as I would not have them judge me and by waiting I assure you that the cause has not suffered a bit.
('51', 175, 4, 12, 313857) It may be that the friends there who are whole hoggers may feel embarrassed to find me acting contrary to their expectation.
('51', 175, 4, 13, 313982) But, as time goes by, you and they may discover many such shocks.
('51', 175, 4, 14, 314048) I regard myself as a seasoned soldier in satyagraha.
('51', 175, 4, 15, 314101) I have acted before, as I have acted now, at similar critical junctures and I cannot recall a single occasion when the cause espoused had lost by waiting.
('51', 175, 4, 16, 314256) On the contrary I can recall many an occa sion when the waiting had proved fruitful.
('51', 175, 4, 17, 314341) Let my assurance there fore be sufficient for you that so far as I am concerned there will be absolutely no surrender on principle, i.e., on the substantial part of the demand and I doubt not that there will be none on the part of the Congress.
('51', 175, 4, 18, 314586) Remember too that satyagraha is a method of carrying convic tion and of converting by an appeal to reason and to the sympathetic chord in human beings.
('51', 175, 4, 19, 314738) It relies upon the ultimate good in every
('51', 175, 5, 20, 314780) 1 In his book To Live in Mankind, Reginald Reynolds writes : “As soon as negotiations were re opened with the Government, I wrote.
('51', 175, 5, 21, 314911) It was not, as it might appear, impertinent interference.
('51', 175, 5, 22, 314969) I had a perfectly legitimate motive, which was that—as one of the few exponents of the Congress case in Britain—I ought to know just where they stood.
('51', 175, 5, 23, 315120) It was of vital importance to me that I should understand the reasons for this change of front if I was to continue writing and speaking in defence of India and her leaders.

('51', 176, 3, 13, 316169) 242. LETTER TO JOHN HAYNES HOLMES CAMP 1 DARYAGANJ, DELHI, February 3, 1931
('51', 176, 4, 14, 316245) DEAR FRIEND,

('51', 176, 5, 16, 316383) I have followed with gratefulness all the efforts that you have been good enough to make on behalf of India.

('51', 180, 5, 8, 322587) BHAI SHIVABHAI, I have just enough time, or can spare it, to answer your ques tions.
('51', 180, 5, 9, 322672) I had got your long letter.
('51', 180, 5, 10, 322700) Coercion should have no room at all in the picketing of foreign cloth.
('51', 180, 5, 11, 322771) It does not matter if without coercion picketing does not succeed.
('51', 180, 5, 12, 322838) I certainly do not believe that fasting is always a form of coercion.
('51', 180, 5, 13, 322908) I have written on this subject for the next issue of Navajivan.
('51', 180, 5, 14, 322972) 2 Read that article and, if you have any questions to ask me, ask them.
('51', 180, 5, 15, 323044) If we have resolved not to tolerate coer cion in any circumstances, we shall con tinually discover new methods of picketing and new means of bring ing about complete boycott.
('51', 180, 5, 16, 323219) In consequence of the picketing of liquor booths, drink addicts will make illicit liquor in their homes and some of them will even sell it.
('51', 180, 5, 17, 323359) This evil may be tolerated if we have taken the necessary measures to make it bearable.
('51', 180, 5, 18, 323447) Most of the addicts, however, will have stopped drinking.
('51', 180, 5, 19, 323505) My impression is that, in picketing liquor booths, our main, or only, aim, has been to deprive the Government of the revenue which it receives from the sale of liquor, whereas our real duty is to stop drink addicts from drinking.
('51', 180, 5, 20, 323735) If we realize this clearly and if we get workers, we can visit each addict in his home and persuade him to give up his habit, and we can also teach him to enjoy harmless drinks in place of liquor.
('51', 180, 5, 21, 323932) Wherever the workers act in a manner contrary to truth, persons like you should stop them from doing so and, if they fail, break off relations with them.

('51', 181, 4, 8, 324551) 251. SPEECH AT HINDU COLLEGE, DELHI 1
('51', 181, 5, 9, 324589) February 25, 1931
('51', 181, 6, 10, 324607) Mahatmaji next unveiled a beautiful portrait of the late Lala Lajpat Rai amid loud shouts of “Jai” and then proceeded to deliver his speech.
('51', 181, 7, 11, 324748) He said he felt very grateful to them for having asked him to unveil the portrait of Lala Lajpat Rai.
('51', 181, 7, 12, 324850) It was in the fitness of things, that at a time when India’s fight for freedom was on, the portrait of a great patriot should be unveiled.
('51', 181, 7, 13, 324989) But mere unveiling of his portrait was not sufficient, they must resolve in their minds that they shall install in their hearts the noble qualities of Lala Lajpat Rai.
('51', 181, 7, 14, 325157) He was also grateful to them for the purses they had presented then.
('51', 181, 7, 15, 325226) He said he always felt great pleasure in sitting among students, chatting with them, playing with them, flattering them, and snubbing them, because he had a self interest and that was “complete independence” and that could not be achieved unless he had attracted every student’s heart and won over his power of sacrifice for balidan (sacrifice) in the yajna (fight) which was going on in the country.
('51', 181, 8, 16, 325627) The whole world was looking towards the students and he would feel much pain and sorrow, if they did not come out successful in their trial.
('51', 181, 8, 17, 325768) He was sorry that the students had not taken their legitimate share in the fight for freedom.
('51', 181, 8, 18, 325862) No doubt they did shout “inquilab” loudly, but he wanted them to cultivate three things : (1) maryada (discipline), (2) sanyam (self control) and (3) charitrabal (power of character).
('51', 181, 8, 19, 326046) Where else could we find these three things?
('51', 181, 8, 20, 326091) The fight for swaraj was a yajna of self purification and he expected the students to contribute the largest share in that yajna.
('51', 181, 9, 21, 326221) But, he was sorry that they had not fulfilled his expectations in the matter.
('51', 181, 10, 22, 326299) 1 After welcome address by S. K. Sen, Principal, three purses were presented to Gandhiji on behalf of the Hindu, St. Stephen’s and Law Colleges.
('51', 182, 0, 1, 326444) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 183
('51', 182, 1, 2, 326489) They had lagged in making the sacrifice that was expected of them.
('51', 182, 1, 3, 326556) Mother India expected much more sacrifice from them and he was sorry that they had not offered that.
('51', 182, 1, 4, 326657) The Mahatma said : I am an optimist and will not give up.
('51', 182, 1, 5, 326715) I still fell hopeful that you would fulfil the expectations of the country.
('51', 182, 2, 6, 326791) It was with these hopes that he had come to address them.
('51', 182, 3, 7, 326849) Mahatmaji said, there were three tasks before them.
('51', 182, 3, 8, 326901) (1) Hindu Muslim unity.
('51', 182, 3, 9, 326925) Let the old men (Hindus and Muslims) fight, because they had in them mistrust arising out of cowardice, which was inevitable for men nearing death.
('51', 182, 3, 10, 327073) But youth should not entertain mistrust and should work whole heartedly for Hindu Muslim unity because they were the best messengers of the cause.
('51', 182, 3, 11, 327220) What, if they had different religions?
('51', 182, 3, 12, 327259) Like the five fingers of one hand, they should protect and help each other.
('51', 182, 3, 13, 327335) It was a pity that we people were doing unreligious things in the name of religion.
('51', 182, 3, 14, 327419) He wanted students to promise to live like brothers in perfect harmony and establish goodwill and cordiality between Hindus and Muslims.
('51', 182, 3, 15, 327556) The second task before them, said Mahatmaji, was doing away with the curse of untouchability which did not mean simply touching the so called untouchables, but it meant regarding the humblest and the poorest in the land as our equal.
('51', 182, 3, 16, 327790) Thirdly, they must use khaddar and promote the use of charkha, which in itself was a great science.
('51', 182, 3, 17, 327890) Sir C. W. Raman and Sir J. C. Bose deserved praise for their scientific discoveries but the charkha too was a powerful science, which would bring salvation to crores of our countrymen.
('51', 182, 3, 18, 328075) Concluding, he said if crores of people were his followers today and called him a Mahatma, it was not because he had given up practice at the Bar, but because he regarded the poorest among the poor as his brother and he believed that the salvation of the country lay in charkha and Hindu Muslim unity.
('51', 182, 3, 19, 328377) He was devoting every minute for the achievement of these ideals.
('51', 182, 4, 20, 328443) Mahatmaji smilingly added : If you follow me you can all become Mahatmas (Laughter) and then I will have many companions to help me in the attainment of our object.
('51', 182, 4, 21, 328608) (Laughter)
('51', 182, 5, 22, 328619) Mahatmaji concluded with a prayer to God to inspire the students with the will and power to sacrifice.
('51', 182, 5, 23, 328722) The Hindustan Times, 27 2 1931
('51', 182, 6, 24, 328753) 252. PICKETING It is an unshakable faith with me that a cause suffers exactly to the extent that it is supported by violence.
('51', 182, 6, 25, 328879) I say this in spite of appearances to the contrary.
('51', 182, 6, 26, 328931) If I kill a man who obstructs me, I may experience a sense of false security.
('51', 182, 6, 27, 329009) But the security will be short 
('51', 183, 0, 1, 329041) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 183, 1, 2, 329083) For I shall not have dealt with the root cause.
('51', 183, 1, 3, 329131) In due course other men will surely rise to obstruct me.
('51', 183, 1, 4, 329188) My business therefore is not to kill the man or men who obstruct me but to discover the cause that impels them to obstruct me and deal with it.
('51', 183, 1, 5, 329332) Even so must one deal with the cause of people selling foreign cloth and not lay violent hands on those who happened to be the dealers for the time being.
('51', 183, 1, 6, 329487) The cause lies on the surface.
('51', 183, 1, 7, 329518) So long as there are buyers of foreign cloth, there will be sellers.
('51', 183, 1, 8, 329587) I must, therefore, gain the ear of the buying public.
('51', 183, 1, 9, 329641) If we would but recognize this cardinal fact we would lay the greatest stress upon work in the villages which send their millions to the foreign cloth market.
('51', 183, 1, 10, 329800) But I must not be understood to mean that we may neglect the cities and the merchants.
('51', 183, 1, 11, 329887) Only under the plan suggested by me need there be neither despair, nor the slightest trace of violence.
('51', 183, 1, 12, 329991) Moreover my plan if fully executed contains within itself the surest chances of success and need never degenerate into rowdyism.
('51', 183, 1, 13, 330120) Let us not forget that we are wedded to non violence and truth.
('51', 183, 1, 14, 330184) The strictest and closest striving towards these two beacon lights would certainly bring us ashore; and whilst reaching us there in the quickest possible time it would enable us in difficult circumstances to discover effective ways out.
('51', 183, 1, 15, 330421) Those who have faith would not be disheartened if they found that some dealers have defied Congress instructions and demands.
('51', 183, 1, 16, 330547) Such disappointments should be used for perfecting our own internal organization and discovering our defects, never for losing faith.

('51', 185, 5, 8, 333411) 255. SPEECH AT SISGUNJ GURDWARA, DELHI 1
('51', 185, 6, 9, 333452) February 26, 1931 I have followed with painful interest the details of police firing 2
('51', 185, 7, 10, 333539) into the sacred precincts of this Gurdwara that have been narrated by the previous figure 3 and I assure you that my grief and resentment at the outrage are not les than yours.
('51', 185, 7, 11, 333716) But as I told my Sikh brethren at the time of Nankana Sahib tragedy when I visited Nankana Sahib in company with Abul Kalam Azad in 1921, we are today fighting not for one Gurdwara but for the bigger Gurdwara, which is the common sacred possession of all of us, viz., purna swaraj.
('51', 185, 7, 12, 333998) Purna—complete— because it is as much for the prince as for the peasant, as much for the rich landowner as for the landless tiller of the soil, as much for the Hindus as for the Mussalmans, as much for the Parsis and Christians as for the Jains, Jews and Sikhs, irrespective of any distinction of caste or creed or status in life.
('51', 185, 7, 13, 334329) The very connotation of the word and the means of its attainment to which we are pledged—truth and non violence—preclude all possibility of that swaraj being more for someone than for the other, being partial to someone and prejudicial to the other.
('51', 185, 7, 14, 334579) Truth and non violence leave no room for fraud or falsehood.
('51', 185, 7, 15, 334640) The Congress has attracted the attention of the world for the simple reason that it is pledged to win freedom by means un employed by nations heretofore.
('51', 185, 7, 16, 334794) The world has so far been familiar with only one method of achieving freedom and that by the use of physical force.
('51', 185, 7, 17, 334910) But luckily for itself and the world, India has launched on the method of non violence and truth for the attainment of its
('51', 185, 8, 18, 335033) 1 This appeared under the caption : “God and Our Bond” as “a condensed translation” of Gandhiji’s speech.
('51', 185, 8, 19, 335139) 2 On May 6, 1930 3 Balwant Singh
('51', 186, 0, 1, 335172) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 187
('51', 186, 1, 2, 335217) independence.
('51', 186, 1, 3, 335231) It is a unique thing in history and the world which began by regarding it with scepticism is today watching India’s great non violent experi ment with bated breath.
('51', 186, 1, 4, 335396) In physical warfare even chicanery and fraud have a place but non violence precludes the use of all other weapons except that of truth and justice.
('51', 186, 1, 5, 335544) Swaraj under this method, therefore, can never be achieved by usurping the rights of any community big or small but by ensuring even handed justice and fair treatment to all—even the poorest and the weakest in the land.
('51', 186, 1, 6, 335764) That being so how can the Congress want to keep even a child out of its own.
('51', 186, 1, 7, 335841) The beauty of non violence is that it carries within it its own security.
('51', 186, 1, 8, 335915) I venture to suggest that the non violence creed of the Congress is the surest guarantee of its good faith and our Sikh friends have no reason to fear betrayal at its hands.
('51', 186, 1, 9, 336089) For the moment it did so, the Congress would not only thereby seal its own doom but that of the country too.
('51', 186, 1, 10, 336198) Moreover the Sikhs are a brave people.
('51', 186, 1, 11, 336237) They will know how to safeguard their rights by the exercise of arms if it should ever come to that.
('51', 186, 1, 12, 336338) Sardar Madhusudan Singh in his speech has asked for an assurance that the Congress would do nothing that might alienate the sympathies of the Sikhs from the Congress.
('51', 186, 1, 13, 336505) Well, the Congress in its Lahore Session a resolution that it would not endorse any settlement with regard to the minority question that failed to satisfy any of the minorities concerned.
('51', 186, 1, 14, 336693) What further assurance can the Congress give you to set you at ease I really fail to understand.
('51', 186, 1, 15, 336790) Then there is the controversy about the inclusion of the Sikh colour in the national flag.
('51', 186, 1, 16, 336881) No blame can possibly attach to the Congress in this respect.
('51', 186, 1, 17, 336943) The present design was suggested by me.
('51', 186, 1, 18, 336983) The Congress has not even formally adopted it.
('51', 186, 1, 19, 337030) I had offered to the Sikh friends to place before the A.I.C.C. their viewpoint if they could apprise me of it.
('51', 186, 1, 20, 337141) But as it turned out, the A.I.C.C. could not meet after that and no one knows as to when it would be able to meet at all.
('51', 186, 1, 21, 337263) Even the Working Committee is out today on sufferance.
('51', 186, 1, 22, 337318) To raise this controversy at this time—a time when the Congress is fighting for its very existence—would be, to say the least, unseemly act.
('51', 186, 1, 23, 337459) You may not obstruct if you cannot help.
('51', 186, 1, 24, 337500) The Sikhs have given their loyal and unstinted co operation to the Congress in many parts in India like Bombay and Delhi, etc.
('51', 186, 1, 25, 337627) But these brave people have never bothered themselves about the flag
('51', 187, 0, 1, 337696) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 187, 1, 2, 337738) question.
('51', 187, 1, 3, 337748) The flag controversy is being conducted mostly by those who have held aloof from the present movement.
('51', 187, 1, 4, 337851) A brave man always gives credit to the other party for its bona fides.
('51', 187, 1, 5, 337922) Why can you have not faith?
('51', 187, 1, 6, 337950) If the Congress should play false afterwards you can well settle surely with it, for you hold the sword.
('51', 187, 1, 7, 338055) I would ask you therefore to cast out suspicion and distrust from you and to plunge into this sacred yajna of freedom whole heartedly.
('51', 187, 1, 8, 338190) You will find that when you are ready to make the extre me sacrifice you will disdain to ask for guarantees.
('51', 187, 1, 9, 338299) It will be for others who will look up to you as the champions of their rights as it will be for you to fulfil their expectations.
('51', 187, 1, 10, 338430) I hold Granth Sahib in high reverence.
('51', 187, 1, 11, 338469) Several parts of it have passed into our daily speech.
('51', 187, 1, 12, 338524) So far as my reading of it goes it inculcates faith, valour and an invincible belief in the ultimate triumph of right and justice.
('51', 187, 1, 13, 338655) I would like you to derive your inspiration and guidance from it.
('51', 187, 1, 14, 338721) I ask you to accept my word and the resolution of the Congress that it will not betray a single individual much less a community.
('51', 187, 1, 15, 338851) If it ever thinks of doing so, it will only hasten its own doom.
('51', 187, 1, 16, 338916) No nation determined to immolate itself at the altar of freedom can be guilty of breach of faith.
('51', 187, 1, 17, 339014) My life has been an open book.
('51', 187, 1, 18, 339045) I have no secrets and I encourage no secrets.
('51', 187, 1, 19, 339091) I pray you therefore to unbosom your selves of all your doubts and apprehensions and I shall try to meet you as best I can.

('51', 187, 1, 21, 339238) What more can I say then this that let God be witness of the bond that binds me and the Congress with you.

('51', 187, 2, 23, 339367) 256. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY
('51', 187, 3, 24, 339395) February 27, 1931
('51', 187, 4, 25, 339413) I saw Mr. Gandhi again today.
('51', 187, 4, 26, 339443) I began by reference to the scope of the further constitutional discussions—in regard to which I said—“The object of future discussions is to consider further the scheme for the constitutional government of India discussed at the Round Table Conference.
('51', 187, 4, 27, 339697) Of the scheme there outlined, Federa tion is an essential part; so also are Indian responsibility, and safeguards, explained by the Prime Minister, as being needed to secure such matters as Crown control of defence and external affairs; the position of minorities; the financial credit of India, and the discharge of obligations.
('51', 187, 4, 28, 340027) The character and form of the arrangements, by which effect should be given to these fundamental principles of Federation,
('51', 188, 0, 1, 340150) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 189
('51', 188, 1, 2, 340195) responsibility and safeguards, are matters for discussion.”
('51', 188, 2, 3, 340255) To this he assented.
('51', 188, 3, 4, 340276) I then referred to the question he had raised as to an examination into debt charges.
('51', 188, 3, 5, 340362) I told him that the position of His Majesty’s Government was that, for reasons of Indian credit, it was impossible for them to assent to an investigation into the Indian debt, and as to any particular charges it was impossible for His Majesty’s Government to express an opinion without knowing more precisely to what these might relate.
('51', 188, 4, 6, 340699) In reply to this he said that he would wish to raise particular subjects,
('51', 188, 5, 7, 340773) though these he was not willing or able precisely to define.
('51', 188, 5, 8, 340834) He instanced however
('51', 188, 6, 9, 340855) the £ 100 million gift in the war.
('51', 188, 6, 10, 340890) I told him that I could only make His Majesty’s
('51', 188, 7, 11, 340938) Government acquainted with what he had said, and that in any event I had no
('51', 188, 8, 12, 341014) doubt that His Majesty’s Government must reserve to themselves complete liberty of
('51', 188, 9, 13, 341097) decision as to how they dealt with particular subjects if raised.
('51', 188, 9, 14, 341163) To this he replied that,
('51', 188, 10, 15, 341188) while appreciating the position of His Majesty’s Government, he must make it clear
('51', 188, 11, 16, 341271) that, in the event of the attitude of His Majesty’s Government on questions raised
('51', 188, 12, 17, 341354) being such as Congress could not accept, he must reserve to Congress the right to
('51', 188, 13, 18, 341436) withdraw from participation in the Conference proceedings.
('51', 188, 14, 19, 341495) He said that he did not contemplate or desire any public pronouncement on
('51', 188, 15, 20, 341569) this subject.
('51', 188, 16, 21, 341583) The next matter to which I referred was secession, on which I told him that, as
('51', 188, 17, 22, 341663) I had made plain at our first interview, I regarded the question in present circumstances
('51', 188, 18, 23, 341753) as academic, and that, though I presumed he could raise it if he so desired, public
('51', 188, 19, 24, 341837) expression of any intention to do so would have the worst possible effect and could
('51', 188, 20, 25, 341921) hardly fail to damage his own cause.
('51', 188, 20, 26, 341958) To this he assented.
('51', 188, 20, 27, 341979) We then turned to the practical questions arising in the event of peace restored.
('51', 188, 20, 28, 342061) I made it plain to him that any reciprocal action by Government depended on the effective discontinuance of the civil disobedience movement, of which I detailed the various activities set out in the memorandum I had before me, and of which I promised to send him a copy.
('51', 188, 20, 29, 342332) He raised a variety of points on particular issues, which were not of great importance, and, after much discussion, the position emerged that apart from these, three matters appeared to present great—and in his phrase, insurmountable— difficulty.
('51', 188, 20, 30, 342579) These were picketing; enquiries into police excesses; and salt.
('51', 188, 20, 31, 342643) On each of these I developed the attitude of Government as defined in the memorandum, and said that I could not hold out any hope of Government going further.
('51', 188, 20, 32, 342802) He argued all three points on lines which after several hours’ discussion have
('51', 189, 0, 1, 342881) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 189, 1, 2, 342923) now become familiar, and promised to send me a note 1 tomorrow, showing precisely what he had in mind as regards picketing.
('51', 189, 1, 3, 343047) I told him that I would consider this when I received it, but that I scarcely thought it could affect my view.
('51', 189, 1, 4, 343158) This was that whatever might be the logical arguments in favour of peaceful persuasion, by way of picketing, the whole experience of the last month showed that it was a conception that had no relation to practical facts, and that it inevitably led to abuses and violence, of which we had had examples in plenty.
('51', 189, 1, 5, 343470) As regards the points of police enquiry and salt, he was frankly dissatisfied.
('51', 189, 2, 6, 343549) I promised to send him a note on all the points discussed, in which I would
('51', 189, 3, 7, 343625) state clearly the position of Government.
('51', 189, 3, 8, 343667) He could then consider whether any further
('51', 189, 4, 9, 343710) meeting would be useful.
('51', 189, 4, 10, 343735) He said he would leave this to me.
('51', 189, 4, 11, 343770) I concluded by again
('51', 189, 5, 12, 343791) urging him to exert his influence on the side of peaceto which he replied by saying
('51', 189, 6, 13, 343875) that he desired peace, but that when in doubt he fell back on “Lead Kindly Light” and
('51', 189, 7, 14, 343961) “One step enough for me”.

('51', 190, 1, 2, 344794) 258. NOTE ON PICKETING
('51', 190, 2, 3, 344817) February 28, 1931 In the event of peace being established picketing of foreign cloth and drink and drug shops will be unaggressive and though, to the extent that it is successful, it must produce political consequen ces, it will be predominantly for social and moral ends as it was before the political consequence was thought of, or intended.
('51', 190, 2, 4, 345161) It will, therefore, be largely confined to villages, and even in cities attention will be directed not so much to the sellers as to the buyers.
('51', 190, 2, 5, 345305) It will thus be predominantly educative.
('51', 190, 2, 6, 345346) There will be no cordons, and no crowds, such as now are the special feature of picketing.
('51', 190, 2, 7, 345437) There will be no hostile demonstrations against those who in sist on selling foreign cloth in defiance of public opinion.
('51', 190, 2, 8, 345559) Naturally it will be absolutely peaceful and conducted so as to cause no public obstruction, and will not be in defiance of the common law.
('51', 190, 3, 9, 345699) From a photostat : C.W. 9334. Courtesy : India Office Library; also G.N. 8950
