('51', 191, 4, 11, 346801) Blessings from BAPU
('51', 191, 5, 12, 346821) From a photostat to the Gujarati: Chandrakanta Papers.
('51', 191, 5, 13, 346876) Courtesy: Gandhi National Museum and Library
('51', 191, 6, 14, 346921) 261. WHAT SHOULD ONE NOT DO?
('51', 191, 7, 15, 346950) Let me note down what, in my opinion, are the things one ought not to do while picketing liquor shops and foreign cloth shops.
('51', 191, 7, 16, 347077) 1. We should not abuse either the seller or the buyer and should never be discourteous in our behaviour.
('51', 191, 7, 17, 347182) 2. We should not lie down before a shop or a vehicle.
('51', 191, 7, 18, 347236) 3. We should not cry out “shame!
('51', 191, 7, 19, 347269) shame!” 4. We should not take out effigies for burning or burying.
('51', 191, 7, 20, 347336) 5. Even while ostracizing people, we should not obstruct their obtaining food or any other service.
('51', 191, 7, 21, 347436) But we should not take meals in their homes or accept any service from them.
('51', 191, 7, 22, 347513) How far service should be rendered, however, requires careful consideration.
('51', 191, 7, 23, 347590) 6.We should not fast in protest against them in any circumstan ces.
('51', 191, 7, 24, 347658) The commonly accepted rule regarding fasting is as follows : Where there is a bond between two parties, one of them may fast if the other violates a condition or a moral law, just as Raihana fasted in Patan.
('51', 191, 7, 25, 347866) Some may say that the boycott of liquor shops or foreign cloth shops cannot succeed through such limited picketing; I would then say that the boycott had better fail in that case.
('51', 191, 7, 26, 348046) Those who raise such doubts, it may be said, do not have full faith in the unfailing success
('51', 192, 0, 1, 348139) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 193
('51', 192, 1, 2, 348184) of non violence.
('51', 192, 1, 3, 348201) Observance of non violence was the object behind entrusting both these tasks to women.
('51', 192, 1, 4, 348288) I am convinced that we can achieve both these boycotts within a short period of time if a non violent atmosphere is maintained.
('51', 192, 1, 5, 348416) On the contrary, if we transgress our limits, however welcome the immediate results may appear to be, bitterness will spread among us in the end and the atmosphere of internecine strife will prevail.
('51', 192, 1, 6, 348616) And if we become victims of family feuds, the boycott will end and, swaraj itself will remain a mere dream.
('51', 192, 1, 7, 348724) Hence my advice and hope is that everyone will accept this prescrip tion as that of an experienced vaid and put it into practice.
('51', 192, 1, 8, 348854) If despite people following my advice—regarding what should be done and what should not be done—the boycott does not succeed, I am aware that the burden of the failure will rest on me.
('51', 192, 1, 9, 349039) I am prepared to shoulder it.
('51', 192, 2, 10, 349069) KHADI AND BOYCOTT OF FOREIGN CLOTH
('51', 192, 3, 11, 349104) As I continue to examine the activities of the past six months, I find that, to some extent, we have deviated from our path.
('51', 192, 3, 12, 349229) Of late, I have been hearing from many quarters voices of swadeshi which are opposed to khadi.
('51', 192, 3, 13, 349324) Some regard themselves as having fulfilled their objective by claiming that they wear swadeshi, i.e., mill made cloth.
('51', 192, 3, 14, 349443) But, from the long range point of view, it will be seen that those who wear Indian mill made cloth and disdain khadi are in the long run harming both khadi and the Indian mills.
('51', 192, 3, 15, 349621) The reason is that without khadi boycott is impossible.
('51', 192, 3, 16, 349677) Here is the proof.
('51', 192, 3, 17, 349696) About 50 per cent of India’s requirements of cloth are imported from abroad.
('51', 192, 3, 18, 349773) Our Indian mills cannot meet this requirement within a short period.
('51', 192, 3, 19, 349842) This task can be accomplished by khadi alone, since our capacity to produce it depends solely on our keenness.
('51', 192, 3, 20, 349953) Just as we insist on making bhakharis (or cooking rice) ourselves and do not get them made or cooked in Indian or foreign factories, like wise, if we desire it, we can produce as much khadi as we need.
('51', 192, 3, 21, 350155) If this much is understood, it is easy to show why a disregard for khadi harms the cause of Indian (textile) mills.
('51', 192, 3, 22, 350271) The latter by themselves cannot make a success of the boycott.
('51', 192, 3, 23, 350334) Hence foreign cloth would enter into such fierce competition with Indian mills, that the latter could not but suffer a set back.
('51', 192, 3, 24, 350463) We have had this experience on many occasions be fore now.
('51', 192, 3, 25, 350522) Hence those who rest satisfied with thoughtlessly wearing Indian mill made cloth deceive themselves and harm the boycott move ment.
('51', 192, 3, 26, 350654) I hope, therefore, that
('51', 193, 0, 1, 350678) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 193, 1, 2, 350720) those who respond to the message of the Congress will use nothing but khadi.
('51', 193, 1, 3, 350797) Swadeshi for them means pure khadi.
('51', 193, 1, 4, 350833) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 3 1931

('51', 194, 1, 2, 351892) 263. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY
('51', 194, 2, 3, 351920) March 1, 1931
('51', 194, 3, 4, 351934) Mr. Gandhi came to see me this afternoon, and before he came I had, after very
('51', 194, 4, 5, 352013) careful examination of the various points raised, come to the conclusion that, apart
('51', 194, 5, 6, 352098) from minor and technical points, there were three main matters of principle on which,
('51', 194, 6, 7, 352184) so far as I could judge, accommodation was impossible.
('51', 194, 6, 8, 352239) These were : Picketing and
('51', 194, 7, 9, 352266) boycott; enquiries into police excesses; and salt.
('51', 194, 7, 10, 352317) I accordingly began the interview
('51', 194, 8, 11, 352351) with a firm determination on one point, which was that on no account must I allow
('51', 194, 9, 12, 352433) the break which I anticipated to come, as I felt certain Mr. Gandhi would try to
('51', 194, 10, 13, 352514) engineer it, on Police alone.
('51', 194, 10, 14, 352544) I accordingly began by taking Mr. Gandhi through the
('51', 194, 11, 15, 352597) memorandum I had sent him the previous day inviting him to let me know on what
('51', 194, 12, 16, 352676) points he was unable to agree with the Government attitude.
('51', 194, 12, 17, 352736) We soon came to a
('51', 194, 13, 18, 352754) stoppage over the question of boycott, and on this matter I, with his concurrence,
('51', 194, 14, 19, 352837) brought in the Home Secretary, Emerson, to deal more fully than I could with some
('51', 194, 15, 20, 352919) technical points.
('51', 194, 15, 21, 352937) After rather a wandering discussion the position emerged that Mr.
('51', 194, 16, 22, 353003) Gandhi was apparently willing to concentrate his claim and his energy upon the
('51', 194, 17, 23, 353082) business of substitution of Indian cloth and goods for foreign, giving up boycott of
('51', 194, 18, 24, 353167) British goods, and giving up boycott as a political weapon.
('51', 194, 18, 25, 353227) Merchants would be at
('51', 194, 19, 26, 353249) liberty to abrogate restrictive agreements, and no element of coercion would be
('51', 194, 20, 27, 353329) applied to them.
('51', 194, 21, 28, 353346) On picketing we had also a long talk in which we respectively re stated our
('51', 194, 22, 29, 353422) position, he saying that all he meant to do was perfectly peaceful picketing, which
('51', 194, 23, 30, 353506) was entirely permissible under the common law, I maintaining the view that,
('51', 194, 24, 31, 353582) whatever his common law rights and the persuasiveness of his logic, peaceful picke 
('51', 194, 25, 32, 353666) ting was a thing that in present circumstances just would not happen.
('51', 194, 25, 33, 353736) People were in
('51', 194, 26, 34, 353751) too excitable a temper for so simple and speedy a transition as he contemplated from
('51', 194, 27, 35, 353836) one sort of picketing to another to be possible.
('51', 194, 27, 36, 353885) He was very frank and said that he
('51', 194, 28, 37, 353920) had been discussing with the Congress Committee, and they were going to stop
('51', 194, 29, 38, 353997) picketing where it was not working smoothly, and was very emphatic that they could
('51', 194, 30, 39, 354080) get their orders obeyed in these matters.
('51', 194, 30, 40, 354122) We left the point at this stage for further
('51', 194, 31, 41, 354166) discussion in order to see how we got on on other things.
('51', 194, 32, 42, 354224) We then came to Police, in regard to which he said the formula in the memo 
('51', 194, 33, 43, 354300) randum was quite unsatisfactory, and he could not possibly accept it.
('51', 194, 33, 44, 354370) I said that I
('51', 194, 34, 45, 354384) appreciated that because, as I presumed, he would feel that however good the evidence
('51', 194, 35, 46, 354470) he might have to bring about particular cases, my formula left it open for local
('51', 195, 0, 1, 354551) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 195, 1, 2, 354593) Governments to refuse to enquire any further on the ground that they already had
('51', 195, 2, 3, 354674) the facts.
('51', 195, 2, 4, 354685) On the other hand, were I to admit his very justifiable point, it would mean
('51', 195, 3, 5, 354762) that I must either open the floodgates to enquiry, or something like it, in innumerable
('51', 195, 4, 6, 354850) cases all over India, wherever anybody wished to get back on the Police, or must
('51', 195, 5, 7, 354931) adopt the line of saying that he could select, say, three cases, which would inevitably
('51', 195, 6, 8, 355019) have the effect of suggesting to the world that these were three selected instances
('51', 195, 7, 9, 355103) typical of a generally prevailing state of police savagery.
('51', 195, 7, 10, 355163) I therefore told him that,
('51', 195, 8, 11, 355190) inasmuch as I could do neither of these things and inasmuch as we really wanted
('51', 195, 9, 12, 355270) peace, would not it be better to drop it altogether?
('51', 195, 9, 13, 355323) No formula that the wit of man
('51', 195, 10, 14, 355354) could devise would really be much good, or was indeed possible.
('51', 195, 10, 15, 355418) I should in fact be
('51', 195, 11, 16, 355438) pretending to give him something that I knew local Governments did not intend.
('51', 195, 12, 17, 355517) seemed a good deal impressed with this kind of line and, after some talk, said that he
('51', 195, 13, 18, 355604) had himself been thinking of dropping it.
('51', 195, 13, 19, 355646) We accordingly, after some further talk,
('51', 195, 14, 20, 355687) drafted a formula to the effect that he had had brought certain allegations to the notice
('51', 195, 15, 21, 355777) of Government, but that Government were unwilling to institute specific enquiries
('51', 195, 16, 22, 355859) because they didn’t think that this would help peace, and that, having regard to those
('51', 195, 17, 23, 355946) considerations, Mr. Gandhi did not press his demand.
('51', 195, 17, 24, 355999) He took the formula away, but I

('51', 195, 19, 26, 356105) We then passed to Salt, on which we covered ground over which we had been
('51', 195, 20, 27, 356179) before.

('51', 195, 21, 29, 356269) mainly vanity.
('51', 195, 21, 30, 356284) I told him that we could not condone publicly the breaches of law;
('51', 195, 22, 31, 356351) that would be to give too great encouragement to evil influences; nor could we in
('51', 195, 23, 32, 356433) present finanical circumstances sacrifice revenue by repealing it.

('51', 199, 0, 1, 363548) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 199, 1, 2, 363590) 266. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY
('51', 199, 2, 3, 363618) [March 3, 1931] 1
('51', 199, 3, 4, 363636) I saw Mr. Gandhi again yesterday.
('51', 199, 3, 5, 363670) Emerson was present at our discussions at Mr. Gandhi’s request.
('51', 199, 4, 6, 363734) We began with a few of the less important points, working up to the question of return of the land that had been sold to third parties.
('51', 199, 4, 7, 363870) He accepted the position of Government that if this was to be recovered for the original owners it must be a question of third parties doing it.
('51', 199, 4, 8, 364015) At the same time he said that it would be difficult in fact for this to get done unless Government officials were sympathetic.
('51', 199, 4, 9, 364142) I adhered to the position that the Government of India was debarred from putting pressure of any kind on the Government of Bombay, that the Government of Bombay would be very sticky about doing anything, but that they would be neutral in the matter, leaving third parties to do what they could.
('51', 199, 4, 10, 364437) He wasn’t at all happy about this, and said that Vallabhbhai Patel was frankly doubtful whether he could carry the settlement in Gujarat unless they got some accommodation of this question.
('51', 199, 4, 11, 364627) I told him however that it was not in my power to vary my position.
('51', 199, 5, 12, 364695) After clearing up the question of Additional Police in which we even tually agreed to treat the money question on the same logical basis as remission of fines (i.e., that moneys collected should not be refunded unless they were in excess of the amount required, but that moneys not collected should be washed out), we came on to boycott and picketing.
('51', 199, 5, 13, 365047) I pressed him very hard either (a) to give up picketing altogether on his own on the ground of disturbance and communal feeling; or (b) to accept an agreement with Government that there would be no picketing for a specified period.
('51', 199, 5, 14, 365279) He would not hear of either, assuring me with the utmost conviction that, if I would only trust his honour in this matter and the honour of Congress, there would be no picketing to which anybody could take objection.
('51', 199, 5, 15, 365496) All he desired to do was to return to the status quo before the civil disobedience movement was started.
('51', 199, 5, 16, 365601) There might be a little more picketing than was done before that movement began, because people had begun to think more constructively about swadeshi, but he could guarantee that there would be no interference or intimidation or the rest.
('51', 199, 5, 17, 365840) After much wrangling we came down to the boycott and picketing formula of the agreement.
('51', 199, 5, 18, 365929) I think it is not too bad.
('51', 199, 5, 19, 365956) It ties it up pretty tight, and pledges Congress at once to suspend it if there is any abuse.
('51', 199, 6, 20, 366050) We had no trouble about the Police formula.
('51', 199, 6, 21, 366094) He had made one or two verbal alterations that on the whole improved it from my point of view.
('51', 199, 6, 22, 366189) In the course of a short discussion we had about this, he revealed what I have by now discovered as the right method of dealing with him.
('51', 199, 6, 23, 366327) He said : “When you or Mr. Emerson use your best arguments it does not always have much effect on me, but, when you tell me that
('51', 199, 7, 24, 366456) 1 The report was prepared on March 4.
('51', 200, 0, 1, 366494) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 201
('51', 200, 1, 2, 366539) Government is in a difficulty and cannot do what I want, then I am inclined to capitulate to you”!
('51', 200, 1, 3, 366638) This was exactly the history of the Police discussion.
('51', 200, 2, 4, 366693) The last subject we tackled was Salt, on which he had had a discussion with Schuster in the morning and on which they had arrived at a working formula.
('51', 200, 2, 5, 366845) While our talks were proceeding the afternoon had been getting on, and it looked as if he was again going to have a race for his evening meal, which he cannot take after the sun has set.
('51', 200, 2, 6, 367032) I accordingly asked him what he would wish done about it.
('51', 200, 2, 7, 367090) It was eventually decided that Mirabai (Miss Slade) should bring it up here, which was done.
('51', 200, 2, 8, 367183) I was greatly interested in meeting her, of whom I had heard much.
('51', 200, 2, 9, 367250) She evidently venerates him very profoundly, and one felt one had suddenly been switched into a rather different world.
('51', 200, 3, 10, 367370) We could not finish all the matters for discussion, and I accordingly asked Gandhi to come back at 9 o’clock to get on with them as far as he could with Emerson, and I promised to look in and see how matters were progressing after finishing a dinner party.
('51', 200, 3, 11, 367627) Later Interview : 9 p.m.
('51', 200, 4, 12, 367652) I joined them again at 10.30 and found they had pretty well agreed to the statement in the form in which it now stands.
('51', 200, 4, 13, 367772) A good deal of verbal redrafting had to be done which took time, but the back of it was broken when we got the Police enquiry off and got agreement about withdrawal of the boycott of British goods.
('51', 200, 4, 14, 367970) We have given more than I like about Salt, but I don’t think we could have got away with much less.
('51', 200, 4, 15, 368070) We concluded, with the old man telling me that he was going to throw his whole heart and soul into trying to co operate in cons titution building, and that, while he felt greatly oppressed with the responsibility of decision, he prayed with all his heart that it might be successful.
('51', 200, 4, 16, 368354) I was impressed, as I have been throughout, with his sincerity.
('51', 200, 4, 17, 368418) He told me, in reply to a question, that he was quite firm about not re starting civil disobedience till the end of the conference discussions anyhow, and hoped never.

('51', 200, 7, 20, 368635) 267. LETTER TO VICEROY
('51', 200, 8, 21, 368658) 1 DARYAGANJ, DELHI, March 4, 1931
('51', 200, 9, 22, 368692) DEAR FRIEND, I write this letter in connection with the lands of civil resisters sold in Gujarat in respect of revenue dues.
('51', 200, 9, 23, 368817) Overworked as you are, it
('51', 200, 10, 24, 368843) 1 For Viceroy’s report to the Secretary of State on the outcome of the talks, vide “Viceroy’s cable to secretary of state”,4 3 1931.
('51', 201, 0, 1, 368976) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 201, 1, 2, 369018) is distressful to me to have to write to you on a matter which may appear to be trivial.
('51', 201, 1, 3, 369107) But I fear that on it hangs the successful working of the settlement just made.
('51', 201, 1, 4, 369187) With all the desire to give the fullest effect to the settlement, Sardar Vallabhbhai tells me that he will find it utterly impossible to implement the Congress obligation of the settlement unless the lands can be restored to the rightful holders.
('51', 201, 1, 5, 369434) I am well aware that as head of the Government of India you cannot by reason of a previous undertaking intervene in the matter, but as an English man interested in the successful working of a settlement built up by your patient and unwearied toil you can perhaps exercise your influence to see justice done and thereby assist its smooth working.
('51', 201, 1, 6, 369780) Shrimati Gangabehn, whose name I have already introduced to you in a previous communication and who has been working in the taluk of Borsad in Kaira District, tells me that the land in Ras, where or near which her social work was being done, was sold to the Dharalas for a song, and that it was bought by them at the instigation of the previous Mamlatdar and in collusion with him.
('51', 201, 1, 7, 370162) If there was proper enquiry I should undertake to prove the alleged collusion.
('51', 201, 1, 8, 370241) But I know that at the present moment I must not, so far as possible, whisper a word about the past.
('51', 201, 1, 9, 370342) That all the lands sold were sold for a song will, I think, be readily admitted.
('51', 201, 1, 10, 370423) To say the least it will be conceded that it was the height of unwisdom, on the part of local authorities, thus practically to give away the lands.
('51', 201, 1, 11, 370571) I therefore ask your assistance so far as it can be given in surmounting the difficulty.
('51', 201, 1, 12, 370660) It is in the confidence that you will do all that is possible to obtain the co operation of the Bombay Government in finding a solution which will restore peace that Sardar Vallabhbhai and I can allow the settlement to go through.
('51', 201, 3, 13, 370891) Yours, etc.,

('51', 201, 6, 16, 371008) Mr. Gandhi came up and had two or three hours’ talk with Emerson at 12 o’clock mainly about the detailed draft of the agreement we had reached and about the methods to be employed for its implementation.
('51', 201, 6, 17, 371212) I did not participate in these
('51', 201, 7, 18, 371243) 1 For Irwin’s views on this letter, vide the following item.

('51', 202, 1, 2, 371349) discussions, but saw him for a short time in the afternoon about a letter 1 he had written to me concerning the land in Gujarat.
('51', 202, 2, 3, 371478) The point of the letter was that unless I could give him an assurance that the land sold would at some time unspecified be returned to their original owners he could not go on with the settlement.
('51', 202, 2, 4, 371675) It had unhappily in his mind attained the importance of a moral scruple which outweighed everything else.
('51', 202, 2, 5, 371781) His trouble was that according to his information some land at Ras had been sold by a dishonest Mamlatdar improperly and unjustly to Dharalas.
('51', 202, 2, 6, 371924) This had been deliberately done according to his information in order to have revenge upon the Patidars, of whom the Dharalas are the natural enemies.
('51', 202, 2, 7, 372075) I told him, as I had repeatedly told him before, that I was under the most strict obligation to the Bombay Government to accept the position, as stated in our note that these transactions must, so far as the Government were concer ned, be regarded as final.
('51', 202, 2, 8, 372333) It was impossible for me, in justice to these undertakings, to put pressure on the Bombay Government in a matter on which I had assured them my support.
('51', 202, 2, 9, 372486) He recognized the force of this, but said that his difficulty must in some way be met.
('51', 202, 2, 10, 372573) I told him that I could not vary the position as stated above, nor could I agree, as he suggested, to omit any reference to land that had been sold from the statement of settlement.
('51', 202, 2, 11, 372755) To do this would inevitably carry the implication that the question was left open, and that Government had no fixed attitude in regard to it.
('51', 202, 2, 12, 372897) The utmost that I could do would be to write to Sir Frederick Sykes drawing
('51', 202, 3, 13, 372973) his attention to any statement on the matter that Mr. Gandhi cared to make to me, and ask him to give his personal attention to the task of finding an equitable solution.
('51', 202, 3, 14, 373144) This I was willing to do, though I was not sanguine of Sir Frederick Sykes being able to find a solution that would meet the case.
('51', 202, 3, 15, 373275) In any event it was highly unlikely that anything could be done at once.
('51', 202, 3, 16, 373348) What might be possible under different conditions when things had quieted down, might be another matter.
('51', 202, 3, 17, 373453) Mr. Gandhi said that he did not care about the time that elapsed before the question could be settled, but he felt so strongly that, without some settlement, the thing would remain an open sore in the Kaira District that he could never reconcile himself to it.
('51', 202, 4, 18, 373714) At this point we left it and I went to a Garden Party where I met Sapru, Jayakar, Sastri, Purshotamdas and Rahimtullah.
('51', 202, 4, 19, 373834) I told them of the difficulty and exhorted them to put their full pressure on Gandhi to save the settlement from being wrecked.
('51', 202, 5, 20, 373962) Sapru, Sastri and Jayakar came to see me at 10.30 p.m.
('51', 202, 5, 21, 374017) with alternative suggestions : (1) that we should omit the paragraph from the statement; (2) that we should insert the words “justly and lawfully sold” as a conditional limitation on non return of land sold.
('51', 202, 5, 22, 374225) I told them both these things were impossible, and finally after much discussion we came to the suggestion of the addition of a note 2 in the form it appears

('51', 203, 1, 4, 374632) to get Gandhi to accept it.
('51', 203, 1, 5, 374660) This he later did.
('51', 203, 1, 6, 374679) The impressions left on my mind by this incident were (1) that it is essential to give no more time for moral scruples to develop.
('51', 203, 1, 7, 374810) Clearly, though imponderable, they are very weighty; (2) that there may be a real grievance in the methods adopted for the sale of some land and, whether this is so or not, the position of the Dharalas owning coveted land in the midst of Patidar villages is not going to be a very happy one.
('51', 203, 1, 8, 375102) I should have supposed it might after two or three months have been possible for friendly arrangements to be made by which the Dharalas might be either bought out at satisfactory profit, or possibly assisted to buy land somewhere else, where it would not give rise to these acute difficulties.

('51', 204, 1, 2, 376678) 270. NOTES
('51', 204, 2, 3, 376689) SWARAJ IS SELF PURIFICATION It is a matter of great joy to me as it is I hope to the readers of Young India that numerous men and women took on the Motilal Shraddha Day 1 vows leading to self purification for the purpose of swaraj.
('51', 204, 2, 4, 376921) My faith in self purification tells me that these vows if carried out to the full will bring us many steps nearer our goal.
('51', 204, 2, 5, 377045) From the letters and information otherwise received I know that those who have taken vows include men and women, boys and girls drawn from all classes and all religious groups.
('51', 204, 2, 6, 377222) Of these Hindu, Mahomedan and Christian names have already come under my observa tions.
('51', 204, 2, 7, 377310) The vows are varied.
('51', 204, 2, 8, 377331) Some have vowed to observe brahmacharya, some to abstain from smoking, some to refrain from using any cloth but khadi.
('51', 204, 2, 9, 377450) The reader will not ask me or himself how these vows can possibly advance swaraj.
('51', 204, 2, 10, 377532) It is not a matter for demons tration through reason.
('51', 204, 2, 11, 377586) The experience of the world shows that wherever people have taken to purity of life there has been self rule, in other words swaraj.
('51', 204, 2, 12, 377719) And self rule by millions is swaraj of millions.
('51', 204, 2, 13, 377768) Any other is not swaraj but mirage.
('51', 204, 2, 14, 377804) The history of past twelve months is a progressive realiza tion of the fact that purification undertaken not merely for the purpose of individual peace but for the purpose of national happiness does result in promoting such happiness.
('51', 204, 2, 15, 378039) Happi ness here means an enlightened realiza tion of human dignity and a craving for human liberty which prizes itself above mere selfish satisfaction of personal comforts and material wants and would readily and joyfully sacrifice these for self preservation.
('51', 204, 2, 16, 378300) AM I SELF DELUDED?
('51', 204, 2, 17, 378319) A friend writes saying that I delude myself in believing that the boycott of foreign cloth has been attained largely through non violence.
('51', 204, 2, 18, 378458) I must deny the charge.
('51', 204, 2, 19, 378482) For I am not unaware of the violent spirit that has crept into our picketing.
('51', 204, 2, 20, 378560) In my opinion any contri bution made by violent picketing will be found to be not only transi tory but is likely to lead to reactions which we will all deplore.
('51', 204, 2, 21, 378721) There shall be no compulsion in matters of trade and the like’ is a sound maxim of conduct.
('51', 204, 2, 22, 378813) Picketing is valuable, even indispensable, aid to
('51', 204, 3, 23, 378863) 1 February 15, 1931; vide “Statement to the press”, 9 2 1931& “Speech on Motilal Day, Allahbad”, 15 2 1931.
('51', 205, 0, 1, 378971) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 205, 1, 2, 379013) conviction and conversion.
('51', 205, 1, 3, 379040) But a man who yields to threat or physical coercion resents it and simply awaits a suitable opportunity to revert to his original ways and resorts to reprisals when he is able to exact them.
('51', 205, 1, 4, 379231) I wish therefore that I could induce the reader to share my belief that every form of violence is harmful in the end and that we shall be able to assimilate only that much result of the past sufferings which was obtained without violence, i.e., through the voluntary sufferings of the people.
('51', 205, 1, 5, 379524) KUMARAPPA The reader I know will feel proud of the statement made by J. C. Kumarappa before the court.
('51', 205, 1, 6, 379627) Who that has read it can say that he did not deserve the punishment he received?
('51', 205, 1, 7, 379708) His was a pure and full sacrifice in more ways than one.
('51', 205, 1, 8, 379765) Young India, 5 3 1931
('51', 205, 2, 9, 379787) 271. WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON PROVISIONAL SETTLEMENT 1
('51', 205, 3, 10, 379849) March 5, 1931 The Working Committee having considered the terms of the provisional settlement 2 arrived at between the Government of India and Mahatma Gandhi on behalf of the Congress endorses them and directs all Congress Committees to take immediate action in accor dance with them.
('51', 205, 3, 11, 380134) The Committee hopes that the country will carry out the terms agreed to in so far as they relate to the various Congress activities, and is of opinion that on a strict fulfilment of the obligations undertaken on behalf of the Congress will depend the advance of India towards purna swaraj.

('51', 206, 1, 2, 380640) 272. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('51', 206, 2, 3, 380670) DELHI, March 5, 1931 In the first place, I would like to state that this settlement, such as it is, would have been impossible without the Viceroy’s inexhaustible patience and equally inexhaustible industry and unfailing courtesy.
('51', 206, 2, 4, 380901) I am aware that I must have, though quite unconsciously, given him causes for irritation.
('51', 206, 2, 5, 380991) I must have also tried his patience but I cannot recall an occasion when he allowed himself to be betrayed into irrita tion or impatience.
('51', 206, 2, 6, 381130) I must add that he was frank throughout these very delicate negotiations and I believe he was determined, if it was at all possible, to have a settlement.
('51', 206, 2, 7, 381285) I must confess that I approached the negotiations in fear and trembling.
('51', 206, 2, 8, 381358) I was also filled with distrust but at the very outset he disarmed my suspicions and put me at ease.
('51', 206, 2, 9, 381459) For myself, I can say without fear of contradiction that when I wrote my letter inviting the invitation to see him, I was determined not to be outdone in the race for reaching a settlement, if it could be reached at all honourably.
('51', 206, 2, 10, 381691) I am, therefore, thankful to the Almighty that the settlement was reached and the country has been spared, at least for the time being, and I hope for all time, the suffer ings which in the event of a breakdown would have been intensified a hundred fold.
('51', 206, 2, 11, 381946) For a settlement of this character, it is not possible nor wise to say which is the victorious party.
('51', 206, 2, 12, 382048) If there is any victory, I should say it belongs to both.
('51', 206, 2, 13, 382106) The Congress has never made any bid for victory.
('51', 206, 2, 14, 382155) In the very nature of things the Congress has a definite goal to reach and there can be no question of victory without reaching the goal.
('51', 206, 2, 15, 382293) I would, therefore, urge all my countrymen and all my sisters instead of feeling elated, if they find in the terms any cause for ela tion, to humble themselves before God and ask Him to give them strength and wisdom to pursue the course that their mission demands for the time being, whether it is by way of suffering or by way of patient negotiation, consultation and conference.
('51', 206, 2, 16, 382674) I hope, therefore, that the millions who have taken part in this struggle of suffering during the past twelve months will now, during
('51', 206, 3, 17, 382808) 1 This appeared as “Press Statement” on “the terms of truce to a gathering of American and Indian journalists and Pressmen”.
('51', 207, 0, 1, 382933) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 207, 1, 2, 382975) the period of conference and construction, show the same willingness, the same cohesion, the same effort and the same wisdom that they have in an eminent degree shown during what I would describe as a heroic period in the modern history of India.
('51', 207, 1, 3, 383222) But I know that, if there would be men and women who will feel elated by the settlement, there are, also those who will be, and are, keenly disappointed.
('51', 207, 1, 4, 383376) Heroic suffering is like the breath of their nostrils.
('51', 207, 1, 5, 383431) They rejoice in it as in nothing else.
('51', 207, 1, 6, 383470) They will endure unendurable sufferings, be they ever so prolonged, but when suffering ceases they feel their occupation gone and feel also that the goal has receded from the view.
('51', 207, 1, 7, 383651) To them I would only say, ‘Wait, watch, pray and hope.’ Suffering has its well defined limits.
('51', 207, 1, 8, 383746) Suffering can be both wise and unwise, and when the limit is reached, to prolong it would be not unwise but the height of folly.
('51', 207, 1, 9, 383875) It would be folly to go on suffering when the opponent makes it easy for you to enter into a discussion with him upon your long ings.
('51', 207, 1, 10, 384009) If a real opening is made, it is one’s duty to take advantage of it and, in my humble opinion, the settlement has made a real opening.
('51', 207, 1, 11, 384144) Such a settlement has necessarily to be provisional as this is.
('51', 207, 1, 12, 384208) The peace arrived at is conditional upon many other things happening.
('51', 207, 1, 13, 384278) The largest part of the written word is taken up with what may be called ‘Terms of Truce’.
('51', 207, 1, 14, 384369) This had to be naturally so.
('51', 207, 1, 15, 384398) Many things had to happen before the Congress could participate in the delibe rations of the Conference.
('51', 207, 1, 16, 384503) A recital of these was absolutely necessary.
('51', 207, 1, 17, 384548) But the goal of the Congress is not to get a redress of past wrongs important though they are: its goal is purna swaraj which, indiffe rently rendered in English, has been described as complete indepen dence.
('51', 207, 1, 18, 384757) It is India’s birthright, as it is of any other nation worthy of that name, and India cannot be satisfied with anything less and throughout the settlement one misses that enchanting word.
('51', 207, 1, 19, 384945) The clause which carefully hides that word is capable, and intentionally capable, of a double meaning.
('51', 207, 1, 20, 385048) Federation may be a mirage or it may mean a vital organic state in which the two limbs might work so as to strengthen the whole.
('51', 207, 1, 21, 385177) Responsibility, which is the second girder, may be a mere shadow or it may be tall, majestic, unbending and unbendable oak.
('51', 207, 1, 22, 385301) Safeguards in the interests of India may be purely illusory and so many ropes tying
('51', 208, 0, 1, 385385) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 209
('51', 208, 1, 2, 385430) the country hand and foot and strangling her by the neck, or they may be like so many fences protecting a tender plant requiring delicate care and attention.
('51', 208, 1, 3, 385588) One party may give one meaning and another may give the three girders the other meaning.
('51', 208, 1, 4, 385677) It is open under that clause to either party to work along its own lines and the Congress if it has shown readiness to take part in the deliberation of the Conference, it is because it seeks to make Federation, Responsibility, Safeguards, reser vations, or whatever other names they may be known by, such as would promote the real growth of the country along political, social, economic and moral lines.
('51', 208, 1, 5, 386081) If the Congress succeeds in making its position acceptable to the Conference, then, I claim that the fruit of that effort will be complete independence.
('51', 208, 1, 6, 386234) But I know that the way to it is weary.
('51', 208, 1, 7, 386274) There are many rocks, many pitfalls, to be found across the way.
('51', 208, 1, 8, 386339) But if Congressmen will approach the new task to which they are called, with confidence and courage, I have no misgivings about the result.
('51', 208, 1, 9, 386479) It is, therefore, in their hands either to make something noble and worth looking at out of the new opportunity that has come to them or, by lack of self confidence and want of courage, to fritter away the opportunity.
('51', 208, 1, 10, 386698) But I know that in this task Congressmen will require the aid of the other parties, the aid of the great Princes of India, and last but by no means the least the aid of Englishmen.
('51', 208, 1, 11, 386879) I need not make any appeal at the present juncture to the different parties.
('51', 208, 1, 12, 386956) I have little doubt that they are no less eager than Congressmen for the real freedom of their country.
('51', 208, 1, 13, 387060) But the Princes are a different proposition.
('51', 208, 1, 14, 387105) Their acceptance of the idea of Federation was certainly for me a surprise, but if they will become equal partners in Federated India, I venture to suggest that of their own free will they should advance towards the position that what is called British India has been all these long years seeking to occupy.
('51', 208, 1, 15, 387413) An undiluted autocracy, however benevolent it may be, and an undiluted democracy are an incompatible mixture bound to result in an explosion.
('51', 208, 1, 16, 387555) It is, therefore, I think, necessary for them not to take up an uncompromising attitude and impatiently refuse to listen to an appeal from or on behalf of the would be partner.
('51', 208, 1, 17, 387732) If they refused any such appeal they would make the position of the Congress untenable and, indeed, most awkward.
('51', 208, 1, 18, 387846) The Congress represents, or endeavours to represent, the whole of the people of India.
('51', 208, 1, 19, 387933) It recognizes no dis 
('51', 209, 0, 1, 387955) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 209, 1, 2, 387997) tinction between those who reside in British India or in Indian States.
('51', 209, 1, 3, 388069) The Congress has, with great wisdom and equally great restraint, refrained from interfering with the doings and affairs of the States and it has done so in order, not to unnecessarily wound the susceptibilities of the States, but, also, by reason of the self imposed restraint, to make its voice heard by the States on a suitable occasion.
('51', 209, 1, 4, 388409) I think that, that occasion has now arrived.
('51', 209, 1, 5, 388454) May I then hope that the great Princes will not shut their ears to the Congress appeal on behalf of the people of the States?
('51', 209, 1, 6, 388580) I would like to make a similar appeal to the English.
('51', 209, 1, 7, 388634) If India is to come to her own through conference and consultation, the goodwill and active help of Englishmen are absolutely necessary.
('51', 209, 1, 8, 388771) I must con fess, that what seems to have been yielded by them at the Conference in London is not even half enough—no approach to the goal that India has in view.
('51', 209, 1, 9, 388933) If they will render real help, they must be prepared to let India feel the same glow of freedom which they themselves would die in order to possess.
('51', 209, 1, 10, 389082) These 1 English statesmen would have to dare to let India wander away into the woods through errors.
('51', 209, 1, 11, 389183) Free dom is not worth having if it does not connote freedom to err and even to sin.
('51', 209, 1, 12, 389267) If God Almighty has given the humblest of His creatures the freedom to err, it passes my comprehension how human beings, be they ever so experienced and able, can delight in depriving other human beings of that precious right.
('51', 209, 1, 13, 389494) Anyway, the implication of inviting the Congress to join the Conference is most decidedly that the Congress may not be deterred from any consideration, save that of incapacity, from pressing for the fullest freedom.
('51', 209, 1, 14, 389710) And the Congress does not consider India to be a sickly child requiring nursing, outside help, and other props.
('51', 209, 1, 15, 389822) I would like also to register my appeal to the people of the great American Republic and the other nations of earth.
('51', 209, 1, 16, 389939) I know that this strug gle based as it is on truth and non violence from which, alas, we the votaries have on occasion undoubtedly strayed, has fired their imagination and excited their curiosity.
('51', 209, 1, 17, 390136) From curiosity they, and spe cially America, has progressed to tangible help in the way of sym pathy.
('51', 209, 1, 18, 390238) And I can say on behalf of the Congress and myself that we are all truly grateful for all that sympathy.
('51', 209, 1, 19, 390343) I hope that in the difficult mission in which the Congress is now about to embark, we shall not only retain their sympathy but that it will grow from day to day.
('51', 209, 2, 20, 390505) 1 The source has “There”.
('51', 210, 0, 1, 390531) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 211
('51', 210, 1, 2, 390576) venture to suggest, in all humility, that if India reaches her destiny through truth and non violence, she will have made no small contribution to the world peace for which all the nations of the earth are thirsting and she would also have, in that case, made some slight return for the help that those nations have been freely giving to her.
('51', 210, 1, 3, 390919) My last appeal is to the Police and the Civil Service departments.
('51', 210, 1, 4, 390986) The settlement contains a clause which indicates that I had asked for an inquiry into some of the police excesses which are alleged to have taken place.
('51', 210, 1, 5, 391139) The reason for waiving that inquiry is stated in the settlement it self.
('51', 210, 1, 6, 391212) The Civil Service is an integral part of the machinery which is kept going by the police department.
('51', 210, 1, 7, 391313) If they really feel that India is soon to become mistress in her own household and they are to serve her loyally and faithfully as her servants, it behoves them, even now, to make the people feel that when they have to deal with the members of the Civil Service and the police department, they are really dealing with their servants, honoured and wise undoubtedly, but nevertheless servants and not masters.
('51', 210, 1, 8, 391721) I owe a word to hundreds, if not thousands, of my erstwhile fellow prisoners on whose behalf I have been receiving wires and who will still be languishing in jails when satyagrahi prisoners who were jailed during the past 12 months will have been discharged.
('51', 210, 1, 9, 391980) Personally, I do not believe in imprisoning, by way of punish ment, even those who commit violence.
('51', 210, 1, 10, 392080) I know that those who have done violence through political motives are entitled to claim, if not the same wisdom, certainly the same spirit of love and self sacrifice that I would claim for myself.
('51', 210, 1, 11, 392278) And, therefore, if I could have justly sec ured their liberty in preference to my own or that of fellow satya grahis I should truthfully have secured it.
('51', 210, 1, 12, 392432) But I trust they will realize that I could not in justice ask for their discharge.
('51', 210, 1, 13, 392515) But that does not mean that I or the members of the Working Committee have not them in mind.
('51', 210, 1, 14, 392608) The Congress has embarked deliberately, though provisionally, on a career of co operation.
('51', 210, 1, 15, 392699) If congressmen honourably and fully implement the conditions applicable to them of the settlement, the Congress will obtain an irresistible prestige and would have inspired Government with confidence in its ability to ensure peace, as I think it has proved its ability to conduct disobedience.
('51', 210, 1, 16, 392993) And if the people in general will clothe the Congress with that power and prestige, I promise that it will not be long before every one of these political prisoners is discharged including the detenus, the Meerut prisoners and all the rest.
('51', 211, 0, 1, 393234) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 211, 1, 2, 393276) There is, no doubt, a small but active organization in India which would secure India’s liberty through violent action.
('51', 211, 1, 3, 393396) I appeal to that organization, as I have done before, to desist from its activities, if not yet out of conviction, then out of expedience.
('51', 211, 1, 4, 393535) They have perhaps somewhat realized what great power non violence has.
('51', 211, 1, 5, 393606) They will not deny that the almost miraculous mass awakening was possible only because of the mysterious and yet unfailing effect of non violence.
('51', 211, 1, 6, 393753) I want them to be patient, and give the Congress, or if they will, me, a chance to work out the plan of truth and non violence.
('51', 211, 1, 7, 393881) After all it is hardly yet a full year since the Dandi march.
('51', 211, 1, 8, 393943) One year in the life of an experiment affecting 300 millions of human beings is but a second in the cycle of time.
('51', 211, 1, 9, 394058) Let them wait yet awhile.
('51', 211, 1, 10, 394084) Let them preserve their precious lives for the service of the Motherland to which all will be presently called and let them give to the Congress an opportunity of securing the release of all the other political prisoners and maybe even rescuing from the gallows those who are condemned to them as being guilty of murder.
('51', 211, 1, 11, 394405) But I want to raise no false hopes.
('51', 211, 1, 12, 394441) I can only state publicly what is my own and the Congress aspiration.
('51', 211, 1, 13, 394511) It is for us to make the effort.
('51', 211, 1, 14, 394544) The result is always in God’s hands.
('51', 211, 1, 15, 394581) One personal note and I have done.
('51', 211, 1, 16, 394616) I believe that I put my whole soul into the effort to secure an honourable settlement.
('51', 211, 1, 17, 394703) I have pledged my word to Lord Irwin that in making good the terms of the settlement in so far as they bind the Congress, I should devote myself heart and soul to the task.
('51', 211, 1, 18, 394876) I worked for the settle ment, not in order to break it to pieces at the very first oppor tunity, but in order to strain every nerve to make absolutely final what today is provisional and to make it a precursor of the goal to attain which the Congress exists.
('51', 211, 1, 19, 395135) Lastly, I tender my thanks to all those who have been unceasing in their efforts in making the settlement possible.
('51', 211, 1, 20, 395251) Young India, 12 3 1931

('51', 212, 1, 2, 395319) 273. TELEGRAM TO PROVINCIAL CONGRESS COMMITTEES 1
('51', 212, 2, 3, 395369) 1 DARYAGANJ, March 5, 1931
('51', 212, 3, 4, 395396) IN VIEW PROVISIONAL SETTLEMENT ARRIVED AT BETWEEN WORKING COMMITTEE ON BEHALF CONGRESS AND GOVERNMENT OF INDIA REQUEST YOU TAKE IMMEDIATE STEPS INFORM ALL CONGRESS COMMITTEES YOUR PROVINCE TO ACT IN ACCORDANCE WITH IT.
('51', 212, 3, 5, 395615) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE AND NO TAX CAMPAIGNS TO BE DISCONTINUED AND NO FURTHER DEFIANCE OF LAWS OR REGULATIONS.
('51', 212, 3, 6, 395722) BOYCOTT OF BRITISH GOODS AS SUCH TO BE DISCONTINUED AND COMPLETE FREEDOM REGARDING THEM GIVEN BUT BOYCOTT OF INTOXICATING DRINK AND DRUGS AND OF ALL FOREIGN CLOTH AND LIQUOR SHOPS IS PER MITTED AND SHOULD BE CONTINUED WHEREVER NECESSARY.
('51', 212, 3, 7, 395960) SUCH PICKETING SHOULD BE UNAGGRESSIVE AND SHOULD NOT INVOLVE COERCION INTIMIDATION RESTRAINT HOSTILE DEMON STRATION OBSTRUCTION TO PUBLIC OR ANY OFFENCE UNDER ORDINARY LAW.
('51', 212, 3, 8, 396133) IF THESE CONDITIONS NOT SATISFIED IN ANY AREA PICKETING TO BE SUSPENDED THERE.
('51', 212, 3, 9, 396212) INSISTENCE ON SWADESHI GOODS IN PREFERENCE TO ALL FOREIGN GOODS ALSO TO BE CONTINUED.
('51', 212, 3, 10, 396298) NO ORGANIZED DISOBEDIENCE OF SALT LAWS AND NO RAIDS BUT VILLAGERS RESIDING IN AREAS WH ERE SALT COLLECTED OR MADE ARE PERMITTED TO CON TINUE TO COLLECT OR MAKE SALT FOR DOMESTIC CONSUMP TION OR SALE IN NEIGHBOURHOOD BUT NO SALE OR TRADING OUTSIDE.
('51', 212, 3, 11, 396546) UNAUTHORIZED NEWS SHEETS SHOULD BE STOPPED.
('51', 212, 3, 12, 396590) TAXPAYERS SHOULD PREPARE PAYMENT LAND REVENUE AND RETURN VILLAGES WHERE VACATED.
('51', 212, 3, 13, 396671) IN CASES ECONOMIC DISTRESS OR INABILITY PAYMENT OTHER METHODS FOR REMISSION OR SUSPENSION SHOULD BE ADOPTED.
('51', 212, 3, 14, 396780) IN VIEW PENDING RELEASE PRISONERS SPECIAL DIRECTIONS FOR ELECTION DELEGATES KARACHI CONGRESS BEING ISSUED PRESS.
('51', 212, 3, 15, 396893) SAYED MAHMUD GENERAL SECRETARY A.I.C.C. File No.

('51', 213, 16, 20, 397642) 277. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY March 5, 1931
('51', 213, 17, 21, 397684) I heard from Mr. Gandhi this morning saying that he was willing to accept the addition of the note as I had drafted it last night, and saying that, while he understood my commitments in the matter to the Bombay Government, he relied on me to use my
('51', 214, 0, 1, 397933) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 215
('51', 214, 1, 2, 397978) influence to secure a solution of the difficulty.
('51', 214, 1, 3, 398028) 1 I replied to him repeating the facts of my earlier undertaking on this particular subject given to the Bombay Government, but saying that, within the limits imposed on me by that undertaking I would certainly convey to the Governor what he said on the subject, and do everything that I properly might in the direction of asking him to address himself to the task of finding an equitable solution of the difficulty.

('51', 214, 5, 8, 398549) DEAR MR. CUNNINGHAM, I thank you for your two letters.
('51', 214, 5, 9, 398604) Pray convey my thanks to His Excellency for the prompt action he has taken on my letter 2 of the 4th instant regarding the sold lands.

('51', 215, 4, 11, 400612) 280. LETTER TO WALCHAND HIRACHAND 1
('51', 215, 5, 12, 400648) March 6, 1931
('51', 215, 6, 13, 400662) DEAR WALCHAND, I thank you for your letter.
('51', 215, 6, 14, 400706) In my opinion the meaning of the clause relating to boycott is absolutely clear.
('51', 215, 6, 15, 400787) The word boycott may be omitted for its origin, when it was first coined, or for its recent memories.
('51', 215, 6, 16, 400889) Let me then say that the exclusion of British in favour of Indian goods, Indian companies, shipping, insurance, etc., is not only permitted but favoured by the clause.
('51', 215, 6, 17, 401057) What is however a taboo under the clause is preference to non Indian foreign goods and foreign services over the British even irrespective of merits, a weapon the country used as a political lever with terrible effect during the civil
('51', 215, 7, 18, 401292) 1 In reply to his letter which read : “In today’s Government communique about the terms of settlement reference to boycott is made which requires, to my mind, to be cleared.
('51', 215, 7, 19, 401466) I understand it to mean that wherever an indigenous industry, commodity or service is available we are still justified in boycotting all non Indian items of such commodities or services even if they happened to be only British.
('51', 215, 7, 20, 401694) “To make my point clear, I will cite shipping and insurance on the coast.
('51', 215, 7, 21, 401768) There is only British shipping against Indian shipping.
('51', 215, 7, 22, 401824) I take it that the Indian shippers can not only boycott British shipping interests but you will expect them to boycott these in order to encourage Indian shipping.
('51', 215, 7, 23, 401988) The same can be said about Indian insurance companies and Indian cloth.
('51', 215, 7, 24, 402060) “I should be grateful if you will kindly let me have your views in detail and permit me to publish them.”
('51', 216, 0, 1, 402166) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 217
('51', 216, 1, 2, 402211) disobedience campaign.
('51', 216, 1, 3, 402234) If a permanent settlement is the aim of the provisional settlement, as it undoubtedly is, boycott or exclusion, by whatever name we call it, should cease whilst an attempt at perpetual friendship continues.
('51', 216, 1, 4, 402441) But preference for swadeshi over non swadeshi is, apart from political consequence which it may not have, a perma nent obligation which no nation can ignore without hurting its interests.
('51', 216, 2, 5, 402629) M. K. GANDHI The Tribune, 8 3 1931

('51', 217, 1, 2, 403275) 283. INTERVIEW TO S. HASAN ALI KHAN 1
('51', 217, 2, 3, 403313) March 6, 1931
('51', 217, 3, 4, 403327) In the course of the interview Mr. S. Hasan Ali Khan put a number of questions to which Mr. Gandhi gave prompt and satisfactory replies.
('51', 217, 4, 5, 403464) The first question naturally related to the settlement just arrived at between the Viceroy and Congress, and Mr. Gandhi expressed himself perfectly satisfied with the compact as it stands.
('51', 217, 5, 6, 403653) Q. What would be the position of zamindars in the coming Constitution?
('51', 217, 6, 7, 403724) A. They will have the same privileges and the same rights as at present.
('51', 217, 6, 8, 403797) Every justice will be extended both to the zamindars and the tenants, provided they go hand in hand with us.
('51', 217, 7, 9, 403906) You know the welfare of the country depends on agriculture and the agricul turists form the great bulk of the country.
('51', 217, 7, 10, 404025) In the course of the recent movement some of the young Congress workers have attempted to set the tenants against the land lords.
('51', 217, 7, 11, 404155) Further, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, in his presidential address at Lahore, expli citly expressed his views against the landlords of the country.
('51', 217, 7, 12, 404298) May I know what the significance of that statement is?
('51', 217, 7, 13, 404353) May I also know how Congress views the question concerning this important class of people?
('51', 217, 7, 14, 404444) Yes, I know that the country entirely depends on agriculture, which in turn depends on zamindars and tenants, the two chief factors of the country.
('51', 217, 7, 15, 404592) No such instruction was sent by the Working Committee.
('51', 217, 7, 16, 404647) We do not want that the tenants should stand against the zamindars.
('51', 217, 7, 17, 404715) I was present at the Lahore Congress session.
('51', 217, 7, 18, 404761) The late Pandit Motilal, myself and Pandit Jawaharlal drafted the resolution concerning the zamindars and ruling chiefs, which was only meant to establish democracy.
('51', 217, 7, 19, 404927) We never meant that there would be no room for the zamindars or for the so termed relics of the past.
('51', 217, 7, 20, 405029) As a matter of fact, we have every sympathy for the zamindars if they show a fair attitude towards the peasantry.
('51', 217, 7, 21, 405143) We assure the zamindars that their rights will be given due consideration in a swaraj constitution.
('51', 217, 7, 22, 405243) I appeal to them to be generous to the Congress.
('51', 217, 7, 23, 405292) The Pioneer, 16 3 1931
('51', 217, 8, 24, 405315) 1 Of the U. P. Zamindars’ Association
('51', 218, 0, 1, 405353) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 219
('51', 218, 1, 2, 405398) 284. INTERVIEW TO “KAISER I HIND” 1
('51', 218, 2, 3, 405434) DELHI, March 6, 1931
('51', 218, 3, 4, 405455) Mahatmaji gave me special interview yesterday in the course of which he paid a glowing tribute to the great services which the Kaiser i Hind and its proprietor,
('51', 218, 4, 5, 405616) Mr. Hirjibehedin, rendered to the national cause and expressed great admiration for the noble part which the Parsi community had played in effectively advancing the country’s fight for freedom.
('51', 218, 4, 6, 405810) Mahatmaji said : Kaiser i Hind khub seva bajavi.
('51', 218, 4, 7, 405859) [Kaiser i Hind had rendered great services.]
('51', 218, 5, 8, 405904) Gandhiji added that he was sure the services of Parsi ladies and gentlemen will be written with gold in the history of India, and he asked me to assure the community through the medium of your paper that he will not forget these services.
('51', 218, 6, 9, 406143) I told Mahatmaji that minority communities were clamouring for special rights and protection and that although there were three Parsis on the Round Table Conference none had pleaded the rights of Parsis; and I asked Mahatmaji whether he would advocate their rights as the Congress had decided to give all consideration to the rights of minorities.
('51', 218, 6, 10, 406491) Mahatmaji said that Parsis were so strong that they could take care of themselves, that if he said that he would champion their cause it would look like egotism.
('51', 218, 6, 11, 406653) Their case did not require special pleading and there was no necessity to remind him of not neglecting their interests.
('51', 218, 6, 12, 406773) He cannot ignore their claims and their services.
('51', 218, 7, 13, 406823) After reflecting carefully Gandhiji said : If it was shown to me that the Parsis had suffered any loss I will repay it with compound interest.
('51', 218, 8, 14, 406966) He gave me permission to convey this message to our beloved community.
('51', 218, 9, 15, 407037) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 3 1931
('51', 218, 10, 16, 407069) 1 Of Bombay; this was reported by the special representative on March 7.
('51', 219, 0, 1, 407142) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 219, 1, 2, 407184) 285. INTERVIEW TO JOURNALISTS 1
('51', 219, 2, 3, 407216) [March 6, 1931] 2
('51', 219, 3, 4, 407234) At exactly 11.30 this morning Mahatma Gandhi invited the various journalists, Indian as well as foreign, who have .
('51', 219, 3, 5, 407350) reporting the peace negotiations, to interview him for approximately an hour .
('51', 219, 3, 6, 407429) Q. You say that complete independence is an indifferent rendering for purna swaraj.
('51', 219, 3, 7, 407513) What then is the real meaning of purna swaraj?
('51', 219, 4, 8, 407560) A. Proper translation I cannot give you.
('51', 219, 4, 9, 407601) I do not know any word or phrase to answer it in the English language—I can, there fore, only give an explanation.
('51', 219, 4, 10, 407716) The root meaning of swaraj is self rule.‘Swaraj’ may, therefore, be rendered as disciplined rule from within and purna means ‘complete’.‘Independence’ has no such limitation.
('51', 219, 4, 11, 407891) Independence may mean licence to do as you like.
('51', 219, 4, 12, 407940) Swaraj is positive.
('51', 219, 4, 13, 407960) Independence is negative.
('51', 219, 4, 14, 407986) Purna swaraj does not exclude association with any nation, much less with England.
('51', 219, 4, 15, 408069) But it can only mean association for mutual benefit and at will.
('51', 219, 4, 16, 408134) Thus, there are countries which are said to be independent but which have no purna swaraj, e.g., Nepal.
('51', 219, 4, 17, 408238) The word swaraj is a sacred word, a Vedic word, meaning self rule and self restraint, and not freedom from all restraint which ‘independence’ often means.
('51', 219, 5, 18, 408393) Is the settlement consistent with the Lahore resolution?
('51', 219, 5, 19, 408450) It is, most decidedly.
('51', 219, 5, 20, 408473) There is nothing to prevent the Congress at Karachi from reaffirming the Lahore resolution, and there is nothing to prevent Congressmen from taking up that position at the forthcoming Round Table Conference.
('51', 219, 5, 21, 408681) In fact, I do not think I am betraying any confidence, when I say that I took good care to ascer tain that point and make the Congress position clear before approac hing the question of settlement.
('51', 219, 5, 22, 408879) I should feel bound to press for purna swaraj at the Conference and we should deny our very exis tence if we did not press for it.
('51', 219, 6, 23, 409010) What did you mean by ‘swaraj without the Empire if necessary’, as you used to say?
('51', 219, 7, 24, 409093) 1 This appeared under the title “The Settlement and Its Meaning” with an introductory note by Mahadev Desai given under the sub heading, “A Catechism”.
('51', 219, 7, 25, 409245) It read : “Questions are asked everywhere about the meaning and implications of the settlement, and it may be useful to present to the reader a catechism which is likely to satisfy many doubts and queries.
('51', 219, 7, 26, 409451) The answers are as nearly in Gandhiji’s language as possible.” 2 From Amrita Bazar Patrika, 10 3 1931
('51', 220, 0, 1, 409553) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 221
('51', 220, 1, 2, 409598) The Empire no longer remains, it having turned into a Commonwealth, and swaraj within the Commonwealth is perfectly possible.
('51', 220, 1, 3, 409724) We may be an independent state and yet form part of a Commonwealth, as the U.S.A.
('51', 220, 2, 4, 409806) Do you think the coming Federation will be like the U.S.A.?
('51', 220, 2, 5, 409866) Have you
('51', 220, 3, 6, 409875) received any guarantee as regards the composition of the Federation?
('51', 220, 3, 7, 409944) No guarantees.
('51', 220, 3, 8, 409959) But it can in no case be less than Dominion Status.
('51', 220, 4, 9, 410011) But how can you say that, having agreed to the safeguards?
('51', 220, 4, 10, 410070) I have agreed to no safeguards that are not in the interest of India.
('51', 220, 4, 11, 410140) The word has a bad odour, I know; it is a dangerous word.
('51', 220, 4, 12, 410198) But I can quite conceive of safeguards essentially in the interests of India.
('51', 220, 4, 13, 410276) The principle of safeguards in the Indian interest has undoubtedly been accepted but no specific safeguard has been accepted.
('51', 220, 4, 14, 410402) The safeguards of my conception are of a totally different character.
('51', 220, 4, 15, 410472) You will, therefore, see no mention even of transition in the clause.
('51', 220, 4, 16, 410542) They can never be burdens imposed from without.
('51', 220, 4, 17, 410590) They should be protec tive, that is, in the real interest of the country.
('51', 220, 4, 18, 410664) I cannot endorse safe guards which compromise the interests of India.
('51', 220, 5, 19, 410734) But you had the same thing presented to you in December 1929. Why should
('51', 220, 6, 20, 410807) we have gone in for this terrible suffering to get no further than the position of 1929?
('51', 220, 6, 21, 410896) You are making a great mistake.
('51', 220, 6, 22, 410928) It is not the same position.
('51', 220, 6, 23, 410957) Lord Irwin could or would then promise nothing.
('51', 220, 6, 24, 411005) He simply reitera ted the goal of Dominion Status.
('51', 220, 6, 25, 411056) Today Dominion Status is in words a certainty and it is within our power to make it as compre hensive as possible so as to mean complete independence.
('51', 220, 6, 26, 411207) In 1929 we had no knowledge of the attitude of the Indian members.
('51', 220, 6, 27, 411274) Today we know.
('51', 220, 7, 28, 411289) There seems to be a gulf of difference between the position at Lahore affirming
('51', 220, 8, 29, 411369) complete independence and the present parleys leading on to a settlement.
('51', 220, 8, 30, 411443) Even when I moved the Lahore resolution, I made it quite clear that independence need not mean complete dissociation from British connection.
('51', 220, 8, 31, 411585) If we had been fighting a violent war there might have been ruin for one or the other party.
('51', 220, 8, 32, 411678) But ours has been a non violent war presupposing compromise.
('51', 220, 8, 33, 411739) We have all the while assumed it, desired it.
('51', 220, 8, 34, 411785) My letter to Lord Irwin was conceived in that spirit.
('51', 220, 8, 35, 411839) The provisional compromise now makes an opening for us to go and ask for what we want.
('51', 220, 8, 36, 411926) As a satyagrahi it was my duty to seek for such an
('51', 221, 0, 1, 411977) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 221, 1, 2, 412019) opening.
('51', 221, 2, 3, 412028) You have said that you can conceive of safeguards which may be in the interest
('51', 221, 3, 4, 412107) of India.
('51', 221, 3, 5, 412117) Are the present safeguards such?
('51', 221, 3, 6, 412150) They are not.
('51', 221, 3, 7, 412164) They are an intolerable burden.
('51', 221, 3, 8, 412196) Englishmen may say they are in India’s interest.
('51', 221, 3, 9, 412245) But they have yet to convince me.
('51', 221, 4, 10, 412279) Would you be prepared to admit any safeguards in the future constitution?
('51', 221, 4, 11, 412353) Yes, those that may be reasonable and wise.
('51', 221, 4, 12, 412397) Take, for example, the question of minorities.
('51', 221, 4, 13, 412444) I can understand that we cannot achieve our purpose as a great nation if we do not regard the right of minorities as a sacred trust.
('51', 221, 4, 14, 412577) I should regard it as a legitimate safe guard.
('51', 221, 4, 15, 412624) Then, as regards Finance, if we have a public debt, it may need to be safeguarded.
('51', 221, 4, 16, 412707) The nature of such safeguard, I have not yet thought the thing out for myself.
('51', 221, 4, 17, 412786) As regards the army and the ser vices, I admit that we should guarantee the pay and fulfilment of any other condition that we may have undertaken, in connection with British officers and soldiers.
('51', 221, 4, 18, 412983) But we must determine whose services are necessary for the welfare of India and under what conditions as to pay, etc.
('51', 221, 5, 19, 413101) Will you repudiate India’s debts?
('51', 221, 5, 20, 413135) I will not repudiate one single farthing that can be legitimately debited to us.
('51', 221, 5, 21, 413216) But, unfortunately, there has been a great deal of con fusion about this talk of repudiation.
('51', 221, 5, 22, 413310) The Congress has never sought to repudiate a single rupee of the national obligation.
('51', 221, 5, 23, 413396) But what the Congress has asked for, and will insist upon, is proof of the justness of the obligation that might be sought to be imposed on the incoming Government, even as a buyer would like to know what obligation he has to undertake when entering on a new purchase.
('51', 221, 5, 24, 413665) The Congress has suggested that in case there can be no agreed adjustments, an inde pendent tribunal should be appointed.
('51', 221, 6, 25, 413787) Do you think the League of Nations a proper tribunal?
('51', 221, 6, 26, 413841) So far as I can say off hand, the League of Nations may be a proper tribunal, but, I do not know whether England would agree to get the question examined by the League, and I can well understand that hesitation.
('51', 221, 6, 27, 414053) Besides, the League of Nations may not undertake such a responsibility.
('51', 221, 6, 28, 414125) There should be no difficulty in securing an acceptable tribunal.
('51', 221, 7, 29, 414191) Will you press this question at the Round Table Conference?
('51', 222, 0, 1, 414251) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 223
('51', 222, 1, 2, 414296) It will be necessary to do so when the question of examination and acceptance of national obligations comes up.
('51', 222, 1, 3, 414408) We would express our views as to the items that should be borne by us.
('51', 222, 1, 4, 414479) But if England holds another view then the question of arbitration would arise and would be necessary.
('51', 222, 1, 5, 414582) What, therefore, we want is a proper audit.
('51', 222, 2, 6, 414626) Does this provisional settlement represent the practical application of the Sermon on the Mount as suggested by the Hindustan Times this morning?
('51', 222, 2, 7, 414772) I do not think I can judge.
('51', 222, 2, 8, 414800) It is for the critics to judge which principles have been applied by either party to the settlement.
('51', 222, 3, 9, 414901) What is your idea of ‘purna swaraj?’ Would it be possible within the British
('51', 222, 4, 10, 414978) Empire?
('51', 222, 4, 11, 414986) It would be possible but on terms of absolute equality.
('51', 222, 4, 12, 415042) Com plete independence may mean separation and popular imagination does understand it in that light.
('51', 222, 4, 13, 415143) But, if we remain part of the Commonwealth, on terms of absolute equality, instead of Downing Street being the centre of the Empire Delhi should be the centre.
('51', 222, 4, 14, 415303) India has a population of 300 millions and that is a factor that cannot be ignored.
('51', 222, 4, 15, 415387) Friends suggest that England will never be able to recon cile itself to that position.
('51', 222, 4, 16, 415474) But I do not despair.
('51', 222, 4, 17, 415496) The British are a practical people and as they love liberty for themselves, it is only a step further to desire the same liberty for others.
('51', 222, 4, 18, 415637) I know if the time comes to concede equality to India, they will say that that was what they had all along meant.
('51', 222, 4, 19, 415751) The British people have a faculty of self delusion as no other people have.
('51', 222, 4, 20, 415827) Yes, to my mind equality means the right to secede.
('51', 222, 5, 21, 415879) Would you like to have purna swaraj under the British flag?
('51', 222, 5, 22, 415939) There may be common flag or each party may have its own.
('51', 222, 5, 23, 415996) Young India, 19 3 1931

('51', 224, 8, 11, 417210) 290. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('51', 224, 9, 12, 417239) DELHI, March 7, 1931
('51', 224, 10, 13, 417260) DEAR MR. EMERSON, An urgent message from Ambala draws my attention to canton ment orders issued against persons suspected of sympathy with or assisting the Congress to leave cantonment limits and residents outside to enter those limits, and asks whether such persons are not protected by the settlement.
('51', 224, 10, 14, 417564) The telegram reminds me that there are such orders in many cantonments.
('51', 224, 10, 15, 417636) If it is clear to you, as it is to me, that such persons are protected by the settlement, will you please issue the necessary instructions?
('51', 224, 11, 16, 417776) A.I.C.C. File No.
('51', 224, 11, 17, 417794) 16 B, 1931. Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('51', 224, 12, 18, 417851) 1 In reply to his “private” letter (C.W. 9340) dated March 6 which read : “I want to write you a personal note of my own.
('51', 224, 12, 19, 417973) Very great thanks to you for all you have done, while we have been working together during these last difficult days.
('51', 224, 12, 20, 418091) It has been a great privilege to me to be given this opportunity of meeting and knowing you; and I hope that, either before I leave India or in England, you will give me the pleasure of seeing you again.
('51', 224, 12, 21, 418295) I do pray—as I believe—that history may say you and I were permitted to be instruments in doing something big for India and for humanity.
('51', 224, 12, 22, 418433) Believe me, with again much thanks, and with deep understanding, .

('51', 225, 1, 2, 418542) 291. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DELHI 1
('51', 225, 2, 3, 418581) March 7, 1931 Before I begin, I must tell you how much I miss Maulana Shau kat Ali here.
('51', 225, 2, 4, 418670) He arrived this morning and it is a matter of inex pressible sorrow to me that he should not be here, and I have no doubt you also will share my sorrow.
('51', 225, 2, 5, 418823) But I may assure you that I shall miss no opportunity, leave no stone unturned, to persuade the Maulana and other Mussalmans to work with us on the same platform.
('51', 225, 2, 6, 418986) It is a matter for shame that the ‘Big Brother’ with whom I travelled through the country for over two years and whom I took particular pleasure in describing as capable of carrying me in his pocket should not be here with me today.
('51', 225, 2, 7, 419219) But if it is a matter for shame, I do not know how far I am responsible for it.
('51', 225, 2, 8, 419299) I have spared no effort to remove that shame, but I have not succeeded.
('51', 225, 2, 9, 419371) In this there is nothing surprising, inasmuch as we find even blood brothers divided by sharp differences of opinion.
('51', 225, 2, 10, 419489) But our differences have not in the least affected our friendship.
('51', 225, 2, 11, 419556) I regard him, even today, as my friend and brother, and I have no doubt that he also has the same regard for me.
('51', 225, 2, 12, 419669) But that affords me little consolation, for I want him to work shoulder to shoulder with me for the welfare of India, and I want his co operation on my terms, as indeed he once used to give me.
('51', 225, 2, 13, 419863) But that work ceased to appeal to him at a certain stage and he left the Congress platform.
('51', 225, 2, 14, 419955) That preamble will give you an inkling of what I am about to say today.
('51', 225, 2, 15, 420027) The settlement that has been just arrived at will fail of effect without a real heart unity between Hindus and Mussalmans.
('51', 225, 2, 16, 420150) Without that unity our going to the Conference will be of no avail.
('51', 225, 2, 17, 420218) No one will pretend that the Conference can help us to achieve that unity.
('51', 225, 2, 18, 420293) A heart unity can be achieved between pure hearts purged of distrust and that can be achieved only outside the Conference.
('51', 225, 2, 19, 420416) In this I seek your co operation and ask you to count on my doing my utmost.
('51', 225, 2, 20, 420493) In a letter I received yesterday the correspondent asks me why I should not make the same advances to the Mussalmans as I did to the Viceroy.
('51', 225, 2, 21, 420635) Why, he asks, should I not wait on esteemed Mussalman friends who are desirous of unity and beg on bended knees for their
('51', 225, 3, 22, 420757) 1 This appeared under the title “Delhi Speech” with an introductory note by Mahadev Desai which read : “Addressing a mass meeting attended by over 50,000 people at Delhi on the 7th of March, Gandhiji delivered a speech in Hindi of which the following is a condensed rendering.”
('51', 226, 0, 1, 421035) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 227
('51', 226, 1, 2, 421080) co operation?
('51', 226, 1, 3, 421094) I like the suggestion and the correspondent may be sure that I shall leave nothing undone to plead with my Mussalman friends.
('51', 226, 1, 4, 421220) But you must understand that there are limits to the capacity of an individual, and the moment he flatters himself that he can undertake all tasks, God is there to humble his pride.
('51', 226, 1, 5, 421402) For myself, I am gifted with enough humility to look even to babes and sucklings for help.
('51', 226, 1, 6, 421493) And that reminds me that in this mission of mine I can count on the hearty and active co operation of my sisters who beat all previous records of suffering and sacrifice during the last heroic campaign.
('51', 226, 1, 7, 421696) To them I say : If you are convinced that Hindu Muslim unity is a sine qua non I ask you to use against your own countrymen the same weapon of satyagraha that you used so effectively against Govern ment.
('51', 226, 1, 8, 421900) Tell your men that you will non co operate with them, you will not cook for them, you will starve yourselves and them so long as they do not wash their hands of these dirty communal squabbles.
('51', 226, 1, 9, 422093) Assure me of your co operation, and you will add tremendously to my strength and to my power of pleading.
('51', 226, 1, 10, 422199) We Hindus are described, to a certain extent rightly, as the majority community.
('51', 226, 1, 11, 422280) Well, to them I would say the same thing as I used to do in 1921, viz., that voluntary surrender on the part of either community—preferably by the majority community—of all rights and privileges would immediately effect this unity.
('51', 226, 1, 12, 422512) It would be a great thing, a brave thing, for the Hindus to achieve this act of self denial.
('51', 226, 1, 13, 422605) Let them say to the Mussalmans: ‘Have as big a share of the spoils as you want; we will be content to serve you.’ What after all are the things you are quarrelling for?
('51', 226, 1, 14, 422774) Not indeed for air and water.
('51', 226, 1, 15, 422804) It is for seats on legislatures and local bodies.
('51', 226, 1, 16, 422854) What has the vast majority of you got to do with them?
('51', 226, 1, 17, 422909) How many of you can go there?
('51', 226, 1, 18, 422939) And what can you do there?
('51', 226, 1, 19, 422966) Outside the legislatures you did wonderful things; you defied the ordinances, you defied lathi charges and ‘firing’ orders, because you were conscious of your strength.
('51', 226, 1, 20, 423135) If you retain the same consciousness, what would it matter to you if your Parliament had all Mussalmans in it and no Hindu?
('51', 226, 1, 21, 423259) I am sick of these squabbles for seats, this scramble for the shadow of power.
('51', 226, 1, 22, 423338) How I wish I could bring home to all Congressmen that they should have nothing to do with these legislatures?
('51', 226, 1, 23, 423448) The very act of voluntary surrender will clothe you with a power undreamt of before.
('51', 226, 1, 24, 423533) And you my sisters, what would you do by going to the Parliament?
('51', 226, 1, 25, 423599) Do you aspire after collectorships, commissionerships or even the Viceroyalty?
('51', 226, 1, 26, 423678) And what would you do if one of you were to
('51', 227, 0, 1, 423722) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 227, 1, 2, 423764) be the Viceroy of India?
('51', 227, 1, 3, 423789) I know you would not care to, for the Viceroy has got to order executions and hangings—a thing you would heartily detest.
('51', 227, 1, 4, 423911) Supposing we, the ‘leaders’, were to run a race for getting the Viceroyalty, we would simply strangle ourselves.
('51', 227, 1, 5, 424024) That is not the prize we have set our hearts on.
('51', 227, 1, 6, 424073) We crave to be humble servants of the country.
('51', 227, 1, 7, 424120) It is this spirit of service which I want to permeate the atmosphere.
('51', 227, 1, 8, 424190) I want you to join me and share this aspira tion.
