('51', 227, 1, 10, 424357) I have no other secret but that of voluntary surrender.
('51', 227, 2, 11, 424413) ‘Where is peace?’ asks the nameless writer of this leaflet.‘The late Pandit Motilal thought of the Garhwalis on his death bed.
('51', 227, 2, 12, 424540) what have you done for them?’ that is another question that has been put to me.
('51', 227, 2, 13, 424620) Well, I may tell you that when on the last day of his presence on earth he referred to the Garhwalis only I was by his side, no one else, not even Jawaharlal.
('51', 227, 2, 14, 424779) I consider that as his last will and testament to me, as those were the last words I heard from him.
('51', 227, 2, 15, 424880) But I know, much better than you, what he was thinking of.
('51', 227, 2, 16, 424939) The writer subscribes himself ‘Young India’, but I may tell him that I am still the editor of Young India.
('51', 227, 2, 17, 425046) Let him who would oust me from the editorship come to me and I will tell him what Pandit Motilal was referring to.
('51', 227, 2, 18, 425161) You must remember that there were no ‘peace talks’ at that time, the peace ambassadors had not even arrived then, and the question of the freedom of Garhwalis could not be in the late Panditji’s mind.
('51', 227, 2, 19, 425362) He was asking whether the relations and dependants of the Garhwalis were being properly looked after.
('51', 227, 2, 20, 425464) The next question is about Bhagat Singh and others who are under sentence to death.
('51', 227, 2, 21, 425548) How can there be peace, I am asked, when a sentence of death is hanging over the heads of these patriots?
('51', 227, 2, 22, 425654) It is unfortunate that the young men distributing these pamphlets should not understand such a simple thing.
('51', 227, 2, 23, 425763) They ought to understand that we have entered into no peace treaty.
('51', 227, 2, 24, 425831) It is a provisional, temporary settle ment we have arrived at.
('51', 227, 2, 25, 425894) I beseech the young men not to bid good bye to common sense, to cool courage, to patience, to reason.
('51', 227, 2, 26, 425996) I have claimed to be a young man of 62. But even if I were to be labelled as a dilapidated old fogey, I have a right to appeal to your good sense.
('51', 227, 2, 27, 426143) I do not want you to take for granted all that old men say to you, but I
('51', 227, 3, 28, 426216) 1 At this stage a ‘red’ leaflet full of posers addressed to Gandhiji was handed to him.

('51', 228, 1, 2, 426349) want you to consider it and weigh it, and if you find that we ‘old’ men have bungled, that we have been guilty of weakness get us to abdicate, and assume the reins yourselves.
('51', 228, 1, 3, 426525) But that presupposes cool courage and solid common sense.
('51', 228, 1, 4, 426583) But let me tell you why Bhagat Singh and the rest have not been released.
('51', 228, 1, 5, 426657) Maybe, if you had been negotiating you might have secured better terms from the Viceroy, but we the Working Committee would secure no more than what we have.
('51', 228, 1, 6, 426815) I may tell you that throughout the negotiations I was not acting on my own, I was backed by the whole Working Committee.
('51', 228, 1, 7, 426936) We brought all the presssure we could to bear on our negotiations and satisfied ourselves with what in justice we could have under the provisional settlement.
('51', 228, 1, 8, 427095) We could not as negotiators of the provisional truce forget our pledge of truth and non violence, forget the bounds of justice.
('51', 228, 1, 9, 427223) But it is still open to us to secure the release of all you have named—and that can be done if you will implement the settlement.
('51', 228, 1, 10, 427353) Let ‘Young India’ stand by the settlement and fulfil all its conditions, and if, God willing, Bhagat Singh and others are alive when we have arrived at the proper stage, they would not only be saved from the gallows but released.
('51', 228, 1, 11, 427583) But I will address to ‘Young India’ a word of warning.
('51', 228, 1, 12, 427638) These things are sooner asked for than obtained.
('51', 228, 1, 13, 427687) You want to secure the freedom of those condemned of violence.
('51', 228, 1, 14, 427750) There is nothing wrong about it.
('51', 228, 1, 15, 427783) My creed of non violence does not favour the punishment of thieves and dacoits and even murderers.
('51', 228, 1, 16, 427882) I cannot in all conscience agree to anyone being sent to the gallows, much less a brave man like Bhagat Singh.
('51', 228, 1, 17, 427993) But I tell you, even you could not save them unless you fulfil the condi tions of the settlement.
('51', 228, 1, 18, 428091) You cannot do so by violent means.
('51', 228, 1, 19, 428126) If you pin your faith to violence, take it from me that you will not only not secure Bhagat Singh’s release but will have to sacrifice thousands of Bhagat Singhs.
('51', 228, 1, 20, 428289) I was not prepared to do so, and hence I preferred the way of peace, of non violence.
('51', 228, 1, 21, 428375) The way that you have adopted has been on trial for centuries and history records numerous instances of the truth that those who use the sword shall perish by the sword.
('51', 228, 1, 22, 428545) You will not stop at using the violent weapon against your rulers, you will use it against your brothers and sisters too, and others of your way of thinking will use it against you.
('51', 228, 1, 23, 428727) I beseech you then, if you want the release of the prisoners, to change your methods, to accept the settlement, and then come and ask
('51', 229, 0, 1, 428861) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 229, 1, 2, 428903) me about the Garhwalis and Bhagat Singh.
('51', 229, 1, 3, 428944) Come to me six months hence, after you have implemented the settlement and gained in strength, and ask me the question you are asking today and I promise to satisfy you.
('51', 229, 1, 4, 429114) Having suspended civil disobedience we now enter a period of disciplined obedience.
('51', 229, 1, 5, 429198) We are now pledged to eschew all passive and active violence, direct and indirect violence in picketing foreign cloth and liquor shops, but we are further pledged to relax our boycott of British goods minus British cloth.
('51', 229, 1, 6, 429420) The settlement is an attempt at re establishing friendly relations and it therefore means that we must lay down all weapons of punishment.
('51', 229, 1, 7, 429559) Boycott of British goods was conceived, essentially, as a weapon of punishment and has, therefore, to be suspended.
('51', 229, 1, 8, 429675) But we have to go ahead, even more energetically with the constructive programme, i.e., boycott of foreign cloth and liquor, the programme which means the economic and moral salvation of our poor starving millions.
('51', 229, 1, 9, 429890) I must also explain that the relaxation of the boycott of British goods does not mean that we should prefer British goods to Indian goods.
('51', 229, 1, 10, 430029) Indian goods you will prefer to all foreign goods for all time.
('51', 229, 1, 11, 430093) Under the settlement you are pledged not to direct the weapon of punishment against the Britisher and accord a favoured treatment to other foreigners.
('51', 229, 1, 12, 430244) And even that condition does not bind you to prefer British goods to other foreign goods; it binds you not to pursue the policy of aggressive boycott that you did heretofore.
('51', 229, 1, 13, 430419) The boycott of foreign cloth and liquor, as I have said before, should not be relaxed, cannot be relaxed.
('51', 229, 1, 14, 430525) It is our permanent progra mme; but it should be purged of all its aggressive forms, e.g., social boycott, and persecution of the seller and the consumer.
('51', 229, 1, 15, 430680) If you say boycott without these elements will lose all its edge, I will tell you that it argues want of faith in the efficacy of non violence.
('51', 229, 1, 16, 430824) Work achieved through aggressive picketing will be of doubtful worth, work achieved through loving persuasive pressure will be lasting.
('51', 229, 1, 17, 430960) I ask you therefore to plead with the foreign cloth seller and liquor seller to give up dealing in foreign cloth and liquor and take to some more honourable and cleaner calling.
('51', 229, 1, 18, 431138) As to the constructive part of foreign cloth boycott I want you to understand that it is impossible to achieve it without khadi.
('51', 229, 1, 19, 431267) Mill cloth is for those whom the Congress has not been able to reach; for Congressmen there can be no cloth other than khadi.
('51', 229, 1, 20, 431393) It is a pity that where a few months ago there were thousands
('51', 230, 0, 1, 431455) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 231
('51', 230, 1, 2, 431500) of taklis working, they should now be conspicuous by their absence.
('51', 230, 1, 3, 431568) The period that follows should be one entirely devoted to constructive efforts.
('51', 230, 1, 4, 431648) In conclusion, I would beseech you to realize the supreme importance of discipline.
('51', 230, 1, 5, 431732) It is open to you to press for a different policy and different programme at Karachi.
('51', 230, 1, 6, 431818) But let it not be said that we are a people incapable of maintaining discipline.
('51', 230, 1, 7, 431899) Indiscipline wil mean disaster, and make one like me who is pining to see swaraj in his lifetime perish in sorrow and grief.
('51', 230, 1, 8, 432024) It is my earnest prayer that God may give you the power to appreciate what I have said and to attain swaraj by pursuing the path of truth, justice and non violence.

('51', 234, 7, 9, 436685) 301. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS March 11, 1931
('51', 234, 8, 10, 436728) Interviewed on Mr. Baldwin’s decision about the non participation of the Conservative Party in the Indian sessions of the Round Table Conference, Mr. Gandhi said : Mr. Baldwin’s statement does not come upon me as a sur prise.
('51', 234, 8, 11, 436954) I must say that the Congress position is unequivocal and quite simple.
('51', 234, 8, 12, 437025) The Congress is out to win purna swaraj at the earliest possible moment.
('51', 234, 8, 13, 437098) It will, therefore, look with grave suspicion upon any dilatory tactics The Conservative fears about the so called safeguards are justified.
('51', 234, 8, 14, 437239) The Congress would accept no safeguard which is not clearly proved to be in the interest of India, and those that were discussed in London were certainly not in India’s interest.
('51', 234, 8, 15, 437418) On questions of vital importance to India equivocation would be a dangerous pastime.
('51', 234, 8, 16, 437503) If the Congress is represented at the Round Table Conference it will do so with the clearest conscience and with all cards laid on the table I therefore welcome Mr. Baldwin’s statement of Conservative policy.
('51', 234, 8, 17, 437712) It will lead the Congress to understand the forces that will be arrayed against it.

('51', 235, 1, 2, 437922) 302. SPEECH TO VOLUNTEERS, AHMEDABAD 1
('51', 235, 2, 3, 437961) March 11, 1931 Addressing a small gathering of men and women volunteers this morning, Gandhiji explained the principles of the new programme.
('51', 235, 2, 4, 438103) At the outset, he congratulated the volunteers on their work and said that though the lady volunteers were less in number, their share was greater.
('51', 235, 2, 5, 438251) Very few believed and the outside world did not at all believe that so many lady volunteers would come forward to go to jail cheerfully and undergo beating.
('51', 235, 2, 6, 438408) The world was greatly impressed.
('51', 235, 2, 7, 438441) It was not to be supposed that they (volun teers) made no mistakes.
('51', 235, 2, 8, 438509) No man was perfect, but on the whole Gandhiji felt that their virtues outnumbered their defects.
('51', 235, 2, 9, 438606) Speaking about the future programme, Gandhiji said it involved greater responsi bility and had to be prosecuted in a calmer atmosphere.
('51', 235, 2, 10, 438742) Those who needed external enthusiasm would find it dry.
('51', 235, 2, 11, 438798) Peaceful picketing meant that even a harsh word could not be used.
('51', 235, 2, 12, 438865) Such great work could not be expected to yield fruit instantaneously like the magician’s mango tree.
('51', 235, 2, 13, 438966) They should not lose interest in the future work of picketing.
('51', 235, 2, 14, 439029) They should decide how far that work should be done by men and women together.
('51', 235, 2, 15, 439108) Mahatma Gandhi desired that women alone should do that work.
('51', 235, 2, 16, 439169) The atmosphere would thereby be elevated.
('51', 235, 2, 17, 439211) Women might take the help of men in the work of organization, etc., but picketing should be their special work.
('51', 235, 2, 18, 439323) The rest of the men should take to production of khaddar without which the boycott of foreign cloth was impossible.
('51', 235, 2, 19, 439439) Concluding, Gandhiji said that volunteers might be paid a subsistence allowance, but their dignity should be greater than that of the Indian Civil Service.
('51', 235, 3, 20, 439595) Searching questions were then put to Gandhiji regarding the boycott of British goods.
('51', 235, 3, 21, 439681) Gandhiji said they could not whip a man for all time.
('51', 235, 3, 22, 439735) They should lay aside the whip, when they were carrying on negotiations for settlement.
('51', 235, 3, 23, 439823) Boycott of British goods was a form of punishing the British people, but if the British befriended them and gave them complete swaraj, they might prefer British goods.
('51', 235, 3, 24, 439991) One should buy goods from a friend.
('51', 235, 4, 25, 440027) Asked what those who had taken pledges of boycott of British goods should do, Gandhiji replied that they could not take a pledge to give two stripes to an individual every day.
('51', 235, 5, 26, 440204) Questioned if they could enter Government colleges, Gandhiji replied in the negative and said they could do so after the final settlement.
('51', 235, 6, 27, 440343) In reply to a question regarding the discipline that volunteers should follow in camps, Gandhiji said they should not tell lies, abuse, smoke or eat sweets.
('51', 235, 6, 28, 440500) When asked if they could drink tea Gandhiji humorously replied that they could drink tea from the river Sabarmati.

('51', 236, 1, 2, 440726) 303. SPEECH TO LABOUR UNION, AHMEDABAD 1
('51', 236, 2, 3, 440767) March 11, 1931 As I think of you may heart goes out for you and I pray to God that the bond of affection between us may be stronger and that you may realize that there is no difference of any kind between you and me.
('51', 236, 2, 4, 440984) I go about among mill owners, I accept their hospitality, but my heart is always with you.
('51', 236, 2, 5, 441075) It is my fervent prayer to God that He may never separate me from you, and that I may lay down my life in the service of the poor.
('51', 236, 2, 6, 441206) You have in your statement rightly said that the swaraj of my dream is the poor man’s swaraj.
('51', 236, 2, 7, 441300) The necessaries of life should be enjoyed by you in common with those enjoyed by the princes and moneyed men.
('51', 236, 2, 8, 441410) But that does not mean that you should have palaces like theirs.
('51', 236, 2, 9, 441475) They are not necessary for happiness, you or I would be lost in them.
('51', 236, 2, 10, 441545) But, you ought to get all the ordinary amenities of life that a rich man enjoys.
('51', 236, 2, 11, 441626) I have not the slightest doubt that swaraj is not purna swaraj until these amenities are guaranteed to you under it.
('51', 236, 2, 12, 441743) I do not know when we will win it but we have all to strive for it.
('51', 236, 2, 13, 441811) Your work is making you known throughout the world.
('51', 236, 2, 14, 441863) Students from the West marvel at the beauty of your organization and try to make a study of it.
('51', 236, 2, 15, 441959) Your Union strikes them as unique.
('51', 236, 2, 16, 441994) The members of your Union are jealous of their rights, and are prepared to lay down their lives for them, but their leaders, who guide them, have no ill will against the capitalists.
('51', 236, 2, 17, 442177) In their welfare and their power you see your own welfare and power.
('51', 236, 2, 18, 442246) That is the secret of your strength.
('51', 236, 2, 19, 442283) Outside people cannot understand your position.
('51', 236, 2, 20, 442331) They have thought of capitalists and working men as exploiters and exploited.
('51', 236, 2, 21, 442409) All capitalists, according to some, are born ogres.
('51', 236, 2, 22, 442461) But there need be no such inherent antipathy between the two.
('51', 236, 2, 23, 442523) It is an erroneous notion.
('51', 236, 2, 24, 442550) If the capitalists are apt to be proud of their wealth, the working men are apt to be proud of their numerical strength.
('51', 236, 2, 25, 442671) We are liable to be swayed and intoxicated by the same passion as the capitalists, and it must be our prayer that both may be free from that passion.
('51', 236, 2, 26, 442821) I feel that no class war poisons the relations between the mill owners and the working men in Ahmedabad.
('51', 236, 2, 27, 442926) I hope and pray, that the present cordial relations may be maintained between them.
('51', 236, 3, 28, 443010) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('51', 237, 0, 1, 443059) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 238
('51', 237, 1, 2, 443101) But the secret of your success is that the men and women, who guide you, have no axes to grind.
('51', 237, 1, 3, 443197) They have no base interest to serve.
('51', 237, 1, 4, 443234) It is the beauty of this organization, moreover, that made it possi ble for the Union to take an active part in the civil disobedience move ment.165 members of the Union took part as volunteers in the Dharasana Raid, and 191 went to jail as volunteers or pickets.
('51', 237, 1, 5, 443498) It is a record of which any union may be proud.

('51', 237, 2, 7, 443569) 304. HOW TO DO IT
('51', 237, 3, 8, 443587) The reader will find in this week’s issue the text of the provisional settlement 1, my Press statement 2, the reprint of my cross examination by the Press correspondents 3 and some of my speeches 4 which I hold to be important for the sake of understanding the settlement.
('51', 237, 3, 9, 443860) I am sure, the reader will appreciate the reprint, if only, for the sake of ready reference.
('51', 237, 3, 10, 443953) My statement,cross examination and speeches have been carefully revised by Mahadev Desai.
('51', 237, 3, 11, 444043) Those who will read the reprints with attention will not fail to discover that, if the last twelve months’ heroic and hurricane campaign has brought us the hope of early attainment of swaraj, the cent per cent observance of the conditions of the settlement to be fulfilled by the nation will make the Congress an irresistible power for vindicating the national position.
('51', 237, 3, 12, 444414) By our future conduct shall our immediate past be judged.
('51', 237, 3, 13, 444472) Even if we have understood non violence as the best policy, we shall now realize that whilst the truce lasts, it is obligatory on us meti culously to respect the laws and orders thereunder.
('51', 237, 3, 14, 444662) I dare say, we shall find it sometimes difficult to carry out orders which to us may appear capricious.
('51', 237, 3, 15, 444766) We need not expect a change of heart in the official world all of a sudden.
('51', 237, 3, 16, 444842) If, therefore, we are conscious of our strength and our ability to resume civil disobedience, whenever it becomes necessary, we should find no difficulty in obeying even irksome orders.
('51', 237, 3, 17, 445028) The greatest difficulty, however, consists in duly observing the limits of picketing.
('51', 237, 3, 18, 445114) I would like all Congress organizations to bear in mind that it is profitable for foreign cloth or liquor and drugs to be sold, now that picketing has to be unaggressive, rather then that there
('51', 237, 4, 19, 445308) 1 Vide “provisional settlement”, 12 3 1931. 2 Vide “Statement to th press”, 5 3 1931. 3 Vide “Interview to journalists”, 6 3 1931. 4 Vide “Speech at public meeting, Delhi”, 7 3 1931.
('51', 238, 0, 1, 445491) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 239
('51', 238, 1, 2, 445536) should be any aggressive picketing smelling of violence in any shape or form.
('51', 238, 1, 3, 445614) Picketing under the settlement has to confine itself to pure educative effort.
('51', 238, 1, 4, 445693) Every conversion brought about by educative effort must lead to permanent result.
('51', 238, 1, 5, 445775) I have no doubt that in the long run unaggressive picketing will be found to be far more effective and the shorter method.
('51', 238, 1, 6, 445898) Such picketing should not mean any undue restraint upon the seller or the consumer.
('51', 238, 1, 7, 445982) After the picketer’s appeal, the seller or the consumer must be free to sell or buy, as the case may be.
('51', 238, 1, 8, 446087) There should be no social boycott, such as, stopping barber’s services, cutting off the water or food supply.
('51', 238, 1, 9, 446197) But we are not obliged to deal with or receive services from those whose conduct we may disapprove.
('51', 238, 1, 10, 446297) Thus, we may refuse to attend the social functions of one who has turned a deaf ear to public opinion or to have dealings with him even in matters other than his business of a seller of foreign cloth or drink and drugs.
('51', 238, 1, 11, 446517) The golden rule is to err on the safe side, i.e., not to do the thing about which there is the slightest doubt.
('51', 238, 1, 12, 446629) It should be borne in mind that whenever there is a clash between the dealer and the pickets, picketing has to be suspended.
('51', 238, 1, 13, 446754) This clash can be avoided if we are gentle in our dealings with the sellers or consumers.
('51', 238, 1, 14, 446844) It will be found on experience that unaggressive picketing will have to be done more in respect of the consumer than the seller.
('51', 238, 1, 15, 446973) In other words, it means Congress penetration into villages.
('51', 238, 1, 16, 447034) After all real service has to be rendered there than in the cities.
('51', 238, 1, 17, 447102) The other most important thing is communal unity.
('51', 238, 1, 18, 447152) It demands urgent attention.
('51', 238, 1, 19, 447181) Without it, it would be vain at least for the Congress to attend the Conference and expect great results.
('51', 238, 1, 20, 447287) How this unity is to be achieved I have shown in the Delhi speech printed elsewhere.
('51', 238, 1, 21, 447372) The tangle can be loosened only by Hindus daring to trust and being content with the remainder left over after the minority have satisfied themselves.

('51', 238, 2, 23, 447546) 305. “YOUNG INDIA” It is possible again to resume publication of Young India under the law.
('51', 238, 2, 24, 447638) The typed sheets were issued t show that possible to distri bute several thousand copies among the readers even in spite of the prohibitive law called Ordinances.The moment however was decl aredthese sheets were discontinued.Fortunately discontinuance only meant a delay of a couple of days in bringing out the printed issue.
('51', 238, 2, 25, 447964) The reader did not know how it was possible to distribute seven thousand copies of Young India sheets and ten thousand of Navajivan
('51', 239, 0, 1, 448096) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 240
('51', 239, 1, 2, 448138) week after week.
('51', 239, 1, 3, 448155) But he will be proud to know that this was possible only because of the willing, brave and self sacrificing help of the old Young India and Navajivan staff who worked for less pay and numerous other volunteers.
('51', 239, 1, 4, 448366) Both the publications cost over two thousand rupees monthly.
('51', 239, 1, 5, 448427) The sheets were sent free of charge as owing to the Ordinance the subs criptions might be confiscated.
('51', 239, 1, 6, 448530) This was done in the hope that when the papers resumed normal publication the generous subscribers would make it a point of honour to pay their arrears of subscriptions.
('51', 239, 1, 7, 448700) This hope, I doubt not, will be realized and from now the arrears will pour in.
('51', 239, 1, 8, 448780) For a few weeks the paper will continue to be sent to the subscribers after which the despatch will discontinue in respect of those who may be in arrears.
('51', 239, 1, 9, 448935) Here I take thankful note of the fact that many subscribers, whom it was impossible to serve, never, in spite of the offer made by the management,asked for a refund of the balance of their paid subscrip tions.
('51', 239, 1, 10, 449145) These will now receive their paper without further payment till the balance is exhausted.
('51', 239, 1, 11, 449235) Last, but not least, to be thanked is J. C. Kumarappa, who, after my imprisonment, added to his ordinary duty the onerous one of editing the paper.
('51', 239, 1, 12, 449383) To him and all the staff and volunteers my thanks are due.
('51', 239, 1, 13, 449442) I hope that the public will join me in the tangible manner they can, namely, by patronizing Young India and what is more fulfilling the mission for which Young India stands.
('51', 239, 1, 14, 449616) The readers know that Young India and Navajivan do not exist for a commercial purpose.
('51', 239, 1, 15, 449703) They are published for the sole purpose of educating the nation to win purna swaraj through truthful and non violent means.

('51', 240, 5, 18, 451257) 307. SPEECH AT BORSAD March 12, 1931 Instead of killing and getting killed, we have accepted the principle of seeking justice by laying down our lives and you, it may be said, have observed that principle to a large extent.
('51', 240, 5, 19, 451481) It is not that there was no anger in you.
('51', 240, 5, 20, 451523) But you Patidars of Kheda and others who are well known for their fiery tempers, who are given to drawing their swords at the slightest provocation and who are a fervent, vigorous people, deserve to be congratulated on having courageously put up with everything.
('51', 240, 5, 21, 451786) The fact that you young men sat quiet while in the by lanes of Borsad women were being beaten with sticks, kicked and subjected to indignities is something that is incredible.
('51', 240, 5, 22, 451962) But you allowed the women to be beaten and did not raise your little finger even in their defence.
('51', 240, 5, 23, 452061) If this had happened in other circumstances, those who had allowed women to be beaten would have been called cowards.
('51', 240, 5, 24, 452179) However, who would use this word with reference to the young men of Borsad?
('51', 240, 5, 25, 452255) The reason was that all of you were bound by your pledge.
('51', 240, 5, 26, 452313) It was your pledge not to use violence on the Government’s men who had harassed you in various ways.
('51', 240, 5, 27, 452414) You were pledge bound like Bhima and Arjuna.
('51', 240, 5, 28, 452459) At the time when Draupadi’s hair was b eing pulled, Bhima was boiling with rage, his eyes were red, but he did not raise his club; the other brothers too were passive spectators the entire scene.
('51', 240, 5, 29, 452655) Would anyone, however, refer to
('51', 241, 0, 1, 452687) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 242
('51', 241, 1, 2, 452729) those five husbands as cowards?
('51', 241, 1, 3, 452761) On the contrary, we congratulate them, regard them as having attained spiritual merit; history sings their praises.
('51', 241, 1, 4, 452877) History will sing your praises also, my heart is doing so now and I am expressing it here.
('51', 241, 1, 5, 452968) If I have been guilty of exaggeration in saying that there was a Thermopylae at various places in Kheda, you yourselves should correct that mistake.
('51', 241, 1, 6, 453117) My task is not that of a professional pane gyrist, I wish to make you worthy of that fame.
('51', 241, 1, 7, 453208) Hence, accept praise to the extent you deserve it.
('51', 241, 1, 8, 453259) I was merely an instrument used for the settlement which has been reached.
('51', 241, 1, 9, 453334) That settlement has taken place between the Congress and the Government despite the fact that it may have been called the Gandhi Irwin Settlement.
('51', 241, 1, 10, 453481) It is the dharma of the Sardar and myself to explain this settlement.
('51', 241, 1, 11, 453551) Some persons have been disappointed by it and ask whether this is to be called a settlement or a disgrace?
('51', 241, 1, 12, 453658) It seems that some persons have a doubt that a person like me has become tired of carrying on a struggle, has become despondent and hence has thrown away his self respect.

('51', 241, 1, 15, 454019) I ask you to point out to me if I had at any time promised to make good this loss.

('51', 241, 1, 25, 454850) The settlement which has been made now is a step forward in our journey towards swaraj.
('51', 241, 1, 26, 454938) The settlement has been made in the hope that what has now to be secured will be done through talks, discussions and negotiations.

('51', 242, 1, 3, 455595) You have been told by beat of drum that your homes will be robbed, you along with your family will become destitute—you were told that you should join the struggle if you were prepared to suffer this, otherwise, not.

('51', 245, 2, 3, 462816) March 14, 1931
('51', 245, 3, 4, 462831) Addressing a large public meeting, Mr. Gandhi said he was glad they continued their work, and made Gujarat known to the world after his arrest.
('51', 245, 3, 5, 462975) Now they should apply themselves to the work that was to be prosecuted.
('51', 245, 4, 6, 463047) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said now they had not to practise civil disobedience of laws, but to do constructive work.
('51', 245, 4, 7, 463161) He emphasized what he had said in 1922 that if they prosecuted constructive work for six months, swaraj would be won.
('51', 245, 4, 8, 463279) But constructive work, which they had to prosecute now, was of a different type.
('51', 245, 4, 9, 463360) Those who could pay should pay up land revenue.
('51', 245, 4, 10, 463408) If there was occasion to renew the fight, they could stop payment of land revenue, which was paid every year.
('51', 245, 5, 11, 463518) Mr. Gandhi added that they had also not to manufacture salt with a view to court jail.
('51', 245, 5, 12, 463605) Those people living near the seashore might manufacture salt for their own consum ption.
('51', 245, 5, 13, 463694) They might even sell among themselves such salt but they could not sell it in distant towns and cities.
('51', 245, 5, 14, 463798) Salt was being manufactured for consumption by the poor and not for trade.
('51', 245, 5, 15, 463873) They could manufacture salt for trade when they had secured political power.
('51', 245, 6, 16, 463950) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said they had to carry on peaceful picketing of liquor and foreign cloth shops.
('51', 245, 6, 17, 464053) They had to approach drunkards in their homes and persuade them to give up drink.
('51', 245, 6, 18, 464135) They might similarly picket foreign cloth shops if there were still any in their villages, but they must take to production of khadi.

('51', 245, 7, 21, 464451) If such panches were established in all villages it was easy to win swaraj.

('51', 246, 2, 18, 466768) 312. MY NOTES
('51', 246, 3, 19, 466782) TO WORKERS You may be tempted to go to Karachi for the Congress session.
('51', 246, 3, 20, 466855) Resist the temptation.
('51', 246, 3, 21, 466878) A Congress session is not a show, not a picnic.
('51', 246, 3, 22, 466926) It is intended for drawing up the next year’s programme; hence the rule is that only that worker goes there who has to go in order to serve.
('51', 246, 3, 23, 467067) One should not delude oneself that one can learn a lot there.
('51', 246, 3, 24, 467129) He who goes there at the call of duty would surely learn something.
('51', 246, 3, 25, 467197) Ordinary people who can spare time, who have no work to do at their places, have a right, and some may even have the duty to attend the Congress.
('51', 246, 3, 26, 467343) The duty of the worker who serves is the opposite of this.
('51', 246, 3, 27, 467402) If his leader sends him there, it is incumbent on him to stick to his duty.
('51', 246, 3, 28, 467478) This duty at the present time particularly holds good for Gujarat.
('51', 246, 3, 29, 467545) When the refugees go back to their villages, it is the duty of every worker to stay with them.
('51', 247, 0, 1, 467640) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 248
('51', 247, 1, 2, 467682) SOME PICKETING RULES 1
('51', 247, 2, 3, 467705) In picketing foreign cloth or intoxicating drinks and drugs, let it be remembered, that the aim is to convert the addict or the buyer.
('51', 247, 2, 4, 467840) Our object is moral and economic reform.
('51', 247, 2, 5, 467881) The political consequence is but a by product.
('51', 247, 2, 6, 467928) If Lancashire ceased to send us its cloth and the Government ceased to use the abkari revenue for any purpose save that of weaning the drunkard or opium eater from his vice, we should still be engaged in picketing work and allied propaganda.
('51', 247, 2, 7, 468170) The following rules therefore must be read in that light : 1. In picketing shops your attention must be riveted on the buyer.
('51', 247, 2, 8, 468296) 2. You should never be rude to the buyer or the seller.
('51', 247, 2, 9, 468352) 3. You may not attract crowds or form cordons.
('51', 247, 2, 10, 468399) 4. Yours must be a silent effort.
('51', 247, 2, 11, 468433) 5. You must seek to win over the buyer or the seller by your gentleness, not by the awe of numbers.
('51', 247, 2, 12, 468533) 6. You may not obstruct traffic.
('51', 247, 2, 13, 468566) 7. You may not cry hai hai or use other expressions of shame.
('51', 247, 2, 14, 468628) 8. You should know every buyer and his address and occupa tion and penetrate his or her home and heart.
('51', 247, 2, 15, 468732) This presupposes continuity of same picketers.
('51', 247, 2, 16, 468779) 9. You should try to understand the difficulties of buyers and sellers, and where you cannot remove them you should report them to your superiors.
('51', 247, 2, 17, 468926) 10. If you are picketing foreign cloth, you should have some khadi or at least sample book with prices and should know the nearest khadi shop to which you could take the buyer.
('51', 247, 2, 18, 469103) If the buyer does not wish to buy khadi and insists on mill cloth, you should direct the buyer to an indigenous mill cloth seller.
('51', 247, 2, 19, 469234) 11. You should have relevant literature upon your person for distribution among the buyers.
('51', 247, 2, 20, 469326) 12. You should join or organize processions, lectures with or without magic lantern, bhajan parties, etc.
('51', 247, 2, 21, 469432) 13. You should keep an accurate diary of your day’s work.
('51', 247, 2, 22, 469490) 14. If you find your effort failing do not be disheartened but rely upon the universal law of cause and effect and be assured that no good thought, word or deed goes fruitless.
('51', 247, 2, 23, 469667) To think well, to speak
('51', 247, 3, 24, 469691) 1 The translation of these Rules is reproduced from Young India, 19 3 1931.
('51', 248, 0, 1, 469767) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 249
('51', 248, 1, 2, 469812) well is ours, reward is in the hands of God.
('51', 248, 1, 3, 469857) If you think of any other rule please forward it to me.
('51', 248, 2, 4, 469913) APPEAL TO FOREIGN CLOTH MERCHANTS
('51', 248, 3, 5, 469947) 1. Remember that you hold in your hands the economic independence of India.
('51', 248, 3, 6, 470023) 2. Remember that a potent cause of India’s slavery is your involvement in the dirty foreign cloth trade.
('51', 248, 3, 7, 470128) 3. If you get ruined for the purpose of atoning for this sin committed by you knowingly or unknowingly, that atonement will be regarded as none too great.
('51', 248, 3, 8, 470283) 4. Remember that you are responsible for the impoverishment of India, the destruction of its extensive industry and the continuing loss.
('51', 248, 3, 9, 470420) 5. Remember that it is the people’s dharma always to boycott foreign cloth.
('51', 248, 3, 10, 470496) 6. Remember that even under swaraj, there will be no trade in foreign cloth.
('51', 248, 3, 11, 470573) 7. If you sell the goods you have with you clandestinely, that is a different thing, however regrettable and shameful.
('51', 248, 3, 12, 470692) But the Congress can never give you permission to sell those goods in India.
('51', 248, 3, 13, 470769) 8. If you decide not to engage in this trade, you can certainly export at a loss the goods lying with you.
('51', 248, 3, 14, 470876) 9. You know that efforts are afoot to extend to you such help as can be given.
('51', 248, 3, 15, 470955) 10. You cannot certainly say that you had not received an adequate warning.
('51', 248, 3, 16, 471031) The Congress has made great efforts since 1920 to wake you up.

('51', 248, 6, 19, 471131) 313. TRAGEDY OF THE ELEVENTH
('51', 248, 7, 20, 471160) We can see that the present awakening among the people has goneday byday out of our control.We got its sad proo on the eleventh at the massive women’s meeting in Ahmedabad.
('51', 248, 7, 21, 471333) After I left, there was such a stampede that seven sisters got crushed in it and received injuries.
('51', 248, 7, 22, 471433) Among them was the wife of shri Moolchand Asharam.
('51', 248, 7, 23, 471484) She survived for a few hours and then died.
('51', 248, 7, 24, 471528) Another sister whose name I
('51', 249, 0, 1, 471556) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('51', 249, 1, 2, 471598) do not know was injured seriously and, until I left Ahmedabad, her life was in danger.
('51', 249, 1, 3, 471685) The remaining five sisters received some injuries.
('51', 249, 1, 4, 471736) Who is to console and how can anyone console all these and the husband of the departed sister?
('51', 249, 1, 5, 471831) How can one condole such deaths?
('51', 249, 1, 6, 471864) Who can be blamed for this?
('51', 249, 1, 7, 471892) Even such tragedies are like offerings at the altar of the swaraj yajna.
('51', 249, 1, 8, 471965) Until we culti vate the ability to regulate, until we learn to organize such mam moth gatherings, accidents will certainly occur.
('51', 249, 1, 9, 472095) Only through them shall we learn discipline and order.
('51', 249, 1, 10, 472150) None can block awakening; meet ings cannot be abandoned and police men cannot be engaged to maintain order.
('51', 249, 1, 11, 472258) No where are they engaged for this purpose.
('51', 249, 1, 12, 472302) Only volunteers maintain order at such meetings and many have already acquired the ability to keep order.
('51', 249, 1, 13, 472408) At the present moment we have been maintaining such order as there is in meetings through a corps of volunteers.
('51', 249, 1, 14, 472521) But the sad and shameful thing is that no rules as to how to maintain order at meetings have been framed for the benefit of the volunteer corps.
('51', 249, 1, 15, 472666) The latter should draw up such rules and train volunteers, and should make these rules widely known among the people too.
('51', 249, 1, 16, 472788) I give herewith some by way of suggestion.
('51', 249, 2, 17, 472831) 1. The meeting should be always held in the open when thou sands are expected to attend.
('51', 249, 2, 18, 472920) It should be circular in shape, the centre containing the dais to be reached by ways protected by strong wooden fences, running radius like to the centre.
('51', 249, 2, 19, 473075) 2. The dais should be made up of planks, and strong enough to support several people.
('51', 249, 2, 20, 473161) 3. The ways to the dais should be clear of spectators and guarded at each end by volunteers.
('51', 249, 2, 21, 473254) 4. The fence should be so constructed as to leave no room for ingress through the fencing.
('51', 249, 2, 22, 473345) 5. The leaders when they enter should not be surrounded by cordons of volunteers.
('51', 249, 2, 23, 473427) 6. The volunteers should stick to their posts firm as a rock.
('51', 249, 2, 24, 473489) 7. The way should be absolutely clear before leaders are taken to the dais.
('51', 249, 2, 25, 473565) 8. Volunteers should be posted at fixed places in the meeting.
('51', 249, 2, 26, 473628) They should not stand, but their presence should be indicated by flags held in their hands.
('51', 249, 3, 27, 473720) 1 The translation of the paragraphs 1 15 is reproduced from Young India, 19 3 1931.
('51', 250, 0, 1, 473804) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 251
('51', 250, 1, 2, 473849) 9. Volunteers ought to know flag signalling.
('51', 250, 1, 3, 473894) 10. If the meeting is held in an enclosed space, it should have a sufficient number of exits, and the attendance should be strictly limited to the capacity of the space.
('51', 250, 1, 4, 474064) 11. Leaflets of instructions should be distributed at every meeting.

('51', 251, 2, 6, 476413) 315. TO PROUD GUJARAT
('51', 251, 3, 7, 476435) Gujarat has immortalized its name and at the same time added to India’s glory.The whole world has come to know Bardoli and Borsad.
('51', 251, 3, 8, 476566) Europe celebrated one Thermopylae, but Tod has recorded that a Thermo pylae was staged in every street in Rajputana.
('51', 251, 3, 9, 476683) Those Thermo pylaes were sanguinary.
('51', 251, 3, 10, 476720) It is no exaggeration to say that in Gujarat, nay in India, non violent Thermopylaes have been enacted almost every where.
('51', 251, 3, 11, 476843) Only men took part in those other Thermopylaes.
('51', 251, 3, 12, 476891) In these non violent Thermopylaes women have played an important role.
('51', 251, 3, 13, 476962) But that is not enough.
('51', 251, 3, 14, 476986) We have to do more yet and what is more difficult.
('51', 251, 3, 15, 477037) What is required for this is quiet strength, not fiery force.
('51', 251, 3, 16, 477099) What a man can do when excited, he cannot do when he quietens down.We like excitement, not industry and constructive work.
('51', 251, 3, 17, 477222) Now industry and constructive work are implicit in action.
('51', 251, 3, 18, 477281) However, if we wish to develop our capacity for swaraj, we must build up both our desructive and constructive capa cities.
('51', 251, 3, 19, 477404) We must clear our field of weeds; but he who lets his field lie fallow after weeding it wastes his effort and unwanted grass grows in it again.
('51', 251, 3, 20, 477548) However, he who sows his field after weeding it is a wise farmer and becomes prosperous.
('51', 251, 3, 21, 477637) In exactly the same way, if we do not sow seeds in the form of constructive activity, the weeding in the form of the past twelve months’ non violent movement will go waste.
('51', 251, 3, 22, 477810) Some people hold that this settlement is no settlement but that we have committed a serious mistake and have lost everythings.
('51', 251, 3, 23, 477937) I hope that no Gujarati will entertain such a doubt.
('51', 251, 3, 24, 477990) But I do know that just as there are doubting Thomases elsewhere, Gujarat too has its share of them.
('51', 251, 3, 25, 478091) It is Navajivan’s duty to allay their fears.
('51', 251, 3, 26, 478136) Here is a doubt : Has any great change occurred in the circumstances to warrant my attending the Round Table Conference without those guarantees
('51', 252, 0, 1, 478281) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 253
('51', 252, 1, 2, 478326) which we had demanded in December 1929 and again from Yeravda Jail?
('51', 252, 1, 3, 478394) Let us consider this question.
('51', 252, 1, 4, 478425) We did not know in 1929 or while I was in Yeravda what stand the British parties and our people would take at the Round Table Conference.
('51', 252, 1, 5, 478563) Today we have to decide the matter after knowing that the Conference has made some headway.
('51', 252, 1, 6, 478655) That makes a lot of difference.
('51', 252, 1, 7, 478687) On those two occasions, we knew nothing of the set up of the Round Table Conference.
('51', 252, 1, 8, 478772) Today we know it somewhat.
('51', 252, 1, 9, 478799) Today we know that the leaders of India have asked for a fully responsible government.
('51', 252, 1, 10, 478886) The British parties have accepted the demand.
('51', 252, 1, 11, 478932) It is true that all those who attended the Round Table Conference have agreed to retain the Empire link.
('51', 252, 1, 12, 479037) We of course are asking for the right to snap that link at our discretion.
('51', 252, 1, 13, 479112) We have complete freedom to demand this right at the Round Table Conference.
('51', 252, 1, 14, 479189) We shall be guilty if we do not attend the Conference, despite getting the right to demand complete independence.
('51', 252, 1, 15, 479303) Moreover, on those two occasions, we did not have a complete measure of our strength.
('51', 252, 1, 16, 479389) Today we have some idea of it.
('51', 252, 1, 17, 479420) If a weak person undertakes negotiations, he is a beggar.
('51', 252, 1, 18, 479478) A strong man is always ready for parleys.
('51', 252, 1, 19, 479520) If a strong party declines to negotiate, it is regarded as arrogant and blameworthy.
('51', 252, 1, 20, 479605) Therefore, by effecting a settlement, the Congress has shown its wisdom and has enhanced its prestige.

('51', 252, 1, 25, 480140) And if we do not observe them or observe them half heartedly, we shall forfeit the prestige already gained.
('51', 252, 1, 26, 480248) In addition to observing these conditions, we must do three things : boycott of foreign cloth, prohibition of intoxicants and khadi production and propaganda.

('51', 254, 1, 2, 482744) 317. SPEECH AT LABOUR MEETING, PAREL 1
('51', 254, 2, 3, 482783) March 16, 1931 I knew that there were Communists in India, but I had not met them outside the Meerut Jail, nor even heard their speeches.
('51', 254, 2, 4, 482921) I made a point of interviewing the Meerut prisoners two years ago during my tour in the U.P. and thus managed to know them somewhat.
('51', 254, 2, 5, 483054) I have heard one of them this evening, and I may tell them that such as they claim to win swaraj for the working men, I have my doubts about their ability to do so.
('51', 254, 2, 6, 483219) I had made the working men’s cause my own long before any of the young Communists here were born.
('51', 254, 2, 7, 483317) I spent the best part of my time in South Africa working for them, I used to live with them, and shared their joys and sorrows.
('51', 254, 2, 8, 483445) You must therefore understand why I claim to speak for labour.
('51', 254, 2, 9, 483508) I expect at least courtesy from you if nothing else.
('51', 254, 2, 10, 483561) I invite you to come to me and discuss things with me as frankly as you can.
('51', 254, 2, 11, 483638) You claim to be Communists, but you do not seem to live the life of communism.
('51', 254, 2, 12, 483717) I may tell you that I am trying my best to live up to the ideal of communism in the best sense of the term.
('51', 254, 2, 13, 483825) And communism does not, I fancy, exclude courtesy.
('51', 254, 2, 14, 483876) I am amongst you today, within a few minutes I will leave you.
('51', 254, 2, 15, 483939) But if you want to carry the country with you, you ought to be able to react on it by reasoning with it.
('51', 254, 2, 16, 484044) You cannot do so by coercion.
('51', 254, 2, 17, 484074) You may deal destruction to bring the country round to your view.
('51', 254, 2, 18, 484140) But how many will you destroy?
('51', 254, 2, 19, 484171) Not tens of millions.
('51', 254, 2, 20, 484193) You may kill a few thousands if you had millions with you.
('51', 254, 2, 21, 484252) But today you are no more than a handful.
('51', 254, 2, 22, 484294) I ask you to convert the Congress if you can and to take charge of it.
('51', 254, 2, 23, 484365) But you cannot do so by bidding goodbye to the elementary rules of courtesy.
('51', 254, 2, 24, 484442) And there is no reason why you should be lacking in ordinary courtesy, when it is open to you to give the fullest vent to your views, when India is tolerant enough to listen patiently to anyone who can talk coherently.
('51', 254, 2, 25, 484661) The truce has done no harm to the labourers.
('51', 254, 2, 26, 484706) I claim that none of my activities has ever harmed the workers, can ever harm them.
('51', 254, 2, 27, 484790) If the Congress sends its representatives to the Conference, they will

('51', 257, 2, 9, 490648) 319. INTERVIEW TO SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE
('51', 257, 3, 10, 490686) BOMBAY, March 16/17, 1931
('51', 257, 4, 11, 490712) At 10 p.m.
('51', 257, 4, 12, 490723) Gandhiji received Mr. Subhas Bose who kept him engaged till 2.30 a.m.
('51', 257, 4, 13, 490793) I understand Mr. Subhas presented his case for the release of all Bengal political prisoners and the right to carry on propaganda in favour of independence.
('51', 257, 4, 14, 490950) Gandhiji explained to him that the Delhi Truce Pact had only suspended hostile activities and the civil disobedience programme, and did not prevent anybody from carrying on propaganda for independence for India.

('51', 257, 4, 16, 491611) He was sure their detention was only a question of six months at the most, and at the time of concluding peace finally the Congress would be justified in making release of all political prisoners a condition precedent.

('51', 258, 2, 6, 492679) 321. INTERVIEW TO “SCRUTATOR”
('51', 258, 3, 7, 492709) BOMBAY, March 17, 1931 I have said nothing publicly yet and I have not yet complain ed but I am daily receiving evidence that in certain parts things are not going on as well as they might.
('51', 258, 3, 8, 492899) I am certain Lord Irwin and the Central Government are playing the game, and doing their utmost to fulfil the letter and spirit of the settlement.
('51', 258, 3, 9, 493046) But it appears to be very different with some of the provincial Governments.
('51', 258, 3, 10, 493123) It is the old question of the district officer, who is really powerful enough to set Viceroys and Governors at nought.
('51', 258, 3, 11, 493242) Again and again it has been my experience that the district officer has the power of making or marring the policy of the Govern ment.
('51', 258, 3, 12, 493376) In some places there was reason and common sense, in some others there was unreason, fierceness and brutality; and in between, there was mere caution and hesitancy.
('51', 258, 3, 13, 493541) Lord Irwin’s spirit has not yet perco lated down to the districts.
('51', 258, 3, 14, 493608) I do not think there should be any difficulty about people who are said to be guilty of a violent speech under Section 124. No one was more violently seditious in this sense than I was, and yet I am out and others are still in jail.
('51', 258, 3, 15, 493841) I am hoping that, within the next few days, most of these people will be released.
('51', 258, 3, 16, 493924) But at the present moment I am receiving far too many complaints to be entirely happy about the situation.
('51', 258, 3, 17, 494031) I am afraid in far too many cases the line between sedition and violence was not drawn in the proper spirit.

('51', 261, 0, 1, 497445) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 261, 1, 2, 497487) 323. SPEECH AT AZAD MAIDAN, BOMBAY 1
('51', 261, 2, 3, 497524) March 17, 1931 An age has passed since I appeared before you on my release and the impossible size of the meeting prevented me from delivering my message to you.
('51', 261, 2, 4, 497686) A new age has begun and I appear before you this evening to deliver again my message which however is far different from the one on the previous occasion.
('51', 261, 2, 5, 497841) That day’s message was simple, today’s is comparatively complex.
('51', 261, 2, 6, 497906) For full twelve months we have developed a war mentality, we thought of war, we talked of war and nothing but war.
('51', 261, 2, 7, 498021) Now we have to sing a completely different tune.
('51', 261, 2, 8, 498070) We are in the midst of truce.
('51', 261, 2, 9, 498100) With some of us, I know the very mention of the word ‘truce’ sends a shiver through their body.
('51', 261, 2, 10, 498196) That is because we had thought of nothing but war and had believed that there could be no compromise.
('51', 261, 2, 11, 498298) But that was not a position becoming a true satyagrahi.
('51', 261, 2, 12, 498354) The satyagrahi whilst he is ever ready for fight must be equally eager for peace.
('51', 261, 2, 13, 498436) He must welcome any honourable opportunity for peace.
('51', 261, 2, 14, 498490) The Working Committee of the Congress saw such an opportunity and availed itself of it.
('51', 261, 2, 15, 498578) The essential condition of a compromise is that there should be nothing humiliating, nothing panicky about it.
('51', 261, 2, 16, 498689) You may be sure that whilst I was being inundated with telegrams to make peace at any price, I was absolutely unmoved by them.
('51', 261, 2, 17, 498816) I am inured to such things and I was absolutely firm that I must not allow any of these telegrams to make me flinch from whatever decision my inner voice gave me.
('51', 261, 2, 18, 498979) Whilst however a satya grahi never yields to panic or hesitancy, neither does he think of humiliating the other party, of reducing it to an abject surrender.
('51', 261, 2, 19, 499137) He may not swerve from the path of justice and may not dictate impossi ble terms.
('51', 261, 2, 20, 499219) He may not pitch his demands too high, neither may he pitch them too low.
('51', 261, 2, 21, 499293) The present settlement, I submit, satisfies all these conditions.
('51', 261, 2, 22, 499359) One of the terms of the settlement seems to have caused some disappointment in certain quarters and some have rushed in to condemn the settlement on that account.
('51', 261, 2, 23, 499522) They complain that we ought not to have entered into the settlement until we had secured the release of all political prisoners.
('51', 261, 2, 24, 499651) I may tell you that we could not in justice make this demand.
('51', 261, 2, 25, 499713) Not that there was any lack of will on our

('51', 266, 2, 9, 509650) 326. THE CONGRESS The Congress will be upon us in a few days from now.
('51', 266, 2, 10, 509721) The broken up organizations will hardly have been put together by that time.
('51', 266, 2, 11, 509798) The delegates, half of whom will be ex prisoners, will hardly have had time to collect themselves.
('51', 266, 2, 12, 509897) And yet, it will meet with a greater prestige than ever before, and with a consciousness of its new strength born of a knowledge of sufferings undergone by tens of thousands of men, women and children, and perhaps unparalleled in history in the sense that the sufferers suffered without retaliation.
('51', 266, 2, 13, 510197) But it would be wrong to brood over the sufferings, to exagge rate them, or to be puffed up with pride.
('51', 266, 2, 14, 510301) True suffering does not know itself and never calculates.
('51', 266, 2, 15, 510359) It brings its own joy which surpasses all other joys.
('51', 266, 2, 16, 510413) We shall, therefore, be guilty of suicide if we live upon the capital amassed during the past twelve months.
('51', 266, 2, 17, 510522) Whilst we must try always to avoid occasions for needless suffering, we must ever be ready for them.
('51', 266, 2, 18, 510623) Somehow or other, those who will walk along the right path cannot avoid suffering notwithstanding the attempt to avoid it.
('51', 266, 2, 19, 510746) It is the privilege of the patriot, the reformer and, still greater, of the satyagrahi.
('51', 266, 2, 20, 510834) The settlement, provisional though it is, has come through God’s grace.
('51', 266, 2, 21, 510906) During the negotiations there were times when break down seemed a certainty.
('51', 266, 2, 22, 510983) Beyond doubt, the suffering would have been ten times multiplied if a breakdown had taken place.
('51', 266, 2, 23, 511080) And yet, I would have been obliged to ask the nation to go through it, had an honourable peace proved impossible.
('51', 266, 2, 24, 511194) But I am not sure that it will be possible to reach the goal without further wider and deeper suffering.
('51', 266, 2, 25, 511299) The measure of our purification seems hardly equal to the prize to be won.
('51', 266, 2, 26, 511374) We have not yet consciously, and on a national scale, got rid of
('51', 267, 0, 1, 511439) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 267, 1, 2, 511481) the curse of untouchability, we have not shed distrust of one another.
('51', 267, 1, 3, 511552) Great though the awakening has been among the rich, they have not yet made common cause with the poor; their life bears no resem blance to that of the poor.
('51', 267, 1, 4, 511709) Though much progress has been made in the case of drink and drugs, much more yet remains to be done; the progress made is still uncertain.
('51', 267, 1, 5, 511848) The drunkard has yielded to pressure of public opinion.
('51', 267, 1, 6, 511904) He has not yet definitely given up the habit.
('51', 267, 1, 7, 511950) He knows the evil but has not been taught to shun it as poison.
('51', 267, 1, 8, 512014) The word ‘taught’ has been used advisedly.
('51', 267, 1, 9, 512057) The workers have confined their attention to the drink and drug shops, they have not made a serious attempt to touch the heart of the addict.
('51', 267, 1, 10, 512199) We have not shed the desire for foreign cloth and fineries, nor have the cloth merchants fully realized magnitude of the wrong they have done to the nation by their trade.
('51', 267, 1, 11, 512371) Many of them still parade the doctrine of individual freedom.

('51', 269, 2, 8, 516986) 328. INTERVIEW WITH VICEROY
('51', 269, 3, 9, 517014) March 19, 1931
('51', 269, 4, 10, 517029) Mr. Gandhi came to see me today on his return from Bombay.
('51', 269, 4, 11, 517088) The first point to which he drew my attention was the statement of the Secretary of State during the debate in the House of Commons, in which he had emphasized that in the considered view of His Majesty’s Government there could be no abatement of the financial safeguards proposed in the Federal Structure Committee.
('51', 269, 4, 12, 517405) He put the point, as I had expected, that if the attitude of the Government was unalterable on the particular proposals in this field, as distinct from the broad necessity of ensuring the general purpose of safeguarding India’s credit, he was very doubtful whether it would be useful for Congress to participate.
('51', 269, 5, 13, 517718) I told him that I did not see the need for any complaint on the ground that the Secretary of State had explicitly stated the position of His Majesty’s Government.
('51', 269, 5, 14, 517881) His own friends and he himself were constantly stating in terms no less explicit the position of Congress.
('51', 269, 5, 15, 517988) I had, for example, seen only this morning a speech of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in which he had said that Congress could agree to nothing, unless the last British soldier was withdrawn from India.
('51', 269, 5, 16, 518184) It might no doubt be that Mr. Gandhi and his friends would find difficulty in accepting the statement of the considered position of His Majesty’s Government, just as His Majesty’s Government would find great difficulty in accepting the position laid down by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, but surely it was unnecessary to despair of reconciliation of views by full discussion, in which it would be the duty of all those participating to bring forward arguments and reasons in defence of their position.
('51', 269, 5, 17, 518681) I had no hesitation in saying that the fundamental purpose of His Majesty’s Government in this matter was simply to make India’s financial credit and stability as sure as it could be made.
('51', 269, 5, 18, 518870) In the view of the Secretary of State and of His Majesty’s Government the particular methods suggested were the best for achieving this result; but I should not suppose that if anybody could bring forward better methods, not less effective, on which greater agreement might be reached, there would be any reluctance on the part of His Majesty’s Government to give them careful consideration.
('51', 269, 5, 19, 519262) He said he would consider the position with his friends; and his attitude on this point, as well as his subsequent conversation, led me to feel that he would not run out over it.
('51', 270, 0, 1, 519441) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 271
('51', 270, 1, 2, 519486) I then referred briefly to the matters that he was going to discuss with Mr. Emerson.
('51', 270, 1, 3, 519572) 1 These were, first of all, the complaints that I understood him to have made on the subject of particular failures on the part of Government to implement the agreement in individual cases of release.
('51', 270, 1, 4, 519773) As to this, I told him that I had naturally not been able to inform myself of individual cases, but that from communications I had from Governors I was quite satisfied that local Governments were playing the game very fairly, and that it was a remarkable achievement to have got rid of something like fourteen thousand prisoners in a few days.
('51', 270, 1, 5, 520117) There were no doubt a number of cases in which the element of doubt arose.
('51', 270, 1, 6, 520192) These were now being examined as expeditiously as possible, but it must be recognized this examination took more time than the treatment of cases in regard to which there was no doubt, and that the discretion in doubtful cases was vested with local Governments.
('51', 270, 1, 7, 520454) I told him that I thought his people were very impatient and with this view he seemed not to disagree.
('51', 270, 2, 8, 520557) We then had a good deal of discussion about the methods being employed by Congress for the encouragement of swadeshi production, and I told him that the method of blacklisting particular mills, which did not conform to terms laid down by Congress, seemed to me wholly outside the spirit of our agreement, in that it seemed to impose severe economic coercion of individual liberty.
('51', 270, 2, 9, 520938) His line of defence in reply was to say that no objection could be taken to exhortation to buyers to purchase only Indian cloth; that in pursuance of this Congress were clearly entitled to make information available as to what were the mills which made Indian cloth; and that this automatically led to other mills wishing to ascertain the conditions that had to be fulfilled by them in order to qualify for inclusion in the approved list.
('51', 270, 2, 10, 521377) He strenuously denied that this was either outside the letter or the spirit of an agreement that gave full latitude for the encouragement of Indian industry.
('51', 270, 2, 11, 521535) He added that their action was purely economic, and that they had expressly withdrawn by circular any injunction against the purchase of British goods as compared with foreign in branches of goods which India could not supply; and also added that many of his people had told him that without effective picketing, which in their view was impossible under the agreement, his plans could not succeed.
('51', 270, 2, 12, 521933) I left this subject saying that I would have all the facts examined, and asked him to discuss the matter in greater detail with Mr. Emerson.
('51', 270, 3, 13, 522074) The last subject we discussed was the future procedure of the Round Table Conference.
('51', 270, 3, 14, 522160) On this he said that it would make it very difficult for Congress to participate if no British delegation came to India before the resumption of the full Round Table Conference in England.
('51', 270, 3, 15, 522349) Already there was suspicion, consequent upon the abandonment of the original idea of a British delegation visiting India.
('51', 270, 3, 16, 522471) It would not be expected that a delegation coming to India would be in a position to take
('51', 270, 4, 17, 522561) 1 Vide “Emerson’s note on interview with Gandhiji”, 19 3 1931.
('51', 271, 0, 1, 522624) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 271, 1, 2, 522666) decisions, and the final stages could well be taken in London.
('51', 271, 1, 3, 522729) But he did attach very great importance to a British delegation coming out to India in june or July for the purpose of making contact, getting into touch with Indian feeling and thought and, if this were done, he saw no great difficulties about the subsequent assembly of the full Conference in London.
('51', 271, 2, 4, 523032) I told him that Jawaharlal’s attitude, as reported in the Press, seemed to me impossible.
('51', 271, 2, 5, 523122) Frankly, he appeared to have no spirit of peace and all his utterances left a clear impression on my mind that he certainly regarded the present arrangement merely as an uneasy truce, which had to be used only for the purpose of strengthening Congress for the next encounter.
('51', 271, 2, 6, 523398) He said that Jawaharlal was very mercurial, but was already beginning to come down.
('51', 271, 2, 7, 523482) Of this, however, I told him I saw no sign.
('51', 271, 3, 8, 523526) In conclusion, he told me that he anticipated no great difficulty at Karachi and said that he proposed to attend my informal meeting 1 on Saturday and hoped to accept my invitation to bring two or three others with him.
('51', 271, 4, 9, 523746) His general attitude was friendly and he seemed not less anxious than he was last week to tread the path of peace.
('51', 271, 5, 10, 523861) As he was leaving, he asked if he might mention the case of Bhagat Singh, saying that he had seen in the Press the intimation of his execution for March 24th.
('51', 271, 5, 11, 524020) This was an unfortunate day, as it coincided with the arrival of the new President of the Congress at Karachi and there would be much popular excitement.
('51', 271, 6, 12, 524174) I told him I had considered the case with most anxious care, but could find no grounds on which I could justify to my conscience commuting the sentence.
('51', 271, 6, 13, 524327) As to the date, I had considered the possibility of postponement till after the Congress, but had deliberately rejected it on various grounds :
('51', 271, 7, 14, 524471) (i) that postponement of execution, merely on political grounds, when orders had been passed seemed to me improper;
('51', 271, 8, 15, 524587) (ii) that postponement was inhuman in that it would suggest to the friends and relatives that I was considering commutation; and
('51', 271, 9, 16, 524716) (iii) that Congress would have been able legitimately to complain that they had been tricked by Government.
('51', 271, 10, 17, 524824) He appeared to appreciate the force of these arguments, and said no more.

('51', 273, 3, 5, 526315) The latter is from one of the best and the most cultured of co workers who is most careful in making statements.
('51', 273, 3, 6, 526428) The wire about salt is from one who has been a member of the Legislative Council, Bombay, and is the Editor of an influential, widely read weekly newspaper.
('51', 273, 3, 7, 526585) The arbitrary limit of one mile practically nullifies the relief clause 2 of the settlement and has been evidently fixed without knowledge of the actual condition of the villages in relation to the salt areas.
('51', 273, 3, 8, 526795) In my opinion there cannot be a mileage limit.
('51', 273, 3, 9, 526842) The limit, as I suggested at our conversations, can be easily and justly fixed by issuing instructions that the villagers, so long as they walk from their villages to the salt areas, should not be interfered with.
('51', 273, 3, 10, 527056) The relief clause was intended to give substantial help to the poor, which it can never do under the one mile formula.
('51', 273, 3, 11, 527175) I hope that both the matters will receive prompt attention.
('51', 273, 3, 12, 527235) I shall thank you to return the telegrams after use.
('51', 273, 4, 13, 527288) Yours sincerely,
