('51', 274, 1, 2, 528162) 332. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('51', 274, 2, 3, 528190) DELHI, March 21, 1931 If Lord Sankey and Mr. Wedgwood Benn regard the safeguards evolved by the Round Table Conference as final in substance and form, then there is no use of our going to London and the Second Round Table Conference, as far as the Indian masses are concerned, must fail.
('51', 274, 3, 4, 528478) Gandhiji pointed out that, under the terms of the recent truce with Lord Irwin scope is allowed not only for a full and free discussion of the whole question of safeguards, but it is expressly stipulated that safeguards are to be considered in the interests of India.
('51', 274, 3, 5, 528746) I feel therefore that the statements in Parliament made by Mr. Wedgwood Benn and Lord Sankey that the safeguards must be in the interests of England as well as of India are not strictly in conformity with the spirit of the truce.
('51', 274, 4, 6, 528976) Concerning the Hindu Muslim question, Gandhiji expressed grave doubts as to whether unity could be achieved before the National Congress at Karachi.
('51', 274, 4, 7, 529125) He hoped however that some measure of accord would be reached which might save the way for an eventual agreement between these two groups, whose dissensions had torn India for centuries.
('51', 274, 5, 8, 529312) Asked if he would favour Geneva for the Second Round Table Conference, Gandhiji, replied : Geneva would be desirable if the British delegation were sitting as an impartial judge over India’s future status, but it is not.
('51', 274, 5, 9, 529533) The British are, in a sense, our opponents.
('51', 274, 5, 10, 529577) Therefore the procedure must be by direct negotiation.
('51', 274, 5, 11, 529632) In such negotiations the atmosphere, sur roundings, and local influences play a vital part.
('51', 274, 5, 12, 529724) I am sure England would never agree to Geneva.
('51', 274, 5, 13, 529771) If I had my way I would hold two con ferences, the first in India and the second in England.
('51', 274, 5, 14, 529864) That would make for fairness all around.
('51', 274, 5, 15, 529905) But wherever the Conference is held, it is of the utmost importance that it should be convened without loss of time.
('51', 274, 6, 16, 530022) Q. Do you expect to hold the National Congress to the terms of the truce with Lord Irwin?
('51', 274, 7, 17, 530112) A. Yes, but if Bhagat Singh is hanged, as it now seems almost certain, it may have highly unfavourable repercussions upon the
('51', 275, 0, 1, 530238) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 275, 1, 2, 530280) younger element in the Congress who may attempt to split the Con gress.
('51', 275, 2, 3, 530352) Q. Do you entertain any hope that Bhagat Singh may be saved at the last minute?
('51', 275, 3, 4, 530432) A. Yes, but it is a very distant hope.
('51', 275, 4, 5, 530471) Gandhiji laughed over the speculation in the London Press as to whether he would bring Mirabai to London.
('51', 275, 4, 6, 530577) If I go to the Second Round Table Conference why should not I bring her?
('51', 275, 4, 7, 530650) She is a most useful assistant and besides she is anxious to see her mother who lives in England.
('51', 275, 5, 8, 530748) Turning from politics to general subjects, Gandhiji answered a number of questions.
('51', 275, 6, 9, 530832) Q. Do you think the League of Nations will succeed in exterminating war?
('51', 275, 7, 10, 530905) A. War will never be exterminated by any agency until men and the nations become more spiritual, and adopt the principle of brother hood and concord rather than antagonism, competition, and brute force.
('51', 275, 7, 11, 531108) Those in the West do not recognize the power of spiritual things, but some day they will and then they will be free from war, crimes of violence and things that go with these evils.
('51', 275, 7, 12, 531290) The West is too materialistic, selfish and narrowly nationalistic.
('51', 275, 7, 13, 531357) What we want is an international mind, embracing the welfare and spiritual advancement of all mankind.
('51', 275, 8, 14, 531460) Q. How would you cure the evil of armaments?
('51', 275, 9, 15, 531505) A. By non violence, which will eventually be the weapon of all nations.
('51', 275, 9, 16, 531577) I say ‘eventually’ deliberately, because we shall have wars and armaments for a very long time.
('51', 275, 9, 17, 531673) It is two thousand years since Christ preached His Sermon on the Mount and the world has adopted only a fragment of the imperishable lofty precepts therein enunciated for the conduct of man toward man.
('51', 275, 9, 18, 531875) Until we take all Christ’s prin ciples to our hearts, war, hatred and violence will continue.
('51', 275, 10, 19, 531969) Q. What is your remedy for the prevailing crimes of violence, divorce, and drink in the United States?
('51', 275, 11, 20, 532072) A. I would cure them all by self purification and non violence.
('51', 275, 12, 21, 532136) Q. Why did you refuse to allow the Ahmedabad Municipality to erect a monument to you?
('51', 275, 13, 22, 532222) A. Because man’s best monument is not a thing of stone, but consists in living deeds and in memory which survives in the minds of those he served.
('51', 275, 13, 23, 532369) Such funds should be used for the uplift of the poor
('51', 276, 0, 1, 532422) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 277
('51', 276, 1, 2, 532467) and not to glorify or immortalize in marble a man who merely served his brother man.
('51', 276, 2, 3, 532552) Q. How long do you expect to live?
('51', 276, 3, 4, 532587) A. Until eternity.
('51', 276, 4, 5, 532606) Q. Do you believe in immortality?
('51', 276, 5, 6, 532640) A. Yes, reincarnation and transmigration of souls are funda mentals of the Hindu religion.
('51', 276, 6, 7, 532731) Q. If all men adopted your simple mode of living, fasting and exercising, do you think they should live to be hundred?
('51', 276, 7, 8, 532850) A. Yes, but that can he determind better after I die.
('51', 276, 8, 9, 532904) Q. Which Government most nearly approaches your idea of an ideal
('51', 276, 9, 10, 532969) Govern ment?
('51', 276, 10, 11, 532982) A. None.
('51', 276, 10, 12, 532991) It should be government wherein man reaches his full stature in every phase of life, and where his interests are para mount over all others.
('51', 276, 11, 13, 533132) Q. Will socialism accomplish that?
('51', 276, 12, 14, 533167) A. Not socialism, as it is practised politically today.
('51', 276, 13, 15, 533223) Asked if he would favour the retention of American and other foreign missionaries when India secured self government, Gandhiji replied : If instead of confining themselves purely to humanitarian work and material service to the poor, they do proselytizing by means of medical aid, education, etc., then I would certainly ask them to with draw.
('51', 276, 13, 16, 533567) Every nation’s religion is as good as any other.
('51', 276, 13, 17, 533616) Certainly India’s religions are adequate for her people.
('51', 276, 13, 18, 533673) We need no converting spiritually.
('51', 276, 14, 19, 533708) The Hindu, 22 3 1931
('51', 276, 15, 20, 533729) 333. DISCUSSION AT MEETING OF R.T.C. DELEGATED, DELHI 2
('51', 276, 16, 21, 533785) March 21, 1931
('51', 276, 17, 22, 533800) His Excellency met this morning (21st March, 1931) at 11 a.m.
('51', 276, 17, 23, 533862) the Ruling Princes and the delegates to the Round Table Conference who are at present in Delhi.
('51', 276, 17, 24, 533958) Mr. Gandhi, Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya and Sir Hugh Cooke also attended.
('51', 276, 18, 25, 534032) 1 For Gandhiji’s clarification of this paragraph, vide “Foreign missionaries”, 23 4 1931. 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('51', 277, 0, 1, 534159) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 277, 1, 2, 534201) His Excellency opened the proceedings by welcoming the gentlemen who were
('51', 277, 2, 3, 534275) present and by describing the rough heads to which, it seemed to him, discussion
('51', 277, 3, 4, 534356) might profitably be directed.
('51', 277, 4, 5, 534386) These heads were five in number, namely :
('51', 277, 5, 6, 534428) (i) The statement made by the Secretary of State in Parliament “about the practical programme which we hope to pursue”.
('51', 277, 6, 7, 534548) (ii) Special investigations recommended by the Round Table Conference.
('51', 277, 7, 8, 534619) (iii) What may we suppose is happening in India itself, for instance as re gards communal settlement and the discussions in States regarding Federation?
('51', 277, 8, 9, 534772) (iv) How do people see the work of the Federal Structure Committee developing and when will the time be ready for its further discussions?
('51', 277, 9, 10, 534911) (v) Would it be useful for the Indian side of the Round Table Conference with additions to meet in India during the summer?
('51', 277, 9, 11, 535035) HEAD I. Under the first head His Excellency enquired what people thought of the general plan described by the Secretary of State so far as it related, in particular, to no British delegation coming to India.
('51', 277, 9, 12, 535243) His Excellency put to the Conference the direct question whether it was the general view that it is desirable to get out a British delegation to India.
('51', 277, 9, 13, 535395) Many of the delegates answered ‘Yes’.
('51', 277, 10, 14, 535433) Mr. Gandhi expressed the view that, at this stage, nothing useful could be done
('51', 277, 11, 15, 535513) by bringing out a delegation (though from what he said later, it might be inferred that
('51', 277, 12, 16, 535601) he merely meant to convey that it was useless at present, i.e., until the communal
('51', 277, 13, 17, 535684) position was more clear.) .
('51', 277, 14, 18, 535712) His Excellency closed the discussion on this head by remarking that the problem was whether a delegation of whatever kind to India could do useful work in clearing ground so that the Round Table Conference in autumn could get to work more quickly in London.
('51', 277, 14, 19, 535970) HEAD II.
('51', 277, 14, 20, 535979) His Excellency then turned to the special enquiries recommended by the Round Table Conference.
('51', 277, 14, 21, 536074) The first of these was the Franchise Enquiry.
('51', 277, 14, 22, 536120) The Government of India favoured the appointment of a Commission by the Secretary of State and thought that it might tour and be employed, say, for six months.
('51', 277, 14, 23, 536280) But the problem which immediately arose was whether an enquiry into the franchise must not await a settlement of the communal problem.
('51', 277, 14, 24, 536415) Mr. Gandhi, being asked if there were prospects of a communal settlement being reached at an early date, stated that every endeavour was being made to reach a solution from the Congress standpoint and apart from everything else that was happening here and outside.
('51', 277, 14, 25, 536680) The Congress, he said, will be hard put to it to take a share in the deliberations of the Round Table Conference in India or in England unless the communal question is settled.
('51', 277, 14, 26, 536857) The Congress is driven more and more to these
('51', 278, 0, 1, 536903) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 279
('51', 278, 1, 2, 536948) conclusions.
('51', 278, 1, 3, 536961) So he will leave no stone unturned to reach a settlement.
('51', 278, 1, 4, 537019) They had found help in making their explorations in the assurances first given by Begum Shah Nawaz and then by Sir Muhammad Shafi and by others who are not here.
('51', 278, 1, 5, 537181) The main position, he said, was that the Congress will entertain no solution of the communal question which does not satisfy the parties concerned.
('51', 278, 1, 6, 537329) Mr. Gandhi mentioned this point in order to show that it is the bounden duty of Congress to find a settlement.
('51', 278, 1, 7, 537440) If Congress unhappily should fail in that duty, it will inform His Excellency and the country.
('51', 278, 1, 8, 537535) Mr. Gandhi could not say if he had a hope of immediate solution but he found no grounds for despair as things were now proceeding.
('51', 278, 1, 9, 537666) If Congress succeeded, it would make an announcement in the near future.
('51', 278, 1, 10, 537739) If Congress failed, its failure would be a discredit to it, and others must take up the task.
('51', 278, 1, 11, 537833) Congress will approach everyone.
('51', 278, 1, 12, 537866) Difficulties are very great but not insurmountable.
('51', 278, 1, 13, 537918) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya agreed with the expression of opinion made by Mr. Gandhi.
('51', 278, 1, 14, 538004) Sir Muhammad Shafi approved of the admirable summary made by Mr. Gandhi and had nothing to add to it.
('51', 278, 1, 15, 538106) His Excellency remarked that, as one standing outside, he could only lend all his prayers and good wishes to those slaving in the cause of peace.
('51', 278, 2, 16, 538252) It was concluded unanimously that it is no use setting up the Franchise Commission while the communal question is still pending.
('51', 278, 3, 17, 538381) His Excellency then propounded the question, “If this question is not settled,
('51', 278, 4, 18, 538460) what would this conference advise His Majesty’s Government to do?
('51', 278, 4, 19, 538526) In these
('51', 278, 5, 20, 538535) circumstances, should His Majesty’s Government itself make an award?” Sir
('51', 278, 6, 21, 538609) Muhammad Shafi, Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, Sir.
('51', 278, 6, 22, 538653) A. P. Patro and Sir B. N. Mitra said that
('51', 278, 7, 23, 538695) in these circumstances Government must make a decision.
('51', 278, 7, 24, 538751) Mr. Gandhi, however,
('51', 278, 8, 25, 538772) remarked : If we have in our helplessness to say to His Majesty’s Government that we had failed, I should not like to live to make that announcement.
('51', 278, 8, 26, 538922) On the domestic solution of this problem lies the future happiness of this much distressed country.
('51', 278, 8, 27, 539022) I would not like to say off hand that His Majesty’s Government should arbitrate between us, for that is what it comes to; but as we proceed in our talks with Muslims and Sikhs we are fast approaching the conclusion that it will be an indispensable condition of any solution that there should be adult franchise.
('51', 278, 8, 28, 539334) In the peculiar conditions of India adult franchise may appear a hard task, but it would be harder still not to have an adequate solution of our communal problems.
('51', 278, 8, 29, 539498) Muslims and Sikhs feel the same.
('51', 278, 8, 30, 539531) Muslims may not be unanimous, but there is a large body of Muslim opinion which feels that adult suffrage is the real solution.
('51', 278, 8, 31, 539659) Let no one be frightened by the strength with which I put
('51', 279, 0, 1, 539717) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 279, 1, 2, 539759) this proposition.
('51', 279, 1, 3, 539777) Adult suffrage will not be so unwieldy as it may appear at first sight.
('51', 279, 1, 4, 539849) We must consider fully the scheme which is now being evolved.
('51', 279, 1, 5, 539911) At the proper time I shall be prepared to discuss this scheme.
('51', 279, 1, 6, 539974) Meanwhile I have wished to let people know in what way Congress mind is working.
('51', 279, 1, 7, 540055) Adult suffrage may prove to be an indis pensable condition of the communal solution.
('51', 279, 2, 8, 540140) Sir Akbar Hydari pointed out that a Franchise Committee cannot get to work
('51', 279, 3, 9, 540215) on the franchise and the constituencies for the Federal Legislature until we know what
('51', 279, 4, 10, 540302) the strength of the two Houses will be.
('51', 279, 4, 11, 540342) His Excellency remarked that this shows how
('51', 279, 5, 12, 540386) closely all questions are joined up, but you must begin somewhere, either with the
('51', 279, 6, 13, 540469) fowl or with the egg.
('51', 279, 6, 14, 540491) People charged with particular tasks must draw alternative
('51', 279, 7, 15, 540550) pictures.
('51', 279, 7, 16, 540560) HEAD II (b).
('51', 279, 7, 17, 540573) His Excellency then referred to the two enquiries in the North West Frontier Provinces which the Round Table Conference had recommended.
('51', 279, 7, 18, 540710) He explained the action which the Government of India had in contemplation.
('51', 279, 7, 19, 540786) The conference approved.
('51', 279, 7, 20, 540811) His Excellency made a similar explanation in regard to Sind with a like result.
('51', 279, 7, 21, 540891) The conference also approved of departmental examination of the classification of subjects but expressed no opinion about the enquiries regarding separate railway authority.
('51', 279, 8, 22, 541065) Mr. Gandhi was understood to remark that the idea of separating Orissa had the support of Congress.
('51', 279, 8, 23, 541165) HEAD V. Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru asked the question “if a British delegation comes out, what then?” His Excellency expressed the opinion that the whole Conference must then meet.
('51', 279, 8, 24, 541341) Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru wanted to know what Mr. Gandhi’s views were.
('51', 279, 8, 25, 541408) Mr. Gandhi said that when he and his friends were considering this question they had built on three things that the Secretary of State had repeatedly said.
('51', 279, 8, 26, 541564) The Secretary of State held out a prospect of a delegation to India, which Mr. Gandhi and his friends had thought was a good idea, because it afforded them an opportunity of discussing matters with the degree of freedom, which they could not take in full Conference in London.
('51', 279, 8, 27, 541841) They had also welcomed the idea of a preliminary conference being held in India, and of the Round Table Conference then assembling in London, to wind up the business and to declare its considered opinion.
('51', 279, 8, 28, 542046) He and his friends still adhered to that opinion.
('51', 279, 8, 29, 542096) Accordingly, Mr. Gandhi was glad to hear today expre ssions of opinion that the idea of a delegation to India which had been abandoned by His Majesty’s Government should be revived and that a delegation should come out.
('51', 279, 8, 30, 542316) But the Congress did not yet fully know its own mind because of internal difficulties, such as the possibility of a failure to find a solution of the communal problem.
('51', 279, 8, 31, 542484) Just as Congress would welcome the coming of a delegation to India and might indeed
('51', 280, 0, 1, 542568) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 281
('51', 280, 1, 2, 542613) consider it almost indispensable, in order that Congress might have its mind informed, so it was true of British Parties or so many as might elect to come to India that their minds should be informed in this way.
('51', 280, 1, 3, 542826) The third consideration leading Congress to welcome, or indeed consider indispensable, the holding of a Conference in India did not overlook the disadvantages of which Mr. Gandhi was aware.
('51', 280, 1, 4, 543016) Some persons thought that it was a handicap to meet and conduct negotiations in an Indian atmosphere.
('51', 280, 1, 5, 543118) But Mr. Gandhi felt that distrust still persists.
('51', 280, 1, 6, 543168) There is distrust between Indians and Europeans.
('51', 280, 1, 7, 543217) There is still greater distrust of the bureau cracy, that is, of officials.
('51', 280, 1, 8, 543293) He and his friends thought that impediments were being placed in the way of reaching an honourable settlement.
('51', 280, 1, 9, 543404) He himself did not dread these things.
('51', 280, 1, 10, 543443) He felt that if India is to take over its own Government, it will have to deal with this very bureaucracy under altered conditions.
('51', 280, 1, 11, 543575) He asked himself the question if officials did not help, what will India have to face if it embarked on the serious responsibility of self government.
('51', 280, 1, 12, 543726) So far as Congress was concerned, it seemed desirable, and even necessary, to have a Conference in India.
('51', 280, 1, 13, 543832) Such a Conference would not act as judges or arbitrators.
('51', 280, 1, 14, 543890) If it did that, he felt that logically it should do so in a neutral place and deliver its verdict.
('51', 280, 1, 15, 543989) He did not feel that these were precisely the conditions.
('51', 280, 1, 16, 544047) By its sittings the Conference will both affect its surrounding atmosphere and be affected by it.

('51', 288, 6, 22, 565191) But in our schools today we learn only what our foreign masters want us to learn.
('51', 288, 6, 23, 565273) We do not get the training we most need.
('51', 288, 7, 24, 565314) Twenty three years ago Gandhiji wrote a book, Indian Home Rule, which
('51', 288, 8, 25, 565384) stunned India and the rest of the world with its terrible on slaught on modern Western civilization.
('51', 288, 8, 26, 565485) “It is Satanic, and the Hindus call it the dark age,” he wrote, and
('51', 289, 0, 1, 565553) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 289, 1, 2, 565595) envisaged the ideal State with no factories, railways, armies or navies and as few hospitals, doctors, and lawyers as are possible.

('51', 289, 4, 9, 566016) 1 DARYAGANJ, DELHI, March 23, 1931
('51', 289, 5, 10, 566051) DEAR FRIEND, It seems cruel to inflict this letter on you, but the interest of peace demands a final appeal.
('51', 289, 5, 11, 566160) Though you were frank enough to tell me that there was little hope of your commuting the sentence of death on Bhagat Singh and two others, you said you would consider my submission of Saturday.
('51', 289, 5, 12, 566354) Dr. Sapru met me yesterday and said that you were troubled over the matter and taxing your brain as to the proper course to adopt.
('51', 289, 5, 13, 566485) If there is any room left for reconsideration, I invite you attention to the following.
('51', 289, 5, 14, 566573) Popular opinion rightly or wrongly demands commutation.
('51', 289, 5, 15, 566629) When there is no principle at stake, it is often a duty to respect it.
('51', 289, 5, 16, 566700) In the present case the chances are that, if commutation is gran ted, internal peace is most likely to be promoted.
('51', 289, 5, 17, 566816) In the event of execution, peace is undoubtedly in danger.
('51', 289, 5, 18, 566875) Seeing that I am able to inform you that the revolutionary party has assured me that, in the event of these lives being spared, that party will stay its hands, suspension of sentence pending cessation of revo lutionary murders becomes in my opinion a peremptory duty.
('51', 289, 6, 19, 567143) Political murders have been condoned before now.
('51', 289, 6, 20, 567192) It is worth while saving these lives, if thereby many other innocent lives are likely to be saved and maybe even revolutionary crime almost stamped out.
('51', 289, 6, 21, 567345) Since you seem to value my influence such as it is in favour of peace, do not please unnecessarily make my position, difficult as it is, almost too difficult for future work.
('51', 289, 6, 22, 567520) Execution is an irretrievable act.
('51', 289, 6, 23, 567555) If you think there is the sligh test chance of error of judgment, I would urge you to suspend for
('51', 290, 0, 1, 567653) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 291

('51', 292, 1, 3, 572076) We should not utilize our energy, our spirit of sacrifice, our labours and our indomitable courage in the way they have utilized theirs.

('51', 292, 2, 19, 573812) 342. INTERVIEW TO “MANCHESTER GUARDIAN”
('51', 292, 3, 20, 573852) [Before March 24, 1931] 1
('51', 292, 4, 21, 573878) Mahatma Gandhi has given an important interview to the special correspondent of the Manchester Guardian in India.
('51', 292, 4, 22, 573992) According to the special correspondent Mahatma Gandhi declared in the interview that he was certain in mind that the Congress attendance at the Round Table Conference would serve no useful purpose unless the question of safeguards was re opened on the basis of providing India with an efficient and stable form of self government.
('51', 292, 4, 23, 574323) Mahatma Gandhi says :
('51', 292, 5, 24, 574345) 1 The interview appeared under the date line “London, March 24, 1931”.
('51', 293, 0, 1, 574416) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 293, 1, 2, 574458) I have been very much disturbed by the tone of Mr. Benn’s statement with reference to safeguards.
('51', 293, 1, 3, 574556) I must emphasize that the Round Table Conference cannot succeed if it is prejudiced by declarations which imply that certain demands made by Britain are final.
('51', 293, 2, 4, 574716) Referring to the debated question of equality of trade rights to Britishers in India, Mahatma Gandhi said : The rights of the existing business interests must be a matter for negotiations in which India does not desire to act unfairly or ungener ously.
('51', 293, 2, 5, 574969) India must retain freedom the future economic development of her resources along lines which commend themselves to Indians.
('51', 293, 3, 6, 575093) Discussing the question of Federation, Mahatma Gandhi declared that the princes must give their subjects a certain minimum of rights as it is impossible to combine complete autocracy and democracy.

('51', 293, 4, 8, 575314) 343. LETTER TO MAHALAKSHMI M. THAKKAR
('51', 293, 5, 9, 575352) BORSAD, March 24, 1931
('51', 293, 6, 10, 575375) MAHALAKSHMI, I had got your letter, but I could not reply to it earlier.
('51', 293, 6, 11, 575448) You have given a good description of the work being done by you both sisters.
('51', 293, 6, 12, 575526) What did you have in mind when saying that the atmos phere had become impure?
('51', 293, 6, 13, 575604) I have been hearing many stories.
('51', 293, 6, 14, 575638) That is why I ask you so that I may have more information.
('51', 293, 6, 15, 575697) Visiting a drink addict daily and talking to him about the same thing over and over again does not help.
('51', 293, 6, 16, 575802) Remember what I said in my speech at Maroli.
('51', 293, 6, 17, 575847) You should take personal interest in the life of an addict and persuade him to take up some work.
('51', 293, 6, 18, 575945) If he does not wish to spin, he may do some other work.
('51', 293, 6, 19, 576001) You should encourage him to talk about his joys and sorrows and listen to him with sympathy.
('51', 293, 6, 20, 576094) You should meet his wife and children, take the latter in hand and make them look more pleasant.
('51', 293, 6, 21, 576191) If you serve him in this manner, he will probably give up drinking.
('51', 293, 6, 22, 576259) Also you should not say that, if one of you gave all her time to one person, we cannot influence all the hundreds of thousands like him in the country in that manner.
('51', 293, 6, 23, 576426) This is the only way to influence such a large number.
('51', 293, 6, 24, 576481) If one person sincerely reforms him self, many others follow his example.
('51', 293, 6, 25, 576555) By serving one person selflessly, we serve all.
('51', 294, 0, 1, 576603) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 295
('51', 294, 1, 2, 576648) I understand what you say about the children.
('51', 294, 1, 3, 576694) I don’t think Madhavji has committed any error.
('51', 294, 1, 4, 576742) He has not informed me again about the court case against him.
('51', 294, 1, 5, 576805) Blessings from
('51', 294, 3, 6, 576820) From a photostat of the Gujarati : G.N. 6812
('51', 294, 4, 7, 576865) 344. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
('51', 294, 5, 8, 576892) WHAT SHOULD THEY DO?
('51', 294, 5, 9, 576913) “What are those scholars who left their schools during the struggle to do now?” was one of the questions asked at the workers’ meeting in Bombay, but which for want of time I was unable to answer.
('51', 294, 5, 10, 577110) My answer now is : 1. The struggle is not yet over, it has assumed a different, i.e., constructive form.
('51', 294, 5, 11, 577215) 2. Scholars can penetrate the homes and the hearts of the drunkard, the opium eater and the user of foreign cloth.
('51', 294, 5, 12, 577330) 3. Scholars can assist those sisters who are engaged in peaceful picketing.
('51', 294, 5, 13, 577406) 4. Scholars can settle down in villages and there organize khadi work.
('51', 294, 5, 14, 577477) 5. Scholars can hawk khadi in city.
('51', 294, 5, 15, 577513) 6. All scholars should work at the wheel or the takli at least for half an hour daily.
('51', 294, 5, 16, 577600) 7. For further reference they should write to the registrars of the national universities.
('51', 294, 5, 17, 577691) FOREIGN CLOTH DEALERS Another question asked was, now that picketing has become mild, new orders for foreign cloth are being given and the sales of existing stock are also brisk.
('51', 294, 5, 18, 577870) What are you going to do to prevent this?
('51', 294, 5, 19, 577912) This questionpresupposes that picketing has hitherto amounted to coercion.
('51', 294, 5, 20, 577987) If such was the case, it is better that freedom of action is restored than that any single person is coerced into acting against his will.
('51', 294, 5, 21, 578126) My conviction is that if the workers will carryon sustained propaganda, the buying public will be converted.We have concentrated too much upon the dealers and too little on the buyers.
('51', 294, 5, 22, 578311) Sustained public education in this matter is what is wanted.
('51', 294, 5, 23, 578372) Conversion is our motto, not coercion.
('51', 295, 0, 1, 578411) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 295, 1, 2, 578453) Coercion is an offspring of violence.
('51', 295, 1, 3, 578491) Conversion is a fruit of non violence and love.
('51', 295, 1, 4, 578539) CAN YOU AVOID CLASS WAR?
('51', 295, 1, 5, 578564) The third question, I find, is, if you will benefit the workers, the peasant and the factory hand, can you avoid class war?
('51', 295, 1, 6, 578688) I can, most decidedly, if only the people will follow the non violent method.
('51', 295, 1, 7, 578766) The past twelve months have abundantly shown the possibilities of non violence adopted even as a policy.
('51', 295, 1, 8, 578871) When the people adopt it as a principle of conduct, class war becomes an impossibility.
('51', 295, 1, 9, 578959) The experiment in that direction is being tried in Ahmedabad.
('51', 295, 1, 10, 579021) It has yielded most satisfactory results and there is every likelihood of its proving conclusive.
('51', 295, 1, 11, 579119) By the non violent method we seek not to destroy the capitalist, we seek to destroy capitalism.
('51', 295, 1, 12, 579215) We invite the capitalist to regard himself as trustee for those on whom he depends for the making, the retention and the increase of his capital.
('51', 295, 1, 13, 579361) Nor need the worker wait for his conversion.
('51', 295, 1, 14, 579406) If capital is power, so is work.
('51', 295, 1, 15, 579439) Either power can be used destructively or creatively.
('51', 295, 1, 16, 579493) Either is dependent on the other.
('51', 295, 1, 17, 579527) Immediately the worker realizes his strength, he is in a position to become a co sharer with the capitalist instead of remaining his slave.
('51', 295, 1, 18, 579667) If he aims at becoming the sole owner, he will most likely be killing the hen that lays golden eggs.
('51', 295, 1, 19, 579768) Inequalities in intelligence and even opportunity will last till the end of time.
('51', 295, 1, 20, 579850) A man living on the banks of a river has any day more opportunity of growing crops than one living in an arid desert.
('51', 295, 1, 21, 579968) But if inequalities stare us in the face the essential equality too is not to be missed.
('51', 295, 1, 22, 580057) Every man has an equal right to the necessaries of life even as birds and beasts have.
('51', 295, 1, 23, 580144) And since very right carries with it a corresponding duty and the corresponding remedy for resisting any attack upon it, it is merely a matter of finding out the corresponding duties and remedies to vindicate the elementary fundamental equality.
('51', 295, 1, 24, 580390) The corresponding duty is to labour with my limbs and the corresponding remedy is to non co operate with him who deprives me of the fruit of my labour.
('51', 295, 1, 25, 580542) And if I would recognize the fundamental equality, as I must, of the capitalist and the labourer, I must not aim at his destruction.
('51', 295, 1, 26, 580675) I must strive for his conver sion.
('51', 295, 1, 27, 580710) My non co operation with him will open his eyes to the wrong he may be doing.
('51', 295, 1, 28, 580788) Nor need I be afraid of someone else taking my place when I have non co operated.
('51', 295, 1, 29, 580870) For I expect to influence my co workers so as not to help the wrongdoing of employer.
('51', 295, 1, 30, 580956) This kind of education of the mass of workers is no doubt a slow process, but as it is also the surest, it is
('51', 296, 0, 1, 581066) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 297
('51', 296, 1, 2, 581111) necessarily the quickest.
('51', 296, 1, 3, 581137) It can be easily demonstrated that destruction of the capitalist must mean destruction in the end of the worker and as no human being is so bad as to be beyond redemption, no human being is so perfect as to warrant his destroying him whom he wrongly considers to be wholly evil.
('51', 296, 2, 4, 581416) WHAT OF THE UNEMPLOYED The fourth question was, what of the civil resistance prisoners who are discharged and are out of employment?
('51', 296, 2, 5, 581549) If they are willing to work and are honest they can, I doubt not, be employed in some Congress organization.
('51', 296, 2, 6, 581658) Nor need everyone look to the Congress and the allied organizations to give them employment.
('51', 296, 2, 7, 581751) A labourer is worthy of his hire.
('51', 296, 2, 8, 581785) And those who are honest and do not mind labouring, no matter what they were previous to imprisonment, can always rely upon being suited.
('51', 296, 3, 9, 581923) SACRIFICING COUNTRY FOR TRUTH Here is the fifth question : How can you explain away your inconsistency involved in your making fond and easy advances to the R.T.C. after the Congress deciding not to participate in it, and Jawaharlal ironically calling them only a few months ago ‘old women’?
('51', 296, 3, 10, 582215) Are you always going to sacrifice your country for Truth and treat us like test tubes in your experiment of non violence and Truth?
('51', 296, 3, 11, 582347) Do you realize that you are staking the whole nation for your individual self evolution?
('51', 296, 4, 12, 582436) Many of us feel that you have become a National Habit which is useful for the capitalist but tragic for the exploited.
('51', 296, 4, 13, 582555) Manners change with the times.
('51', 296, 4, 14, 582586) Foolish consistency is the hob goblin of little minds.” If I am inconsistent I am wisely so.
('51', 296, 4, 15, 582679) But I see no inconsistency between my present conduct and the past.
('51', 296, 4, 16, 582747) There never was any question of permanent boycott of the Round Table Conference.
('51', 296, 4, 17, 582828) The Congress refused when it could not go there on its terms, it may go now because in its opinion the way is open.
('51', 296, 4, 18, 582944) And I hope that those who go will deliver the nation’s message in no uncertain tones.
('51', 296, 4, 19, 583030) Here there is no question of my ‘sacrificing the country for Truth’.
('51', 296, 4, 20, 583099) In the first place the decision is that of the Working Committee and in the second place there is no sacrifice of the country.
('51', 296, 4, 21, 583226) But writing parentheti cally I have no hesitation in saying that I should, if there could be such a choice, most decidedly sacrifice the country for Truth which t o me is God.
('51', 296, 4, 22, 583402) I further hold that no individual or nation has ever gained by the sacrifice of Truth, there therefore, no such thing as sacrifice of country for Truth.
('51', 297, 0, 1, 583555) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 297, 1, 2, 583597) Those who join me in my experiments in Truth seeking are not my ‘test tubes’, they are my valued fellow workers, sharing with me the joy that the search for Truth brings as no other search does.
('51', 297, 1, 3, 583792) I do not realize that I am ‘staking a whole nation for self evo lution’.For self evolution is wholly consistent witha nation’s evolution.
('51', 297, 1, 4, 583930) A nation cannot advance without the units of which it is composed advancing and, conversely, no individual can advance without the nation of which he is a part also advancing.
('51', 297, 1, 5, 584106) The last charge is thoughtlessly made.
('51', 297, 1, 6, 584145) My experiments began in South Africa and they were made on behalf of the exploited.
('51', 297, 1, 7, 584229) The latter gained.
('51', 297, 1, 8, 584248) They gained again in Champaran, Kheda and Ahmedabad.
('51', 297, 1, 9, 584301) If I may share the merit of the first Borsad campaign, brilliantly fought by Sardar Vallabhbhai during my absence but in strict accord with my prescription, and then again in Bardoli, I may say that the peasants had the benefit of the two fights.
('51', 297, 1, 10, 584548) What may be the last experiment on a nation wide scale is still being tried.
('51', 297, 1, 11, 584625) It is yet too soon to forecast the result.
('51', 297, 1, 12, 584668) But he who runs may see that the phenomenal mass awakening cannot have taken place without the masses having added considerably to their stature.
('51', 297, 1, 13, 584814) This recital has not been made here to claim credit for myself.
('51', 297, 1, 14, 584878) I am but an humble instrument in the hands of God.
('51', 297, 1, 15, 584929) Credit belongs to Truth and non violence.
('51', 297, 1, 16, 584971) The writer’s question seems to doubt the efficacy of Truth and more perhaps of non violence.
('51', 297, 1, 17, 585064) The series of examples I have given ought to set at rest all doubt.
('51', 297, 1, 18, 585132) If we were offering civil disobedience, it was for gaining purna swaraj and if now we have suspended it and are ready to join the Round Table Conference, other conditions being fulfilled, we shall be going to it also for the same noble end.
('51', 297, 1, 19, 585373) That we may fail to achieve the end is quite possible.
('51', 297, 1, 20, 585428) Even so we shall be putting ourselves in the wrong if we rejected the advance made by the Government.
('51', 297, 1, 21, 585530) If we make the right use of suspension, if we carry out the terms of the settlement to the fullest extent possible, if we complete the two boycotts, if we intensify the khadi spirit, at the end of the period of grace we shall find ourselves stronger for battle, if we have not by then already gained our end.
('51', 297, 1, 22, 585839) We must work away with faith in the settlement leading us to our goal.
('51', 297, 1, 23, 585910) Young India, 26 3 1931
('51', 297, 2, 24, 585933) 345. THE GIANT AND THE DWARF
('51', 297, 3, 25, 585962) The reader’s attention is invited to Sjt.
('51', 297, 3, 26, 586004) Walchand Hirachand’s letter published elsewhere.
('51', 297, 3, 27, 586053) It has undergone some corrections in order
('51', 298, 0, 1, 586096) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 299
('51', 298, 1, 2, 586141) to represent my views 1 correctly.
('51', 298, 1, 3, 586176) The discussion to which the letter refers arose out of the formula that “there should be no discrimination between the rights of the British mercantile community, firms and companies trading in India and the rights of Indian born subjects.” The formula reads innocent enough but it covers the most dangerous position.
('51', 298, 1, 4, 586494) The situation today is this.
('51', 298, 1, 5, 586523) The Britisher is the top dog and the Indian the under dog in his own country.
('51', 298, 1, 6, 586601) In the administration of the country, the Indian generally is a mere clerk.
('51', 298, 1, 7, 586677) In business he is at best a commission agent getting hardly five per cent against his English principal’s 95 per cent.
('51', 298, 1, 8, 586796) In almost every walk of life the Englishman by reason of his belonging to the ruling class occupies a privileged position.
('51', 298, 1, 9, 586919) It can be said without fear of contradiction and without any exaggeration that he has risen upon the ruin of India’s commerce and industries.
('51', 298, 1, 10, 587061) The cottage industry of India had to perish in order that Lancashire might flourish.
('51', 298, 1, 11, 587146) The Indian shipping had to perish so that British shipping might flourish.
('51', 298, 1, 12, 587221) In a word we were suppressed in order to enable the British to live on the heights of Simla.
('51', 298, 1, 13, 587314) It was not a mere picturesque expression of Gokhale’s when he said that our growth was stunted.
('51', 298, 1, 14, 587410) To talk then of no discrimination between Indian interests and English or European is to perpetuate Indian helotage.
('51', 298, 1, 15, 587527) What is equality of rights between a giant and a dwarf?
('51', 298, 1, 16, 587583) Before one can think of equality between unequals, the dwarf must be raised to the height of the giant.
('51', 298, 1, 17, 587687) And since millions living on the plains cannot be translated to the heights of Simla, it follows that those entrenched in those heights must descend to the plains.
('51', 298, 1, 18, 587851) The process may seem harsh but it is inevitable if the millions of the plains are to be equals of the privileged few.
('51', 298, 1, 19, 587969) It is to be feared therefore that before we reach the state of equality, the levelling process will have to be gone through.
('51', 298, 1, 20, 588094) Justice demands this.
('51', 298, 1, 21, 588116) It will be a misnomer to call the process one of racial discrimination.
('51', 298, 1, 22, 588188) There is no such question.
('51', 298, 1, 23, 588215) There is room enough in our country for every British man, woman and child, if they will shed their privileged position and share our lot.
('51', 298, 1, 24, 588354) They must then exchange the British army and the force of the cities for the goodwill of a whole nation, which is at their disposal for the asking.
('51', 298, 1, 25, 588502) Our goodwill is the truest safeguard that we can offer to them and I make bold to say that will be infinitely better and more dignified both of us.In the process there will be apparent discrimination felt everywhere.
('51', 298, 1, 26, 588719) It need not be felt by those who realize that the present is a wrong and unnatural

('51', 299, 1, 2, 588900) position.

('51', 299, 1, 4, 589147) The true formula therefore should be this.

('51', 300, 1, 2, 590934) 346. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('51', 300, 2, 3, 590964) KARACHI, March 26, 1931 I failed in my efforts to bring about the commutation of the death sentences on Bhagat Singh and his friends, and that is why the young men vented their wrath against me.
('51', 300, 2, 4, 591159) 2 I was quite prepared for it.
('51', 300, 2, 5, 591190) Although they were incensed against me, they gave vent to their wrath in what I would call a most dignified manner.
('51', 300, 2, 6, 591306) It was open to them to do physical injury but they refrained from doing so.
('51', 300, 2, 7, 591382) It was open to them to insult me in many other ways, but they confined their resentment and insult to handing me black cloth flowers representing, I imagine, the ashes of the three patriots.
('51', 300, 2, 8, 591573) These also they could have showered on me or thrown at me instead of which they gave me the option of receiving the flowers from their hands which I did gratefully.
('51', 300, 2, 9, 591738) Of course, they shouted, “Down with Gandhism”, “Go back Gandhi”.
('51', 300, 2, 10, 591803) This I consider to be a legitimate expression of their anger.
('51', 300, 2, 11, 591865) Having been used to such an exhibition and that in a much worse and in more serious form, I was unruffled and took these insults as only a mild expression of their deep grief and consequent anger.
('51', 300, 2, 12, 592062) I am only hoping that they will exercise the restraint that they did yesterday throughout the Congress session for they know I am trying to reach the same goal with them.
('51', 300, 2, 13, 592233) Only I am following a method wholly different from theirs.
('51', 300, 2, 14, 592292) I have not a shadow of a doubt that as time goes they will discover the error of their ways.
('51', 300, 2, 15, 592385) Whatever may be true of other countries, in this country which is teeming with famished millions the cult of violence can have no meaning.
('51', 300, 2, 16, 592524) In this country of self suppression and timidity almost bordering on cowardice we cannot have too much bravery, too much self sacrifice.
('51', 300, 2, 17, 592661) One’s head bends before Bhagat Singh’s bravery and sacrifice.
('51', 300, 2, 18, 592723) But I want the greater bravery, if I might say so without offending my young friends, of the meek, the gentle and the non violent, the bravery that will mount the gallows without injuring, or harbouring any thought of injury to a single soul.
('51', 300, 3, 19, 592966) Does the execution of Bhagat Singh and his friends alter your position in any way with regard to the settlement?
('51', 300, 4, 20, 593079) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 Gandhiji refers to the demonstration by members (wearing red shirts)of Naujawan Bharat Sabha, on his arrival at Malir station near Karachi; vide also “Speech at Karachi congress”, 26 3 1931.
('51', 301, 0, 1, 593321) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 301, 1, 2, 593363) My own personal position remains absolutely the same, though the provocation has been of the most intense character.
('51', 301, 1, 3, 593480) I must confess that the staying of these executions was no part of the truce, and so far as I am concerned, no provocation offered outside the terms will deflect me from the path I had mapped out when I agreed to the settlement.
('51', 301, 2, 4, 593709) Do you not think it impolitic to forgive a government which has been guilty of a thousand murders?
('51', 301, 2, 5, 593808) I do not know a single instance where forgiveness has been found so wanting as to be impolitic.
('51', 301, 3, 6, 593904) But no country has ever shown such forgiveness as India is showing to Britain?

('51', 301, 3, 8, 594014) What is true of individuals is true of nations.
('51', 301, 3, 9, 594062) One cannot forgive too much.

('51', 301, 4, 13, 594185) 347. STATEMENT ON KANPUR RIOTS
('51', 301, 5, 14, 594216) KARACHI, March 26, 1931
('51', 301, 6, 15, 594240) Gandhiji who was at the Working Committee meeting was informed of the state of affairs in Cawnpore by the representative of the Associated Press and he made the following statement : The Working Committee which is sitting at the time of giving this message having read the report of the awful communal strife going on in Cawnpore has felt troubled and grieved over the events there.
('51', 301, 6, 16, 594623) I cannot too strongly condemn this strife.
('51', 301, 6, 17, 594666) A committee will certainly investigate the causes, but indications have been coming in from other sources also to show that the slightest thing disturbs the mental balance.
('51', 301, 6, 18, 594839) I can only hope that the poison will not be allowed to stay and that people will remain calm and not allow the harmonious relations to be disturbed.
('51', 301, 6, 19, 594988) I hope also that the local leaders in Cawnpore will put their heads together and quickly restore peace.
('51', 301, 6, 20, 595092) Let it be remembered by those who are in a hurry to achieve India’s freedom that every such strife makes progress towards the goal more and more difficult.
('51', 301, 6, 21, 595248) The Bombay Chronicle, 27 3 1931
('51', 302, 0, 1, 595280) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 303
('51', 302, 1, 2, 595325) 348. REPLY TO INDIAN MERCHANTS’ ASSOCIATIONS, KARACHI
('51', 302, 2, 3, 595379) March 26, 1931
('51', 302, 3, 4, 595394) A deputation of Indian merchants of Karachi representing Buyers’ and Shippers’ Chambers and Indian Merchants’ Association led by Mr. Jamshed Mehta waited on the Congress Working Committee this morning, in connection with the demand of British commercial interests for equality of trading rights with Indians.
('51', 302, 4, 5, 595703) Gandhiji who replied on behalf of the Working Committee stated that the Congress needed no urging in that connection and would take all possible steps to get the clause about the equality of trading rights totally rescinded.
('51', 302, 4, 6, 595928) The Congress, he added, felt even more strongly on the question than the merchants themselves and would certainly go further than the demand put forward by the deputationists in safeguarding Indian interests.
('51', 302, 5, 7, 596137) Gandhiji compared the demand for equality of the powerful British commercial community with Indians, as a demand on behalf of an elephant to be on equal plane with an ant.
('51', 302, 5, 8, 596309) Gandhiji said he had dealt with the question in Young India in connection with a letter addressed by Mr. Walchand Hirachand regarding the interview a Bombay merchant had with him.
('51', 302, 5, 9, 596489) Gandhiji said it however was not possible nor politic to exaggerate the power of Congress as was seen in the case of Bhagat Singh and his comrades whose execution the Congress has been helpless to prevent, despite their best efforts.
('51', 302, 6, 10, 596723) But on behalf of the Congress he wanted to assure the deputationists that whether it was Dominion Status, or anything else, any constitution which impaired in any way the right of the future Indian Parliament to discriminate against non national, whenever necessary, as in the national, interest, was worthless and would not be acceptable to the Congress.
('51', 302, 6, 11, 597079) Gandhiji added that the assurance was a pledge.
('51', 302, 6, 12, 597127) On his part he urged the Indian mercantile community to play a greater part in national struggle than what they had hitherto done and suggested them to treat the poorer sections of the people, including labourers and untouchables, as their own kith and kin.
('51', 302, 6, 13, 597385) The Bombay Chronicle, 27 3 1931

('51', 302, 8, 15, 597451) March 26, 1931
('51', 302, 9, 16, 597466) The first speech in the Congress pandal, or the inauguration address if I may so call it, was delivered by Gandhiji on the 26th, when a vast audience listened to him
('51', 302, 10, 17, 597632) 1 As reported by Mahadev Desai, under the title “Under the Canopy of Heaven”

('51', 303, 1, 3, 597763) The canopy of heaven, under which the Congress is meeting for the first time in its history, lent not only special charm and colour to the address, but also a rare inspiration, to which the great silence around him also contributed.
('51', 303, 1, 4, 597996) This is how he began : We are accustomed to think of heaven as the Kingdom of God.
('51', 303, 1, 5, 598079) We imagine that He sends us His messages and commands from above and we thus establish communion with Him.
('51', 303, 1, 6, 598186) Until now we had a screen between God and us.

('51', 303, 1, 9, 598486) We have chosen for our march towards freedom the ancient path of truth and non violence, and we must let God’s covenant that those who tread on the strait and narrow path shall never come to grief inspire us with faith and hope.
('51', 303, 1, 10, 598715) By the executions the Government have given the nation grave cause for provocation.
('51', 303, 1, 11, 598799) It has shocked me too inasmuch as my negotiations and talks had made me entertain a distant hope that Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev might be saved.
('51', 303, 1, 12, 598951) I am not surprised that young men are angry with me for not having been able to save them.
('51', 303, 1, 13, 599042) But I have no reason to be angry with them.
('51', 303, 1, 14, 599086) For one thing, this is not the first occasion of its kind in my life.
('51', 303, 1, 15, 599156) It is the duty of him who claims to serve humanity not to be angry with those whom he is serving.

('51', 308, 9, 19, 611724) On the question of Federation, Gandhiji, in the course of his conference with workers who interviewed him, is reported to have expressed his view that the Congress should not put express conditions because the Princes were shy and were likely to be frightened.
('51', 308, 9, 20, 611985) He was not prepared to allow the Princes to break away by the Congress insisting on too many conditions precedent.
('51', 308, 9, 21, 612100) But he was going to use his influence with the Princes, if necessity arises, to make them recognize the need for satisfying the States people’s claims to a reasonable extent.
('51', 308, 10, 22, 612275) Gandhiji continues to feel that he is not able yet to see light in respect of the communal settlement and appears to think that the Congress would be well advised not to say anything definitely about it.
('51', 308, 11, 23, 612479) Among the earliest interviewers today were Mr. Subhas Bose and Mr. Satyamurti, both of whom pressed for insisting on the release of all prisoners sentenced in connection with the civil disobedience movement, the former going further and urging release of all Bengal detenus.
('51', 308, 12, 24, 612754) Gandhiji is reported to have assured them that there was no need to make any express conditions in these matters, because he had always insisted upon these things in his conversations with the Viceroy and he was satisfied that, after some time, all prisoners would be released.

('51', 310, 1, 2, 615106) 353. DISCUSSION WITH RED SHIRTS OF NAUJAWAN BHARAT SABHA 1
('51', 310, 2, 3, 615165) [March 27, 1931] 2
('51', 310, 3, 4, 615184) A few representatives of the Red Shirts waited in deputation on Gandhiji and he had a long heart to heart talk with them.
('51', 310, 3, 5, 615306) They explained that it was never their intention to do any physical harm to him, that his life and his health were as dear to them as to anyone else, and that individual terrorism was not their creed.
('51', 310, 3, 6, 615507) They were adamant in their quarrel with the truce which, they believed, can never lead them to their goal of Workers’ and Peasants’ Free Republic in India.
('51', 310, 3, 7, 615663) Gandhiji said : But my dear young men, go and see Bihar and you will find a workers’ and peasants’ republic working there.
('51', 310, 3, 8, 615786) Where there was fear and slavery ten years ago, there is courage and bravery and resistance to wrong.
('51', 310, 3, 9, 615888) If you want capital to be extinct or you want to abolish moneyed men or the capitalists, you will never succeed.
('51', 310, 3, 10, 616001) What you must do is to demonstrate to the capitalists the power of labour and they will consent to be the trustees of those who toil for them.
('51', 310, 3, 11, 616144) I do not want anything more for workers and peasants than enough to eat and house and clothe themselves and live in ordinary comfort as self respecting human beings.
('51', 310, 3, 12, 616310) After that condition of things is brought about the brainiest among them will certainly manage to acquire more wealth than the rest.
('51', 310, 3, 13, 616443) But I have told you what I want.
('51', 310, 3, 14, 616476) I want the rich to hold their riches in trust for the poor or to give them up for them.
('51', 310, 3, 15, 616564) Do you know that I gave up all my property when I founded Tolstoy Farm?
('51', 310, 3, 16, 616636) Ruskin’sUnto This Last inspired me and I built my farm on those lines.
('51', 310, 3, 17, 616707) You will now recognize that I am, so to say, a “foundation member” of your peasants’ and workers’ republic.
('51', 310, 3, 18, 616815) And what do you prize more, wealth or work?
('51', 310, 3, 19, 616859) Supposing you were to be stranded in the desert of Sahara with cart loads of money, how would it help you?
('51', 310, 3, 20, 616966) But if you can work you may not have to go hungry.
('51', 310, 3, 21, 617017) How then is wealth to be preferred to work?
('51', 310, 3, 22, 617061) Go and see for yourselves the Labour Union of Ahmedabad at work and see how they are trying to establish a republic of their own.
('51', 310, 4, 23, 617191) Q. Punjab is goonda raj, Mahatmaji.
('51', 310, 4, 24, 617227) Where do find the change of heart?
('51', 310, 5, 25, 617262) A. But I never said that there had been a change of heart on the part of the Government.

('51', 311, 4, 12, 618224) Gandhiji spoke both in the Subjects Committee and the open Congress 3 on the resolution 4 on provisional settlement.
('51', 311, 4, 13, 618341) Here is a report of the English speech in the Subjects Committee : Though the resolution before you is very brief, I venture to suggest to you that it is very comprehensive and capable of passing the most rigorous test that a man who believes in complete independence can exact.
('51', 311, 4, 14, 618620) The resolution makes it incumbent upon any delegation that may take part in the Conference deliberations to bear in mind the Congress goal, or as it is called the Congress objective of purna swaraj as stated in the Lahore resolution, and not in the Madras resolution which was a pious wish.
('51', 311, 4, 15, 618911) Purna swaraj is not a pious wish today.
('51', 311, 4, 16, 618951) Purna swaraj is the incessant yearning of the soul of the nation which is impatient to get it, and its impatience was demonstrated during the past twelve months.
('51', 311, 4, 17, 619113) And so it is the immediate objective that the delegation has got to keep in view in agreeing to any single thing that may happen in the Conference.
('51', 311, 4, 18, 619261) But that is not enough.
('51', 311, 4, 19, 619285) Some idea or some inkling of purna swaraj or complete independence has also been given here as essential, and so it is incumbent upon your delegation to obtain control over the defence forces, etc.

('51', 312, 1, 2, 619810) But the trap—or sting as you would call it—is in the tail of the resolution : “Provided, however, the Congress delegation would be free to accept such adjustments as may be necessary in the interests of India.” Now in this there is a trap and there is no trap.
('51', 312, 1, 3, 620071) There is no trap if you will choose your delegation well and trust it.
('51', 312, 1, 4, 620142) There is a trap because ‘adjustments’ is really synonymous with ‘safeguards’.
('51', 312, 1, 5, 620220) The principle of safeguards is accepted in the terms of the settlement, but the safeguards that might be accepted have to be in the interests of India, and they must be demonstrably necessary, not merely absolutely necessary as it has been suggested in one of the many amendments.
('51', 312, 1, 6, 620501) Demonstrably for our purpose is a superior word to absolutely.
('51', 312, 1, 7, 620564) I have given my meaning of the ‘safeguards’ very fully elsewhere 1 and I will not dilate upon it.
('51', 312, 1, 8, 620662) Having said this, I want to say something about another amend ment that has been suggested, that whatever action the delegates may take should be subject to ratification by a special session of the Congress or by the All India Congress Committee.I venture to suggest to you with all the force at my command, that this is not only unnece ssary but unbecoming of a Congress thathas lived progressively for the past 45 years and has acquired a prestige unrivalled by any other organi zation in India and a prestige now acquired by it throughout the world.
('51', 312, 1, 9, 621215) Surely this Congress is not so poor as not to be able to produce representatives who can fully represent the Congress at any conference or any assembly.
('51', 312, 1, 10, 621368) Therefore if you send your delegation, that delegation should have the same powers as if the whole Congress was being transported to the Conference.
('51', 312, 1, 11, 621517) Without that matters such as those that confront us really cannot be adjusted.
('51', 312, 1, 12, 621596) We will be one among many parties.
('51', 312, 1, 13, 621631) Those who go to the Conference are expected to have full credentials and full authority to bind their principals.
('51', 312, 1, 14, 621745) But if they go there and have to say, ‘We have come here, we will discuss; but we cannot bind our principals, we shall have to refer to our principals’, the procedure becomes interminable, cumbrous and wholly ineffective for the purpose in view.
('51', 312, 1, 15, 621991) Hence it is absolutely necessary not to put any such proviso as has been suggested.
('51', 312, 1, 16, 622075) What is the position of the Congress, inter se?
('51', 312, 1, 17, 622123) What is the position of the Congress with reference to the intermediate bodies, the All India Congress Committee and the Working Committee?
('51', 312, 1, 18, 622263) Although the committees are given a general power of attorney to act on behalf of the Congress, still the right of repudiation is a right of

('51', 316, 1, 12, 631545) However, there are some rights which do credit to those who possess them only if they are enjoyed in name only.
('51', 316, 1, 13, 631657) If a person exercises all his rights on all occasions, in the end they are destroyed.
('51', 316, 1, 14, 631743) On this occasion, the Government would have brought credit to itself if it had not exercised its rights and this would have been highly useful in maintaining peace.
('51', 316, 1, 15, 631908) However, it is obvious that the Government has not to date develo ped such discretion.

('51', 316, 1, 22, 632493) We should not break the pledge we have taken just because our hopes have not been fulfilled, but should bear this blow which has fallen upon us and honour our pledge.
('51', 316, 1, 23, 632660) By doing so under even such trying circumstances, our strength to get what we desire will increase rather than decrease, while, if we break our pledge or violate the truce, we shall suffer loss of vigour, loss of strength and it will add to our present difficulties in reaching our objective.
('51', 316, 1, 24, 632953) Hence our dharma is to swallow our anger, abide by the settlement and carry out our duty.

('51', 317, 1, 2, 633122) 356. THE ANSARI DHARMASALA
('51', 317, 2, 3, 633149) I had had plenty of experience of Dr. Ansari’s generosity, but during my recent trip to Delhi I had more of it at his house.
('51', 317, 2, 4, 633274) He insisted that all the members of the Working Committee should put up with him.
('51', 317, 2, 5, 633356) Besides these, there were other guests also.
('51', 317, 2, 6, 633401) His large bungalow having proved incommodious, tents had to be put up in his compound.
('51', 317, 2, 7, 633488) There must have been some hundred guests having their meals at his home every day.
('51', 317, 2, 8, 633571) On the one hand, there was his large practice and the time which had to be devoted to it and, on the other, there was a stream of people from the native States coming and going and then again there was his hospitality to be offered to so many guests and the talks to be held in connection with the work of the Congress.
('51', 317, 2, 9, 633891) Despite all this, I have never found Dr. Ansari overcome by worry, become impatient or lose his temper.
('51', 317, 2, 10, 633995) An ordinary man would have got tired if he had to accommodate such a large number of guests.
('51', 317, 2, 11, 634088) I never found any trace of fatigue in Dr. Ansari.
('51', 317, 2, 12, 634138) What must be the explanation for such good organization?
('51', 317, 2, 13, 634195) It was Begum Ansari.
('51', 317, 2, 14, 634216) One day I asked Dr. Ansari in the presence of Begum Ansari, “How is it that you can cope with so many persons having their meals and so on, with you?’ He replied, “The credit for all this goes to the Begum Saheba.
('51', 317, 2, 15, 634430) I make over to her whatever I earn.
('51', 317, 2, 16, 634466) She is very well versed in Urdu and maintains an account of every single pie spent.
('51', 317, 2, 17, 634550) She orders whatever she wishes and spends whatever she likes.
('51', 317, 2, 18, 634612) Hence I have never borne the worries of running a household.” Hearing this, I bowed my head to Begum Ansari.
('51', 317, 2, 19, 634721) It is not that there is only one such woman among Hindus and Muslims, there must be countless numbers of them in every nook and corner.
('51', 317, 2, 20, 634857) We do not know of them.
('51', 317, 2, 21, 634881) Readers will be happy to learn that there are two kitchens running in Dr. Ansari’s home.
('51', 317, 2, 22, 634970) Brahmin cooks prepare separate meals for those who are vegetarians.

('51', 319, 3, 4, 636443) 360. RESOLUTION ON PROVISIONAL SETTLEMENT 1
('51', 319, 4, 5, 636487) [March 29, 1931] 2
('51', 319, 5, 6, 636506) This Congress, having considered the Provisional Settlement between the Working Committee and the Government of India, endorses it, and desires to make it clear that the Congress goal of purna swaraj (complete independence) remains intact.
('51', 319, 5, 7, 636746) In the event of the way being otherwise open to the Congress to be represented at any conference with the representatives of the British Government, the Congress delegation will work for this goal and, in particular, so as to give the nation control over the army, external affairs, finance and fiscal and economic policy, and to have a scrutiny, by an impartial tribunal, of the financial transactions of the British Government in India and to examine and assess the obligations to be undertaken by India or England, and the right to either party to end the partnership at will; provided, however, that the Congress delegation will be free to accept such adjustments as may be demonstrably necessary in the interest of India.
('51', 319, 5, 8, 637473) The Congress appoints and authorizes Mahatma Gandhi to represent it at the Conference with the addition of such other delegates as the Working Committee may appoint to act under his leadership.
('51', 319, 6, 9, 637667) From a photostat : C.W. 9345. Courtesy : India Office Library

('51', 324, 5, 24, 651367) It is open to every one of you to reject the resolution and to repudiate the settlement if you wish to.
('51', 324, 5, 25, 651471) But if you endorse the settlement, then it is also your duty actively to support it, carry out all its items faithfully and honourably and do the various things which are set out before you in the resolution, so that you daily increase the
('51', 325, 0, 1, 651711) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 325, 1, 2, 651753) power of the Congress andmake it possible for the Congress delegation to vindicate the position of the Congress and possibly to bring the very thing for which you have suffered for the last twelve months.
('51', 325, 1, 3, 651958) One thing more.
('51', 325, 1, 4, 651974) If this delegation goes as far as the Conference, it does not mean that the delegation will bring in its pocket purna swaraj.
('51', 325, 1, 5, 652100) If it does not bring purna swaraj, it does not mean that it returns humiliated.
('51', 325, 1, 6, 652180) Nothing of the kind.
('51', 325, 1, 7, 652201) All that we expect to be able to do is to go and tell the British people and the British Minister what we want, and if we do not get what the Congress expects the delega tion to accept within the terms of the resolution, we are bound to return empty handed and receive your compliments, not curse.
('51', 325, 1, 8, 652499) But you will be entitled to give us curses if we return having sold the interests of the country.
('51', 325, 1, 9, 652597) That is what you have a perfect right to do.
('51', 325, 1, 10, 652642) But it will not be proper for you to say, ‘you were not able to fulfil your promises.’ No promise has ever been made.
('51', 325, 1, 11, 652760) No promise is being made now that if the deputation goes to the Conference, whether here or in England, or enters upon further negotiations, that deputation is going to bring purna swaraj.
('51', 325, 1, 12, 652949) Purna swaraj will come when the full authority of the Congress has been manifested and not a minute before.
('51', 325, 1, 13, 653057) It will be the greatest achievement of the Congress to bring swaraj if it does.
('51', 325, 1, 14, 653137) All that I promise faithfully to you on my own behalf and on behalf of any delegation that you might wish to send with me is that we shall not be disloyal to the Congress in any shape or form.
('51', 325, 2, 15, 653330) The appeal did not fall on deaf ears, practically all the amendments were
('51', 325, 3, 16, 653404) withdrawn, and the resolution was passed without the change of a comma or colon.

('51', 326, 1, 2, 653569) 362. RESOLUTION ON FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND ECONOMIC CHANGES 1
('51', 326, 2, 3, 653630) March 31, 1931 This Congress is of opinion that to enable the masses to appre ciate what swaraj, as conceived by the Congress, will mean to them, it is desirable to state the position of the Congress in a manner easily understood by them.
('51', 326, 2, 4, 653869) In order to end the exploitation of the masses, political freedom must include real economic freedom of the starving millions.
('51', 326, 2, 5, 653996) The Congress, therefore, declare that any constitution which may be agreed to on its behalf should provide, or enable the Swaraj Government to provide, for the following : 1. Fundamental rights of the people, including : (a) freedom of association and combination; (b) freedom of speech and of the Press; (c) freedom of conscience and the free profession and practice of religion, subject to public order and morality; (d) protection of the culture, language and scripts of the minorities; (e) equal rights and obligations of all citizens, without any bar on account of sex; (f) no disability to attach to any citizen by reason of his or her religions, caste or creed or sex in regard to public employment, office of power or honour and in the exercise of any trade or calling; (g) equal rights to all citizens in regard to public roads, wells, schools and other places of public resort; (h) right to keep and bear arms in accordance with regulations and reservations made in that behalf; (i) no person shall be deprived of his liberty nor shall his dwelling or property be entered, sequestered or confiscated, save in accordane with law.
('51', 326, 2, 6, 655135) 2. Religious neutrality on the part of the State.
('51', 326, 2, 7, 655185) 3. Adult suffrage.
('51', 326, 2, 8, 655204) 4. Free primary education.
('51', 326, 3, 9, 655231) 1 Presumably drafted by Gandhiji
('51', 327, 0, 1, 655264) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 327, 1, 2, 655306) 5. A living wage for industrial workers, limited hours of labour, healthy conditions of work, protection against the economic consequences of old age, sickness and unemployment.
('51', 327, 1, 3, 655484) 6. Labour to be freed from serfdom or conditions bordering on serfdom.
('51', 327, 1, 4, 655555) 7. Protection of women workers, and specially adequate provisions for leave during maternity period.
('51', 327, 1, 5, 655656) 8. Prohibition against employment of children of school going age in factories.
('51', 327, 1, 6, 655736) 9. Rights of labour to form unions to protect their interests with suitable machinery for settlement of disputes by arbitration.
('51', 327, 1, 7, 655865) 10. Substantial reduction in agricultural rent or revenue paid by the peasantry, and in case of uneconomic holdings exemption from rent for such period as may be necessary, relief being given to small zamindars wherever necessary by reason of such reduction.
('51', 327, 1, 8, 656124) 11. Imposition of a progressive income tax on agricultral incomes above a fixed minimum.
('51', 327, 1, 9, 656213) 12. A graduated inheritance tax.
('51', 327, 1, 10, 656246) 13. Military expenditure to be reduced by at least one half of the present scale.
('51', 327, 1, 11, 656328) 14. Expenditure and salaries in civil departments to be largely reduced.
('51', 327, 1, 12, 656401) No servant of the State, other than specially employed experts and the like, to be paid above a certain fixed figure which should not ordinarily exceed Rs. 500 per month.
('51', 327, 1, 13, 656572) 15. Protection of indigenous cloth by exclusion of foreign cloth and foreign yarn from the country.
('51', 327, 1, 14, 656672) 16. Total prohibition of intoxicating drinks and drugs.
('51', 327, 1, 15, 656728) 17. No duty on salt manufactured in India.
('51', 327, 1, 16, 656771) 18. Control over exchange and currency policy so as to help Indian industries and bring relief to the masses.
('51', 327, 1, 17, 656881) 19. Control by the State of key industries and ownership of mineral resources.
('51', 327, 1, 18, 656960) 20. Control of usury—direct or indirect.
('51', 327, 1, 19, 657001) It shall be open to the A.I.C.C. to revise, amend or add to the foregoing so far as such revision, amendment or addition is not inconsistent with the policy and principles thereof.
('51', 327, 2, 20, 657182) A.I.C.C. File No.
('51', 327, 2, 21, 657200) 199, 1931. Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('51', 328, 0, 1, 657256) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 329
('51', 328, 1, 2, 657301) 363. SPEECH ON FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS, KARACHI CONGRESS 1
('51', 328, 2, 3, 657355) March 31, 1931
('51', 328, 3, 4, 657370) In moving the resolution 2 on fundamental rights in the open Congress Gandhiji, speaking in Hindi, said : This resolution is meant for those who are no legislators, who are not interested in intricate questions of constitution, who will not take an active part in the administration of the country.
('51', 328, 3, 5, 657669) It is meant to indicate to the poor, inarticulate Indian the broad features of swaraj or Ramarajya.
('51', 328, 3, 6, 657769) Before my march to Dandi I had included some of these features in my eleven points.
('51', 328, 3, 7, 657853) These have been made more compre hensive.
('51', 328, 3, 8, 657895) They are now presented to you in a separate resolution.
('51', 328, 3, 9, 657951) They were advisedly omitted from the main resolution because that would have made the mandate for the delegation burdensome.
('51', 328, 3, 10, 658076) But by passing this resolution we make it clear to the world and to our own people what we propose to do as soon as we come into power.
('51', 328, 3, 11, 658212) Let Government also take note of it.
('51', 328, 3, 12, 658249) Let those who may have to deal with us at the Round Table Conference also take note of the fact that the Viceroy, under swaraj, should not get more than Rs. 500 per month.
('51', 328, 3, 13, 658421) The position has been made as clear as possible, in order that we may not be accused of having sprung sudden surprises on those who have to deal with us.
('51', 328, 3, 14, 658575) They are also meant to forewarn all concerned.
('51', 328, 3, 15, 658622) Let them prepare themselves for the coming legislation by modelling their lives in the light of coming changes.
('51', 328, 3, 16, 658734) I shall take a few instances.
('51', 328, 3, 17, 658764) Clause I (d) of the fundamental rights protects the culture, language and scripts of the minority.
('51', 328, 3, 18, 658863) Now though I am sure that Islamic and Aryan cultures are not mutually exclusive and fundamentally different, I must recognize that Mussal mans look upon Islamic culture as distinctive from Aryan.
('51', 328, 3, 19, 659059) Let us therefore cultivate tolerance.
('51', 328, 3, 20, 659097) Let us try to learn the Urdu language and Urdu script and understand the Mussalmans’ insistence on it.
('51', 328, 3, 21, 659200) Then there is the abolition of all disabilities attaching to women, in regard to public employment, office of power or honour, etc.
('51', 328, 3, 22, 659332) The moment this is done many of the disabilities to which the women are
('51', 328, 4, 23, 659404) 1 This appeared under the title “Gandhiji on the Main Resolutions” with a sub heading “The Twenty Points”.
('51', 328, 4, 24, 659511) 2 For the text of the resolution, vide the preceding item.
('51', 329, 0, 1, 659570) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 329, 1, 2, 659612) subjected will cease.
('51', 329, 1, 3, 659634) So far as the Congress is concerned, we have admitted no such disability.
('51', 329, 1, 4, 659708) We have had Dr.Besant and Shrimati Sarojini Devi as our presidents and in the future free State it will be open to us to have women presidents.
('51', 329, 1, 5, 659852) Religious neutrality is another important provision.
('51', 329, 1, 6, 659905) Swaraj will favour Hinduism no more than Islam, nor Islam more than Hinduism.
('51', 329, 1, 7, 659983) But in order that we may have a State based on religious neutrality, let us from now adopt the principle in our daily affairs.
('51', 329, 1, 8, 660110) Let not a Hindu merchant hesitate to have deserving Muslims as his employees, and let every Congressman make religious neutrality his creed in every walk of life.
('51', 329, 1, 9, 660273) Item number five deserves the immediate attention of all mill and factory owners who should anticipate humane legislation fore shadowed in the clause.
('51', 329, 1, 10, 660424) The last item relates to the control of usury.
('51', 329, 1, 11, 660471) Islam strictly prohibits the charging of interest but there is no reason why usury should not be regarded as criminal in a Hindu.
('51', 329, 1, 12, 660601) The Pathans have forgotten the Islamic injunction, have followed our bad example and are known to charge from 200 to 300 per cent interest.
('51', 329, 1, 13, 660741) I wish I could persuade Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan to go to our parts to wean his co religionists from usury.
('51', 329, 1, 14, 660847) Let also our bankers and money lenders betimes make drastic reductions in their rates of interest, lest drastic legislation should find them unprepared.
('51', 329, 1, 15, 661000) The peasants are being crushed to extinction.
('51', 329, 1, 16, 661046) So let the money lenders adopt 8 per cent as the maximum rate to afford them some relief.
('51', 329, 1, 17, 661136) Let the zamindars and the Maharajas be assured that the Con gress does not seek to destroy them, but is determined to destroy all wrong and injustice.
('51', 329, 1, 18, 661287) Let them make an earnest endeavour to under stand the grievances of their tenants and introduce adequate measures of relief before legislation overtakes them.
('51', 329, 1, 19, 661446) It is open to them to join the Congress as Raja Saheb of Kalakankar and Chowdhary Raghuvir narayan Sinha have done.
('51', 329, 1, 20, 661562) Let it be understood that this resolution by no means has any finality.
('51', 329, 1, 21, 661634) It is open to the A.I.C.C. to revise, amend or add to the twenty points and so let no one oppose the resolution for mere diffe rence on matters of detail.
('51', 329, 1, 22, 661789) Those however who are opposed to the policy and principle must reject it, but they must bear in mind that
('51', 330, 0, 1, 661895) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 331
('51', 330, 1, 2, 661940) the poor man’s swaraj is soon coming and let them not be found unprepared when it actually comes.
