('51', 331, 1, 2, 663549) 366. INTERVIEW TO “THE STATESMAN”
('51', 331, 2, 3, 663583) KARACHI, April 1, 1931
('51', 331, 3, 4, 663606) In an hour’s conversation with me early this morning, Mr. Gandhi indicated in
('51', 331, 4, 5, 663684) some measure the manner in which he would put his case at the Round Table
('51', 331, 5, 6, 663758) Conference, his attitude on the question of safeguards, his fears and hopes for the
('51', 331, 6, 7, 663842) communal problem and last, but not least, his faith in the honesty of Great Britain’s
('51', 331, 7, 8, 663928) present policy towards India, however mistaken that policy may be.
('51', 331, 8, 9, 663995) He said that on the whole he was very well content with the week’s work in
('51', 331, 9, 10, 664070) Congress.
('51', 331, 10, 11, 664080) I asked Mr. Gandhi if he felt secure in the freedom of the mandate that
('51', 331, 11, 12, 664152) Congress had given him for his work at the Round Table Conference.
('51', 331, 11, 13, 664219) He replied : The mandate is not an absolutely free mandate, for I am bound by the terms of the main resolution 1 passed by the Congress this week.
('51', 331, 11, 14, 664366) I do not think you could say that those terms are exactly ambiguous, but rather that they are fairly comprehensive.
('51', 331, 11, 15, 664482) Yet they do allow me some latitude, for obviously there must be latitude in a discussion such as we shall have at the Conference.
('51', 331, 11, 16, 664612) For instance, the words“such adjustments as may be demonstrably nece ssary in the interest of India” mean what they say, but they give us an opportunity to modify as well as to constrict our present ideas about safeguards and other things if we find that must be done for the sake of freedom.
('51', 331, 11, 17, 664905) We are prepared to surrender what can be surrendered with honour, but there can be no dishonourable surrender.
('51', 331, 12, 18, 665016) Q. What exactly do you mean by this new term ‘equality of partnerships’?
('51', 331, 12, 19, 665089) Does it mean a national status like Australia’s within the British Commonwealth of Nations?
('51', 331, 13, 20, 665181) A. No, it does not mean that.
('51', 331, 13, 21, 665211) Until a short time ago I thought that such a status would be suitable for India, but now I have come to see that certain things stand in the way.
('51', 331, 13, 22, 665357) You see, the nations in the British Commonwealth are essentially British or, as in the case of South Africa, are closely identified with British ideas and culture.
('51', 331, 13, 23, 665521) Their people are racially British and their institutions are British.
('51', 331, 13, 24, 665591) We cannot say that of India.
('51', 331, 13, 25, 665620) We do not aspire
('51', 331, 14, 26, 665637) 1 Vide “Resolution on provisional settlement”, 29 3 1931.
('51', 332, 0, 1, 665695) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 333
('51', 332, 1, 2, 665740) to identify our culture with British and the West.
('51', 332, 1, 3, 665791) We are content and passionately want to retain and develop our own culture and order of society.
('51', 332, 1, 4, 665888) So there is no real analogy at all between, say, Australia’s status and India’s future status within the British Commonwealth.
('51', 332, 1, 5, 666015) There can, however, be a partnership between Britain and India which will mean a bandobast 1 between the two countries for assistance, one to the other, in many things and for reciprocal obligations.
('51', 332, 2, 6, 666215) You mean, a kind of semi contractual alliance.
('51', 332, 2, 7, 666262) Just as England has an alliance
('51', 332, 3, 8, 666294) with France for certain purposes of war, so you want an alliance between Britain and
('51', 332, 4, 9, 666379) India, only this alliance will cover several other things besides war and will be a more
('51', 332, 5, 10, 666468) fruitful and, let us say, a happier partnership than an alliance merely for war?
('51', 332, 5, 11, 666549) Yes, yes, that’s it exactly.
('51', 332, 6, 12, 666578) And you do not want any more Viceroys, any more Lord Irwins?
('51', 332, 6, 13, 666639) No, I do not want any more Lord Irwins, any more Viceroys.
('51', 332, 7, 14, 666698) But when you get to the Round Table Conference, will you keep your mind open to conviction that Dominion Status will be suitable to India?
('51', 332, 7, 15, 666837) If you come to see there that membership of the British Commonwealth would be in India’s honourable interests, would you accept Dominion Status?
('51', 332, 7, 16, 666982) I am open to conviction about that, but I cannot conceive of its possibility.
('51', 332, 7, 17, 667060) If I were persuaded of what you say, then I should frankly confess it and I should do my utmost to bring Congress round to the same point of view.
('51', 332, 7, 18, 667207) Acceptance of Dominion Status is outside the mandate.
('51', 332, 7, 19, 667261) There must therefore be previous reference to the All India Congress Committee and may be even to the Congress.
('51', 332, 7, 20, 667373) But there will not be any quarrel about words.
('51', 332, 7, 21, 667420) If there has to be a quarrel, it will be about the substance.
('51', 332, 8, 22, 667482) And what about these safeguards, Mr. Gandhi?
('51', 332, 8, 23, 667527) The Working Committee admits the necessity for certain safeguards.
('51', 332, 8, 24, 667594) Is one of them the retention of British troops in India?
('51', 332, 8, 25, 667651) I myself do not believe that any Army, Indian or British, is necessary at all, but there the Working Committee disagrees with me.
('51', 332, 8, 26, 667781) That being so, I am prepared to agree that for a transitional period the Indian Army will need some British officers, because you have never allowed our own officers to learn all that must be learned about modern warfare.
('51', 332, 8, 27, 668003) Perhaps some British regiments would be necessary
('51', 332, 9, 28, 668053) 1 Arrangement
('51', 333, 0, 1, 668067) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 333, 1, 2, 668109) also, partly for the same reasons.
('51', 333, 1, 3, 668144) But they must be subject to the control of the Indian Government.
('51', 333, 2, 4, 668210) But how and why do you expect that they will be willing to serve here under an
('51', 333, 3, 5, 668289) alien Government?
('51', 333, 3, 6, 668307) Well, we have known of mercenary armies in Europe in the past and though the inspiration of patriotism has supplanted pure mercenarism, the soldier asks for and receives monetary wages for his services.
('51', 333, 3, 7, 668510) Why should he not be willing to lend his services on similar terms for the common good of humanity?
('51', 333, 3, 8, 668610) But if your officers and men will not serve here under our own Government—well, we shall have to do without them.
('51', 333, 4, 9, 668724) Will you not admit that English troops are necessary in communal distur bances?
('51', 333, 4, 10, 668804) I do not.
('51', 333, 4, 11, 668814) If our own troops are found wanting, the most that can happen is that we might have to put up with civil war for a time.
('51', 333, 4, 12, 668935) But it is better that we should have communal strife and fight our own battles against it than that we should have to appeal to another country to set our house in order with troops over which our people have no control.
('51', 333, 4, 13, 669156) Very possibly there will be some serious communal strife when we have got swaraj, but only for a little while.
('51', 333, 4, 14, 669267) If you will not help us to stop it in the way I suggest, then it may perhaps end itself in the exhaustion or destruction of one community or the other.
('51', 333, 4, 15, 669419) There may be jealousies and disputes between factions, interests (if you insist on the point), even whole provinces.
('51', 333, 4, 16, 669536) It is not consistent with the self respect of a country or a race that it should give carte blanche to the power of another nation or another race or individual members of it to say, ‘These people cannot manage their own affairs, so they gave us a free hand to do it for them.’ Whatever the differences between us here, we are all Indians and our land is India.
('51', 333, 4, 17, 669898) But I am not so pessimistic as to think that the lesson will be learned too late.
('51', 333, 5, 18, 669980) And what other safeguards have you in mind?
('51', 333, 5, 19, 670024) There is finance, for instance.
('51', 333, 5, 20, 670056) You have slightly alarmed some people in India who cannot afford a depreciation of the rupee’s purchasing power.
('51', 333, 5, 21, 670169) There are other people, Indians who have sent much capital out of the country with the intention of bringing it back to their own great profit when, as they hope, self governing India will have sunk the rupee’s value to very little.
('51', 334, 0, 1, 670402) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 335
('51', 334, 1, 2, 670447) Yes, I know that is being done and it is very bad.
('51', 334, 1, 3, 670498) It must be stopped.
('51', 334, 1, 4, 670518) And I know that there are people in some parts of India who do not want the rupee ratio reduced.
('51', 334, 1, 5, 670615) But, I do not see why the rupee should not return to its old value of 1s.
('51', 334, 1, 6, 670689) As to the financial safeguards to be discussed at the Round Table Conference, well, we should of course, be under an obligation to pay for whatever assistance we seek from you.
('51', 334, 1, 7, 670866) The British came here first simply for the sake of trade.
('51', 334, 1, 8, 670924) Now they say that they have a trust.
('51', 334, 1, 9, 670961) Their rule has been disastrous for India, but nevertheless I will agree that the man in the street is honest in his belief that he has a trust to fulfil for India.
('51', 334, 1, 10, 671125) The mischief is due to ignorance—the ignorance of insularity.
('51', 334, 1, 11, 671187) I have said that I cannot conceive of my accepting Dominion Status when I go to the Round Table Conference.
('51', 334, 1, 12, 671295) I should welcome a closer association in equal fellowship that can make an outstanding contribution to spiritual greatness in international and inter racial affairs.
('51', 334, 1, 13, 671461) The Statesman, 2 4 1931
('51', 334, 2, 14, 671485) 367. SPEECH PROPOSING WORKING COMMITTEE, A.I.C.C. MEETING, KARACHI
('51', 334, 3, 15, 671552) April 1, 1931
('51', 334, 4, 16, 671566) Mahatmaji, in consultation with the President and Mr. Jawaharlal Nehru, had prepared a list overnight, which he placed before the Committee and explained the inclusion of new names and the exclusion of other names to find accommo dation.
('51', 334, 5, 17, 671804) Mahatmaji walked into the A.I.C.C. meeting and moved, besides the office 
('51', 334, 6, 18, 671878) bearers, the following for the new Working Committee : Gandhiji, Dr. Ansari,
('51', 334, 7, 19, 671955) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Messrs Rajendra Prasad, Sen Gupta, Aney, Nariman, Dr.
('51', 334, 8, 20, 672034) Alam, Mrs. Naidu and Sardar Sardul Singh.

('51', 342, 2, 21, 690968) But remember, you will not be able to maintain your ascendancy if you keep up your habit of taking liquor.
('51', 342, 2, 22, 691075) The author of the Bhagavata has said that the Yadavas perished because of drinking.
('51', 342, 2, 23, 691159) Remember another thing, that under swaraj the Head of State will not draw a salary of over Rs. 500; hence give up comforts and pleasures, else it will be difficult for Parsis to participate in the swaraj govern ment.
('51', 342, 2, 24, 691376) When I arrived here, the Sardar told me to rest and said that he would go and meet the Parsis.
('51', 342, 2, 25, 691471) I replied that elsewhere I would ask him to deputize for me but here that would not do.
('51', 342, 2, 26, 691559) Here I must place my statement of account before you, and ask for yours.
('51', 342, 2, 27, 691632) Mine is of course an open book.
('51', 342, 2, 28, 691664) On scrutiny, yours shows large debits against khadi and prohibition.
('51', 342, 2, 29, 691733) Clear both of them and join the Congress in large numbers, so that you will always win victory, victory, victory.
('51', 342, 2, 30, 691847) Young India, 16 4 1931

('51', 343, 0, 1, 691915) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 343, 1, 2, 691957) 370. AFTER THE CONGRESS
('51', 343, 2, 3, 691981) The Congress is finished.
('51', 343, 2, 4, 692007) It was an object lesson in quick orga nization.Without the willing co operation of nearly three thousand volunteers, men, women and childern, and the public, a city accommo dating twenty thousand persons with all the conveniences could not have been brought into being in twentyfive days.
('51', 343, 2, 5, 692296) A band of mer chants undertook the kitchen work, ensuring efficiency, economy and good service.
('51', 343, 2, 6, 692392) The women volunteers vied with the men in hard work often involving prolonged vigils.
('51', 343, 2, 7, 692478) But the real credit belongs to the Lord Mayor of Karachi, the great Parsi humanitarian and philan thropist, Jamshed Mehta.
('51', 343, 2, 8, 692601) There are seasoned Congress workers who strove to make the organization so perfect.
('51', 343, 2, 9, 692685) These I need not mention.
('51', 343, 2, 10, 692711) The chief architectural feature of the Congress was its vast pandal which had no canopy but that of the blue sky.
('51', 343, 2, 11, 692825) It became thus possible to ensure freedom from suffocating air and to provide ample accommodation.
('51', 343, 2, 12, 692924) It saved enormous expenses.
('51', 343, 2, 13, 692952) Instead of building the dais and galleries they were obtained by excavation as at the time of the Ahmedabad Congress.
('51', 343, 2, 14, 693070) Another feature was the great khadi exhibition which beat all the previous ones in scientific arrangement.
('51', 343, 2, 15, 693177) Although it was not part of a big show, it attracted vast crowds and was thoroughly successful from the financial standpoint.
('51', 343, 2, 16, 693303) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel’s address was perhaps the briefest of all presidential addresses.
('51', 343, 2, 17, 693394) He was able to finish the proceedings in two days—not a bad record.
('51', 343, 2, 18, 693462) A day saved means much saving of expense and more of the fagged out exertion of the over worked volunteers.
('51', 343, 2, 19, 693570) The Congress has endorsed the provisional settlement and issued in the clearest possible terms its delegation.
('51', 343, 2, 20, 693681) Much has yet to happen before the delegation can take part in any conference that may be held.
('51', 343, 2, 21, 693776) The duty of Congressmen is now clear.
('51', 343, 2, 22, 693814) They must faithfully observe the terms of the provisional settlement.
('51', 343, 2, 23, 693884) They must clear the atmosphere of every trace of violence and therefore first examine and purify themselves.
('51', 343, 2, 24, 693993) The nation must achieve the boycott of foreign cloth and see that the gospel of the wheel spreads through every village of India.
('51', 343, 2, 25, 694123) Before this can be accomplished, we must develop much greater love of the famishing millions than we have.
('51', 343, 2, 26, 694230) The drunkard and the drug addict must be induced, not forced to give up their vice.
('51', 343, 2, 27, 694314) These things require greater
('51', 344, 0, 1, 694343) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 345
('51', 344, 1, 2, 694388) organization, greater co operation among ourselves and a living faith in non violence in thought, word and deed.
('51', 344, 1, 3, 694501) Whether it is taken up as a policy or a creed, mind and body must act together while the policy or the creed is in operation.
('51', 344, 1, 4, 694627) While the truce lasts we must not boycott British goods as such.
('51', 344, 1, 5, 694692) Last but not least, one must achieve Hindu Muslim unity.
('51', 344, 1, 6, 694749) How this is to be done I know.
('51', 344, 1, 7, 694780) The Hindus have to dare to trust them and let the Mussalmans and the Sikhs take what they want.
('51', 344, 1, 8, 694876) This rids the nation of all communal taint.
('51', 344, 1, 9, 694920) But of this hereafter.
('51', 344, 1, 10, 694943) Young India, 2 4 1931
('51', 344, 2, 11, 694965) 371. LET US REPENT
('51', 344, 3, 12, 694984) But the hatred which was created and which has been shown in words and actions has been so intolerable that it must set one to think whether release of such mighty forces of hatred all round the country is advisable.
('51', 344, 3, 13, 695201) From morning till late night one heard through talks, songs, through slogans and felt such mighty torrents of hatred that it was sickening to find such a degradation in large mass of people.
('51', 344, 3, 14, 695392) I use the word ‘degradation’ with full responsibility.
('51', 344, 3, 15, 695447) It appeared that speaking lies was a matter of full licence and liberty.
('51', 344, 3, 16, 695520) To attack Government officers, police officers, men who disagreed, for something which was entirely untrue, for something which never happened, was a daily common event seen on the roads and everywhere.
('51', 344, 3, 17, 695723) More than words can express the cruelties and the injustice inflicted on the traders of British goods especially, and some other foreign goods were wide, intolerable and unbearable.
('51', 344, 3, 18, 695905) To request a man not to deal in one article and to request another not to purchase an article is one thing, but to force a man by all possible
('51', 344, 4, 19, 696048) means, by abusing him, by obstructing him, by making his life miserable in every way is another thing, and there, I must admit, non violence has miserably failed.
('51', 344, 4, 20, 696211) I am certain in my mind that the hatred created and the cruelties inflicted were far from non violence and against all principles and teachings of Mahatmaji.
('51', 344, 4, 21, 696369) It was a common practice to obstruct and inflict with all kinds of tactics to make persons’ lives miserable whenever one disagreed with the general movement.
('51', 344, 4, 22, 696527) In every province there were different types of activities and it appears that either one had to accept such dictation of somebody or one had to go through whatever was inflicted upon him by any small or large band of children, ladies or full grownup men.
('51', 344, 4, 23, 696783) According to them, to differ in any way was pro British, pro Government or unfaithfulness to the country, and today one can see clearly mental victims of these forces of hatred in several houses.
('51', 345, 0, 1, 696979) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 345, 1, 2, 697021) But the danger is still greater.
('51', 345, 1, 3, 697054) The taste of the blood—breaking laws— has been so attractive that one finds today this blessed satyagraha on the lips of everyone.
('51', 345, 1, 4, 697185) As soon as you differ anywhere, be it in a school, in a house, in a group, in a circle of friends, in business, in an office, you find immediately threat of satyagraha pointed out to you at every time.
('51', 345, 1, 5, 697387) Between employer and employee, landlord and tenant, parents and children, teachers and pupils, brothers and friends, everywhere this pointed bayonet of satyagraha seems to be ready for use.
('51', 345, 1, 6, 697577) To break laws and rules of society or of the State seems to be so easy and handy.
('51', 345, 1, 7, 697659) If a college professor suggests discipline, if a municipal officer recommends extra tax, if children are requested not to make noise, if hawkers are told to remove obstructions on roads, if changes or transfers are being arranged, if anything is done which does not suit anybody else, there is this dagger of satyagraha pointed at you.
('51', 345, 1, 8, 697995) Discrimination where to use and how to use seems to have been entirely lost in the whole nation, and this is a danger signal for any nation or country.
('51', 345, 1, 9, 698147) It is exactly like an aeroplane, which is being used generally to fly from one country to another speedily and is also used for throwing bombs.
('51', 345, 1, 10, 698291) It is exactly like matches, which give light, and are also used for burning a house.
('51', 345, 1, 11, 698376) One can clearly see this danger signal in the satyagraha weapon also.
('51', 345, 1, 12, 698446) Satyagraha can be used to advantage but it can also be misused to entire destruction.
('51', 345, 1, 13, 698532) I feel that unless those who proclaim satyagraha as the best weapon to the wide world did feel their responsibility in this matter, they would soon find the tables turned not only against themselves but on the whole country.
('51', 345, 1, 14, 698757) If I can humbly suggest, I feel that some of the rigidly trained leaders, free from hated, should now do nothing else but pass some years of their lives in each province and each city and village to make people understand what real satyagraha or true non violence means, how it can be brought into operation and when it ought to be brought into operation.
('51', 345, 1, 15, 699113) I would humbly suggest a regular school of non violence in every province, where high minded souls who thoroughly understand this subject scientifically and religiously ought to be teachers to the students of policies who in return should be kept as all time workers to go round the country, give this message and teach what it is in reality.
('51', 345, 1, 16, 699456) This can be the only safeguard for saving the country in my opinion.
('51', 345, 1, 17, 699525) Jamshed Mehta, the Lord Mayor of Karachi, is a patriot of the purest type.
('51', 345, 1, 18, 699600) But for his identification with the Congress to the extent he was capable of and but for his having placed at the disposal of the Reception Committee all the resources of his Municipality, the wonderful Congress city would not have been brought into being in the incredibly short space of twenty five days.
('51', 345, 1, 19, 699907) His sympathy for the satyagrahis when the campaign was going on is well known.
('51', 346, 0, 1, 699986) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 347
('51', 346, 1, 2, 700031) criticism from one like him must therefore arrest attention.
('51', 346, 1, 3, 700092) The quotation given above is an extract from Sjt.
('51', 346, 1, 4, 700142) Jamshed Mehta’s article in a Karachi Anglo Gujarati weekly called Parsi Sansar and Lokasevak.
('51', 346, 1, 5, 700236) The criticism I have copied follows a glowing tribute paid by him to the satyagrahis who bore suffering without retaliation.
('51', 346, 1, 6, 700361) But we have no reason to be puffed up with pride over certificates of merit.
('51', 346, 1, 7, 700438) In so far as we observed non violence we only did our duty.
('51', 346, 1, 8, 700498) It is then the warning of this true friend of humanity and his country that we must treasure and profit by.
('51', 346, 1, 9, 700606) What he has said of Karachi is likely to be true more or less of other places.
('51', 346, 1, 10, 700685) Non violence to be a potent force must begin with the mind.
('51', 346, 1, 11, 700745) Non violence of the mere body without the co operation of the mind is non violence of the weak or the cowardly and has therefore no potency.
('51', 346, 1, 12, 700886) It is, as Jamshedji says truly, a degrading performance.
('51', 346, 1, 13, 700943) If we bear malice and hatred in our bosoms and pretend not to retaliate, it must recoil upon us and lead to our destruction.
('51', 346, 1, 14, 701068) For abstention from mere bodily non violence not to be injurious, it is at least necessary not to entertain hatred if we cannot generate active love.
('51', 346, 1, 15, 701218) All the songs and speeches betokening hatred must be taboo.
('51', 346, 1, 16, 701278) It is equally true to say that indiscriminate resistance to authority must lead to lawlessness, unbridled licence and consequent self destruction.
('51', 346, 1, 17, 701425) If Jamshedji’s criticism was not more than balanced by his appreciation, that is to say, if the sum total of real non violence had not overbalanced the unreal, India would not have gone forward as it has done.
('51', 346, 1, 18, 701635) But better even than the Karachi Lord Mayor’s appreciation is the undoubted fact that the villagers have instinctively observed non violence in a manner never before thought of.
('51', 346, 1, 19, 701813) It is their non violence that has conduced to the growth of nationl consciousness.
('51', 346, 1, 20, 701896) The mysterious effect of non violence is not be measured by its visible effect.
('51', 346, 1, 21, 701976) But we dare not rest content so long as the poison of hatred is allowed to permeate society.
('51', 346, 1, 22, 702069) This struggle is a stupendous effort at conversion.
('51', 346, 1, 23, 702121) We aim at nothing less than the conversion of the English.
('51', 346, 1, 24, 702180) It can never be done by harbouring ill will and will pretending to follow non violence.
('51', 346, 1, 25, 702268) Let those therefore who want to follow the path of non violence and yet harbour ill will retrace their steps and repent of the wrong they have done to themselves and country.

('51', 347, 1, 2, 702507) 372. SPEECH TO SIND DESH SEVA MANDAL 1, KARACHI
('51', 347, 2, 3, 702555) [April 2, 1931] 2
('51', 347, 3, 4, 702573) Institutions like yours ought to be governed by strict rules and restrictions.
('51', 347, 3, 5, 702652) The question put to me is whether workers who join the institution should take something for their livelihood or not.
('51', 347, 3, 6, 702770) There are some who consider it below their dignity to take something and prefer to work in an honorary capacity.
('51', 347, 3, 7, 702883) Some others say that even the nation’s servants must get a subsistence allowance or else we shall have to seek millionaires as servants.
('51', 347, 3, 8, 703020) I must say that there is false pride in holding that one would serve without taking money; there is no shame in taking just a subsistence allowance; it is one’s duty.
('51', 347, 3, 9, 703187) Mr. Gokhale began with Rs. 40 and never took more than Rs. 75. He lived all his life Rs. 75. He used to be a member of commissions, etc., and whatever he got by way of allowances, etc., he made over to the Servants of India Society.
('51', 347, 3, 10, 703420) He used to consider it a part of his religion to take just enough for subsistence; how can we regard that as an error?
('51', 347, 3, 11, 703539) It is desirable that even a millionaire’s son should not rely on his millions but should donate his property to such an institution and then like other workers draw as much as is required for his livlihood.
('51', 347, 3, 12, 703746) The other point is whether such institutions ought to be bound by rules.
('51', 347, 3, 13, 703819) A man without a pledge is like a ship without a rudder.
('51', 347, 3, 14, 703875) I am not convinced by the argument that here one cannot manage without a hundred rupees.
('51', 347, 3, 15, 703964) The Sindhis may well believe that they cannot manage with less, but my experience tells me that one can manage without difficulty on a much smaller amount.
('51', 347, 3, 16, 704120) The institutions of Lalaji and Gokhaleji are well because of their names, but there are may other institutions which function in face of difficulties and restrictions and which have people who draw barely Rs. 25 to Rs. 30. Not more than Rs. 15 to Rs. 20 are ever drawn in Orissa.
('51', 347, 3, 17, 704400) Hence we should lay down our requirements taking into consideration our country’s condition.
('51', 347, 4, 18, 704493) 1 Sind National Service League, an institution “whose object is to organize public activities through the agency of whole time workers, either in the capacity of permanent member or temporary workers”.

('51', 348, 1, 2, 704818) Till today we worked in a wrong way—we did all our work in cities and formulated all our schemes keeping cities in view.
('51', 348, 1, 3, 704939) We stayed away from village folk, hence they have so far regarded their privations as the result of divine wrath and could think of no other causes.
('51', 348, 1, 4, 705088) Institutions of public service should be located among the people, be partners of their joys and sorrows and render service by spreading knowledge among them.

('51', 350, 7, 17, 709393) 376. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS NEW DELHI, April 6, 1931
('51', 350, 8, 18, 709446) Mr. Gandhi was shown the speech delivered by Mr. Zahur Ahmed at the All India Muslim Conference today in which Mr. Zahur Ahmed had stated : “Mr. Gandhi had stated that there would be civil war in the country which would continue till one community was completely exhausted.

('51', 351, 0, 1, 710006) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 351, 1, 2, 710048) 377. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON COMMUNAL PROBLEM
('51', 351, 2, 3, 710096) [April 6, 1931] 1
('51', 351, 3, 4, 710114) I see that much misrepresentation is going on with reference to my attitude on the Hindu Muslim question.
('51', 351, 3, 5, 710220) My own personal view is quite clear.
('51', 351, 3, 6, 710257) It is that of full surrender to any unanimously expressed wish of the Mussalmans and the Sikhs.
('51', 351, 3, 7, 710353) I would like the Hindus to see the beauty of the solution.
('51', 351, 3, 8, 710412) It can come only out of consciousness of moral strength.
('51', 351, 3, 9, 710469) It follows that before I can cultivate Hindu opinion on a particular formula, I must have that formula.
('51', 351, 3, 10, 710573) That is not forthcoming.
('51', 351, 3, 11, 710598) That which was given to the Congress deputation at the Muslim Parties’meeting on the 4th instant was not a unanimous minimum.
('51', 351, 3, 12, 710724) For one thing I had the warning of the Nationalist Muslims not to accept anything that did not proceed on the principle of joint electorates based on adult suffrage.
('51', 351, 3, 13, 710890) Some of the Nationalists are my oldest co workers to whom Maulana Shaukat Ali gave certificates for honesty, bravery and true love of Islam and who have proved the truth of the Maulana’s certificates.
('51', 351, 3, 14, 711091) When they tell me that separate electo rates are bad for Mussalmans, I must listen to them.
('51', 351, 3, 15, 711183) They further claim that the Mussalman masses do not want separate electorates.
('51', 351, 3, 16, 711262) Be that as it may, I cannot identify myself with any solution which is frankly based on communalism and yet has not what may be called unanimous support of the community concerned.
('51', 351, 3, 17, 711443) A solution that is admittedly defective and antinational must, to be acceptable, have the merit at least of almost unanimous support from those affected by it.
('51', 351, 3, 18, 711603) I am unable to understand the anger that is being shown against those who do not at once subscribe to the separate electorate idea.
('51', 351, 3, 19, 711735) There is no doubt that it is possible for any large body of opinion to stop the country’s march towards swaraj.
('51', 351, 3, 20, 711847) Swaraj based on non violence cannot be obtained if it is resisted by even a respectable minority.
('51', 351, 3, 21, 711945) It is wrong to say suggest that under swaraj there will be majority rule.
('51', 351, 3, 22, 712019) In true swaraj there can only be the rule of justice.
('51', 351, 3, 23, 712073) In spite of the great awakening that has taken place, I for one would be content to wait if the accredited leaders of the Mussalmans or the Sikhs would oppose the attainment of a swaraj constitution.
('51', 351, 3, 24, 712273) The fight
('51', 351, 4, 25, 712283) 1 From The Hindu, 7 4 1931
('51', 352, 0, 1, 712310) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 353
('51', 352, 1, 2, 712355) for swaraj once begun can only end when the constitution which is its visible symbol is framed and passed.
('51', 352, 1, 3, 712462) The next phase of the struggle in the absence of a communal solution may, therefore, assume a different form, the goal still remaining the same.
('51', 352, 1, 4, 712607) Members of the All India Muslim Conference have made angry references to the occurrences at Cawnpore, Benares, Mirzapur, Agra and other places.
('51', 352, 1, 5, 712751) But will anger solve the question?
('51', 352, 1, 6, 712786) I find highly exaggerated statements being made.

('51', 361, 1, 2, 733208) 383. SOLE DELEGATE
('51', 361, 2, 3, 733227) The appointment by the Working Committee of me as the sole delegate to any conference to which the Congress delegation is desired by the Government was made after over two hours’ exhaustive discussion.
('51', 361, 2, 4, 733429) The idea behind it was that what was to be presented was not several points of view but only the Congress view.
('51', 361, 2, 5, 733541) The Congress view was set forth in the mandate.
('51', 361, 2, 6, 733589) What was not in the mandate was to be covered either by a letter of instructions from the Working Committee or instructions received from time to time.
('51', 361, 2, 7, 733741) Either therefore the whole Working Committee should be appointed or only one member holding its power of attorney.
('51', 361, 2, 8, 733856) The latter arrangement thus easily became the best, most efficacious and most economical in every sense of the word.
('51', 361, 2, 9, 733973) For not only would money be saved but energy.
('51', 361, 2, 10, 734019) What is more, Congress could not afford to keep away from the country without sufficient cause its best workers for any length of time.
('51', 361, 2, 11, 734155) It is the implicit belief of Congressmen that in the end it will not be work at the Conference that will bring swaraj; it can only be work in India that can do it.
('51', 361, 2, 12, 734319) Not the ability of the delegation will tell at the Conference but the power behind it.
('51', 361, 2, 13, 734406) It was further thought that the Congress delegation was not designed to enter into or examine details but to discuss and examine principle and their application.
('51', 361, 2, 14, 734568) And whether at the end of the Conference it was to be peace or war, every available hand was needed in the country.
('51', 361, 2, 15, 734684) We want all our men and women in the country to avoid war.
('51', 361, 2, 16, 734743) For the best way to ensure peace is to push up the constructive programme and to implement the conditions of the provisional settlement.
('51', 361, 2, 17, 734880) Moreover the reader should know that the people directly affected by the settlement are not at all satisfied with the way in which the agents of the Government are carrying out its conditions.
('51', 361, 2, 18, 735073) Constant vigilance on the spot is therefore necessary.
('51', 361, 2, 19, 735128) From every point of view, therefore, the appointement of sole delegation was not only desirable but almost necessary.
('51', 361, 2, 20, 735246) But this appointment enchances my responsibility a thousand fold.
('51', 361, 2, 21, 735312) My task, however, becomes light with the thought that I have but to carry out the instructions of my principals.
('51', 361, 2, 22, 735425) For the rest I have to seek God’s infalliable guidance and ‘be careful for nothing’.
('51', 362, 0, 1, 735510) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 363
('51', 362, 1, 2, 735555) then who knows that if and when the time comes, the way will be open for me to attend the Conference?

('51', 367, 2, 9, 747136) 388. THE NATIONAL WEEK It may be said that I had forgotten the National Week this time, or you may say that ever since I came out of Yeravda Prison, it has been one unbroken National Week for me.
('51', 367, 2, 10, 747332) Under pressure of continu ous work which keeps coming up, I become oblivious of the day of the week, the date, whether according to the Engligh calendar or the Indian one.
('51', 367, 2, 11, 747504) I was not even aware of the single meal that I was to take on the 6th.
('51', 367, 2, 12, 747575) Luckily, of late owing to travelling and lack of sleep, I eat practically only one meal a day, hence it may be said that I unknowingly observed the 6th.
('51', 367, 2, 13, 747728) I know that what happened to me also happended to others, as I am not aware of anyone in the camp having recalled this fact.
('51', 367, 2, 14, 747853) If even a single person had thought of it.
('51', 367, 2, 15, 747896) I would have known it.
('51', 367, 2, 16, 747919) The truth of the matter is that the awakening of the past twelve months has made us forget such special days like the National Week.
('51', 367, 2, 17, 748052) Prior to this, we pretended to be active during the National Week, thus making some amends for our year long idleness.
('51', 367, 2, 18, 748171) That idleness is no longer there and the impatience to win swaraj has kept many of us busy in the final bid for it.
('51', 367, 2, 19, 748287) This is as it should be.
('51', 367, 2, 20, 748312) But it may be said that our effort is, to a small or large extent, blind.
('51', 367, 2, 21, 748386) We would have reached our destina tion long ago if our effort were equally matched by knowledge and discretion.
('51', 367, 2, 22, 748498) Although there is enthusiasm, it tosses us hither and thither for want of a lighthouse in the form of discretion.
('51', 367, 2, 23, 748612) If that were not so, the unfortunate incidents which took place in Kanpur, Benares, Agra, Mirzapur and other places would not have occurred.
('51', 367, 2, 24, 748753) Both Hindus and Muslims lost their sanity.
('51', 367, 2, 25, 748796) Both descended to a level lower than even that of beasts.
('51', 367, 2, 26, 748854) These are no signs of eagerness on our part to win swaraj.Those Hindus who used to blame the Muslims started indulging
('51', 368, 0, 1, 748973) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 369
('51', 368, 1, 2, 749018) in the very acts which they had condemned.Our peacefulness truned out to be merely verbal.
('51', 368, 1, 3, 749109) Those who have learnt the lesson of peace know that a peaceful attitude has to be maintained not only towards the British, but also amongst oursevles.
('51', 368, 1, 4, 749260) However, I hope to write more on this subject when I find time to do so.
('51', 368, 1, 5, 749333) What applies to peace also applies to khadi.
('51', 368, 1, 6, 749378) I have regarded khadi as the very embodiment of peace, that is, non violene.
('51', 368, 1, 7, 749455) For, khadi implies pure love towards the poor, it implies unalloyed co operation with them.
('51', 368, 1, 8, 749547) Although those who give alms to the starving may be said to be compassionate, their co operation with the poor is not untained; they put the latter under an obligation and so regard them as inferior to themselves.
('51', 368, 1, 9, 749761) Those who wear khadi made by the hallowed hands of the poor—whether it be fine or coarse, expensive or otherwise—become their comrades and always help them to become industrious as also preserve their self respect.
('51', 368, 1, 10, 749976) The propa ganda for khadi becomes an important activity druing the National Week.
('51', 368, 1, 11, 750058) And so too with untouchability.
('51', 368, 1, 12, 750090) At the Jallianwala Bagh, the blood of all was shed together.
('51', 368, 1, 13, 750151) There was no distinction there between the “touchables” and untouchables, between the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs.
('51', 368, 1, 14, 750272) A further attempt is also made during the National Week to make people forget these differences.
('51', 368, 1, 15, 750369) In other words, this Week is celebrated for the purpose of self purification.
('51', 368, 1, 16, 750447) This article should be in the hands of the reader on the 12th instant, so that two days of the Week would still remain.
('51', 368, 1, 17, 750567) Every reader who has not undergone these three kinds of purification should wake up and make his contribution to the best of his ability.

('51', 369, 3, 11, 751781) 390. MY NOTES THOUGHTLESS ARGUMENTS The following extract 1 is from a letter written by a resident of Ahmedabad who has given his name and address.
('51', 369, 3, 12, 751929) There is a good deal of thoughtlessness in this argument.
('51', 369, 3, 13, 751987) I do not harm the cause of the spinning wheel when I stay at a mill owner’s place.
('51', 369, 3, 14, 752070) Though I love the spinning wheel, I bear no ill will towards mill owners.
('51', 369, 3, 15, 752144) I started propaganda for the spinning wheel twelve years ago and my association with the mill owners also dates back to the same time.
('51', 369, 3, 16, 752279) This is not the first time that I have stayed with these people.
('51', 369, 3, 17, 752344) A satyagrahi bears no ill will towards anyone.
('51', 369, 3, 18, 752391) He accom plishes his task through love.
('51', 369, 3, 19, 752431) Even while staying with the mill owners, I make them render some service to the cause of khadi.
('51', 369, 3, 20, 752527) I take funds also from them for khadi.
('51', 369, 3, 21, 752566) I have such friends among the mill owners
('51', 369, 4, 22, 752608) 1 Not translated here
('51', 370, 0, 1, 752630) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 371
('51', 370, 1, 2, 752675) who, along with their families, habitually wear khadi.
('51', 370, 1, 3, 752730) This is no outward show on their part, but it indicates their faith in khadi.
('51', 370, 1, 4, 752808) At present, the textile mills are doing no harm to khadi as the entire country has not become khadi minded.
('51', 370, 1, 5, 752916) The mill owners would readily given up the textile mills if the entire country took to khadi and the spinning wheel plied in every home.
('51', 370, 1, 6, 753053) I believe they would not be against khadi even for a moment.
('51', 370, 1, 7, 753114) I also believe that, if they are depraved enough to oppose it, their attempt to do so would prove futile.
('51', 370, 1, 8, 753220) It is almost impossible to prevent the setting up of new textile mills so long as there are innumerable people who wear mill made cloth.
('51', 370, 1, 9, 753357) The mills should be prevented from competing with khadi.
('51', 370, 1, 10, 753414) This has been done to some extent and attempts are being made to stop the mills’ competition altogether.
('51', 370, 1, 11, 753519) Hence the duty of the citizens of Ahmedabad and others is to carry on propaganda for khadi and to spread spinning far and wide.
('51', 370, 1, 12, 753647) This task cannot be accomplished by bearing ill will towards the mill owners or by severing my connection with them.
('51', 370, 2, 13, 753764) FOREIGN CLOTH DEALERS It is a matter of sorrow that foreign cloth dealers do not still seem to be able to resist temptation.
('51', 370, 2, 14, 753889) They should realize that foreign cloth—whether English, Japanese or any other—will no more be consumed in India.
('51', 370, 2, 15, 754002) The opposition to it is increasing and not decreas ing and it will keep on gaining in tempo.
('51', 370, 2, 16, 754095) The golden remedy for the hunger of crores of people lies hidden in giving up foreign cloth.
('51', 370, 2, 17, 754188) In order to make a success of this renunciation, some have laid down their lives, thousands have suffered lathi blows, thousands have cour ted imprisonment.
('51', 370, 2, 18, 754345) Do not the foreign cloth merchants regard this as an adequate sacrifice?
('51', 370, 2, 19, 754418) As compared to he loss suffered by the country, these people will find that they have no right to bemoan their own loss.
('51', 370, 2, 20, 754539) The latter means their giving up a portion of the income which they have gained by carrying on an immoral trade for many years, and their being satisfied with perhaps a smaller income in future.
('51', 370, 2, 21, 754734) Why do they not exchange their business for that of khadi?
('51', 370, 2, 22, 754793) The art, interest and purity in the khadi trade are not there in the trade in foreign cloth.
('51', 370, 2, 23, 754886) As the former is something new, there is scope in it for the full use of one’s intelligence and courage.
('51', 370, 2, 24, 754991) Both self interest and benevolence are subsumed in it.
('51', 370, 2, 25, 755046) Hence if it is carried on with integrity, it will be regarded as an untainted form of business.
('51', 371, 0, 1, 755142) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 371, 1, 2, 755184) But the subject matter of this article is not trade in khadi, but the abandonment of trade in foreign cloth.
('51', 371, 1, 3, 755293) After giving up the latter, merchants may trade in anything else they like.
('51', 371, 1, 4, 755369) They should, however, shun foreign cloth looking upon it is sinful.
('51', 371, 1, 5, 755437) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 12 4 1931

('51', 374, 1, 16, 761596) Apart from the point of view of peace and expediency, I have suggested that the appointments which are admittedly temporary and “until further orders” can in no sense be regarded as permanent in terms of the settlement.
('51', 374, 1, 17, 761816) However, the consideration that generally applies to the appointment of a Mukhi, viz., that he should be of the people and more or less a representative enjoying among them a status and influence is lacking in every case.
('51', 374, 1, 18, 762038) In any event there seems to have been much dilatoriness in the reappointment of Mukhis and

('51', 375, 1, 4, 762323) As I told you yesterday, there are men acting for these old Talatis.
('51', 375, 1, 5, 762392) It is ominously strange that not one of the Talatis in Bardoli has been reinstated.
('51', 375, 2, 6, 762476) CONFISCATED AND OCCUPIED PROPERTY Property in Bardoli confiscated under the Criminal Law Amendment Act has been restored practically intact, but in Kaira District, there are serious allegations of misappropriations.
('51', 375, 2, 7, 762692) A number of articles belonging to the Kaira District Congress Committee are missing (fountain pens, watch chain, currency notes worth Rs. 10/ , etc.).
('51', 375, 2, 8, 762843) 250 maunds of fuel in possession of the Ras Chhawni seems to have been appropriated by the Police.
('51', 375, 2, 9, 762942) In Tranja in Mater, 20 maunds of cotton and five maunds of tobacco in Devataj were attached.
('51', 375, 2, 10, 763035) Both are undisposed of, but lying in the chora, instead of being restored to the rightful owners.
('51', 375, 2, 11, 763133) There has been vexatious delay in restoring confiscated property.
('51', 375, 2, 12, 763199) There can be no question of contumacy as the revenue is being steadily paid wherever possible.
('51', 375, 2, 13, 763294) Confiscated property should therefore be returned automatically under the settlement whereas in some [cases] Mamlatdars have asked for applications from those who want their lands back.
('51', 375, 2, 14, 763480) As the sowing season is fast approaching, it is essential that people should be put in possession of confiscated property as soon as possible.
('51', 375, 2, 15, 763623) ASSESSMENT As to assessment I have suggested that there should be no coercive processes and no fines or payments on account of Rakhas should be demanded.
('51', 375, 2, 16, 763777) I have suggested that in every case the Colle ctors should confer with our local workers and come to an under standing as to the assessment.
('51', 375, 2, 17, 763918) A place like Ras where movables are taken away, locks of houses broken, houses burnt, crops destroyed can hardly be expected to pay anything.

('51', 380, 14, 20, 771605) I am writing you because I believe that there are some ideas in my latest book—which is a criticism of this industrialized civilization of ours—which may be interest and perhaps of help to you.

('51', 381, 1, 2, 772492) 401. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('51', 381, 2, 3, 772536) AHMEDABAD, April 15, 1931
('51', 381, 3, 4, 772562) Mahatma Gandhi again visited his Ashram this morning.
('51', 381, 3, 5, 772616) Asked by a representative of the Associated Press if his visits to the Ashram were a breach of the vow 1 taken by him last year, Mahatma Gandhi said : I have been going to the Ashram recently every day to see Imam Saheb, who is very seriously ill and other patients.
('51', 381, 3, 6, 772883) It is quite untrue to suggest that this is in any shape or form a breach of my vow about not going to the Ashram.
('51', 381, 3, 7, 772997) The vow has refe rence to settling down in the Ashram and leading there the ordi nary settled Ashram life but it does not in any way preclude me from visiting the ashram for seeing the patients or in furtherance of the very thing for which the vow was taken.
('51', 381, 3, 8, 773256) Indeed, nothing in the vow prevents we from staying at the Ashram whenever I come to Ahmedabad but I deliverately refrain from doing so in order not to create any confusion in the minds of the large body of people who would not and have no time to understand the full significance of the vow.
('51', 381, 3, 9, 773549) I consider it to be an improtant pledge having been taken by many of my companions.
('51', 381, 3, 10, 773633) I wanted, therefore, to be extra cautious and hence did not stay in the Ashram even temporarily, but I should be defeating the very and of the vow if I heartlessly refuse to go there and see and console patients, or attend to some such matter.
('51', 381, 4, 11, 773877) Asked if he had permitted some of the volunteers with whom he had marched to Dandi last year, [and who were bound by the] pledge to stay at the Ashram, Gandhiji said : If I found that it was necessary to keep any of my fellow pilgrims for the furtherance of the cause, I should not hesitate to keep them at the Ashram without laying them open to the charge of a breach of the vow.
('51', 381, 4, 12, 774258) The Bombay Chronicle, 16 4 1931
('51', 381, 5, 13, 774290) 1 Gandhiji, at the time of Dandi march, had taken a vow not to return to the Ashram before India attained swaraj.
('51', 381, 5, 14, 774404) Vide “Speech at prayer meeting, Sabarmati ashram”, 12 3 1930 and “Violation of pledge”, 26 4 1931.

('51', 384, 1, 2, 777048) 404 THE CULT OF VIOLENCE
('51', 384, 2, 3, 777073) Mr. Peddie’s 1 murder and the making of the murderer of Mrs. Curtis 2 a hero at the Sikh League meeting bring out in clear light the tragic fact that the cult of violence has still many votaries.
('51', 384, 2, 4, 777269) The extolling of murderers is being overdone.
('51', 384, 2, 5, 777315) If we are to sing the praises of every murderer because the murder has a political motive behind it, we should proceed from praising the deed to the deed itself.
('51', 384, 2, 6, 777477) The praising of Sajjan Singh as a hero raises a doubt in my mind about the wisdom of my having been the authour of the Congress resolution 3
('51', 384, 3, 7, 777618) about Bhagat Singh.
('51', 384, 3, 8, 777638) My motive was plain enough.
('51', 384, 3, 9, 777666) The deed was condemned.
('51', 384, 3, 10, 777690) The spirit of bravery and sacrifice was praised.
('51', 384, 3, 11, 777739) The hope behind was that we would thereby be able to distinguish between the deed and the motive, and ultimately learn to detest deeds such as political murders, no matter how high the motive might be.
('51', 384, 3, 12, 777941) But the effect of the Congress resolution has been perhaps quite the contrary.
('51', 384, 3, 13, 778020) It seems to have given a passport for extolling murder itself.
('51', 384, 3, 14, 778083) I repeat my deliberate opinion that whatever may be true of other countries, in India at least political murder can only harm the country.
('51', 384, 3, 15, 778222) This is much more true whilst an experiment on the largest scale yet known to the world is being made to win liberty through strictly peaceful methods.
('51', 384, 3, 16, 778374) He who runs can see that the experiment has proved its merit beyond all expectation, and is almost on the point of succeeding.
('51', 384, 3, 17, 778501) I make bold to say that had the experiment not been interrupted by political murders and the violence in thought and less often in speech and still less often in action of civil resisters, India would by this time have been free.
('51', 384, 3, 18, 778731) Non violence is the weapon not of the weak but of the strong.
('51', 384, 3, 19, 778793) Non violence means forgiving an injury and not retaliat ing.‘For giveness is an ornament of the strong,’ 4 says a Sanskrit proverb.
('51', 384, 3, 20, 778925) Yudhishthira gave an exhibition of this quality when he even though
('51', 384, 4, 21, 778993) 1 The District Magistrate of Midnapore.
('51', 384, 4, 22, 779033) He was shot dead by the terrorists on April 7. 2 Wife of a British officer, she was murdered at Lahore on January 13. 3 Vide “Resolution on Bhagat Singh and comrades”, 29 3 1931. 4 ˇÊ◊Ê ﬂË⁄USÕ ÷Í·áÊ◊Ô˜
('51', 385, 0, 1, 779235) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 385, 1, 2, 779277) provoked beyond measure by Virata not only for gave him but took extraordinary measures to protect him against the wrath of his brother Arjuna who would but for those precautions have killed him for insulting and injuring the great king Yudhishthira.
('51', 385, 1, 3, 779528) Non violence is not a mechanical performance.
('51', 385, 1, 4, 779574) It is the finest quality of the heart and comes by training.
('51', 385, 1, 5, 779635) When it comes, it seems, because it is, natural, and the posessor wonders that it should have cost any trouble at all in its attainment.
('51', 385, 1, 6, 779772) What can be more natural than to return blow for blow, says the beast in us.
('51', 385, 1, 7, 779849) What can be more natural or more human than that we should return a blow with forgiveness, says the man in us.
('51', 385, 1, 8, 779960) He who gave the blow was ignorant and forgot himself.
('51', 385, 1, 9, 780014) Why should the injured person betray ignorance and forget himself?
('51', 385, 1, 10, 780081) Are the many wives who suffer the brutalities of their brutal husbands more than human because they forgive their husbands?
('51', 385, 1, 11, 780205) They would of course do better if they would not add pampering to their forgiveness and would withdraw co operation from their husbands for the the latter’s own sakes.
('51', 385, 1, 12, 780373) But let me not go into deeper waters.
('51', 385, 1, 13, 780411) Those who profess nonviolence should realize their strength and be non violent in thought, word and deed.
('51', 385, 1, 14, 780517) Let those who still doubt the efficacy of the non violent method and are not sure of that of the violent method, ponder over the following : 1. India’s millions have no tradition of the violent method.
('51', 385, 1, 15, 780719) 2. They, the villagers, have never been known to have combined on any large scale to use the violent method.
('51', 385, 1, 16, 780828) 3. They have no definite ideas as yet of political freedom in terms of India as one country.
('51', 385, 1, 17, 780921) 4. Where, as in Europe, the people have gained their freedom by the violent method, the people were more or less trained in the use of arms.
('51', 385, 1, 18, 781062) 5. They, the peoples of Europe, gained their freedom by being able to use greater violence than the enthroned authority.
('51', 385, 1, 19, 781183) 6. It is at least doubtful if they, not excluding the English, have got real freedom.
('51', 385, 1, 20, 781269) The masses there still feel that they are being ground down by the moneyed classes who have the reins of government in their hands.
('51', 385, 1, 21, 781401) Look at their varied problems ever
('51', 386, 0, 1, 781436) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 387
('51', 386, 1, 2, 781481) increasing in perplexity.
('51', 386, 1, 3, 781507) 7. In India on the other hand we know that it is through the non violent method alone that the phenomenal massconsciousn ess, including the awakening of women, has come into being.
('51', 386, 1, 4, 781688) 8. We know as a proved fact that where the people erred and became violent, they lost ground, became demoralized and were cowed down.
('51', 386, 1, 5, 781822) If I were to give more thought to the past twelve months I could elaborate the list.
('51', 386, 1, 6, 781907) But as it is, it is perhaps enough for my purpose.
('51', 386, 1, 7, 781958) To those who have settled convictions in favour of the violent method, I say: You will give me the same credit that you claim for yourselves for love of the country.
('51', 386, 1, 8, 782124) If so, you should accept my testimony that by mixing your method with mine you protract the agony.
('51', 386, 1, 9, 782223) The belief which, I know, some of you hold that an occasional murder of an official helps the cause is wholly unfounded.
('51', 386, 1, 10, 782344) On the contrary I know that every murder has hampered me in my pursuit.
('51', 386, 1, 11, 782416) I know that you are as anxious as I am—you will probably say you are more anxious than I am—for the release of all political prisoners.
('51', 386, 1, 12, 782552) You must admit that the terrorist method can only retard their discharge.
('51', 386, 1, 13, 782626) Constituted as this Government is, all governments are, they will not discharge political offenders convicted of violence when political violence takes place.
('51', 386, 1, 14, 782785) All things considered, therefore, you will do well to listen to my advice and request, and suspend your activities whilst the nation is giving a trial to my experiment.

('51', 387, 1, 2, 783019) 405. AN ENGLISHMAN’S DILEMMA
('51', 387, 2, 3, 783048) India knows the Englishman who carried my letter containing the eleven points to the Viceroy and who waged a ceaseless struggle in the face of heavy odds in England whilst the Civil Disobedience was going on.
('51', 387, 2, 4, 783257) Mr. Reginald Reynolds now writes the following plaintive letter :
('51', 387, 3, 5, 783323) I was very glad to hear from you in reply to my letter.
('51', 387, 3, 6, 783379) Before this reply came the newspapers had already informed me, of course, of all that happened at Delhi, which from my point of view so badly needed explanation.
('51', 387, 4, 7, 783541) I must frankly confess that your letter leaves me entirely unconvinced.
('51', 387, 4, 8, 783613) No one who knows you would doubt your sincerity, and so long as you can still speak for India, it is hardly the business of any Englishman to criticize your actions.
('51', 387, 4, 9, 783779) Nevertheless, you will be the first to recognize my complete right to disagree with you, which I do emphatically on the following points :
('51', 387, 5, 10, 783918) 1. The Government is not pledged to grant purna swaraj, and it would be
('51', 387, 6, 11, 783990) thrown out if it attempted to do so.
('51', 387, 6, 12, 784027) MacDonald only remains in office because he has not the courage to deal justly with your country, and justice would cost him that office.
('51', 387, 6, 13, 784165) If you accept less than purna Swaraj —less than your
('51', 387, 7, 14, 784218) birthright, that is to say,—where does the Independence Resolution at Lahore 1
('51', 387, 8, 15, 784297) come in, and how does it differ from “Dominion Status”?
('51', 387, 8, 16, 784353) What advance was made, and what did the pledge really mean?
('51', 387, 9, 17, 784413) 2. Oppressin still continues.
('51', 387, 9, 18, 784443) How do you hope for freedom from the hands of those who defy Indian public opinion and use their armed forces to drive bargains with you on your own soil for a ‘truce’?
('51', 387, 9, 19, 784612) Where is the ‘change of heart’?
('51', 387, 10, 20, 784644) 3. From time to time you have put forward terms—the Delhi Manifesto of November 1929 2, your own Eleven Points 3, the terms you gave to Slocombe 4, the ‘Gandhi Nehru Terms’ 5. What has become of these?
('51', 387, 10, 21, 784846) The Government meets them in graceful ‘concessions’ whereby a few are to be fulfilled in some measure at its own ‘discretion’.
('51', 387, 11, 22, 784973) They have not pledged themselves to anything in the way of self 
('51', 387, 12, 23, 785038) government.

('51', 389, 1, 2, 788219) made that clear, and done my best to dispel the common idea that swaraj means the rule of the Brahmin and the Bania and the oppression of the poor.

('51', 389, 2, 9, 789268) I know there are men among them who are above the interests of class; but what do these as a body represent that is not more bound up with British Imperialism than with Indian democracy?

('51', 390, 1, 3, 790960) Service must be its own and sole reward.
('51', 390, 1, 4, 791001) Whether therefore the argu ment and facts I am about to set forth serve their purpose or not, it must be sufficient for the reader as it is, I am aware, for Reynolds to know that in entering upon and advising the acceptance of the Settlement, I have done what in my opinion was not only right but obligatory.
('51', 390, 1, 5, 791310) Now for the facts and the arguments.
('51', 390, 1, 6, 791347) Reynolds and those who think like him have been led into confusion because he and they have missed the historical perspective.
('51', 390, 1, 7, 791474) A single new factor may change a whole situation.
('51', 390, 1, 8, 791524) Reynolds mentions four events: (1) The Delhi Manifesto of November 1929, (2) The Eleven points, (3) The terms given to Mr. Slocombe, (4) The Gandhi Nehru terms.
('51', 390, 1, 9, 791685) The Delhi Manifesto was an answer to Lord Irwin’s famous declaration and was therefore just confined to that declaration.
('51', 390, 1, 10, 791807) The Eleven point letter was written as a precursor to Civil Disobedience and set forth the conditions on which Civil Disobe dience could be averted.
('51', 390, 1, 11, 791956) It had therefore to be different from the November Manifesto.
('51', 390, 1, 12, 792018) The terms to Mr. Slocombe were given just after the commen cement of civil disobedience.
('51', 390, 1, 13, 792107) There was therefore a slight variation from the Eleven point letter but no reduction of it.
('51', 390, 1, 14, 792199) The Gandhi Nehru terms were given during the height of the movement and whilst we were all in custody and thus by being shut out of the world at a disadvantage.
('51', 390, 1, 15, 792360) In all the four stages the Round Table Conference had not been held, the Government policy was not declared.
('51', 390, 1, 16, 792469) The Settlement is the natural evolution from the first stage.
('51', 390, 1, 17, 792531) Whatever the variations between the stages, they are due to the varying situations.
('51', 390, 1, 18, 792615) Unlike as in the four stages, the Round Table Conference had been held and the Government policy declared before the fifth stage, i.e., the Settlement, was reached.
('51', 390, 1, 19, 792780) At no other time was it possible to offer co operation at the Round Table Conference because the British Government would not declare its policy and the intention of the delegates to the Conference was not known.
('51', 390, 1, 20, 792993) But at Delhi last March the demand of the Conference delegates was known as was also known the British policy.
('51', 390, 1, 21, 793104) The demand was Dominion Status.
('51', 390, 1, 22, 793136) The British policy was a declaration tantamount to the acceptance of the demand.
('51', 391, 0, 1, 793217) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 391, 1, 2, 793259) Not that either the Indian demand for Dominion Status or the British declaration satisfy the Congress requirement, especially as they are hedged in by the so called safeguards which, according to the Congress notion, certainly are not designed in the interest of India.
('51', 391, 1, 3, 793529) Nevertheless this is an unmistakable advance upon the past uncertainty.
('51', 391, 1, 4, 793601) And when it was ascertained that it was possible for the Congress to press forward its view to the fullest extent, it was felt that the Congress would put itself in the wrong if it had declined to put forth its demand and press for its acceptance at a Round Table.
('51', 391, 1, 5, 793866) The Congress would have been bound at any stage to enter upon a discussion of its claims after such declaration as has been made by the British Government.
('51', 391, 1, 6, 794022) A satyagrahi never misses, can never miss, a chance of compromise on honourable terms, it being always assumed that in the event of failure he is ever ready to offer battle.
('51', 391, 1, 7, 794196) He needs no previous preparation, his cards are always on the table.
('51', 391, 1, 8, 794265) Suspension or continuation of battle is one and the same thing to him.
('51', 391, 1, 9, 794336) He fights or refrains to gain precisely the same end.
('51', 391, 1, 10, 794390) He dare not always distrust his opponents.
('51', 391, 1, 11, 794433) On the contrary he must grasp the hand of friendship whenever there is the slightest pretext.
('51', 391, 1, 12, 794527) The pretext here was the unex pectedly unanimous Indian demand, the British response, inadequate though it was, and the utter sincerity running through Lord Irwin’s conversations.
('51', 391, 1, 13, 794707) I have never claimed any change of heart on the part of the powers that be.
('51', 391, 1, 14, 794783) That has still to come.
('51', 391, 1, 15, 794807) When it comes, there will be a settlement not merely provisional but absolutely permanent.
('51', 391, 1, 16, 794898) Then there will be full surrender on the part of the satyagrahi; for change of heart means surrender to the Indian demand in toto and without any mental reservation.
('51', 391, 1, 17, 795064) Lastly, throughout all the stages there never has been a lowering of the flag.
('51', 391, 1, 18, 795143) Dominion Status was given up on 23rd December 1929. It is now Complete Independence, i.e., association if possible with the British on equal terms and with the right to either party to dissolve it at will.
('51', 391, 1, 19, 795349) That this may not be attained through conference as yet is quite possible; that the so called safeguards may remain the halters that they are is also highly possible.
('51', 391, 1, 20, 795516) If so the Congress will not be responsible for failure, but it will come out with enhanced moral prestige and its demand more fully known and equally fully justified.
('51', 391, 1, 21, 795683) It is true that all the political prisoners are not discharged.
('51', 391, 1, 22, 795747) Their discharge could not be demanded as part of the Provisional Settlement.
('51', 391, 1, 23, 795824) They will be discharged if full settlement is reached.
('51', 391, 1, 24, 795879) If it is not reached, those who
('51', 392, 0, 1, 795911) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 393
('51', 392, 1, 2, 795956) are temporarily out will then be in and increase the army of political prisoners.
('51', 392, 1, 3, 796038) For a satyagrahi a prisoner’s life is no disability, no unhappiness.
('51', 392, 1, 4, 796107) Prison for him is the gateway to freedom.
('51', 392, 1, 5, 796149) Lastly, let there be no mistake as to what purna swaraj means to the Congress.
('51', 392, 1, 6, 796228) It is full economic freedom for the toiling millions.
('51', 392, 1, 7, 796282) It is no unholy alliance with any interest for their exploitation.
('51', 392, 1, 8, 796349) Any alliance must mean their deliverance.
('51', 392, 1, 9, 796391) Young India, 16 4 1931
('51', 392, 2, 10, 796414) 406. NOTES MALAVIYAJI AND WORKING COMMITTEE
('51', 392, 3, 11, 796458) A reader asks :
('51', 392, 4, 12, 796474) You explained to the Subjects Committee at Karachi why you kept out the
('51', 392, 5, 13, 796546) members from the South; you never explained why you kept out Pandit
('51', 392, 6, 14, 796614) Malaviyaji.
('51', 392, 7, 15, 796626) The explanation was so obvious that nobody called for it.
('51', 392, 7, 16, 796684) There could be no question of offending Malaviyaji.
('51', 392, 7, 17, 796736) He is above being offended.
('51', 392, 7, 18, 796764) No organization can add to his status or impor tance by enrolling him as a member.
('51', 392, 7, 19, 796847) His membership can add to its prestige.
('51', 392, 7, 20, 796887) The Working Committee deliberately kept him out in order to preserve his independence and freedom of action at a given moment.
('51', 392, 7, 21, 797014) Without being a memebr, since the release of leaders, he has always been attending the Working Committee meetings and taking an active part in its deliberations.
('51', 392, 7, 22, 797176) Valuable as his work on the Committee has been, the members thought that his being subjected to the Committee’s discipline might prove embarrassing to him.
('51', 392, 7, 23, 797332) Indeed Dr. Ansari was so eager for Malaviyaji to be on the Committee that he preferred to be dropped out in favour of Malaviyaji.
('51', 392, 7, 24, 797462) But the consi deration I have just mentioned was so effectively urged by Jamnalalji that Dr. Ansari too became reconciled to Malaviyaji being kept out.
('51', 392, 7, 25, 797614) This arrangement permits the Committee to avail itself of Malaviyaji’s advice at its deliberations and at the same time leaves intact his freedom of action.
('51', 392, 7, 26, 797771) Indeed even the Government has recognized his unique position in society by separately inviting him to the Round Table Conference.
('51', 392, 8, 27, 797902) 1 Vide “Speech proposing working committee, A.I.C.C. meeting, Karachi”, 1 4 1931.
('51', 393, 0, 1, 797984) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 393, 1, 2, 798026) BOYCOTT THROUGH KHADI
('51', 393, 2, 3, 798048) Last year saw a striking increase in the production and sale of khadi all over the country.
('51', 393, 2, 4, 798140) This was in the main due to the pheno menal demand stimulated by the struggle of which khadi at once became the symbol.
('51', 393, 2, 5, 798260) Sales so far outran the demand that workers were hard put to it to organize new fields of production to meet the sudden rise in demand.
('51', 393, 2, 6, 798396) The ground thus gained during the year of national awakening should not be lost, but on the contrary, should be made the basis of still further expansion.
('51', 393, 2, 7, 798551) The devotion of war time must continue during the period of peace, if the fruits of the work are not to be lost.
('51', 393, 2, 8, 798664) The Congress attitude in favour of khadi remains the same in spite of the recognition of indigenous mills as a part of the boycott pro gramme.
('51', 393, 2, 9, 798807) It must not mean supersession of khadi.
('51', 393, 2, 10, 798847) Mill manufacture is to supplement khadi where the latter is absolutely unobtainable.
('51', 393, 2, 11, 798932) But at the present moment kahdi can overtake all the demand that can be made upon it.
('51', 393, 2, 12, 799018) Khadi holds the key position in the foreign cloth boycott programme.
('51', 393, 2, 13, 799087) Not merely is no effective boycott of foreign cloth possible without working up the vast possibilities of khadi production, but if the fruits of the national boycott are to benefit the millions of our village population and not merely the moneyed few, it can be done only by the widest possible spread of the life giving wheel.
('51', 393, 2, 14, 799415) That is why the Congress at Karachi has again emphasized the unique position of khadi in the boycott programme, and has appealed to all “Congress organization and allied bodies to intensify foreign cloth boycott by increasing khadi propaganda.” The experience of the last year has shown the capacity of khadi production to respond promptly to any increase in demand; and we have to maintain not merely the existing work, but extend the spinning activities still further.
('51', 393, 2, 15, 799886) The least that we must do is to reach the level of last year if we cannot show a substantial increase upon it.
('51', 393, 2, 16, 799997) Young India, 16 4 1931

('51', 394, 7, 16, 800630) 408. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS BOMBAY, April 18, 1931
('51', 394, 8, 17, 800681) Answering questions put to him by a group of pressmen, regarding the recent
('51', 394, 9, 18, 800757) complaint in a section of the Press, to which the retiring Viceroy also had alluded in
('51', 394, 10, 19, 800844) his reply to the Mill owners’ Association address, Mahatma Gandhi declared : I have no war mentality.
('51', 394, 10, 20, 800946) I have peace mentality at the present moment and I should strain every nerve to retain that mentality and establish permanent peace in the country for which my companions also are striving.
('51', 394, 11, 21, 801136) Proceeding, he reiterated his view that the would not go to the Round Table Conference until the communal problem was solved.
('51', 394, 11, 22, 801262) He added that for the present he had dismissed the idea of going to the Round Table Congerence until a communal solution was found.
('51', 394, 11, 23, 801394) Asked what his next programme was, he said he didn’t know it and would not be able to evolve one until he felt that no solution to the communal problem was in sight.
('51', 394, 12, 24, 801560) Q.Can you make any statement regarding the communal problem?
('51', 394, 13, 25, 801621) A.I am unable to make any statement except that I shall leave no stone unturned and pray for success because I know prayer can move even mountains.
('51', 395, 0, 1, 801769) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 395, 1, 2, 801811) Q.Are you against separate electorates ?
('51', 395, 2, 3, 801852) A. I am against nothing that will end the communal trouble.
('51', 395, 3, 4, 801912) Q.Will not separate electorates widen the gulf between communities?
('51', 395, 4, 5, 801980) A.These are not things for me to consider.
('51', 395, 5, 6, 802023) Q.Do you expect to satisfy every section of Muslims?
('51', 395, 6, 7, 802076) A.I hope to satisfy all sections.
('51', 395, 7, 8, 802110) Q.What do you say about Mr. Shaukat Ali’s recent statement about you being a danger in Indian politics?
('51', 395, 8, 9, 802214) A.Seeing that he is an old friend of mine, he was perfectly right to say that thing about me.
('51', 395, 9, 10, 802308) Q.What do you say to the complaint made in the Anglo Indian Press that the
('51', 395, 10, 11, 802383) Congress is not keeping the terms of the Truce?
('51', 395, 10, 12, 802431) I say emphatically “No”, except there have been isolated cases and I am surprised to read Mr. Benn’s reply.
('51', 395, 10, 13, 802539) In Gujarat, there was satisfactory response.
('51', 395, 10, 14, 802584) In Bardoli, for instance, peasants have been paying up dues as quickly as possible.
('51', 395, 10, 15, 802668) Up to the 16th instant, Bardoli and Valod have paid Rs. 1,16,658 while Jalalpur paid Rs. 1,96,453, after the announcement of Provisional Settlement.
('51', 395, 10, 16, 802817) I regard these as handsome figures and I cannot help saying they have been grossly misinformed.
('51', 395, 10, 17, 802913) Regarding lands already sold to third parties, he said he would ask on bended knees these purchasers to return them and felt sure that every inch of land would be returned.
('51', 395, 11, 18, 803086) Asked if he was not keeping the country in suspense, he said that the country
('51', 395, 12, 19, 803164) knew that every effort was being made to achieve lasting peace and if it be not
('51', 395, 13, 20, 803244) available, the country should be prepared to suffer.
('51', 395, 14, 21, 803297) Asked if he thought that by negotiations he could achieve permanent peace, he
('51', 395, 15, 22, 803375) declared that in negotiations backed by real strength, he most deci dedly believed
('51', 395, 16, 23, 803458) real peace could be had.
('51', 395, 16, 24, 803483) Referring to the re export of foreign cloth, he said that the
('51', 395, 17, 25, 803545) scheme 1 was being put into execution and also con tradicted the report that he had
('51', 395, 18, 26, 803629) any talk with Mr. Geoffrey Corbett about the same.
('51', 395, 19, 27, 803680) The Hindu, 19 4 1931

('51', 396, 1, 2, 803939) 409. SPEECH IN REPLY TO CORPORATION ADDRESS, BOMBAY 1
('51', 396, 2, 3, 803993) [April 18, 1931 ] 2
('51', 396, 3, 4, 804013) I had thought that the one address you had given me six years ago 3 was quite enough, but love knows no bounds and your love has prompted you to present to me another address.
('51', 396, 3, 5, 804189) But you may be sure that I am not so unthinking as to appropriate all that love for myself, for I know that as in 1924 so now it has been given to me as a representative of the toilers of the land.
('51', 396, 3, 6, 804387) I claim to live for the semi starved paupers of India and swaraj means the emancipation of these millions of skeletons.
('51', 396, 3, 7, 804507) Purna swaraj denotes a condition of things when the dumb and the lame millions will speak and walk.
('51', 396, 3, 8, 804607) That swaraj cannot be achieved by force, but by organization and unity.
('51', 396, 3, 9, 804679) Your address I take it is a token of your sympathy for Daridranarayana.
('51', 396, 3, 10, 804751) You have in your address referred to my endeavour for the uplift of the so called untouchables.
('51', 396, 3, 11, 804847) Their rights should be our sacred trust, but one of the indispensable conditions of swaraj is that Hindus wipe out that stain on Hinduism.
('51', 396, 3, 12, 804986) India does not live in its towns but in its villages.
('51', 396, 3, 13, 805040) But if the cities want to demonstrate that their populations will live for the villagers of India the bulk of their resouces should be spent in ameliorating the condition of and befriending the poor.
('51', 396, 3, 14, 805240) We must not lord it over them, we must learn to be their servants.
('51', 396, 3, 15, 805307) When the cities realize that they must live for the welfare of the poor, they will make their palaces and institutions and the life of their inhabitants correspond somewhaat to our villages.
('51', 396, 3, 16, 805498) Whilst therefore I am accepting an address from you for a second time you will permit me to hope that you will more and more make the cause of the poor your own and as an earnest of you desire to do so I want you to identify yourselves with the thousands of workers in the city.
('51', 396, 3, 17, 805777) I want you to make them feel that the Corporation is theirs as it is of the well to do.
('51', 396, 3, 18, 805865) Handsome is that handsome does, and Bombay the beautiful must do beautiful things for the poor.
('51', 396, 3, 19, 805961) If Bombay is the premier city in India it is chiefly because of the Parsis whom the world recognizes as the most generous in their charities.
