('51', 398, 1, 2, 807689) 410. TO THE SATYAGRAHI FARMER
('51', 398, 2, 3, 807719) Many satyagrahi farmers in the Kheda, Surat and Broach districts forfeited their lands, lost their crops, had their homes robbed; they were rendered homeless, the homes of some were burnt down and a settlement was made without getting anything in return for this and, going even further, those who could pay have been asked to pay up their revenue dues and, as if this was not enough, so many Patels and Talatis have not been restored to their offices—those who think along these lines can never be satisfied.
('51', 398, 2, 4, 808229) But another line of thought can be as follows.
('51', 398, 2, 5, 808276) The farmer has no grounds whatsoever to complain.
('51', 398, 2, 6, 808326) This is so because when he joined the struggle, he had decided to risk the loss of his fields, his home, his livestock and his life and property.
('51', 398, 2, 7, 808472) He was prepared to lose his all in order to win swaraj.
('51', 398, 2, 8, 808528) Hence, if he gets something back now, it should be regarded as a windfall.
('51', 398, 2, 9, 808603) If he reasons on these lines, he would have no cause for complaint at all.
('51', 398, 2, 10, 808678) Some may argue in their impatience : How can we be reconciled to the losses as long as swaraj has not been won?
('51', 398, 2, 11, 808790) The reply to this is that this Truce has been signed in the midst of the struggle; it is not the end of it.
('51', 398, 2, 12, 808898) While suffering a total loss, whatever has been spared should be gladly accepted.
('51', 398, 2, 13, 808980) We should welcome any opportunity of sacrificing our all, till such time as swaraj is won.
('51', 398, 2, 14, 809071) Hence no one should have any reason for despon dency because of losses incurred.
('51', 398, 2, 15, 809152) This Settlement has not been made in order to make good our losses; rather, it is a step towards swaraj.
('51', 398, 2, 16, 809257) Underlying it is indeed the idea that we should spare ourselves any avoidable loss.
('51', 398, 2, 17, 809341) This is already being realized.
('51', 398, 2, 18, 809373) Whatever has been made good from the loss already incurred should be regarded as a fresh gain.
('51', 398, 2, 19, 809468) Those who realize this should not become impatient; let those who are being tried be released at a later date, let there be delay in returning lands which have been attached, let some time elapse before Patels and others who had resigned and relinquished their offices can take up their posts again.
('51', 398, 2, 20, 809768) This may involve a violation of the Pact in some respects on the part of the Government.
('51', 398, 2, 21, 809857) We should put up with it and continue to observe the conditions which bind us.
('51', 398, 2, 22, 809936) If we do so, we shall add to our strength in every way.
('51', 399, 0, 1, 809992) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 399, 1, 2, 810034) As we are not at present practising non co operation with the Government, we can meet its officials and put before them whatever complaints we wish to.
('51', 399, 1, 3, 810186) One of the biggest complaints is in respect of the lands which have been sold.
('51', 399, 1, 4, 810265) It is necessary to be patient in regard to this.
('51', 399, 1, 5, 810314) Owners of lands should be convinced at heart that in the end they will certainly be restored to them.
('51', 399, 1, 6, 810416) But we wish to do so only in a straightforward way and not through force.
('51', 399, 1, 7, 810490) We have a right to reason and plead with those who have bought these lands.
('51', 399, 1, 8, 810566) I believe that we shall succeed in persuading them.
('51', 399, 1, 9, 810618) But even if we fail, what does it matter?
('51', 399, 1, 10, 810660) That should not make anyone conclude that we shall never recover the lands.
('51', 399, 1, 11, 810736) We should have the self confidence that we shall secure swaraj within a short time.
('51', 399, 1, 12, 810820) The first task of the government under swaraj should be to redress such acts of injustice.
('51', 399, 1, 13, 810911) Here I am speaking not of the distant future but of the immediate future.
('51', 399, 1, 14, 810985) Suppose we do not win swaraj in the near future, then the time will again come for us to abandon our lands and our homes, and the Sardar, I and others will be enjoying ourselves in the prison palace.
('51', 399, 1, 15, 811185) Hence those whose lands have been sold, should have patience.
('51', 399, 1, 16, 811247) However, I myself have nost lost hope of persuading those who have bought the lands.
('51', 399, 1, 17, 811332) These are our own brethren.
('51', 399, 1, 18, 811360) It is reported that there are Parsis, Muslims and Dharala Thakores amongst them.
('51', 399, 1, 19, 811441) All of them have a heart.
('51', 399, 1, 20, 811467) They all know that they have bought the land cheap.
('51', 399, 1, 21, 811519) They too would be ashamed of this fact.
('51', 399, 1, 22, 811559) I believe that they will certainly return the land if they realize the fact that the land had been owned by those who had come forward to suffer for the sake of swaraj.
('51', 399, 1, 23, 811728) The Patidars have a special duty towards the Dharala Thakores.
('51', 399, 1, 24, 811791) They should remove whatever injustices the latter have suffered in the past; they should be made to feel one with the rest of us.
('51', 399, 1, 25, 811921) It does no credit to a swarajist to give up hope of ever persuading the purchasers.
('51', 399, 1, 26, 812005) Whatever happens, we should not start a struggle of any kind against them.
('51', 399, 1, 27, 812080) We should avoid all such situations which would lead to a clash with them.
('51', 399, 1, 28, 812155) The land will remain untilled this monsoon.
('51', 399, 1, 29, 812199) It is our dharma to put up with this loss and those who have self confidence will do so.
('51', 399, 1, 30, 812288) A few words now regarding the payment of revenue dues.
('51', 399, 1, 31, 812343) It is the dharma of those who can to pay up their dues.
('51', 399, 1, 32, 812399) Let no one believe in the topsyturvy justice that if one person pays up, others must necessarily do so; likewise, it is contrary to law to believe that no one
('51', 400, 0, 1, 812558) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 401
('51', 400, 1, 2, 812603) should pay up because someone does not do so.
('51', 400, 1, 3, 812649) The right course is the one which I have suggested.
('51', 400, 1, 4, 812701) Those who can should certainly pay up.
('51', 400, 1, 5, 812740) There is no question here of paying up by contracting debts.
('51', 400, 1, 6, 812801) It is solely a questions of one’s own capacity.
('51', 400, 1, 7, 812849) Our goodness and our strength lie in abiding by the conditions of the Settlement even at the cost of some hardship to ourselves.
('51', 400, 1, 8, 812978) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 4 1931

('51', 403, 1, 2, 817054) 415. LETTER TO J. H. GARRETT 1
('51', 403, 2, 3, 817085) April 20, 1931 I enclose herewith a translation of what purports to be a notice from the Borsad Mamlatdar.
('51', 403, 2, 4, 817192) You had left me under the impression that you would investigate the matters I had discussed with you and that I would know from you what was intended to be done.
('51', 403, 2, 5, 817354) The notice seems to ignore these conversations and the Congress as the intermediery between the Government and the people.
('51', 403, 2, 6, 817477) If this is to the position to be finally taken up by the Government it will, in my opinion, be a distinct breach of the Settlement.
('51', 403, 2, 7, 817609) After the conference with the local workers Sardar Vallabhbhai and I have come to the following conclusions : 1. Ras has been so hard hit that it can hardly pay anything.
('51', 403, 2, 8, 817780) 2. The remaining villages will endeavour to pay one year’s dues to the utmost extent possible.
('51', 403, 2, 9, 817875) I am having an exhaustive note prepared on this matter.
('51', 403, 2, 10, 817931) 3. Taqavi and the balance of arrears shold be suspended.
('51', 403, 2, 11, 817988) If the Government notice of 11th March last re suspends suspended arrears in all cases, how much more are the villages affected by the movement in need of such relief?
('51', 403, 2, 12, 818156) That in the opinion of the Government their misfortunes may be considered to be due to their own fault is an irrelevant consideration after the Settlement.
('51', 403, 2, 13, 818312) 4. The Settlement clearly contemplates waiver of Rakha, attach ment, and notice fee charges.
('51', 403, 2, 14, 818405) These therefore should not be deman ded.
('51', 403, 2, 15, 818446) On receipt of a reply from you I shall arrange with the people for payment in accordance with the foregoing offer.
('51', 403, 2, 16, 818561) I leave Ahmedabad for Bardoli on 21st by the 10.55 p.m.
('51', 403, 2, 17, 818617) passenger train.

('51', 405, 3, 4, 821162) 418. LETTER TO J. H. GARRETT GUJARAT VIDYAPITH, AHMEDABAD, April 21, 1931
('51', 405, 4, 5, 821236) DEAR MR. GARRETT, I have to thank you for your exhaustive reply.
('51', 405, 5, 6, 821301) The chief point of the moment is with reference to the status of the Congress in the Settlement.
('51', 405, 5, 7, 821398) If you agree that the Settlement is between the Congress and the Government, and if it is the Congress that has to implement its terms so far as they are applicable to the people, it follows that the Congress must be recognized as the inter mediary between the Government and the people whom the Congress represents.
('51', 405, 5, 8, 821715) If such was not the case, I suppose that I should have no right to see you or to correspond with you or to receive your replies in the several matters arising out of the Settlement.
('51', 405, 5, 9, 821897) Your letter raises a question of the first magnitude, and on your reply to it will depend the action to be taken by me in connection with the Settlement.
('51', 405, 5, 10, 822051) Meanwhile, I refrain from dealing with the details covered by your letter.
('51', 405, 6, 11, 822126) Yours sincerely, J. H. GARRETT, ESQUIRE AHMEDABAD

('51', 406, 7, 16, 823212) 420. SPEECH AT SABARMATI ASHRAM, AHMEDABAD April 21, 1931
('51', 406, 8, 17, 823270) Mahatma Gandhi was present this evening on the occasion of the marriage ceremony of Lakshmi, daughter of Lakshmidas Gandhi, a khadi worker, in Dr. Pranjivandas’s Bungalow near Sabarmati Ashram.
('51', 406, 8, 18, 823464) The marriage ceremony was very simple and brief.
('51', 406, 8, 19, 823513) Mahatma Gandhi administered the marriage oath.
('51', 406, 9, 20, 823560) Before the marriage ceremony, Gandhiji entered his Ashram and attended the evening prayer for the first time after his Dandi March.
('51', 406, 9, 21, 823692) Addressing a small congregation consisting of the inmates of the Ashram, Mahatma Gandhi said that he did not expect to be back in the Ashram at so short a time.
('51', 406, 9, 22, 823853) He had, however, not returned to the Ashram after the conclusion of peace.
('51', 406, 9, 23, 823928) He had come for a special occasion, viz., the marriage of a girl who was brought up in the Ashram.
('51', 406, 9, 24, 824027) The marriage of one connected with the Ashram during the time of war would cause surprise, but this
('51', 406, 10, 25, 824127) 1 Recitation
('51', 407, 0, 1, 824140) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 407, 1, 2, 824182) marriage was not to serve as an example.
('51', 407, 1, 3, 824223) Those who could not do without marriage were at liberty to marry.
('51', 407, 1, 4, 824289) Celibacy was enjoined in the Ashram, but it was not compulsory.
('51', 407, 1, 5, 824353) Those who could not remain celibate, might leave the Ashram.
('51', 407, 2, 6, 824414) It was not known, when the fight would be resumed.
('51', 407, 2, 7, 824465) But it would be a fierce
('51', 407, 3, 8, 824490) fight, if it was resumed.
('51', 407, 3, 9, 824516) The inmates of the Ashram should therefore be alert and
('51', 407, 4, 10, 824572) augment their strenght.
('51', 407, 4, 11, 824596) Courage and purity of the people had been fully awakened,
('51', 407, 5, 12, 824654) and if the fight was resumed, crores would take part.
('51', 407, 5, 13, 824708) But if all of them lost heart and
('51', 407, 6, 14, 824742) remained aloof they (inmates of the Ashram) were to set example and give the lead.

('51', 407, 13, 27, 825329) 422. LETTER TO R. M. MAXWELL 1
('51', 407, 14, 28, 825360) BARDOLI, April 22, 1931 I enclose herewith copies of the latest correspondence between the Commissioner, Northern Division, and myself.
('51', 407, 14, 29, 825496) If His Ex cellency too takes the same view that Mr. Garrett does about the Congress mediation, I feel that it nullifies the whole Settlement.
('51', 407, 14, 30, 825638) It was only when the Government of India and the British Govern ment recog nized that the Congress truly represented the people that there was the Settlement between it and the Government.
('51', 407, 14, 31, 825827) To repudiate the Congress as the intermediary between the people and the Government means repudiation of the Settlement.
('51', 407, 15, 32, 825948) 1 Private Secretary to Acting Governor of Bombay
('51', 408, 0, 1, 825997) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 409
('51', 408, 1, 2, 826042) In the light of this extraordinary development, the other matters about which I complained on the 17th instant pale into insignificance.
('51', 408, 1, 3, 826179) But I recapitulate the main points here to show how far Government have till now failed to implement the Settlement.
('51', 408, 1, 4, 826296) 1. Some of the Sholapur prisoners and several other prisoners who the Congress claims are covered by the Settlement still remain undischarged.
('51', 408, 1, 5, 826439) 2. Several such prosecutions are still continued.
('51', 408, 1, 6, 826489) 3. Civil resisters coming under the Foreigners’ Act have not yet had the ban removed.
('51', 408, 1, 7, 826575) 4. Vatan and Inam cases against civil resisters have not yet been withdrawn.
('51', 408, 1, 8, 826652) 5. Officials such as Patels, etc.
('51', 408, 1, 9, 826686) who resigned during the Civil Disobedience period still remain unreinstated though the appoint ments held by the new incumbents are all, so far as I am aware, tempo rary or “until further orders”, and although several new Patels are undesirable.
('51', 408, 1, 10, 826932) 6. Confiscated movables and immovables have not yet under some pretext or other been returned.
('51', 408, 1, 11, 827027) 7. Liquor vendors still continue their unlicensed business in spite of the knowledge of the authorities.
('51', 408, 1, 12, 827132) 8. Names and prices of the forfeited lands with the dates of sales and the way in which they were sold have not yet been supplied.
('51', 408, 1, 13, 827263) 9. On the ground of ‘non co operation’ during the Civil Disobedience period, the Government still withhold grants from the Ahmedabad municipality for education, dispensation from revenue dues for lands used for purposes of sanitation and for a hospital and maternity home.
('51', 408, 1, 14, 827536) This matter though not specifically mentioned in the Settelment clearly falls within its scope.
('51', 408, 1, 15, 827632) I would like to have Government’s final decision on all these points.
('51', 408, 1, 16, 827702) I promised to furnish Mr. Collins with details of the cases under clauses 1 and 4. These are being collected.
('51', 408, 1, 17, 827812) But I think a general order will cover these cases.
('51', 408, 1, 18, 827864) But if the Congress is not recognized as the proper intermediary, everything else recedes in the background.
('51', 408, 2, 19, 827973) Young India, 20 8 1931

('51', 411, 0, 1, 830345) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 411, 1, 2, 830387) 427. FOREIGN CLOTH AND OTHER BRITISH GOODS
('51', 411, 2, 3, 830430) It is devoutly to be wished that Englishmen in general and Lancashire mill owners in particular will realize that India to be free from chronic starvation must for ever banish foreign cloth whether English, Japanese or any other.
('51', 411, 2, 4, 830660) This is an economic necessity which will not be removed even when India acquires the most complete independence.
('51', 411, 2, 5, 830773) Among the very first acts of a popular government would certainly be complete prohibition of foreign cloth.
('51', 411, 2, 6, 830881) And foreign cloth will be replaced not by indigenous millcloth but by khaddar spun and woven in 7,00,000 villages of India.
('51', 411, 2, 7, 831005) Though the indigenous mills undoubtedly and automatically benefit by the foreign cloth boycott, the Congress concentrates its main energy in this boycott, on behalf of khaddar, i.e., the toiling millions.
('51', 411, 2, 8, 831210) Let all the foreigners understand that this boycott mevement is a mass movement, it is a humanitarian movement.
('51', 411, 2, 9, 831322) Foreign manufacturers will in the end advance their own and their operatives’ interest by realizing and recognizing the intensity and the purity of the movement.
('51', 411, 2, 10, 831484) It has political consequences, but being a purely economic and humani tarian movement it should command the support of the whole world.
('51', 411, 2, 11, 831620) And yet needlessly bitter and unwarranted agitation has been launched out against foreign cloth boycott in England.
('51', 411, 2, 12, 831736) The tre mendous advantage gained by England owing to the removal of the boycott of British goods is hardly ever noticed.
('51', 411, 2, 13, 831857) This is not fair play.
('51', 411, 2, 14, 831880) This suppression of a fact of very great importance makes much more difficult the solution of the Indian question which is already difficult enough.
('51', 411, 2, 15, 832029) Do the English public know that the British goods boycottt movement is over thirty years old?
('51', 411, 2, 16, 832123) Do they realize that it gained the greatest impetus during the last struggle and that it attained success almost as great as the movement against foreign cloth?
('51', 411, 2, 17, 832284) India will for a long time to come, if not always, need certain things from foreign countries.
('51', 411, 2, 18, 832379) Today the Settlement is provisional.
('51', 411, 2, 19, 832416) Suppose there is a lasting settlement and an honourable partnership between England and India, will not the trade with England in other articles that India may need to import more than compensate for the loss of the piece goods and yarn custom which England must forgo in every case?

('51', 412, 2, 7, 833356) 428. FOREIGN MISSIONARIES
('51', 412, 3, 8, 833382) Correspondents angry or curious have sent me clippings from the Press or their comments on what has been ascribed to me by interviewers on the subjects of foreign missionaries.

('51', 413, 1, 2, 835082) by the people of India are adepuate for her people.

('51', 413, 1, 4, 835200) Let me now amplify the bald statement.

('51', 413, 1, 26, 837104) Through such friendly contact it will be possible for us all to rid our respective faiths of shortcomings and excres cences.

('51', 414, 1, 2, 837638) 429. ‘ONE OF THE MANY’ (?)
('51', 414, 2, 3, 837665) The open letter written by “One of the Many” is the late Sukhdev’s letter.
('51', 414, 2, 4, 837740) Sukhdev was Sardar Bhagat Singh’s comrade.
('51', 414, 2, 5, 837783) The latter was delivered to me after his death.
('51', 414, 2, 6, 837831) Want of time prevented me from giving the letter earlier publication.
('51', 414, 2, 7, 837901) It is printed without any alteration.
('51', 414, 3, 8, 837939) The writer is not “one of the many”.
('51', 414, 3, 9, 837976) Many do not seek the gallows for political freedom.
('51', 414, 3, 10, 838028) However condemnable political murder may be, it is not possible to withhold recognition of the love of the country and the courage which inspire such awful deeds.
('51', 414, 3, 11, 838191) And let us hope that the cult of political assassination is not growing.
('51', 414, 3, 12, 838264) If the Indian experiment succeeds, as it is bound to, the occupation of the political assassin will be gone for ever.
('51', 414, 3, 13, 838382) At any rate I am working in that faith.
('51', 414, 3, 14, 838422) The writer does me less than justice when he says that I have made no more than sentimental appeals to the revolutionaries to call off their movement, and I claim on the contrary that I have given them hard facts which, though they have been often repeated in these columns, will bear recapitulation : 1. The revolutionary activity has not brought us near our goal.
('51', 414, 3, 15, 838788) 2. It has added to the military expenditure in the country.
('51', 414, 3, 16, 838848) 3. It has given rise to reprisals on the part of the Government without doing any good.
('51', 414, 3, 17, 838936) 4. Whenever revolutionary murder has taken place, it has for a time and in that place demoralized the people.
('51', 414, 3, 18, 839046) 5. It has in no way contributed to mass awakening.
('51', 414, 3, 19, 839097) 6. Its effect on the masses has been doubly bad in that they had to bear the burden ultimately of additional expense and the indirect effect of Government wrath.
('51', 414, 3, 20, 839259) 7. Revolutionary murder cannot thrive in the Indian soil, Indian tradition, as history teaches us, being unfavourable to the growth of political violence.
('51', 414, 3, 21, 839414) 8. If the revolutionaries seek to convert the masses to their method, we would have to wait for an indefinitely long time for it to permeate the masses and then to gain freedom.
('51', 414, 4, 22, 839592) 1 Vide “Letter from Sukhdev”, 23 4 1931.
('51', 415, 0, 1, 839633) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 415, 1, 2, 839675) 9. If the method of violence ever becomes popular, it is bound to recoil, as it has done in other countries, on our own heads.
('51', 415, 1, 3, 839802) 10. The revolutionaries have an ocular demonstration of the efficacy of the opposite method, i.e., non violence, which has gone on in spite of sporadic cases of violence on their part and in spite even of violence occasionally done by the so called votaries of non violence.

('51', 422, 3, 4, 851170) It is my confirmed belief thay my pledge not to visit the Ashram is still intact and that it has not been violated in the least.
('51', 422, 3, 5, 851299) To abstain from going to the Ashram implies not staying there for any length of time.
('51', 422, 3, 6, 851385) This never implied, and should not imply, that in case of need I cannot visit the sick there.
('51', 422, 3, 7, 851479) Moreover, it did not and does not mean that I cannot go there if it becomes necessary to do so for the sake of the struggle itself.
('51', 422, 3, 8, 851611) I cannot go there for my convenience or other selfish end.
('51', 422, 3, 9, 851670) The Ashram is everything to me.
('51', 422, 3, 10, 851702) I feel an attachment to it, as it is my creation.
('51', 422, 3, 11, 851752) For me it is the place where my ideals can be realized.
('51', 422, 3, 12, 851808) It is a source of inspiration to me.
('51', 422, 3, 13, 851845) Ever since my return to India, it is there that I derived the inspiration for many, if not all, of the fresh steps which I have taken.
('51', 422, 3, 14, 851980) By beginning this latest struggle through the Ashram inmates, I hope that even in the unhappy event of everyone being defeated someone from the Ashram will come forward to continue the fight to the very end.
('51', 422, 3, 15, 852188) Regarding the Ashram I cherish the hope and the delusion that at a time when violence prevails, a witness for non violence will come forth from the Ashram.
('51', 422, 3, 16, 852344) It may be that there are no grounds for this hope.
('51', 422, 3, 17, 852395) It may well be that the person of whom we may entertain expectations may disappoint us, whereas one from whom we expect nothing at all may surpass our hopes.
('51', 422, 3, 18, 852553) This may well happen.
('51', 422, 3, 19, 852575) I am publicly giving expression to my fond hopes.
('51', 422, 3, 20, 852625) I am pointing out where my expectations lie.
('51', 422, 3, 21, 852670) My prayer is that many non violent, truthful persons may arise in the country who will fight unto death.
('51', 422, 3, 22, 852775) For me who has the illusion that even if this prayer is not granted, some fruit will at least be reaped from the Ashram—it is too much to give up the Ashram.
('51', 422, 3, 23, 852933) My renunciation holds good only so far as my self interest is concerned; it cannot imply the giving up of any occasion for rendering service.
('51', 422, 3, 24, 853075) Such renunciation cannot involve doing harm to its very object.
('51', 422, 4, 25, 853139) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('51', 422, 4, 26, 853176) The correspondent had referred to Gandhiji’s vow not to return to the Ashram before India attained swaraj.
('51', 422, 4, 27, 853283) Vide also “Speech at prayer meeting, Sabarmati ashram”, 12 3 1930 and “Interview to associated press of India”, 15 4 1931.
('51', 423, 0, 1, 853406) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 423, 1, 2, 853448) I find no substance in the opposition to the red bungalow.
('51', 423, 1, 3, 853507) The only offence which it has committed is that it is in the neighbourhood of the Ashram.
('51', 423, 1, 4, 853597) It is absolutely detached from the Ashram.
('51', 423, 1, 5, 853640) Why should I not stay in the red bung a low if I have some work pertaining to the Ashram but do not wish to live in it?
('51', 423, 1, 6, 853760) If there is no harm in staying at the Vidyapith, if there is no harm in staying at Ambalalbhai’s house, why cannot I stay at the red bungalow?
('51', 423, 1, 7, 853903) As a matter of fact, I would not regard it as a violation of my pledge even if during my visits to Ahmedabad I put up at the Ashram.
('51', 423, 1, 8, 854036) But I gave up the idea of doing so as that would have been misunderstood by people and from experience I find that it was all to the good.
('51', 423, 1, 9, 854175) It is not right that we should interpret a pledge literally.
('51', 423, 1, 10, 854236) Rather than stick to the letter, we should consider its spirit.
('51', 423, 1, 11, 854300) This is the golden rule of interpreting a pledge.
('51', 423, 1, 12, 854350) If more than one interpretation is possible, we should give up that which is favourable to us and suffer any inconvenience which results from an unfavourable interpretation and stick to it.
('51', 423, 1, 13, 854540) Hence I cannot go to the Ashram or stay there for accepting some service there.
('51', 423, 1, 14, 854620) If I am hungry and the Ashram is nearby, I cannot go there to get food but should suffer my hunger until I find food elsewhere.

('51', 424, 1, 2, 854830) 440. THE SARDA ACT 1
('51', 424, 2, 3, 854851) A correspondent asks the following questions: 2
('51', 424, 3, 4, 854899) In my opinion, the following are the replies, in the order of the questions: 1. One can go and register complaints.
('51', 424, 3, 5, 855015) 2. A true priest would not yield to threats or pressure.
('51', 424, 3, 6, 855072) 3. Risks have to be taken in trying to do a good deed.
('51', 424, 3, 7, 855127) Hence when a certain course of action clearly seems to be our dharma, it should be followed even at the risk of one’s life and property.
('51', 424, 3, 8, 855264) Every individual should decide for himself on every occasion whether his duty demands risking his life and property.
('51', 424, 3, 9, 855381) 4. The Congress does not stop with mere political activity.
('51', 424, 3, 10, 855441) It takes up all tasks which help in the uplift of the people.
('51', 424, 3, 11, 855503) All servants of the nation—whether men or women—should bear this in mind while making their own decisions.
('51', 424, 3, 12, 855610) Making a decision is not always an easy task.
('51', 424, 3, 13, 855656) There are many reforms which have to be abandoned in the larger interests of the country.
('51', 424, 3, 14, 855746) Hence the question that arises is always as follows : “By taking up the cause of this reform, do I increase or diminish my overall usefulness?” If the reply tends towards the latter, we should think twice before taking up the cause of that reform.
('51', 424, 3, 15, 855994) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 4 1931
('51', 424, 4, 16, 856031) 441. WOMEN VOLUNTEERS AND KHADI
('51', 424, 5, 17, 856063) There is an association of women volunteers in Nadiad and this question has come up there.
('51', 424, 5, 18, 856154) Some people claim that a woman volun teer can carry on picketing while clad in a mill made sari, etc; that it is no longer necessary now for those working for the Congress to wear khadi.
('51', 424, 5, 19, 856341) This reasoning is erroneous and the use of mill made saris and other clothes is not permitted.
('51', 424, 5, 20, 856436) The rule passed by the Congress is almost eight years old now.
('51', 424, 5, 21, 856499) It was attacked by many and was fully discussed at the annual session.
('51', 424, 5, 22, 856570) Despite this, Congress representatives have refused to alter the clause relating to khadi and hence khadi has

('51', 425, 1, 4, 856967) In my opinion, therefore, the above question should not have arisen at all.
('51', 425, 1, 5, 857043) But I have been told that if the condition in regard to khadi is not relaxed, there will be a sharp fall in the number of women volun teers and perhaps not a single woman volunteer will be forthcoming locally in the Kheda district who would be prepared to wear khadi.
('51', 425, 1, 6, 857311) If this is a fact, it is a sad thing.
('51', 425, 1, 7, 857349) Nevertheless, as the person who has laid down the Shastra of khadi, I am prepared to put up with this set back.
('51', 425, 1, 8, 857461) If there is real strength in khadi and if there is any tapascharya behind it, it will overcome this new difficulty which it is facing.
('51', 425, 1, 9, 857596) In the world, wherever people have swerved from the path of truth they have done so to evade such difficulties.
('51', 425, 1, 10, 857708) There is no other motive for swerving from the path of truth.
('51', 425, 1, 11, 857770) Human nature tries to avoid difficulties.
('51', 425, 1, 12, 857812) It seeks an easy way out.
('51', 425, 1, 13, 857838) The easy way takes one downhill, the difficult way leads one upwards.
('51', 425, 1, 14, 857908) The rule of physics applies also to spiritual matters.
('51', 425, 1, 15, 857963) An object drops heavily to the ground due to gravitation, whereas trying to lift it up makes one breathless.
('51', 425, 1, 16, 858072) Hence neglecting khadi in our impatience to boycott foreign cloth is like abandoning the path of truth.
('51', 425, 1, 17, 858176) Every volunteer—man or woman— should bear in mind that the boycott cannot succeed by deviating from that path, and even if succeeded, it would not be worth while.
('51', 425, 1, 18, 858339) We regard the boycott of foreign cloth as our dharma because in it we see the means of satisfying, more or less, the hunger of crores of persons and the spinning wheel is the means and this implies khadi.
('51', 425, 1, 19, 858544) Hence no Congress volunteer, whether a man or a woman, can use anything but khadi.
('51', 425, 1, 20, 858627) What, then, of mill made cloth?—some people thoughtlessly ask.
('51', 425, 1, 21, 858690) The movement for boycott was not started for the sake of the Indian textile mills.
('51', 425, 1, 22, 858773) However, mills too grow under the shade of the great tree of khadi.
('51', 425, 1, 23, 858841) Khadi spreads at a snail’s pace.
('51', 425, 1, 24, 858874) Its use has not yet become widespread.
('51', 425, 1, 25, 858913) It is not available in every town and every local ity.
('51', 425, 1, 26, 858968) In such circumstances, the Indian mills can readily sell their stocks.
('51', 425, 1, 27, 859039) But if these compete with khadi, both would be faced with ruin.
('51', 425, 1, 28, 859103) Whereas khadi needs the assistance of advertising and exhibi tions, the Indian textile mills stand in no need of these.
('51', 425, 1, 29, 859223) The latter get protection through the khadi movement.
('51', 425, 1, 30, 859277) A woman volunteer who is aware of this situation, while pleading for boycott will insist upon the use of khadi and never ask the people
('51', 426, 0, 1, 859413) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 427
('51', 426, 1, 2, 859458) to use mill made cloth.

('51', 432, 1, 2, 871445) 447. LETTER TO SURENDRA SINGH 1
('51', 432, 2, 3, 871477) BARDOLI, April 26, 1931
('51', 432, 3, 4, 871501) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter as also a copy of the speech you would have made at the Sikh League 2. With some parts of your letter I can heartily agree and I wish that we were rid of the slightest commu nal taint.
('51', 432, 3, 5, 871727) But it seems that, if there is any settlement in the immediate future, there would be at least some communalism about it.
('51', 432, 3, 6, 871849) I have never been able to understand the nationalism which remains nationalistic only if all the rest do so and otherwise become uncompromisingly communalistic.
('51', 432, 3, 7, 872010) I have not the dread that you have of adult suffrage.
('51', 432, 3, 8, 872064) Every form of suffrage will be liable to abuse, adult suffrage perhaps the least so.
('51', 432, 3, 9, 872149) And I have an effective antidote that might, to a certain extent, obviate the mischief.
('51', 432, 3, 10, 872237) But I need not dilate upon it at the present moment.
('51', 432, 3, 11, 872290) I am also in agreement with you that we should have education on the widest scale possible of the masses, not so much of children as of grown up men and women who will presently be armed with great powers for good or evil.
('51', 432, 3, 12, 872513) That education, I think, the Congress has given not always successfully, not always well, but on the whole undoubtedly successfully and well.
('51', 432, 3, 13, 872655) I do think that the association of high salaries with efficiency and public honesty is an hypnotic effect produced by the rulers.
('51', 432, 3, 14, 872785) The sooner we get out of it the better it will be for us.
('51', 432, 3, 15, 872843) The present civil service is open to influences which are far more subtle and deadly than open bribery.
('51', 432, 3, 16, 872947) Nor do I consider the administration to be efficient except in so far as it guarantees at the point of the bayonet safety for the lives of the European population but certainly not of the masses.
('51', 432, 3, 17, 873143) I think that we have patriotic men and women enough in the country who, when we come to our own, will gladly give their services for maintenance money that will easily bear comparison with the average imcome of the toiling but starving millions.
('51', 432, 3, 18, 873389) Poverty, if it is due to ignorance, is no less due to heartless unparalleled exploitation.
('51', 432, 4, 19, 873480) 1 Of the Ministry of Agriculture 2 The meeting of the Sikh League was held at Amritsar on April 8.
('51', 433, 0, 1, 873579) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 433, 1, 2, 873621) Thus though we have differences of opinion I have valued your letter and the enclosure, both of which I have read with a great deal of interest.
('51', 433, 1, 3, 873766) Do please therefore favour me again whenever you have anything of importance to tell me.
('51', 433, 2, 4, 873855) Yours sincerely,
('51', 433, 3, 5, 873872) SARDAR SURENDRA SINGH PUNJAB CIVIL SECRETARIAT LAHORE

('51', 433, 5, 7, 873956) 448. SPEECH TO VILLAGERS, AKOTI
('51', 433, 6, 8, 873988) April 26, 1931
('51', 433, 7, 9, 874003) When Mr. Gandhi arrived the villagers told him that all their rice crop worth
('51', 433, 8, 10, 874081) about Rs. 50,000 which was the main crop of the village, had been attached and sold
('51', 433, 9, 11, 874165) to a parsi for Rs. 1,400. They had no means of support and depended on the relief
('51', 433, 10, 12, 874247) given by the Congress, but still the Mamlatdar called upon them to pay land revenue.
('51', 433, 11, 13, 874332) Mr. Gandhi said that in view of their condition they were entitled under the
('51', 433, 12, 14, 874409) terms of the Truce to get time for the payment of land revenue.
('51', 433, 12, 15, 874473) He advised them as
('51', 433, 13, 16, 874492) well as all peasants in Gujarat to pay land revenue if they could, but if they could not
('51', 433, 14, 17, 874581) pay they should not be afraid to refuse to pay land revenue and patiently bear all the
('51', 433, 15, 18, 874668) consequences.
('51', 433, 16, 19, 874682) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 4 1931

('51', 434, 1, 2, 874759) 449. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('51', 434, 2, 3, 874788) AS AT BORSAD, April 27, 1931
('51', 434, 3, 4, 874817) DEAR MR. EMERSON, When I wrote to you last copy of an important letter 1 was not sent to you for which I apologize and which I now send.
('51', 434, 3, 5, 874954) More corres pondence has grown since.
('51', 434, 3, 6, 874992) I send you copies of these also.
('51', 434, 3, 7, 875025) There are other ominous things which I need not mention now.
('51', 434, 3, 8, 875086) You will recall that the Government of India authorized co ercive measures on the strength of the Bombay Government report of which you gave me a copy.
('51', 434, 3, 9, 875238) I have already shown to you how mislea ding that report was and how nobly, in my opinion, the people have paid in spite of the fact that even now the terms of the Settlement in several matters remain unfulfilled by the local officials.
('51', 434, 3, 10, 875474) I attach hereto a list which will enforce what I have said.
('51', 434, 3, 11, 875534) These people deserve better treatment than notices of coercive processes.
('51', 434, 3, 12, 875608) If the matters brought to your notice are not clear to you, and if you think it necessary, you may drag me to Simla.
('51', 434, 3, 13, 875725) And if you do, it will be necessary for you to stop all coercive processes at least pending our conversations.
('51', 434, 3, 14, 875836) I want your help in preventing a breakdown of the Settlement.
('51', 434, 3, 15, 875898) I have pledged my honour to Lord Irwin that I shall do nothing that I could honourably refrain from doing to prevent a breakdown.
('51', 434, 3, 16, 876028) But it takes two to play a game.
('51', 434, 3, 17, 876061) I feel safe in the confidence that you on your part will not, if it is at all possible, allow a breakdown in regard to what you have rightly said is a gentleman’s agreement.
('51', 434, 4, 18, 876235) Yours sincerely, H. W. EMERSON, ESQ.

('51', 436, 2, 3, 877424) APPENDIX I
('51', 436, 3, 4, 877435) PRIME MINISTER’S DECLARATION AT R.T.C .
('51', 436, 4, 5, 877475) January 19, 1931
('51', 436, 5, 6, 877492) The view of His Mejesty’s Government is that responsibility for the Govern 
('51', 436, 6, 7, 877568) ment of India should be placed upon Legislatures, Central and Provincial, with such
('51', 436, 7, 8, 877652) provisions as may be necessary to guarantee, during a period of transition, the
('51', 436, 8, 9, 877732) observance of certain obligations and to meet other special circumstances, and also
('51', 436, 9, 10, 877816) with such guarantees as are required by minorities to protect their political liberties
('51', 436, 10, 11, 877904) and rights.
('51', 436, 11, 12, 877916) In such statutory safeguards as may be made for meeting the needs of the
('51', 436, 12, 13, 877989) transitional period, it will be a primary concern of His Majesty’s Government to see
('51', 436, 13, 14, 878074) that the reserved powers are so framed and excercised as not to prejudice the
('51', 436, 14, 15, 878152) advance of India through the new constitution to full responsibility for her own
('51', 436, 15, 16, 878233) government.
('51', 436, 16, 17, 878245) His Majesty’s Government, whilst making this declaration, is aware that some
('51', 436, 17, 18, 878322) of the conditions which are essential to the working of such a constitution as is
('51', 436, 18, 19, 878404) contemplated, have not been finally settled, but it believes that as the result of the
('51', 436, 19, 20, 878491) work done here, they have been brought to a point which encourages the hope that
('51', 436, 20, 21, 878572) further negotiations, after this declaration, will be successful.
('51', 436, 21, 22, 878638) His Majesty’s Government has taken note of the fact that the deliberations of
('51', 436, 22, 23, 878716) the Conference have proceeded on the basis, accepted by all parties, that the Central
('51', 436, 23, 24, 878802) Government should be a Federation of all India, embracing both the Indian States and
('51', 436, 24, 25, 878887) British India in a bi cameral legislature.
('51', 436, 24, 26, 878930) The precise form and structure of the new
('51', 436, 25, 27, 878972) Federal Government must be determined after further discussion with the Princes and
('51', 436, 26, 28, 879056) representatives of British India.
('51', 436, 26, 29, 879090) The range of subjects to be committed to it will also
('51', 436, 27, 30, 879144) require further discussion, because the Federal Government will have authority only in
('51', 436, 28, 31, 879231) such matters concerning the States as will be ceded by their Rulers in agreements
('51', 436, 29, 32, 879313) made by them to entering into Federation.
('51', 436, 29, 33, 879355) The connection of the States with the
('51', 436, 30, 34, 879393) Federation will remain subject to the basic principle that in regard to all matters not
('51', 436, 31, 35, 879481) 1 Vide “Interview to associated press of India”, 26 1 1931 & “Interview to The Pioneer”, 5 2 1931.
('51', 437, 0, 1, 879580) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 437, 1, 2, 879622) ceded by them to the Federation their relations will be with the Crown acting through
('51', 437, 2, 3, 879708) the agency of the Viceroy.
('51', 437, 3, 4, 879735) With a Legislature constituted on a federal basis.
('51', 437, 3, 5, 879786) His Majesty’s Government
('51', 437, 4, 6, 879811) will be prepared to recognize the principle of the responsibility of the Executive to
('51', 437, 5, 7, 879897) the Legislature.
('51', 437, 6, 8, 879914) Under existing condition the subjects of Defence and External Affairs will be reserved to the Governor General, and arrangements will be made to place in his hands the powers necessary for the administration of those subjects.
('51', 437, 6, 9, 880141) Moreover, as the Governor General must, as a last resort, be able in an emergency to mintain the tranquillity of the State, and must similarly be responsible for the observance of the constitutional rights of minorities, he must be granted the necessary powers for these purposes.
('51', 437, 7, 10, 880422) As regards finance, the transfer of financial responsibility must necessarily be subject to such conditions as will ensure the fulfilment of the obligations incurred under the authority of the Secretary of State and the maintenance unimpaired of the financial stability and credit of India.
('51', 437, 7, 11, 880713) The Report of the Federal Structure sub Committee indicates some ways of dealing with this subject including a Reserve Bank, the service of loans, and Exchange policy, which in the view of His Majesty’s Government will have to be provided for somehow in the new constitution.
('51', 437, 7, 12, 880989) It is of vital interest to all parties in India to accept these provisions to maintain financial confidence.
('51', 437, 7, 13, 881098) Subject to these provisions the Indian Government would have full financial responsibility for the methods or raising revenue and for the control of expenditure on non reserved services.
('51', 437, 8, 14, 881285) This will mean that under existing conditions the Central Legislature and Executive will have some features of dualism which will have to be fitted into the constitutional structure.
('51', 437, 9, 15, 881468) The provision of reserved powers is necessary in the circumstanced and some such reservation has indeed been incidental to the development of most free constitutions.
('51', 437, 9, 16, 881635) But every care must be taken to prevent conditions arising which will necessitate their use.
('51', 437, 9, 17, 881728) It is, for instance, undesirable that Ministers should trust to the special powers of the Governor General as a means of avoiding responsibilities which are properly their own, thus defeating the development of responsible Govern ment by bringing into use powers meant to lie in reserve and in the background.
('51', 437, 9, 18, 882038) Let there be no mistake about that.
('51', 437, 10, 19, 882074) The Governor’s Provinces will be constituted on a basis of full responsibility.
('51', 437, 10, 20, 882154) Their Ministries will be taken from the Legislature and will be jointly responsible to it.
('51', 437, 10, 21, 882245) The range of Provincial subjects will be so defined as to give them the greatest possible measure of self government.
('51', 437, 10, 22, 882363) The authority of the Federal Government will be limited to provision required to secure its administration of Federal subjects, and
('51', 438, 0, 1, 882495) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 439
('51', 438, 1, 2, 882540) so discharge its responsibility for subjects defined in the constitution as of all India concern.
('51', 438, 2, 3, 882638) There will be reserved to the Government only that minimum of special
('51', 438, 3, 4, 882708) powers which is required in order to secure, in exceptional circumstances, the preser 
('51', 438, 4, 5, 882795) vation of tranquillity, and to guarantee the maintenance of rights provided by Statute
('51', 438, 5, 6, 882882) for the Public Services and minorities.
('51', 438, 6, 7, 882922) Finally, His Majesty’s Government considers that the institution in the Pro vinces of responsible government requires both that the legislatures should be enlarged, and that they should be based on a more liberal franchis.
('51', 438, 7, 8, 883145) In framing the Constitution His Majesty’s Government considers that it will be its duty to insert provisions guaranteeing to the various minorities, in addition to political representation, that differences of religion, race, sect or cast shall not themselves constitute civic disabilities.
('51', 438, 8, 9, 883436) In the opinion of His Majesty’s Government it is the duty of the communities to come to an agreement amongst themselves on the points raised by the Minorities sub Committee but not settled there.
('51', 438, 8, 10, 883632) During the continuing negotiations such an agreement ought to be reached and the Government will continue to render what good offices it can to help to secure that end, as it is anxious not only that no delay should take place in putting the new Constitution into operation, but that it should start with the goodwill and confidence of all the communities concerned.
('51', 438, 9, 11, 883999) The various sub committee which have been studying the more important principles of a Constitution which would meet Indian condition have surveyed a considerable part of the structure in detail and the still unsettled points have been advanced a good way to an agreement.
('51', 438, 9, 12, 884271) His Majesty’s Government, however, in view of the character of the Conference and of the limited time at its disposal in London, has deemed it advisable to suspend its work at this point, so that Indian opinion may be consulted upon the work done, and expedients considered for overcoming the difficulties which have been raised.
('51', 438, 9, 13, 884601) His Majesty’s Government will consider, without delay, a plan by which our co operation may be continued so that the result of our completed work may be seen in a new Indian Constitution.
('51', 438, 9, 14, 884789) If, in the mean time, there is a response to the Viceroy’s appeal to those engaged at present in civil disobe dience, and others wish to co operate on the general lines of this declaration, steps will be taken to enlist their services.
('51', 438, 10, 15, 885025) I must convey to you all on behalf of the Government its hearty appreciation of the services you have rendered not only to India but to this country, by coming here and engaging in these personal negotiations.
('51', 438, 10, 16, 885235) Personal contact is the best way of removing those unfortunate differences and misunderstandings which too many people on both sides have been engendering between us in recent years.
('51', 438, 10, 17, 885418) A mutual understanding of intention and difficulty, gained under such conditions as have
('51', 439, 0, 1, 885507) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 439, 1, 2, 885549) prevailed here, is by far the best way for discovering ways and means of settling differences and satisfying claims.
('51', 439, 1, 3, 885666) His Majesty’s Government will strive to secure such an amount of agreement as will enable the new Constitution to be passed through the British Parliament and to be put into operation with the active goodwill of the people of both countries.
('51', 439, 2, 4, 885908) India in 1930 31, pp.

('51', 439, 4, 6, 885942) VICEROY’S STATEMENT 1
('51', 439, 5, 7, 885964) NEW DELHI,
('51', 439, 6, 8, 885975) January 26, 1931
('51', 439, 7, 9, 885992) The following statement has been issued by His Excellency the Governor General this afternoon :
('51', 439, 8, 10, 886088) “In order to provide opportunity for the consideration of the statement made by the Prime Minister on the 19th January, my Government, in consultation with local Governments, have thought it right that the members of the Working Committee of the All India Congress should enjoy full liberty of discussion between themselves and with those who have acted as members of the Committee since Ist January, 1930.
('51', 439, 9, 11, 886495) “In accordance with this decision and with this object, and in order that there may be no legal bar to any meeting they may wish to hold, the notification declaring the Committee to be an unlawful Association under the Criminal Law Amendment Act will be withdrawn by all local Governments and action will be taken for the release of Mr. Gandhi and others who are now members of the Gommittee, or who have acted as such, since Ist January 1930.
('51', 439, 10, 12, 886939) “My Government will impose no conditions on these releases, because we feel that the best hope of the restoration of peaceful condition lies in discussions being conducted by those concerned under term of unconditional liberty.
('51', 439, 10, 13, 887167) Our action has been taken in pursuance of a sincere desire to assist the creation of such peaceful condition as would enable the Government to implement the undertaking given by the Prime Minister that if civil quiet were proclaimed and assured, the Government would not be backward in response.
('51', 439, 11, 14, 887463) “I am content to trust those who will be affected by our decision to act in the same spirit as inspires it.
('51', 439, 11, 15, 887571) And I am confident that they will recognize the importance of securing for those grave issues calm and dispassionate examination.”

('51', 440, 2, 3, 887829) LETTER FROM GANGABEHN VAIDYA1
('51', 440, 3, 4, 887859) You know that there was to be a procession in honour of Lilavati and as a protest against the ourtrageous assault on her by the police.
('51', 440, 3, 5, 887995) It was not possible for me to keep out of the procession.
('51', 440, 3, 6, 888053) In fact I took it upon myself to organize the procession by placing the Ashram girls at the head of small batches of women coming from various parts of the town.
('51', 440, 3, 7, 888215) Whilst I was leading my batch I was informed that Shakariben and Kalavatiben who were at the head of the Ras batch were being belaboured by the police with lathis.
('51', 440, 3, 8, 888379) I immediately ran to the spot.
('51', 440, 3, 9, 888410) I found that a girl was profusely bleeding.
('51', 440, 3, 10, 888454) I went and cheered her up and asked the rest of the sisters to march forward reciting Raghupati Raghava Raja Ram.
('51', 440, 3, 11, 888568) I was also asking the passers 
('51', 440, 4, 12, 888599) by to keep on one side of the road so as not to obstruct the procession, when all of a sudden the policy came down upon us with a shower of lathi blow.
('51', 440, 4, 13, 888751) I came in for a big share of them, receiving several on the head, the arms, the back, the face and the ears.
('51', 440, 4, 14, 888860) Blood streamed out from a wound caused on my head but I did not budge an inch and asked the other sisters to sit down.
('51', 440, 4, 15, 888979) Seeing that I would not be deterred the Foujdar came and arrested me and handed me over to the police.
('51', 440, 4, 16, 889082) I was taken, bleeding, to the police choki where I found Shakariben, Kalavati, Padma, Lakshmi and Madhu who had all had their share of the blows.
('51', 440, 4, 17, 889228) My head was still bleeding and I sat down allowing the sun’s rays to fall on the bleeding part.
('51', 440, 4, 18, 889324) I was perfectly peaceful.
('51', 440, 4, 19, 889350) Some time after the police came and asked every one of us if we had been injured.
('51', 440, 4, 20, 889432) “Can’t you see with your own eyes ?” I told them.
('51', 440, 4, 21, 889482) To which he replied: “You would like to be taken to the hospital ?” “No”, said I, “suppose we can get well without medical aid.” At this moment another police official arrived on the scene and sternly said to the man who was gloting over our agonies : “Don’t you see that she is still bleedin?
('51', 440, 4, 22, 889776) Take them quickly to the hospital.
('51', 440, 4, 23, 889811) How could you allow them to remain here unattended so long?” Thereupon we were taken to the hospital where we found Maitri, Lalita, Lakshmi and other girls who had all been hammered and already admitted as in patients.
('51', 440, 4, 24, 890030) My wound was then dressed.
('51', 440, 4, 25, 890057) It was, the doctor told me, three quarters of an inch to one inch.
('51', 440, 4, 26, 890124) The others were treated, but were later turned out, evidently because they had chosen to arrest only Vasumati and me.
('51', 440, 5, 27, 890242) We are in the lock up.
('51', 440, 5, 28, 890265) My wound is being dressed daily and I am quite
('51', 440, 6, 29, 890312) happy and peaceful.
('51', 440, 6, 30, 890332) I have my prayers regularly, but have not yet been given my takli.
('51', 440, 6, 31, 890399) It was on this occasion that I understood somewhat the meaning of ahimsa.
('51', 440, 7, 32, 890473) I was quite fearless when the blows were coming down upon me and I assure you that I
('51', 440, 8, 33, 890558) had no hatred or anger in me.
('51', 440, 8, 34, 890588) Even now I feel no resentment towards the police, and it
('51', 440, 9, 35, 890645) 1 Vide “Letter to Viceroy”, 1 2 1931.
('51', 441, 0, 1, 890683) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 441, 1, 2, 890725) is growing upon me that we shall achieve success only to the extent we cultivate the
('51', 441, 2, 3, 890810) spirit of ahimsa.
('51', 441, 2, 4, 890828) The other sisters bore the blows with exemplary brabery.
('51', 441, 2, 5, 890885) In some
('51', 441, 3, 6, 890893) cases the assaults were outrageous, many being kicked on their chests with the hells
('51', 441, 4, 7, 890978) of the policemen’s boots.
('51', 441, 4, 8, 891004) Not one budged an inch, everyone stood unflinching at her

('51', 441, 10, 17, 891309) VICEROY’S CABLE TO SECRETARY OF STATE1
('51', 441, 11, 18, 891348) Immediate, Private and Personal
('51', 441, 12, 19, 891380) I HAVE HAD TWO LONG TALKS WITH GANDHI.
('51', 441, 12, 20, 891419) APART FROM THE
('51', 441, 13, 21, 891434) VARIETY OF IMPORTANT POINTS RELATING TO ACTUAL TERMS ON
('51', 441, 14, 22, 891490) WHICH CONGRESS WOULD CALL OFF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE TO
('51', 441, 15, 23, 891542) WHICH I WILL REFER LATER, THE MAIN MATTERS OF SUBSTANCE WE
('51', 441, 16, 24, 891601) DISCUSSED WERE:
('51', 441, 17, 25, 891617) (A) THE SCOPE OF FUTURE CONSTITUTIONAL DISCUSSIONS;
('51', 441, 18, 26, 891669) (B) THE INTENTIO OF THE CONGRESS, IF THEY CAME INTO THE
('51', 441, 19, 27, 891725) DISCUSSION, REGARDING POTENTIAL RESUMPTION OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE.
('51', 441, 20, 28, 891791) 2. AS TO THE FIRST I TOLD HIM THAT THREE MAIN PRINCIPLES OF
('51', 441, 21, 29, 891851) THE CONFERENCE WERE FEDERATION, SAFEGUARDS AND INDIAN
('51', 441, 22, 30, 891905) RESPONSIBILITY, THAT THESE WERE FUNDAMENTAL, BUT DETAILED
('51', 441, 23, 31, 891963) APPLICATION OF THESE PRINCIPLES WAS OPEN TO FURTHER DISCUSSION.
('51', 441, 24, 32, 892027) 3. HE ASKED ABOUT THE RIGHT TO RAISE IN DISCUSSION THE
('51', 441, 25, 33, 892082) QUESTION OF DISSOLUTION OF PARTNERSHIP BY WHICH HE PRESUMABLY
('51', 441, 26, 34, 892144) MEANT THE RIGHT OF SE CESSION FROM THE EMPIRE.
('51', 441, 26, 35, 892191) I SAID THAT I
('51', 441, 27, 36, 892205) PRESUMED HE COULD RAISE IT, IF HE SO DESIRED, BUT THAT IT WOULD BE
('51', 441, 28, 37, 892272) VERY DAMAGING IF HE MADE ANY PUBLIC STATEMENT TO THIS EFFECT.
('51', 441, 29, 38, 892334) GATHER HE DID NOT ATTACH MUCH IMPORTANCE TO THE POINT AND
('51', 441, 30, 39, 892392) THIS IMPRESSION HAS BEEN CONFIRMED BY SAPRU AND OTHERS.
('51', 441, 31, 40, 892448) 4. HE ALSO MENTIONED QUESTION OF STATE SUBJECTS.
('51', 441, 31, 41, 892497) I SAID I PRESUMED

('51', 444, 1, 2, 897203) APPENDIX V
('51', 444, 2, 3, 897214) JAWAHARLAL NEHRU‘S NOTE ON PROVISIONAL SETTLEMENT1
('51', 444, 3, 4, 897265) In consequence of the provisional settlement between the Working Committee
('51', 444, 4, 5, 897340) and the Government of India a period of truce has been proclaimed.
('51', 444, 4, 6, 897407) It is with regret
('51', 444, 5, 7, 897425) that, on the morrow of this agreement, I have to strike a note of discord.
('51', 444, 5, 8, 897500) I recognize
('51', 444, 6, 9, 897512) that, in many respects, the terms of settlement are honourable and give evidence
('51', 444, 7, 10, 897593) of the strength that the nation has gained by the sacrifice and suffering of the
('51', 444, 8, 11, 897674) past year.
('51', 444, 8, 12, 897685) I recognize also that the settlement is provisional, leaving all the
('51', 444, 9, 13, 897754) vital questions open, and the final settlement is yet to come.
('51', 444, 9, 14, 897817) But I feel that there
('51', 444, 10, 15, 897839) is a certain commitment in it regarding the scope of discussions and a certain
('51', 444, 11, 16, 897918) limitation of our ideal as laid down at Lahore.
('51', 444, 11, 17, 897966) Safeguards and reservations are
('51', 444, 12, 18, 897998) referred to and, although these are said to be in the interests of India, they may be,
('51', 444, 13, 19, 898085) and I fear will be, interpreted to mean a limitation of our freedom in regard to
('51', 444, 14, 20, 898166) defence, external affairs, finances and the public debt.
('51', 444, 14, 21, 898223) The Congress and the
('51', 444, 15, 22, 898244) Working Committee are pledged to the full control by the people of India of the
('51', 444, 16, 23, 898324) defence services, the financial and economic policy, and the .
('51', 444, 16, 24, 898387) 2 many of my
('51', 444, 17, 25, 898400) colleagues of the W.C. are of opinion that the reference to safeguards and reser 
('51', 444, 18, 26, 898482) vation does not limit their freedom in any way to work for the independence of India.
('51', 444, 19, 27, 898568) I hope they are right and will prove their contention by their achievements in the
('51', 444, 20, 28, 898651) coming Conference.
('51', 444, 20, 29, 898670) But, as I cannot get over my doubts in regard to this
('51', 444, 21, 30, 898724) phraseology, I am unable to accept or reconcile myself to any reference to safeguards
('51', 444, 22, 31, 898810) and reservations.
('51', 444, 22, 32, 898828) I do not desire however that any impediment should be placed in the
('51', 444, 23, 33, 898896) way of those who interpret the words differently from me and who propose to extract
('51', 444, 24, 34, 898980) independence out of them.
('51', 444, 24, 35, 899006) Truce having been proclaimed by the Working
('51', 444, 25, 36, 899050) Committee, I trust all of us will honour it and carry out the directions of the W.C. in
('51', 444, 26, 37, 899138) regard to it.

('51', 445, 1, 2, 899321) APPENDIX VI
('51', 445, 2, 3, 899333) PROVISIONAL SETTLEMENT
('51', 445, 3, 4, 899356) The following statement 1 by the Governor General in Council published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary of 5th March 1931 gives the conditions on which
('51', 445, 4, 5, 899513) the civil disobedience movement is to be suspended pending final terms of
('51', 445, 5, 6, 899587) settlement.
('51', 445, 5, 7, 899599) 1. Consequent on the conversations that have taken place between His Excellency the Viceroy and Mr. Gandhi, it has been arranged that the civil disobedience movement, be discontinued, and that, with the approval of His Majesty’s Government certain action be taken by the Government of India and local Governments.
('51', 445, 5, 8, 899913) 2. As regards constitutional questions, the scope of future discussion is stated, with the assent of His Majesty’s Government, to be with the object of considering further the scheme for the constitutional Government of India discussed at the Round Table Conference.
('51', 445, 5, 9, 900180) Of the scheme there outlined, Federation is an essential part; so also are Indian responsibility and reservation; or safeguards in the interest of India, for such matters as, for instance, defence; external affairs; the position of minorities; the financial credit of India, and the discharge of obligations.
('51', 445, 5, 10, 900489) 3. In pursuance of the statement made by the Prime Minister in his announcement of the 19th of January 1931, steps will be taken for the participation of the representative of the Congress in the further discussion that are to take place on the scheme of constitutional reform.
('51', 445, 5, 11, 900767) 4. The settlement relates to activities directly connected with the civil disobedience movement.
('51', 445, 5, 12, 900864) 5. Civil disobedience will be effectively discontinued and reciprocal action will be taken by Government.
('51', 445, 5, 13, 900970) The effective discontinuance of the civil dis obedience movement means the effective discontinunace of all activities in furtherance thereof, by whatever methods pursued and, in particular, the following:
('51', 445, 6, 14, 901175) (i) The organized defiance of the provisions of any law.
('51', 445, 7, 15, 901232) (ii) The movement for the non payment of land revenue and other legal dues.
('51', 445, 8, 16, 901308) (iii) The publication of news sheets in support of the civil disobedience movement.
('51', 445, 9, 17, 901392) (iv) Attempts to influence civil and military servants of village officials against Government or to persuade them to resign their posts.
('51', 445, 10, 18, 901530) 1 Of the Gandhi Irwin agreement
('51', 446, 0, 1, 901562) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 447
('51', 446, 1, 2, 901607) 6. As regards the boycott of foreign goods, there are two issues involved:
('51', 446, 2, 3, 901682) firstly, the character of the boycott and secondly, the methods employed in giving
('51', 446, 3, 4, 901765) effect to it.
('51', 446, 3, 5, 901779) The position of Government is as follows.
('51', 446, 3, 6, 901821) They approve of the
('51', 446, 4, 7, 901841) encouragement of Indian industries as part of the economic and industrial movement
('51', 446, 5, 8, 901924) designed to improve the material condition of India, and they have no desire to
('51', 446, 6, 9, 902004) discourage methods of propaganda, persuasion or advertisement pursued with this
('51', 446, 7, 10, 902084) object in view, which do not interfere with the freedom of action of individuals, or are
('51', 446, 8, 11, 902173) not prejudicial to the maintenance of law and order.
('51', 446, 8, 12, 902226) But the boycott of non Indian
('51', 446, 9, 13, 902256) goods (except of cloth which has been applied to all foreign cloth) has been directed
('51', 446, 10, 14, 902342) during the civil disobedience movement cheifly, if not exclusively, against British
('51', 446, 11, 15, 902426) goods, and in regard to these it has been admittedly employed in order to exert
('51', 446, 12, 16, 902506) pressure for political ends.
('51', 446, 13, 17, 902535) It is accepted that a boycott of this character, and organized for this purpose,
('51', 446, 14, 18, 902616) will not be consistent with the participation of representatives of the Congress in a
('51', 446, 15, 19, 902702) frank and friendly discussion of constitutional questions between representatives of
('51', 446, 16, 20, 902787) British India, of the Indian States, and of His Majesty’s Government and political
('51', 446, 17, 21, 902870) parties in England, which the settlement is intended to secure.
('51', 446, 17, 22, 902934) It is, therefore, agreed
('51', 446, 18, 23, 902959) that the discontinuance of the civil disobedience movement connotes the definite
('51', 446, 19, 24, 903040) discontinuance of the employment of the boycott of British commodities as a
('51', 446, 20, 25, 903116) political weapon and that, in consequence, those who have given up, during a time of
('51', 446, 21, 26, 903201) political excitement, the sale or purchase of British goods must be left free without
('51', 446, 22, 27, 903287) any form of restraint to change their attitude if they so desire.
('51', 446, 23, 28, 903353) 7. In regard to the methods employed in furtherance of the replacement of non Indian by Indian goods, or against the consumption of intoxicating liquor and drugs, resort will not be had to methods coming within the category of picketing, except within the limits permitted by the ordinary law.
('51', 446, 23, 29, 903647) Such picketing, shall be unaggressive and it shall not involve coercion, intimidation, restraint, hostile demonstration, obstruction to the public, or any offence under the ordinary law.
('51', 446, 23, 30, 903834) If and when any of these methods is employed in any place, the practice of picketing in that place will be suspended.
('51', 446, 24, 31, 903952) 8. Mr. Gandhi has drawn the attention of Government to specific allegation against the conduct of the police, and represented the desirability of a public enquiry into them.
('51', 446, 24, 32, 904126) In present circumstances Government see great difficulty in this course and feel that it must inevitably lead to charges and counter charges, and so militate against the re establishment of peace.
('51', 446, 24, 33, 904323) Having regard to these conside rations, Mr. Gandhi agreed not to press the matter.
('51', 446, 25, 34, 904406) 9. The action that Government will take on the discontinuance of the civil disobedience movement is stated in the following paragraphs.
('51', 447, 0, 1, 904542) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 447, 1, 2, 904584) 10. Ordinances promulgated in connection with the civil disobedience
('51', 447, 2, 3, 904653) movement will be withdrawn.
('51', 447, 2, 4, 904681) Ordinance No.
('51', 447, 2, 5, 904695) 1 of 1931 relating to the terrorist move 
('51', 447, 3, 6, 904737) ment does not come within the scope of the provision.
('51', 447, 4, 7, 904791) 11. Notifications declaring association unlawful under the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1908 will be withdrawn, provided that the notifications were made in connection with the civil disobedience movement.
('51', 447, 4, 8, 904998) The notifications recently issued by the Burma Government under the Criminal Law Amendment Act do not come within the scope of this provision.
('51', 447, 4, 9, 905141) 12 (i) Pending prosecutions will be withdrawn if they have been filed in connection with the civil disobedience movement and relate to offences which do not involve violence other than technical violence, or incitement to such violence.
('51', 447, 5, 10, 905378) (ii) The same principles will apply to proceedings under the security provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code.
('51', 447, 6, 11, 905491) (iii) Where a local Government has moved any High Court or has initiated proceedings under the Legal Practitioners’s Act in regard to the conduct of legal practitioners in connection with the civil disobedience movement, it will make application to the Court concerned for permission to withdraw such proceedings, provided that the alleged conduct of the persons concerned does not relate to violence of incitement to violence.
('51', 447, 7, 12, 905919) (iv) Prosecutions, if any, against soldiers and police involving disobe dience of orders will not come within the scope of this provision.
('51', 447, 8, 13, 906058) 13 (i) Those prisoners will be released who are undergoing imprisonment in connection with the civil disobedience movement for offences which did not involve violence, other than technical violence, or incitement to such violence.
('51', 447, 9, 14, 906289) (ii) If any prisoner who comes within the scope of (i) above has been also sentenced for a jail offence, not involving violence, other than technical violence, or incitement to such violence, the latter sentence also will be remitted, or if a prosecution relating to an offence of this character is pending against such a prisoner, it will be withdrawn.
('51', 447, 10, 15, 906643) (iii) Soldiers and police convicted of offences involving disobedience of orders—in the very few cases that have occurred—will not come within the scope of the amnesty.
('51', 447, 11, 16, 906812) 14. Fines which have not been realized will be remitted.
('51', 447, 11, 17, 906869) Where an order for the forfeiture of security has been made under the security provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code, and the security has not been realized, it will be similarly remitted.
('51', 447, 12, 18, 907062) Fines which have been realized and securities forfeited and realized under any law will not be returned.
('51', 447, 13, 19, 907167) 15. Additional police imposed in connection with the civil disobedience movement at the expense of the inhabitants of a particular area will be withdrawn at
('51', 448, 0, 1, 907324) VOL. 51 : 6 JANUARY, 1931 28 APRIL, 1931 449
('51', 448, 1, 2, 907369) the discretion of local Governments.
('51', 448, 1, 3, 907406) Local Governments will not refund any money, not in excess of the actual cost, that has been realized, but they will remit any sum that has not been realized.
('51', 448, 2, 4, 907565) 16 (a) Movble property, which is not an illegal possession and which has
('51', 448, 3, 5, 907638) been seized in connection with the civil disobedience movement, under the
('51', 448, 4, 6, 907712) Ordinances or the provisions of the Criminal Law, will be returned, if it is still in the
('51', 448, 5, 7, 907802) possession of Government.
('51', 448, 6, 8, 907828) (b) Movable property, forfeited or attached in connection with the
('51', 448, 7, 9, 907895) realization of land revenue of other dues, will be returned, unless the Collector of the
('51', 448, 8, 10, 907984) District has reason to believe that the defaulter will contumaciously refuse to pay the
('51', 448, 9, 11, 908072) dues recoverable from him within a reasonable period.
('51', 448, 9, 12, 908126) In deciding what is a
('51', 448, 10, 13, 908148) reasonable period, special regard will be paid to cases in which the defaulters, while
('51', 448, 11, 14, 908235) willing to pay, genuinely require time for the purpose, and if necessary, the revenue
('51', 448, 12, 15, 908321) will be suspended in accordance with the ordinary principles of land revenue
('51', 448, 13, 16, 908398) administration.
('51', 448, 14, 17, 908414) (c) Compensation will not be given for deterioration.
('51', 448, 15, 18, 908468) (d) Where movable property has been sold or otherwise finally disposed of
('51', 448, 16, 19, 908542) by Government, compensation will not be given and the sale proceeds will not be
('51', 448, 17, 20, 908622) returned, except in so far as they are in excess of the legal dues for which the property
('51', 448, 18, 21, 908712) may have been sold.
('51', 448, 19, 22, 908732) (e) It will be open to any person to seed any legal remedy he may have on
('51', 448, 20, 23, 908806) the ground that the attachment or seizure of property was not in accordance with the
('51', 448, 22, 24, 908891) 17 (a) Immovable property of which possession has been taken under
('51', 448, 23, 25, 908958) Ordinance IX of 1930 will be returned in accordance with the provisions of the
('51', 448, 24, 26, 909037) Ordinance.
('51', 448, 25, 27, 909048) (b) Land and other immovable property in the possession of Government,
('51', 448, 26, 28, 909119) which has been forfeited or attached in connection with the realization of land
('51', 448, 27, 29, 909199) revenue or other dues, will be returned unless the Collector of the district has reason
('51', 448, 28, 30, 909287) to believe that the defaulter will contumaciously refuse to pay the dues recoverable
('51', 448, 29, 31, 909372) from him within a reasonable period.
('51', 448, 29, 32, 909409) In deciding what is a reasonable period
('51', 448, 30, 33, 909449) special regard will be paid to cases in which the defaulter, while willing to pay,
('51', 448, 31, 34, 909532) genuinely, requires time for the purpose, and if necessary the revenues will be
('51', 448, 32, 35, 909612) suspended in accordance with the ordinary principles of land revenue administration.
('51', 448, 33, 36, 909697) (c) Where immovale property has been sold to third parties, the transac tion must be regarded as final, so far as Government are concerned.
('51', 449, 0, 1, 909837) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('51', 449, 1, 2, 909879) Mr. Gandhi has represented 1 to Government that according to his information and belief some, at least, of these sales have been unlawful and unjust.
('51', 449, 1, 3, 910029) Government on the information before them cannot accept this contention.
('51', 449, 2, 4, 910102) (d) It will be open to any person to see any legal remedy he may have on the ground that the seizure or attachment of property was not in accordance with the law.
('51', 449, 3, 5, 910265) 18. Government believe that there have been very few cases in which the realization of dues has not been made in accordance with the provisions of the law.
('51', 449, 3, 6, 910421) In order to meet such cases, if any, local Governments will issue instructions to District Officers to have prompt enquiry made into any specific complaint of this nature, and to give redress without delay if illegality is established.
('51', 449, 4, 7, 910657) 19. Where the posts rendered vacant by the resignations have been permanently filled, Government will not be able to reinstate the late incumbents.
('51', 449, 4, 8, 910805) Other cases of resignation will be considered on their merits by local Governments who will pursue a liberal policy in regard to the reappointment or Government servants and village official who apply for reinstatement.
('51', 449, 5, 9, 911025) 20. Government are unable to condone breaches of the existing law relating to the salt administration, nor are they able, in the present financial condi tions of the country, to make substantial modifications in the Salt Acts.
('51', 449, 6, 10, 911252) For the sake however of giving relief to certain of the poorer classes, they are prepared to extend their administrative provisions, on lines already prevailing in certain places, in order to permit local residents in villages, immediately adjoining areas where salt can be collected or made, to collect or make salt for domestic consumption or sale within such villages, but not for sale to, or trading with, individuals living outside them.
('51', 449, 7, 11, 911695) 21. In the event of Congress failing to give full effect to the obligations of this settlement, Government will take such action as may, in consequence, become necessary for the protection of the public and individuals and the due observance of law and order.
('51', 449, 8, 12, 911955) H. W. EMERSON

('51', 450, 4, 19, 913835) HE HAS GIVEN ME ASSURANCE THAT IN NO CASE WILL HE RESTART CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE TILL CONCLUSION OF CONFERENCE DISCUSSIONS, AND THAT AFTER THAT HE WOULD HOPE NOT TO RESTART AT ALL THOUGH HE CANNOT GIVE DEFINITE UNDERTAKING BEYOND CONFERENCE STAGE.
('51', 450, 5, 20, 914079) I MUCH HOPE YOU WILL FEEL ABLE TO APPROVE STATEMENT AS IT STANDS.
